webTitle: Six sun spots within easy flying distance

fields.headline: Chasing the sun
fields.standfirst: Sarah Barrell finds six sun spots within easy flying distance
fields.trailText: Sarah Barrell finds six sun spots within easy flying distance
fields.body:
Winter is the ideal time to visit Morroco: gone is the blood-boiling "chergui" wind that blows in off the desert during summer months; instead temperatures in the lowland and coastal areas average a bone-warming 20C. After the sun goes down, the temperature drops to around 9C.

Marrakesh is truly magical during the winter. Ramadan allowing (something approaching a public holiday-style shutdown lasts one month from November 27), Christmas shopping in the medina, backed by the snow-dusted Atlas Mountains, is an unforgettable experience.

Stay within the hallowed walls of La Mamounia hotel, in Marrakesh, famed as much for being Winston Churchill's favourite bolthole as for its 17 acres of orange-scented gardens and art-deco luxury. For departures on December 2, Elegant Resorts (0870 3333370) offers seven nights in a Park View twin room, overlooking the gardens, from £1,350 per person, based on room-only accommodation, return flights and private car transfers.

A new and long-awaited addition to the hotel A-list in Marrakesh is the Amanjena , built to resemble a traditional Moroccan Palace. Located 7km outside the city, it comes complete with steaming hamman, library, guestrooms with open fires and plush suede furnishings, so it's likely you'll never make it beyond the palace gates. The Best of Morocco (01380 828533) offers one week at the Amanjena, departing between now and December 12, priced at £2,238pp, based on two sharing room-only accommodation, and including return flights and transfers.

With temperatures well into the 20s throughout December, January and February, the Canary Islands are northern Europe's preferred winter sun spot. Guaranteed to get you to parts of the Canaries that other companies can't reach, though, is Canarian Dreams (01326 317506; www.canariandreams.com) which offers luxury and private villas in rural settings along with a range of walking and wildlife holidays. On the wild west coast of Lanzarote, near the fishing village of Famara, it offers offer accommodation at the Villa Taguera. Located on the island's longest stretch of beach, the villa has a solar-heated outdoor swimming pool set beneath a 2,000ft mountain range and overlooks three offshore islands. The price for departures in December is £695 a week, based on two sharing the villa, which sleeps six (additional guests are charged a supplement of £75 per person, a week).

Something a little more alternative is the Canary's second smallest island (after El Hierro), La Gomera, 20 miles west of Tenerife. Stay at Argayall (Place of Light), a traditional finca and centre for meditation, relaxation and natural healing. The full-board daily tariff is £35 per person (based on two sharing a double room with private bathroom). All food is organic, picked and cooked fresh from the villa gardens. Both prices quoted do not include flights but they can be arranged (from around £130 return).

Madeira is blessed with a close-to-perfect climate, never suffering from either extremes of hot or cold - temperatures rarely dip below 20C throughout the winter. However, the mercury drops swiftly with altitude and winter holidaymakers can enjoy the novel experience of taking a morning climb to the snow-capped Pico do Arieiro at 1,810m, before returning to the hotel pool for an afternoon's sunbathing. Mountain trekking, in particular walking the levadas (some 2,150km of irrigation canals that weave their way through the humpback terrain) is becoming increasingly popular with tourists.

Those travelling in December can expect the pre-festive excitement to mount from December 8 onwards when every tree, house and garden shed in the capital of Funchal is illuminated with thousands of coloured bulbs; a forerunner to the pyrotechnics that make up Madeira's legendary New Year's Eve festivities.

For departures during December, Crystal Premier Cities (0870 8880022) offers two nights in the sunny south of the island from £255pp, based on two sharing, including return flights and B&B accommodation at the three-star Hotel Do Carmo, in Funchal. This price also includes a comprehensive guided tour of the island.

With average temperatures in the mid-teens, Majorca enjoys the same mild winter as much of southern Spain and this is perhaps the best time to don hiking boots and head into the pine-scented trekker's paradise that is the Sierra de Tramuntana mountains.

Liberated from the beer-fuelled stampede of the 18-30s package tourist, the island's capital, Palma, offers civilised sight-seeing (art galleries, Renaissance mansions, Moorish hammam and a Gothic cathedral), and is home to cafés that retain their stronghold over the pavements throughout the winter months.

One of the cheapest options is to fly to Palma with easyJet (0870 6000000; www.easyjet.com ), which offers returns from £40, or £35 if booked online. For accommodation, Sovereign (08705 768373) offers four nights in Palma at the superior two-star Hotel Horizonte, from £259pp, based on two sharing, including return flights and car hire.

Another more rustic option is the Ca'n Gaia, a traditional 18th-century Majorcan country house, located in S'Horta, just north-east of Palma. Prices are from £409pp for four nights, based on the same Sovereign inclusives and departures from January 1.

Unless you enjoy temperatures that top 50C, the northern European winter is the best time to visit Egypt where the average daily reading in the south of the country is well into the 20s. But even in the scorching south, temperatures drop as low as 8C during the winter nights. Between December 11 and 24, British Airways Holidays (0870 2424245) is offering seven nights at the Luxor Hilton, located in peaceful gardens beside the Nile, for £417 including return charter flights, transfers and hotel accommodation with breakfast.

For those seeking an active holiday, Discover Red Sea (020-7407 2111; www. discover-redsea.com) features dive sites in Sharm el-Sheikh, Dahab and Eilat with a selection of shore diving, boat diving and PADI courses throughout. Three days guided shore diving starts from £75pp and includes tanks, weights, guide and transport. Beginners can take the five-day PADI Open Water course, which involves classroom tuition, swimming-pool instruction and diving in open water, from £185pp.

The Azores are not a traditional winter sun destination - temperatures hover around the mid-teens and they are prone to variable weather sequences - but winter is perhaps the best time to explore the islands' volcanoes and untrammelled hinterland.

Destination Portugal (01993 773269; www.destination-portugal.co.uk) offers a 10-day tailor-made multi-centre holiday beginning with three nights on the island of São Miguel, staying at the Terra Nostra hotel, set in the middle of sub-tropical forest complete with botanical gardens and hot springs. The next stop is by plane to the island of Faial for two nights, at the Hotel Horta set in a buzzing fishing village. The final part is by boat to Pico island for two nights, staying at the Aldeia manor house, where hiking, biking and flora and fauna tours are the speciality, before returning to Faial for the last three nights. For departures in December, the price is £519pp based on two sharing, and including all flights, boat travel and accommodation.

For departures during December, Crystal Premier Cities (0870 8880022) offers two nights in the sunny south of the island from £255pp, based on two sharing, including return flights and B&B accommodation at the three-star Hotel Do Carmo, in Funchal. This price also includes a comprehensive guided tour of the island. With average temperatures in the mid-teens, Majorca enjoys the same mild winter as much of southern Spain and this is perhaps the best time to don hiking boots and head into the pine-scented trekker's paradise that is the Sierra de Tramuntana mountains. Liberated from the beer-fuelled stampede of the 18-30s package tourist, the island's capital, Palma, offers civilised sight-seeing (art galleries, Renaissance mansions, Moorish hammam and a Gothic cathedral), and is home to cafés that retain their stronghold over the pavements throughout the winter months. One of the cheapest options is to fly to Palma with easyJet (0870 6000000; www.easyjet.com ), which offers returns from £40, or £35 if booked online. For accommodation, Sovereign (08705 768373) offers four nights in Palma at the superior two-star Hotel Horizonte, from £259pp, based on two sharing, including return flights and car hire. Another more rustic option is the Ca'n Gaia, a traditional 18th-century Majorcan country house, located in S'Horta, just north-east of Palma. Prices are from £409pp for four nights, based on the same Sovereign inclusives and departures from January 1. Unless you enjoy temperatures that top 50C, the northern European winter is the best time to visit Egypt where the average daily reading in the south of the country is well into the 20s. But even in the scorching south, temperatures drop as low as 8C during the winter nights. Between December 11 and 24, British Airways Holidays (0870 2424245) is offering seven nights at the Luxor Hilton, located in peaceful gardens beside the Nile, for £417 including return charter flights, transfers and hotel accommodation with breakfast. For those seeking an active holiday, Discover Red Sea (020-7407 2111; www. discover-redsea.com) features dive sites in Sharm el-Sheikh, Dahab and Eilat with a selection of shore diving, boat diving and PADI courses throughout. Three days guided shore diving starts from £75pp and includes tanks, weights, guide and transport. Beginners can take the five-day PADI Open Water course, which involves classroom tuition, swimming-pool instruction and diving in open water, from £185pp. The Azores are not a traditional winter sun destination - temperatures hover around the mid-teens and they are prone to variable weather sequences - but winter is perhaps the best time to explore the islands' volcanoes and untrammelled hinterland. Destination Portugal (01993 773269; www.destination-portugal.co.uk) offers a 10-day tailor-made multi-centre holiday beginning with three nights on the island of São Miguel, staying at the Terra Nostra hotel, set in the middle of sub-tropical forest complete with botanical gardens and hot springs. The next stop is by plane to the island of Faial for two nights, at the Hotel Horta set in a buzzing fishing village. The final part is by boat to Pico island for two nights, staying at the Aldeia manor house, where hiking, biking and flora and fauna tours are the speciality, before returning to Faial for the last three nights. For departures in December, the price is £519pp based on two sharing, and including all flights, boat travel and accommodation.

fields.headline: Comforts and joy
fields.standfirst: You don't have to go that far to enjoy strange and exotic experiences.  Julie Burchill  ventures a few miles up the coast, checks into the Grand and finds herself back in the glory days of the English seaside
fields.trailText: You don't have to go that far to enjoy strange and exotic experiences. Julie Burchill ventures a few miles up the coast, checks into the Grand and finds herself back in the glory days of the English seaside.
fields.body:
Sussex is the county which more than any other you don't have to be born in to love. When you meet people from Yorkshire or Essex, say, there's always this element of bitterness and blood-pull mingled with the real affection. But because Sussex is so soft, so sexy, it attracts many wanderers who adopt it as their own and then have all the nice feelings that come with belonging - security, pride; and none of the bad ones - smothering, resentment. Even though I am a West Country girl, I think of Sussex as being home, and quite tear up when I hear the song of my local football team, Brighton & Hove Albion:

"For we're the men from Sussex/ Sussex by the sea/ We plough and sow and reap or mow/And useful men are we./ And when you go to Sussex,/ Whoever you may be,/You may tell them all that we stand or fall/For Sussex by the sea!/ Oh Sussex, Sussex by the sea!/ Good old Sussex by the sea!"

Sussex, or more specifically my 'burg, East Sussex, is small (ish) and spectacular, with all this stuff going on at once - the rivers and beaches, the sea and the Downs and the cliffs - that it makes other counties look rather blowsy and barren. Occasionally, of course, it can have a bit too much water going on, as we learned recently when the Ouse and the Arun burst their banks as one, or when "ancient springs" were discovered under parts of Brighton, making it flood unprecedentedly. But, on the whole, it's heaven.

Brighton, of course, is the sparkling star of the Sussex Coast, a magnet to slackers, runaways and pleasure-seekers ever since the Prince Regent first had his palace of ill-repute built here. "Success smells of Brighton," said the Yorkshire-born Laurence Olivier, who moved here in the 1950s and, when he was enobled chose the title Lord Olivier of Brighton. But Brighton, in its indecent irrepressibility, is in many ways uncharacteristic of the south coast, where life is slow and stately and for good reason the chosen retirement roost of the elderly. Of a weekend, there is nothing my companion and I like more - well, OK, but only about five other things - than to jump in the jalopy, put on some Penguin Café Orchestra and tootle along the coast road in search of the sleeping small towns of East Sussex, some of which have amusingly obscene or scarily Gothic names - Climping and Fulking, Cold Christmas and Hurstpierpoint.

Eastbourne is far from undiscovered, though. In the first part of the century, it was the swell of the south coast, watering hole of emperors and ballerinas, kings and coloraturas. Now, in the words of their most famous sons (since the late Russ Conway) Toploader, it is seen as "the blue rinse capital of the world". Indeed someone cruelly told me that "it makes Hove look like Manumission".

I was initially attracted to it because of my hotel fetish; the 125-year-old, five-star Grand is simply the most magnificent beast in the whole of the south-east. But personally, I also love the tranquil, Morrissey-ish melancholia of English seaside resorts out of season: with their Winter Gardens and bandstands, tiny palm trees and carveries, they are among the few places where you can still imagine what the 1950s felt like, what a world without America would feel like. Eastbourne is strange and beautiful, like Scandinavia or the moon, with rather more to see and do.

The Grand Hotel looms over Eastbourne as defiantly and definitively as the Statue of Liberty loomed over Charlton Heston at the end of Planet of the Apes; it reared up at us out of the night, ice-white and towering, like something out of St Petersburg. All by itself, set back from the road, scorning the neighbouring hotels whose names also recall the glory days of the English seaside - the Albany, the Burlington, the Chatsworth, the Cavendish - you could see why it was known as "The White Palace" in the years between the wars, when the BBC Palm Court Orchestra broadcast live from the Great Hall every Sunday night from 1924 to 1939. Dennis Potter, whose Cream In My Coffee was filmed there, called it "a huge, creamy palace".

Opulent yet easeful, the utterly lush reception has greeted everyone from Winston Churchill, Haile Sellasie and Aneurin Bevan to Charlie Chaplin, Arthur Conan Doyle, Elgar, Anna Pavlova and Paul Robeson, These days it may be somewhat reduced to Harold Pinter, Celine Dion and Liam Gallagher, but you still get the essence of the place where Debussy completed La Mer. As far back as the 1880s, the Eastbourne Grand was, a byword for luxury and progress going hand-in-hand; advertisements boasted of the private omnibus to collect rail travellers, a library and public rooms lit with electric light, a hydraulic lift and separate tables in the dining room. The King of Spain was so impressed by the Grand's cabstand that he had an exact replica built in Madrid; from 1918 to 1952, the hotel was so popular that it had its own farm supplying guests with fruit, veg, eggs and poultry.

Today the Grand's entirely justified pride in its own singularity can be seen in its huge, gorgeous outdoor and indoor swimming pools, among other things. As a bit of a swimming pool connoisseur, this is the first aspect of a hotel I pay attention to once the register has been signed and the luggage has been dumped, and I've come across some lulus in my time, even in five-star hotels. In Brighton, for instance, the modest Metropole has the loveliest indoor pool imaginable, while the jumped-up Grand next door has an alleged "swimming" pool that I can't see giving sufficient legroom to anyone when Snow White and the Seven Dwarves isn't playing at the Theatre Royal.

But like all great hotels - The Imperial (Torquay), Reid's (Madeira), Pink Sands, (The Bahamas) - the real glory of this hotel is its staff, and what almost seems like the Indonesian wayang shadow ballet of preparation, interaction and performance. This can be seen at its most prancing level of perfection in the Grand's two dining rooms, the Garden Restaurant and the Mirabelle. On the first night, In the Garden Restaurant, I knocked back smoked salmon with quails eggs and Dover sole and thought how very sad it was that now the new Radio 2 is the official home of the Beautiful South and the even more beautiful Corrs, you have to find a restaurant with a pianist in order to hear those wonderful old songs for swinging lovers like Volare, Misty and Baubles, Bangles and Beads.

On the second night in the Mirabelle - according to the Good Food Guide one of 20 best troughs in the British Isles, and I for one certainly wouldn't argue with them - I reflected that any restaurant that has the pianist playing The Shadow Of Your Smile as one sits down, could serve one rancid Pot Noodle and they'd still have my vote. But never one to look a gift horse in the kisser, I nevertheless accepted seared scallops on a cauliflower purée with a dressing of caper and grape, a ribeye of Scottish beef with a rich red wine jus and a selection of cheeses I loved so much that I wanted to put them on my Friends and Family phone list. My young friend grappled with a pressing of pork set in a star anise-infused jelly with a chutney of apple, a risotto of parmesan and thyme and a warm chocolate fondant with white chocolate ice-cream. The pianist played You'll Never Know and the staff performed the arrogant, yielding ballet of service. I felt so lit up, so glowing with pure protein that I could have served as an incandescent illustration for that poor mad old man who used to shoulder his heavy banner along Oxford Street, "Protein = Lust". My friend and I just looked at each other and laughed, it was so brilliant.

The next morning we drove out to Beachy Head in a raging gale, bent on flagellating our swinish selves. Beachy Head is only about 15 minutes from Eastbourne and, with silver sea sneaking round on either side, it must be one of the most beautiful places in England in sunshine. But as we walked the Peace Path around the top of the cliff, all I could think about was all the poor suicides who'd pitched themselves off. I didn't much fancy following them and demanded we turn back, to which my boyfriend replied that we'd feel really righteous once we'd done it. With this, he turned the corner straight into a force-nine gale - the first time I've heard wind actually screaming - which he could barely stand-up in. He suggested that we turn back, and we staggered to the car to recover. It was without doubt the scariest moment of my life (apart from the first morning I woke up in the same bed as Tony Parsons), but it certainly got the adrenaline going.

Be that as it may, I felt that I'd had enough of nature's wild grandeur, and demanded to be taken somewhere totally unnatural. Within 10 minutes, we were in one of the hugest covered malls I've ever seen - Eastbourne's Arndale Centre. A compromise was called for, so we drove down to the seafront to soak up the vibes. The pier is typically solid, boasting both a newsagent's and a flower shop which we certainly don't have on Brighton pier. Not suprisingly, the tattoo shop had closed down, but the charming Bar Copa at the end of the pier proclaimed itself to be the ideal spot "for sporting and cavorting". There were boat trips on offer, too: cruises round Beachy Head and speedboat rides on the thrillingly named 007. Once again, this was in pleasing contrast to Brighton - where it is easier to get raw opium than a boat-ride.

The esplanade was pleasantly melancholic: a sign threatened a whopping £500 fine for cycling on the seafront and a yellowing poster promised The Manfreds with Chris Farlowe, Alan Price and Cliff Bennett (but sadly, no Rebel Rousers) at the Congress Theatre. Best of all, in a basement beneath the Cumberland Hotel, we were Invited to "In-Step Sunday Club: Ballroom and Sequence Dancing with Peter Harvey's Hi-Fi Show". It made me miss my mum and wish Alan Bennett was with me and I thought how very pleasant the old English way of taking one's pleasure was, without all that neurotic chasing about and taking pictures of everything, just so the folks back home will believe you were there.

It was about 5pm on a Sunday afternoon, just getting dark, and then the most gorgeous thing happened. We went up the front steps of the Grand and into the lobby - and there, in the Great Hall right in front of us, was a string quartet playing chamber music. Smart old couples took tea at tiny tables, and as we went up in the lift, suddenly it could have been any year between 1924 and 1939. The immaculate Grand could have been the rundown Overlook from The Shining, full of between-the-war ghosts.

The music followed us right up to our suite, then faded away. It was one of the strangest and most enchanting things I've ever experienced. Indeed, being in Eastbourne was in many ways stranger, more foreign than being abroad - particularly the Caribbean, which in its more profitable enclaves can feel like lodging in a luxury franchise of America. But you can occasionally find good parts of Britain - Porthmadoc in Wales is another - where the American takeover seems never to have happened. And never underestimate the refreshing qualities of sneaking off the Yankee yoke, if only for a weekend.

After five years of feverish globetrotting in the course of my work, I can honestly say that, particularly this year, the holidays I took at home - in Torquay and Portmeirion - were far more enjoyable than my holidays in Jamaica and Corsica, very agreeable though these were too. I'm not sure what the definition of sophistication is, but I think a good part of it is the ability to derive as great a kick from humdrum pleasure as from exotic ones though, of course, it probably doesn't signify unless you've tried the exotic ones, too. Eastbourne isn't St Tropez, but I had a brilliant time there. And far from taking this as proof of my infirmity, I'd prefer to think that it merely shows that I am not yet some sad old sack who needs the warmth of the Med or the Caribbean to fire up my chilly English blood.

Really, I'm the last person to refuse a bit of long-haul winter sun, but I do believe that (and this must, sadly, be the one recorded incidence in which my views tally with those of the Green lobby and the anti-suntan-bores) we often go much further than we need to in search of our rest, recreation and restoration when often a change of scene and someone else making the bed is all we need. I know people who routinely take 14-hour flights to faraway countries where - reeling from jetlag, inoculations and delays - they spend 10 days burning off their outer epidermis and 10 nights drinking cheap booze before taking another 14-hour flight home - where they'll complain they feel exhausted! Whereas I left Brighton on Friday night overworked and undersexed but, after three rainy nights in Eastbourne, came back feeling a new person. I hope you'll excuse the smutty gag, by the way - but I always find that there's nothing like an English seaside town, however genteel, for effortlessly doubling one's entendre.

The practicals

Julie Burchill stayed at The Grand Hotel, King Edwards Parade, Eastbourne East Sussex BN21 4EQ (tel: 01323 412345, www.grandeastbourne.com).

The short-break rate (min two-night stay) starts at £195 a night for a deluxe bedroom based on two sharing and goes up to £450 a night for the presidential suite. Prices include full breakfast, three-course dinner, newspaper and use of the health club. Until Dec 22, there is a special rate of £125 per night per deluxe bedroom based on two people sharing. The four-day Christmas House Party from Dec 23 includes full board and entertainment starting from £790pp.

webTitle: Choosing the sports book of the year

fields.headline: Choosing the sports book of the year
fields.standfirst: The 2000 William Hill prize fight - known as 'the Bookie prize' - is decided on Monday. Frank Keating considers a strong shortlist and sports writing, post-Hornby
fields.trailText: Of course, one thing the sponsor William Hill cannot do in all propriety is run a book on its annual sports-lit award. For "the Bookie prize", the vote for the year's best sports book which is up for grabs again on Monday, you have to come up with your own set of odds for outsiders and favourite, although rumours suggest that from the shortlist of six the judges have taken a shine to Peak Performance, co-written by a Kiwi quartet of authors.
fields.body:
Of course, one thing the sponsor William Hill cannot do in all propriety is run a book on its annual sports-lit award. For "the Bookie prize", the vote for the year's best sports book which is up for grabs again on Monday, you have to come up with your own set of odds for outsiders and favourite, although rumours suggest that from the shortlist of six the judges have taken a shine to Peak Performance, co-written by a Kiwi quartet of authors.

Should the aptly named Peak Performance gallop into the winner's enclosure, it will - alas, although I suppose it is what a new book should do - reflect the age in which we live in and which sport increasingly inhabits.

For sport counts the score these days in greenbacks. Peak Performance is an examination, and a gushingly over-enthusiastic one at that, of what makes the market forces of some of the world's most bankable sporting businesses - from the Atlanta Braves to yachting's Team New Zealand - tick. To heck with actually playing the game; this is narrow-eyed sport as product, as brand image, as designer label.

If you are going to have a bet with a rival bookmaker, then for pedigree's sake go for the other "political and economic" nominee.

Sportswriting - and the less precise writing-about-sport - could never, we were told, be the same after young Hornby had taken up his pen and written:

"Chapter One. I fell in love with football as I was later to fall in love with women: suddenly, inexplicably, uncritically, giving no thought to the pain or disruption it would bring with it. In May '68 (a date with connotations, of course, but I am still more likely to think of Jeff Astle than of Paris) ..."

Hornby's tour de force not only touched a nerve which had been waiting to be vitalised but was the inspiration for the first generation in British football to "come out", as it were, about their passion for the game. Suddenly it was not only OK but almost compulsory for every city's "top-end Hampstead" intellectuals to gather round dinner tables and talk with rapt studiousness, not about Pinter or Amis or Truffaut, but Robson and Seaman and Gazza.

The year after Fever Pitch won, the London Review of Books even had a huge portrait of young Gascoigne on its front cover. Inside, without a bat of the eyelid from the magazine editor Karl Miller, it described the tubby midfielder as a "priapic monolith" - and, in passing, a "dive" by Jürgen Klinsmann was ranked a "piece of German theatre that could have earned him a place in Goethe's Walpurgisnacht".

The 1992 William Hill winner untapped a whole new liturgy for the literati and let men's feelings out of the closet in much the same way as the militantly feminist books had a couple of decades before. Fever Pitch also spawned whole shelves of copycat supporters' tracts.

Mercifully, there are no post-Hornby howlers on this year's excellent shortlist - although I would have liked to see David Downing's brilliant history of the Moscow Dynamos' 1945 visit to England (Passovotchka, Bloomsbury, £16.99) elbow itself in, as well as one of the University of Wales Press's two series of fine rugby and soccer essays (respectively More Heart And Soul and For Club And Country, each £14.99).

And, for necessary light relief in the mixed-up game of rugby union, it would have been good to have had Martin Johnson (not the shop steward of Twickenham but the pin-sharp and unputdownable breezy journalist) and his Rugby And All That, An Irreverent History (Hodder, £14.99) barging his way in. It is the most congenial rugby book since 1960 and Michael Green's Art Of Coarse Rugby which, in its different way, was almost as seminal for sports-book publishing as Fever Pitch more than three decades later.

Me, I am putting my money on the cricket book, the compelling story of Jack Iverson, whose unique spinning technique - middle finger compressed behind the ball on delivery - we all tried to copy at school. Or, in my case, until I painfully dislocated the bottom knuckle and matron had to take me to outpatients.

What might dissuade the judges against Gideon Haigh's terrific book - Australia's finest cricket writer, by the by, should have been shortlisted in 1998 for his near-perfect The Summer Game - is that two of the last three winners, Derek Birley and Simon Hughes, have been for cricket. Which is also the reason, probably, that David Underdown's scholarly early history of the game (Start Of Play, Penguin, £20) grievously gets no mention this year.

The competition's co-sponsor, as it ever has been, is Sportspages, the irreplaceable London and Manchester bookshop. Permanent chairman of the judges (Cliff Morgan, Ian Wooldridge, Frances Edmonds, John Inverdale and Danny Kelly) is Sportspages' founder John Gaustad. And each year the competition, in a way, also doubles as a chance to raise a toast in gratitude to us book buyers and browsers who came tumbling out of the closet and into our addicts' den when young Gaustad bravely opened his treasure-trove doors in September 1985.

A bookshop exclusive to sport? No hope, the business world scoffed. On his first day he opened at 9am and a customer did not approach the counter until 3.20pm. He bought a copy of A Concise Light On Yoga, and Gaustad was up and running. Now Sportspages is a worldwide club and meeting place for the freemasonry; even Yanks take vacations to pore in wonder over its baseball shelves.

Before Sportspages there was only WH Smith, where you could go tremulously in any spring and ask, "Do you stock Wisden?" And a slip of a gormless girl would look up from painting her nails and stare back blankly: "Is that Norman Wisdom then?"

fields.headline: All over the shop
fields.standfirst: A strong dollar may be chipping away at savings, but the Windy City is still a spectacular place to go shopping, says  Stephen Moss
fields.trailText: A strong dollar may be chipping away at savings, but the Windy City is still a spectacular place to go shopping, says Stephen Moss
fields.body:
Shopping is hardly war reporting, you might think, but then you have never had to brave the accusing stares of the staff in American Girl Place, a temple to the doll just off swish North Michigan Avenue. The store was filled with perfectly dressed moms, their divine, doll-coveting daughters, and slovenly me, trying (unsuccessfully, I would guess) not to look shifty. It has its own theatre, which stages The American Girls Revue (tickets $25), and a restaurant where dolls will join you at the table. The American Girl doll comes in 20 variants - different hair, skin and eye colour - and retails at $84. Outside, a little girl whose mother was clutching two new dolls was wailing. Wrong colour eyes maybe.

North Michigan Avenue, aka the Magnificent Mile, has just about every store even a screeching American girl could ever want: the world's largest Polo Ralph Lauren, the world's largest Gap, Niketown, three vertical malls, and an array of designer stores - Armani, Bulgari, Cartier, Chanel, Tiffany. It also has what is claimed to be the world's best popcorn store, Garrett's, and has people queueing round the block to prove it.

Chicago, which has been booming over the past decade, takes shopping very seriously, and sees it as a trump card in its battle with New York to win UK short-break visitors, especially in the run-up to Christmas. Hotels in Chicago are cheaper, the stores are less spread out, and the city is reckoned to be more "user-friendly". (The latter is, of course, a question of taste: New York's warm blanket of collective neurosis can be deeply comforting.)

Chicago, which hugs the south-western shore of Lake Michigan, is certainly beautiful - and possibly the cleanest city I have ever visited. Mayor Richard M Daley, son of the legendary Richard J who ran Chicago from 1955-76, has a policy of "beautification", which seems to include showing zero tolerance towards litterers. The buildings gleam, the streets are broad and traffic-free, the parks are perfect, and the locals talk with horror of rat infestation in New York.

The city has been reborn over the past 20 years. "The streets are now safe and people are having a good time. I've seen Chicago become number one," a taxi driver told me. It's a long way from the city of John Dillinger, Al Capone and the St Valentine's Day Massacre, though this is a WASP-ish weekend break and it is a different story on the South Side.

Shopping - you remember my mission - isn't confined to North Michigan Avenue. The downtown area, which is the business heart of the city, has several long-established department stores, including Marshall Field's, a turn-of-the-century landmark which was the model for Selfridge's.

Marshall Field's is the Vatican City of shopping. It is the second largest department store in the world after Macy's in New York (bleak words for any Chicagoan to hear) and is anxious to preserve its aesthetic appeal. It has a remarkable 14-storey lightwell, a walnut-panelled restaurant and a blue-tiled dome that would not be out of place in a mosque. At Marshall Field's, you can shop and sightsee at the same time: the clock outside the store has been the city's traditional meeting place for more than 100 years. The store, like many others in Chicago, offers a 10% discount to foreign visitors.

Downtown is very quiet on Saturday - in contrast to the crowds on North Michigan Avenue - and the atmosphere of hushed reverence in Marshall Field's seems entirely appropriate for this cathedral of commerce. Outside the store, on North State Street, in place of the designer shoppers of the Magnificent Mile, there are beggars and evangelists, including one representing the High Way Church of God in Christ: "Let us not touch, taste or handle unclean things, such as tobacco, snuff, alcohol and drugs. My friend, once Christ frees you from these habits, be not entangled again with the yoke of bondage. Don't be a slave to one little thing." Except maybe shopping.

Christmas is a big deal in Chicago, though commercialism can sometimes overwhelm sentiment: this year's lights procession, marking the official beginning of seasonal insanity, was led by Mickey Mouse and Co, Santa having been given the sack. If you want the full-on Christmas experience, Chicago will provide it, but to get the price right (especially at a time when the pound is weak against the dollar), timing is everything. Flight prices soar to £550-plus after December 17 as the Christmas stampede gathers pace, and many hotels will stick on a $100-a-night supplement, too, so the first and second weeks of the month are likely to be best. I paid $169 a night for a double room at the Regal Knickerbocker just off North Michigan Avenue and close to the lake. A single would cost $149, but beware those Christmas supplements.

There is an excellent visitor centre in the old water tower on the Mag Mile (one of the few buildings to survive the great fire of 1871). It's the place to start for a stay in Chicago: bang in the centre of the touristic part of town, tons of literature, knowledgeable staff, half-price theatre tickets, and pretty good coffee.

There is plenty to do culturally in Chicago, too. I spent an afternoon at the Art Institute (entrance $8), which is about eight museums in one - painting, sculpture, photography, furniture, armour, Buddhist artefacts, even an exhibition on skyscrapers, which gamely accepts that the Sears Building is now only the second tallest building in the world after the Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur (this is a matter of dispute because each is constantly adding radio masts to up the ante).

Chicago has three of the world's top 10 tall buildings, with the Amoco Building and the John Hancock Center joining the Sears Building in the big league. You can have a drink or lunch at the top of the 100-storey Hancock Center: great views of the city and lake, but very busy and around $40 (plus drinks) for a three-course meal. The lift does the 100 storeys in about a second, and you hardly notice it.

You can't come to Chicago and not hear some jazz and blues. Jazz Showcase is reckoned to be the best venue: entrance is $20 and it is open every night, including Sundays when a lot of venues are closed. I caught a cerebral set (as we jazzers like to say) by a Panamanian quintet: full of meandering 15-minute numbers that were rapturously received by an earnest-looking audience. I sipped my Sam Adams and looked intense.

Just across from Jazz Showcase on North Clark Street is one of Blue Chicago's two venues (entrance $6), which proved a good deal less earnest. It bothered me slightly that a large part of the audience was Japanese and drinking mineral water, but it was still a fun, traditional blues set, if mildly parodic - a gnarled, grey-haired man singing about life in jail and a vast, don't-mess-with-me woman whose husband had done her wrong (or had she done her husband wrong? - who knows, I wasn't drinking mineral water).

There is also great theatre in Chicago - allegedly, because my time was short. Big, old theatres downtown and the trendy, smaller theatre groups such as Steppenwolf that shot to prominence in the 70s to the north of the city centre in buzzing Wrigleyville (so named after the Chicago Cubs' baseball field). The Vagina Monologues at the Apollo Theater was the hot ticket while I was there - a discourse on the pleasures of shopping, I am reliably informed. American girls are flocking to see it.

Restaurants

Gibson's Steakhouse 1028 N Rush St (tel: 312 266-8999).

You will need to reserve a table to enjoy the big porterhouse steaks and even bigger desserts ($40-50 per person).

Mia Francesca

3311 N Clark St (773 281-3310).

Big pasta dishes, popular pizzas and a vibrant atmosphere add to the appeal of this always crowded restaurant ($20-30 per person).

Topolobampo

445 N Clark St (312 661-1434).

Has a national reputation for its authentic Mexican cuisine. Great appetisers and side dishes ($20-30 per person).

Yoshi's Cafe

3257 N Halsted St (773 248-6160).

Eclectic mix of Japanese, Italian and French dishes in casual atmosphere ($30-40 per person).

Bars

Andy's

11 E Hubbard St, at N State St (312 642-6805).

Large, crowded horseshoe bar with high-quality jazz lunchtimes and evenings (cover varies but usually less than $10).

Beat Kitchen

2100 W Belmont Avenue, at N Hoyne Avenue (773 281-4444).

Slide into a booth, sit back and enjoy live music in the back room, or make your way to the front to grab a bite to eat while listening to a range of musical styles including ska, pop and rock (cover varies but usually less than $10).

Cubby Bear Lounge

1059 W Addison St, at N Clark St (773 327-1662).

Located just across from Wrigley Field and always jam-packed before and after Cubs games. Intimate atmosphere and music from local pop and rock bands (cover varies but usually less than $10).

Harry's Velvet Room

56 W Illinois St, at N Dearborn St (312 527-5600)

Deeply romantic despite the daunting aroma of cigars. Relaxing sofas beckon you to snuggle up with someone special as you sip your champagne (no cover).

Zebra Lounge

1220 N State St, at W Division St (312 642-5140)

Charming piano bar with relaxed atmosphere and long record of friendly service (no cover).

Clubs

Berlin

954 W Belmont Avenue, at N Sheffield Anenue, Lake View, (773 348-4975).

Dark, loud and decidedly risqué (cover $5 or less depending on the day).

Crobar

1543 N Kingsbury St, at W Weed St, Lincoln Park (312 413-7000).

Check what you're wearing twice, this club is only for those fabulously dressed. DJs from around the world spin the freshest, latest music (cover varies from $5-20 depending on the day).

Exit

1315 W North Avenue, at N Elston Avenue, Lincoln Park (773 395-2700).

Punk rock, metal and ska vibrate through the walls at this two-floor club. Lots of black leather (cover $5 at weekends).

Insider's guide
US v UK in the shops

Chicago / London

Levi's 501 Jeans £31.65 / £49

Sony Minidisc Player £107.90/ £122.99

Women's Nike 'Converge Triax' Running Shoe £64.75 / £70

Barbie doll £18 / £22.95

Clinique Happy Perfume 1.7oz £25 / £29.50

Based on $1.39=£1

The practicals

The flight time from Heathrow to Chicago is nine hours. BA (0345 222111), Virgin (01293 747747), American (0845 7789789) and United (0845 8444777) all fly direct, and the quotes we obtained for an economy flight varied between £194 and £232. Between December 18 and 24, prices rise to between £565 and £577.

The Water Tower visitor centre is on the corner of North Michigan Avenue and 163 East Pearson St, and is open every day 7.30am- 7pm. The Art Institute of Chicago is open 10.30am-4.30pm weekdays, except Tuesday when it is open to 8pm; it opens 10am-5pm on Saturday and noon-5pm Sunday. The Sears Tower (entrance $8.50) is open every day from 9am to 10pm; the Hancock Center has an observatory (entrance $8.75).

Useful info can be found on www.chicago.il.org/ (for hotels, sights and maps), www.ci.chi.il.us/Tourism/ (for cultural attractions) and www.metromix.com (for entertainment and attractions).

fields.headline: Truth behind the window dressing
fields.standfirst:
Diversity training

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The big buzzword in business at the moment is diversity. It's also a big money-spinner. There are now at least 90 consultancies listed in the Diversity Directory - an official guide to the subject - offering cultural "diversity training" as a core service to organisations; and their client base is growing all the time. Diversity strategies have in recent years nudged their way on to the websites and mission statements of many FTSE 100 companies.
fields.body:
The big buzzword in business at the moment is diversity. It's also a big money-spinner. There are now at least 90 consultancies listed in the Diversity Directory - an official guide to the subject - offering cultural "diversity training" as a core service to organisations; and their client base is growing all the time. Diversity strategies have in recent years nudged their way on to the websites and mission statements of many FTSE 100 companies.

Yet despite this growth, there have been doubts on the success of this training, which is aimed to encourage a better ethnic representation across the workplace.

In a report on the experience of ethnic minority police officers, Staffordshire University sociologist Professor Ellis Cashmore argues that "valuing cultural diversity and racism awareness training is wasteful in terms of money and human resources... It's chief value to the police is symbolic". He describes the training as "window dressing ...providing a shield against criticism".

Organisations are under enormous pressure to deliver race equality, so there is an explosion of demand for consultants and trainers, says Chris Myant of the Commission for Racial Equality. " But many lack the necessary skills."

There is no formal accreditation for diversity trainers. The Diversity Directory editor Mary Gray says, "It would help employers if a body was set up to take responsibility for accreditation and set a benchmark for quality."

Training is often an easy option for employers, such as banks and telecommunication companies. "There's a tendency to throw training at the problem and hope it goes away," says Chris Myant

But what exactly is the training designed to achieve? According to Roger Hurley, the principal of diversity consultants Phoenix HR, one of the organisations that have undertaken police training, "Diversity is about acknowledging and accepting difference."

Education about cultural differences does not in itself prevent discrimination. Professor Cashmore, who carried out race awareness training for C&A, explains: "My idea of a training programme would be a place where you give clear indicators of acceptable behaviour. If you step over those limits you're censured."

Conrad Peters, a former training and development manager at Barclays, and one of the few black people in a senior corporate position, says cultural awareness training will have little effect on those with deep-rooted prejudice. "As soon as those people go back into the real world, they revert to old patterns. What would be really useful would be to evaluate the people you recruit for open-mindedness."

One of the problems with these programmes concerns the practicalities of delivery. Usually, sessions occur in short bursts often only for selected employees. At Shell in the UK, diversity training was offered to line managers just a few days prior to recruiting candidates. "It was about awareness of cultural and racial differences and it was pretty superficial," says Dr Dwain Neil, himself black and formerly head of recruitment at Shell in the UK. "To my knowledge, there was no widespread diversity training among staff managers."

At Barclays, which boasts an explicit equal opportunities policy, diversity training consists of 90 minutes on a CD Rom package for all those "responsible for managing performance, recruitment and selection". Conrad Peters says, "It was utter rhetoric with Barclays because very little was actually done. After answering simple questions on the CD Rom there was no follow-up discussion with anyone to test the person's understanding or awareness."

A spokesperson for Barclays said the bank was currently reviewing its equal opportunities and diversity programme.

If diversity training is to be at all effective, it must be subject to evaluation. But how? Most trainers ask students to fill in question naires after the programme - not necessarily the most objective measure. When Phoenix HR train managers they carry out evaluations several months later. Even then the results cannot reflect the impact on the entire firm.

The best test, says Mr Hurley, is a company audit of ethnic minority representation. As the Runnymede Trust survey discovered few multinational companies are keen to take this approach. The Guardian contacted the NatWest Group, BT, Shell and HSBC for figures and information on their diversity strategies with no response.

Barclays and Lloyds TSB both monitor their representation and were happy to share the information. At Lloyds TSB, for example, the company says a diversity strategy has resulted in some concrete gains: 20% of their graduate intake are from ethnic minority backgrounds compared to just 4% four years ago, and they have witnessed a 28% increase in ethnic minority managers over the last 12 months. Overall, however, only 1% of ethnic minorities are in senior management. Lloyds TSB points out that, unlike some of its competitors, the company uses figures based on the total workforce, instead of excluding those who describe their ethnicity as unknown, and this makes its figure lower.

According to Lloyds TSB's Mr Wakelin, ethnicity awareness training given regularly to all staff by black and Asian consultants has played a prominent role in the change. He also cites other helpful initiatives including career development programmes tailored for ethnic minority candidates.

Diversity training does not come cheap. Lloyds TSB pays some £1,000 a day for a consultant to run an in-house course and £500 per person per day to send delegates to an external one.

Diversity specialists Focus Consultancy refuse to take on purely training contracts. "To practise diversity successfully, you have to take on institutional aims and targets, not just individual behaviour. So if someone asks us to do five weeks of ad hoc training - one day a week for 100 people in an organisation of 5000 - we say, 'Not unless we can carry out a proper needs analysis which will map out all the training requirements, the policy requirements, and the procedural requirements'. Often all these need changing. Not surprisingly, not everyone takes us on,"says Focus chairman and chief executive Professor Chris Mullard.

Conrad Peters believes publicised targets are the only way organisations will effect real change. However it is one thing to set them, and another to enforce them. Very few organisations will admit to them at all. Even at Lloyds TSB where they say they want to see parity with the country's ethnic minority population (6.4%) throughout the organisation this is described as an "aspirational goal".

But at the CRE, Mr Myant is in no doubt about the way ahead. He says, "Managers must be accountable through their appraisal system for anything in the working of the organisation to do with race equality, whether it's harassment or representation across the grades."

Professor Cashmore's recommendation to the police service is to "dump training" altogether, and to bring in what he calls "beneficial training" where real-life examples of good practices are communicated throughout the force. He also advocates fast-tracking ethnic minority officers through the system. Such ideas make the private sector very nervous.

For a copy of The Diversity Directory, call 01234 881 380

The unspoken barrier

Evidence suggests that people from ethnic minorities continue to face barriers at work, although the accumulation of such data is difficult. Earlier this year the Runnymede Trust carried out a study of ethnic minority employees in the top FTSE 100 companies. Only 55 companies responded to the questionnaire, 40 completed it and 15 gave reasons for not participating, ranging from "company reorganisation" to "having a stated policy agreed with the trade unions, of not doing any ethnic monitoring".

Of those 55, only 27 were able to provide data on ethnic minority representation. The statistics showed that whereas 5.4% of staff were from ethnic minorities (who make up 6.4% of total UK population), 3.2% were in junior and middle management and only 1% were senior managers.

The Trust points out that representation varies across different ethnic groups with those from an Indian ethnic origin, for example, reaching senior positions more frequently than those from an Afro-Caribbean background.

fields.headline: White weekends
fields.standfirst: A winter break no longer means losing a week of your annual holiday.  Nicky Holford takes the last plane out on Friday night
fields.trailText: A winter break no longer means losing a week of your annual holiday. Nicky Holford takes the last plane out on Friday night.
fields.body:
The view of Mont Blanc is breathtaking as we get out of the small cable car at the top of Chamonix's Aiguille du Midi. Normally, it's a bun fight to reach the "arret", a narrow ridge that starts the 23km Vallée Blanche descent. For us, it's uncrowded because it's a Saturday - change-over time for most tour operators, but the first day of our ski weekend.

Catching the last Swissair flight from London on Friday night meant we were in Chamonix before midnight French time with three full days of skiing ahead of us.

It's still not cheap because most weekend specialists use scheduled airlines, which cost more than charters, and accommodation for three or four nights often costs the same as it would for a week. But according to two of Britain's top weekend operators, Ski Weekend and FlexiSki, the weekenders are here to stay.

To get the most out of your weekend, you need to choose resorts within easy reach of the airport: Verbier and Villars in Switzerland, Chamonix and Megève in France and Courmayeur in Italy are all within 1€ hours of Geneva; Lech and St Anton in Austria are 2€ hours from Zurich.

Weekend specialists have got the details down to a fine art. You don't want to waste time renting skis or getting a lift pass on that precious first day. And unless you book well in advance, it's virtually impossible without paying a premium to get the last flight out of Heathrow on a Friday night plus the Sunday night return from Geneva. It's worth leaving all that to the experts.

Tour operators are also getting into the short-break skiing market. Airtours even offers day trips to Chamonix, Courchevel and Kitzbühel from Gatwick or Manchester. For this, you need stamina. With a 4.30am start, you can get a good five to six hours skiing in Chamonix if all goes well, but don't expect to be at your best the next day.

Courmayeur
This resort on the sunny Italian side of the Mont Blanc tunnel (closed for the second season by a fire) has an abundance of charm and attracts the weekending Milanese. The village is old with cobble-stoned alleys and delightful small hotels and pensions. There is an extensive choice of bars and restaurants - from pizza to 12-course menus.

Italians do not race for the first lifts, so if you are an early riser you will have the slopes to yourself. Hard to resist are the numerous traditional wooden huts turned into cosy mountain restaurants. Don't miss the Christiania at Plan Checrouit or La Grolla at Val Veny.

The resort skiing is mostly intermediate. For more advanced skiers, the top of the two-stage cable car at Cresta d'Arp is the start of two great off-piste runs, but guides are recommended for this. Another cable car takes you to the Punta Helbronner, the start of the Italian Vallée Blanche leading to Chamonix. But the closure of the tunnel has made the return journey unfeasibly long. Instead, there is a 10km run down the Toula Glacier to La Palud.

Momentum Travel 020-7371 9111
www.momentum.uk.com
Three nights in a pension with Ryanair flights, Stansted-Turin, and car hire starts at £229pp based on two people sharing a double room (£299 for a three-star hotel).

Chamonix
The first choice for any passionate skier, Chamonix lives up to its reputation. Over the years, it has been the start for many first ascents both in climbing and extreme skiing and is the home of one of the most respected guiding bodies, the Compagnie des Guides de Chamonix.

Serious skiers head to Argentière and the Grands Montets, but the Chamonix valley caters to all levels. Les Houches and Le Tour are the easiest. Le Brevant and La Flégère, recently linked, provide variety for beginners and intermediates and some excellent off-piste skiing. On a sunny day, the Vallée Blanche glacier in the shadow of Mont Blanc is a magical run. It's not difficult, and the scenery is breathtaking.

Chamonix is quite a large town with a wide variety of restaurants and nightlife. The smaller village of Argentière also offers several choices.

Collineige 01276 24262
www.collineige.com
Now in its 21st year, the Chamonix specialist has a selection of four-night weekends in several chalets. Breakfast, tea and three-course dinners with wine start at £595. Off piste or skiing with a guide can be arranged. Price includes scheduled flights and private transfer.

Ski Weekend 01367 241636
www.skiweekend.com
Three-day weekends in a two-star hotel start from £389 B&B (£419 half board) including return scheduled flights on Swissair or Crossair, transfer, ski orientation and services of a resort co-ordinator. Ski passes cost £20 per day. Four days' off-piste skiing with guide Yves Detry start at £599 including flights, transfer and two-star accommodation.

Verbier
To make the most of Verbier, you will need stamina. Not just for its glaciers, couloirs, moguls and powder but also for its legendary nightlife. Those who brave Fergie's old haunt, the Farm Club, rarely leave before 3am after inflicting some serious damage to both heads and wallets.

Verbier is not for beginners, but intermediates and boarders will find more than enough to keep them busy at Savoleyres and Lac des Vaux. The Four Valley lift pass is a linked network of 96 lifts covering 400km of piste.

For advanced and expert skiers, the skiing is unlimited from Tortin, a steep and wide slope pounded into knee-high moguls, to the front face of Mont Gelé. From the top of the Mont Fort cable car, you can pick your route from red to black or some good off-piste off the back. On a powder day, you'll need to catch the first cable car or you will find that famous runs such as Stairway to Heaven and the Hidden Valley are skied out.

Despite its upmarket reputation, Verbier does not boast gourmet restaurants on the mountain. On Savoleyres, the most authentic place is Buvette de la Marenaz, but it's off-piste to get there. For something simple, try the station café at Le Chble. In town, head to hangouts such as Offshore and the Pub at Mont Fort.

FlexiSki 0870 9090 754
www.flexiski.co.uk
Now owned by First Choice, the former small independent will tailor-make any weekend. Prices for four-nights start at £445, including scheduled flights, transfers and half-board accommodation in the luxury Chalet Bouvreuil.

Inghams 020-8780 4444
www.inghams.co.uk
Short ski breaks of two nights or more are available to most of its Swiss ski resorts. Travel is by scheduled airlines on any day of the week, with transfers by rail. Prices start from £285 for two nights' half board at the Hotel Edelweiss in Mürren. Short-break hotels include the four-star Sunstar Park in Arosa from £359 and the five-star Grand Hotel Regina in Grindelwald start from £411.

Airtours 0870 157 7775
www.airtours.co.uk
Two-nightski weekends departing on Friday morning to Zell am See in Austria and returning Sunday night cost £319 including flights, transfer and half-board accommodation. Two-night weekends to Courchevel start at £329. Day trips from Manchester and Gatwick to Chamonix cost £179 and from Gatwick to Kitzbühel £189.

Ski consultants

Alpine Answers 020-8871 4656
www.alpineanswers.co.uk

Ski Solutions 020-7471 7700
www.skisolutions.com

Useful numbers

Courmayeur Tourist Office
00 39 165 842060
www.courmayeur.com

Chamonix Tourist Office
00 33 450 53 00 24
www.chamonix.com

Verbier Tourist Office
00 41 27 775 3888
www.verbier.ch

Switzerland Travel Centre
Freephone 00800 100 200 30

www.MySwitzerland.com
A specialist for all travel to Switzerland.

fields.headline: Pope Julius II, Raphael (1511-12)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Raphaelo Sanzio of Urbino (1483-1520), called to Rome in 1508 to work in the Vatican. Along with Leonardo and Michelangelo, he took the hard, bright style of the early Renaissance and turned it into Europe's supreme art. In addition to divine talent, wrote the 16th-century art historian Giorgio Vasari, he had grace, industry, beauty, modesty and excellence of character.

Subject: Giuliano della Rovere, Pope Julius II (1443-1515), elected pope in 1503 after one of the shortest conclaves ever (he bribed everyone). He was a lover of war, who led his own armies; and a lover of art, commissioning some of the greatest works in western history: Raphael's decorated rooms in the Vatican and Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel ceiling.

Distinguishing features: Julius doesn't look at you, as if he won't or can't bear to; and the aged, melancholy softness of his face only adds to the sense that his disapproval is terrible and final. This is God himself turning his head away, leaving us to depart miserably from his presence. When contemporaries saw it, Vasari wrote, they found it "so true and so lifelike that the portrait caused all who saw it to tremble, as if it had been the living man himself". The painting makes you feel like a terrified retainer called into the pope's presence for some savage dressing-down. Instead of shouting, he is too sad to speak, too disheartened to look you in the eye.

In fact, Julius was depressed because the city of Bologna had seceded from the papal states. He expressed his grief at this political disaster by growing a beard, imitating what Renaissance humanists had discovered was an ancient form of mourning. It is the beard that enables this portrait to be dated. It is soft and strong, milky-white yet bristling like a hog's hair paintbrush. The face from which it radiates has lined, sagging flesh yet its structure is forceful. There is a sensuality to the pope's ochre and bronze flesh. Only Raphael and Titian could make old men's skin as beautiful as this. On his hands are signet rings of emerald and ruby. He clutches a silk handkerchief, indicating his inward sensitivity. The golden acorns on either side of his head are family symbols. Beneath the green drapery in the background are traces of an earlier design of the papacy's crossed keys. It is the precise realisation of a person's physical presence that makes this painting so awe-inspiring.

Raphael's use of oil paint is almost unequalled in history. Look at the wrinkling of the skin as his left hand grips the throne, the flow of ruched, white fabric over his knees, the sense of his wiry body inside his robes. This is a self enthroned - the throne and robes are part of Julius.

Julius's image as bearded patriarch invites comparison with Michelangelo's Moses carved on the pope's unfinished tomb at the church of San Pietro in Vincoli, Rome.

Michelangelo's Moses and Raphael's Julius both look past us, are seated in majesty over us, and have the power to judge us for eternity. Michelangelo said when he fell out with Julius he could feel the rope around his neck. Looking at Raphael's portrait, we are in the presence of unquestionable authority.

Inspirations and influences: Papal portraiture is a genre in its own right, in which the robes and throne of office set the subject apart. Popes are old, and painters with the task of glamorising them had to find ways to make age seductive. They did this through startling frankness about the nature of Machiavellian princedom. Raphael's portrait of Pope Leo X (1518-19) shows him with two cardinals in what looks like a scene of heavyweight intrigue. Titian's Pope Paul III (1546) has the pope engaged in similar top-level chicanery. Velazquez repeats Raphael's vision of the pope in throned majesty in his Pope Innocent X (1650).

Where is it? The National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885).

webTitle: Do You Think We'll Ever Get To See Earth, Sir? by  Sheenagh Pugh

fields.headline: Do You Think We'll Ever Get To See Earth, Sir?
fields.trailText:
I hear they're hoping to run trips

one day, for the young and fit, of course...
fields.body:
I hear they're hoping to run trips

one day, for the young and fit, of course.

I don't see much use in it myself;

there'll be any number of places

you can't land, because they're still toxic,

and even in the relatively safe bits

you won't see what it was; what it could be.

I can't fancy a tour through the ruins

of my home with a party of twenty-five

and a guide to tell me what to see.

But if you should see some beautiful thing,

some leaf, say, damascened with frost,

some iridescence on a pigeon's neck,

some stone, some curve, some clear water;

look at it as if you were made of eyes,

as if you were nothing but an eye, lidless

and tender, to be probed and scorched

by extreme light. Look at it with your skin,

with the small hairs on the back of your neck.

If it is well-shaped, look at it with your hands;

if it has fragrance, breathe it into yourself;

if it tastes sweet, put your tongue to it.

Look at it as a happening, a moment;

let nothing of it go unrecorded,

map it as if it were already passing.

Look at it with the inside of your head,

look at it for later, look at it for ever,

and look at it once for me.

fields.headline: Don't move house - move your mortgage
fields.standfirst: Shop around for a better remortgage deal and you could have up to £200 extra a month to spend, reports Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: Shop around for a better remortgage deal and you could have up to £200 extra a month to spend, reports Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
Remortgaging has reached record levels as growing numbers of people become aware of the savings they can make by moving their mortgage to another lender.

Official figures out this week show that last month, for the first time ever, remortgages accounted for a third of all the home loans granted - in October 1999 they made up less than a quarter of the total.

The surge in interest in switching your home loan partly reflects the competition in the mortgage market, which has resulted in a plethora of attractive deals.

Experts say it also reflects the fact that people are now more savvy when it comes to products such as mortgages. The internet has contributed to this, putting borrowers in the driving seat by letting them browse the various offers on the market.

Below we look at some of the best deals around for those looking to remortgage.

There can be huge sums at stake. Ray Boulger at mortgage broker Charcol says many people can easily slice a quarter off their mortgage payments by switching, up to £100 or even £200 a month.

While the typical bank standard variable rate is 7.74%, there are two and three-year fixed rate and discounted deals available as low as 5.24%.

The message has to be that if you're sitting on your lender's standard variable rate, and there are no lock-in redemption penalties tying you in, you are simply throwing money away.

Your options are to talk to your lender to see if they will do you a better deal, or walk away and take another lender's deal. If you've been a good customer, your lender won't want to lose you, so get on the phone to them.

The cut throat competition means some lenders are pro-actively talking to their customers about better deals. Halifax is currently writing to 200,000 existing borrowers a month offering them the chance to move to other deals such as tracker loans (where the rate you pay follows the ups and downs of the Bank of England base rate) or fixed rates.

You might want to check out the deals on offer by surfing the net or scanning the Jobs & Money best buys before you talk to your lender.

If they can't come up with anything attractive, think seriously about taking your custom elsewhere. Many people perceive that a mortgage transfer is a huge, costly hassle. In truth, it does take a bit of sorting out, and you will probably have to dig out documents and fill in some forms. Many lenders are so desperate for your custom that they will pay your legal costs, waive the arrangement fee and throw in a free valuation as well.

If you are locked in to your current loan by early redemption penalties, it's not quite so simple. You will need to make sure that paying the penalty and going elsewhere will cost you less than staying on your current rate. One estimate is that only about 25% of people who do have redemption penalties would enjoy sufficient savings by remortgaging to make it worthwhile paying the penalty and moving.

So what good remortgage deals are on offer? Charcol says that Coventry Building Society is offering some competitive remortgage deals only available via its website, www.remortgages.co.uk for those happy to arrange their mortgage over the net.

They include a fee-free fixed rate where what you pay is pegged at 5.39% until February 28, 2003, and a fee-free discounted rate giving 2.35% off the standard rate until the same date (initial payment rate: 5.35%). Neither has early redemption penalties at any time.

Charcol is offering its own almost fee-free remortgage where you get a 2% discount off the 7.75% standard variable rate in the first year (giving a current payment rate of 5.75%), a 1.85% discount in the second year, and 1.7% off in the third year. The deal is funded by the Woolwich and is flexible.

While there are redemp tion penalties within the first three years, you are allowed to pay back up to 25% of the mortgage each year without penalty. There's a £49 booking fee.

Bath-based broker London & Country Mortgages highlights several deals.

On the fee-free front, Halifax is offering a tracker deal giving 0.45% off the bank base rate for two years, which means a current pay rate of 5.55%. The deal is completely free of redemption penalties.

Halifax also has a deal fixed at 5.65% until February 28, 2003. With this, there is a £195 arrangement fee and redemption penalties only within the period. Both loans require a deposit of 25%-plus.

Britannia Building Society has a deal giving 2.4% off the standard rate for two years, giving a current payment rate of 5.24%. There is a £195 arrangement fee, there are no redemption penalties at all, and a deposit of at least 25% is required.

Northern Rock is offering a loan fixed at 5.39% until January 1, 2003 but there is a £495 fee to pay. There are redemption penalties within the period.

National Counties Building Society has a discount mortgage capped at 5.69% until June 1, 2003 with a guaranteed discount of 1.5% off the standard rate.

There is a £300 completion fee to pay and there are penalties within the period.

Early Christmas present for borrowers

Nationwide building society this week gave many of its 1.25m borrowers an early gift in the form of a mortgage rate cut which will reduce the bill of borrowers with an average sized loan by £10 a month, writes Rupert Jones .

It has trimmed its standard variable mortgage rate by 0.2%, taking it down to 7.09% - significantly lower than the 7.74% charged by rival lenders such as Halifax and Abbey National.

The move affects those on the standard variable rate and on discounted deals, but won't of course have any impact on those with fixed rate loans. Nationwide says a typical £60,000 interest-only borrower on the standard rate will see their bill cut by £10 a month, while a £100,000 borrower will see a £16.66 a month saving.

The bad news is that savings rates will also be reduced.

Many borrowers with rival lenders will wonder whether they too will be treated to a mortgage rate cut. While experts think it's unlikely the Halifax et al will immediately follow the Nationwide's example ahead of any Bank of England base rate move, some commentators took the view that the picture could change over the coming months.

Many economists now believe interest rates have peaked, and mortgage broker Charcol says that when the first base rate cut does arrive, it is possible some lenders may drop their borrowing costs by more than the amount of the reduction. So if there was a 0.25% base rate cut they could lop, say, 0.35% off their standard variable mortgage rate.

Johannes Kennard at mortgage broker London & Country adds: "At some point you are going to see lenders doing something. I cannot believe that Nationwide is going to be out there on its own."

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Honest Italian restaurant cooking is still hard to beat, says Matthew Fort in Turin
fields.trailText: Honest Italian restaurant cooking is still hard to beat, says Matthew Fort in Turin
fields.body:
The other day I was given a lesson in eating. It was done quietly, without fuss, but incontrovertibly. It wasn't a matter of manners or menu selection. It all had to do with pacing. He finished dinner. I couldn't manage it.

I met the Wing Commander in Turin. He is an old Torinese hand, having been drawn to the city in his youth by his passion for Juventus football club. Don't ask me why. I can only suppose that it was a long way from Carlisle, place of his birth. Anyway, I had suggested that he direct me to a classic restaurant of the city, and he did just that.

Unless you knew about it, you could easily pass by the Ristorante Tre Galline without a second glance. Tucked away in an obscure side street, it has a slightly battered, tattered air, although a closer look at the building reveals an unmistakable pedigree. It turns out that it was designed by Filippo Juvarra, the architect whose fantastical Superga basilica - into which a plane carrying all the members of the great Torino football team crashed in 1949 - graces a hill overlooking the city.

Just like Turin, Tre Galline exudes solid virtue. It is the epitome of a well-tried, well-used, well-loved bourgeois watering hole: no frills, no frivolity, no designer flim-flam - just serious and proper comfort, and crisp, professional service. God, what a relief after the perpetual razzle-dazzle of London. Here is a place that has the quality and confidence of an established identity and long practice.

That goes for the food, too. You don't go to Tre Galline for cucina nuova or the grilled-vegetable-grilled-meat pastiches of Italian food with which we in England are now all too familiar. Here is unreconstructed, hearty, hefty Piedmontese cooking: tortino gratinato di patate e alici freschi, sformato di Castelmagno con leggera bagna caoda, gnocco di castagne con Gorgonzola di Novara, cinghiale al civet con polenta di ceci (or, to you and me, potato gratin with fresh anchovy, cheese flan with bagna caoda, gnocchi in chestnut and gorgonzola sauce, civet of wild boar with chickpea polenta). And so on and so on, with the daily regular specials - arrosti misti al carrello (mixed roast meats) on Monday and Tuesday, bollito misto (mixed boiled meats) on Wednesday and Thursday, fritto misto alla Piemontese (mixed deep-fried seafood) on Friday, and a proper big bagna caoda on Saturday thrown in for good measure.

That's regularity, dependability, and knowing what your customers want because they keep on coming back. One such was the writer, Cesare Pavese, whose novels and short stories charted the changes in urban Italy in the 30s and 40s.

All this information flowed out of the Wing Commander in a seamless flow, in between his discourses on Italian food lore, the wave theory and obscure football players of South America, another topic on which he was bewilderingly well-informed. And while this was going on, I was eating. I ate the plateful of titbits that was supposed to do for both of us; and antipasti caldi alla piemontese, a cracking array of veg - sweet, fleshy roasted pepper with a dab of bagna caoda, a delicate stuffed courgette, a kind of melted roast onion - and other bits too numerous to mention; and a pile of tajarin (a thin egg pasta of the tagliatelle/tagliarini family) with porcini, which was an exercise in silky, sexy slipperiness; and then a helping of bollito misto, which included a slice of ox cheek, a chunk of beef, a slab of veal, a hunk of cotecchino, a section of tongue and a wedge of chicken breast along with four sauces and mostarda di Cremona. Well, I say that I ate all this, but the shaming thing is that I slowed to a crawl and then ground to a halt. Meat-eater's manna though the line-up was, I couldn't finish it.

The Wing Commander, meanwhile, continued to discourse and consume in a steady manner. Away went his antipasti caldi alla Piemontese. He passed on the pasta, reserving his fire for tapulone di Borgomanero, a stew of imposing richness, spiciness and toothsome qualities made from donkey.

Now, there are those who may find the idea of eating donkey rather hard to stomach, but the Wing Commander is made of sterner stuff, and I think that it's better that a departed donkey is made into something so delicious as the tapulone di Borgomanero than end up as dog meat.

Finally, my friend dealt with a plate of the classic Torinese pudding, bunet - a heavyweight though mousse-like concoction of eggs, coffee and Amaretto -at the same easy, swinging gait with which he had demolished everything else.

Coffee, wine - two bottles of Roero to be exact, which is a combination of masterful elegance and compatibility - from a list that, as you would expect, sticks to neighbourhood plonk - led to a bill of L170,000, roughly £28 a head.

What makes such experiences so satisfying, and why are they so rare in Britain? Actually, in many ways parts of the menu have much in common with British cooking. What is bollito misto but boiled beef with knobs on? What is tapulone di Borgomanero but braised mutton, albeit with donkey in place of the sheep? What is... oh, all right, I won't press the analogy - it may not take the strain - but there is a heartiness and robustness here that is distinctly familiar.

It is a food of a tradition that is still honoured, made from soundly sourced materials, expertly cooked, utterly satisfying. This is what is meant by the term "good food". Tre Galline is a good restaurant. It was a pleasure to be there
