And so on and so on, with the daily regular specials - arrosti misti al carrello (mixed roast meats) on Monday and Tuesday, bollito misto (mixed boiled meats) on Wednesday and Thursday, fritto misto alla Piemontese (mixed deep-fried seafood) on Friday, and a proper big bagna caoda on Saturday thrown in for good measure. That's regularity, dependability, and knowing what your customers want because they keep on coming back. One such was the writer, Cesare Pavese, whose novels and short stories charted the changes in urban Italy in the 30s and 40s. All this information flowed out of the Wing Commander in a seamless flow, in between his discourses on Italian food lore, the wave theory and obscure football players of South America, another topic on which he was bewilderingly well-informed. And while this was going on, I was eating. I ate the plateful of titbits that was supposed to do for both of us; and antipasti caldi alla piemontese, a cracking array of veg - sweet, fleshy roasted pepper with a dab of bagna caoda, a delicate stuffed courgette, a kind of melted roast onion - and other bits too numerous to mention; and a pile of tajarin (a thin egg pasta of the tagliatelle/tagliarini family) with porcini, which was an exercise in silky, sexy slipperiness; and then a helping of bollito misto, which included a slice of ox cheek, a chunk of beef, a slab of veal, a hunk of cotecchino, a section of tongue and a wedge of chicken breast along with four sauces and mostarda di Cremona. Well, I say that I ate all this, but the shaming thing is that I slowed to a crawl and then ground to a halt. Meat-eater's manna though the line-up was, I couldn't finish it. The Wing Commander, meanwhile, continued to discourse and consume in a steady manner. Away went his antipasti caldi alla Piemontese. He passed on the pasta, reserving his fire for tapulone di Borgomanero, a stew of imposing richness, spiciness and toothsome qualities made from donkey. Now, there are those who may find the idea of eating donkey rather hard to stomach, but the Wing Commander is made of sterner stuff, and I think that it's better that a departed donkey is made into something so delicious as the tapulone di Borgomanero than end up as dog meat. Finally, my friend dealt with a plate of the classic Torinese pudding, bunet - a heavyweight though mousse-like concoction of eggs, coffee and Amaretto -at the same easy, swinging gait with which he had demolished everything else. Coffee, wine - two bottles of Roero to be exact, which is a combination of masterful elegance and compatibility - from a list that, as you would expect, sticks to neighbourhood plonk - led to a bill of L170,000, roughly £28 a head. What makes such experiences so satisfying, and why are they so rare in Britain? Actually, in many ways parts of the menu have much in common with British cooking. What is bollito misto but boiled beef with knobs on? What is tapulone di Borgomanero but braised mutton, albeit with donkey in place of the sheep? What is... oh, all right, I won't press the analogy - it may not take the strain - but there is a heartiness and robustness here that is distinctly familiar. It is a food of a tradition that is still honoured, made from soundly sourced materials, expertly cooked, utterly satisfying. This is what is meant by the term "good food". Tre Galline is a good restaurant. It was a pleasure to be there

fields.headline: Chinese shoppers glimpse scenes from a mall
fields.standfirst: Monolithic western-style retail and office complex opens in Beijing
fields.trailText: A new shopping mall which is wider than Tiananmen Square has opened in Beijing after years of controversy over the vast Oriental Plaza project to which it belongs.
fields.body:
A new shopping mall which is wider than Tiananmen Square has opened in Beijing after years of controversy over the vast Oriental Plaza project to which it belongs.

Stretching for hundreds of yards in the heart of the capital, it signals another stage in China's consumer revolution.

"Before, people would only buy on street corners," explains property agent Sunnie Wu. "Then the department stores became popular when they started stocking western-style goods. The shopping mall is a brand new concept: it will take time for them to shift to it."

Oriental Plaza, which includes office towers and a five-star hotel as well as the mall, occupies an entire block within walking distance of the Forbidden City. Its promoters claim it will rival Oxford Street and the Champs-Elysées, but critics say it is out of scale with central Beijing and should never have been built.

Yesterday the 100,000 square metre shopping area of the mall was still half empty. Salesgirls stood outside some of the clothes shops hustling for customers as if they were in the street market.

But property agent DTZ hails the 1,800 square metre Volkswagen showroom as a sign of the future. Leather-jacketed Chinese entrepreneurs inspect an Audi TT 1.8 coupe - price 800,000 Renminbi (£69,000) - with a confident air.

"Showroom is the wrong word," insists VW communications manager Sharon Lee. "We are a concept store. We try to show the [car] culture you have to tap into. People can feel it and smell it, this is a totally interactive place."

There is also an exhibition of sculpture from the Academy of Art, because of the "very close link between cars and art".

The £1.4bn Oriental Plaza is Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing's most ambitious construction project. It was originally approved by Beijing's former communist party boss Chen Xitong who is now serving a long prison sentence for corruption.

Mr Li's connections in Beijing reach as high as President Jiang Zemin. After Chen's downfall, the Oriental Plaza plan was re-evaluated but not scrapped.

It was originally planned as one monolithic bloc to be the largest single commercial complex in the world.

"We were not happy with its architectural scale," says a senior city architect, Cheng Enjian. "Our experts complained to the [Communist party] centre that it was too large and did not conform to the centre's own building guidelines."

The original height not only broke restrictions but would have allowed international executives on the upper floors to spy on the Zhongnanhai - the park-like central government area beyond the Forbidden City where Mr Jiang and other senior figures work.

The compromise solution was to lower the maximum height to that of the adjacent Beijing Hotel. The project's total area was also reduced and broken into eight separate blocks.

Special exemption was granted to allow working round the clock to make up for the delay. The facade was completed just before last year's 50th anniversary of the communist revolution.

According to Mr Cheng, city guidelines also require new buildings in the centre "not to copy indiscriminately foreign architecture, but to reflect the spirit of the Forbidden City".

However, Oriental Plaza is now hailed officially as an example of modernism appropriate for the new millennium.

The Plaza seeks to sell office space by its proximity to the Chinese seat of power, claiming to be "the most superb location for multinationals". It draws attention to "the luxurious interiors of the executive showers (which) emanate exclusivity".

Property analysts have been sceptical about the commercial prospects of such a large supply of office space hitting the market, but the Plaza is pinning its hopes on China's entry to the World Trade Organisation.

It may take time for the shopping mall to acquire the prestige which it also claims. Foreign retailers have difficulty in obtaining licences unless they can operate under the umbrella of a department store. For reasons which are not entirely clear, the Plaza cannot help them.

But McDonald's, removed from the site when its lease was terminated in an earlier controversy, is about to re-open.

webTitle: Gardens: Christopher Lloyd supports the Royal Horticultural Society trials

fields.headline: Judge for yourself
fields.standfirst: The Royal Horticultural Society trials need support if they are to survive, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: The Royal Horticultural Society trials need support if they are to survive, says Christopher Lloyd.
fields.body:
The RHS trials of vegetables and flowers carried out on the Portsmouth Field at Wisley are of supreme importance. Nowhere else in the world are similar trials, both from seed and plants, conducted, so this is a testing ground where comparisons can be made.

It is not, I believe, given sufficient recognition by the visiting public, partly because the venue is a little off the beaten track, partly because the average visitor doesn't know what to look out for, and partly because of the constant din from the adjoining A3. You can ignore this if you try - well, almost - but it is imperative that the trials receive both publicity and recognition, because they are expensive to run and are in constant danger of either paring down or extinction due to the arguments of accountants, who can see the bottom line but have no concept of value.

Still vivid in my mind's eye was the trial that came to a head in spring last year that involved small-flowered violas. Until then, I had no conception of their range and what a tremendous and prolonged display they could provide. Sown in July (generally the best month for all pansies and violas), they started flowering in October; many were going strong in January, but the overall display peaked in March and continued until June. Amazing.

The trouble with pansies is that their flowers are often too large for their own good - the upper petals tend, from their own weight and expanse, to collapse over the centre of the flower. Small-flowered violas have no such problems, however. and the abundance of their blossom results in a greater display of colour than is gained from the pansies. Do remember, though, when planting, that, like many other flowers, they turn towards where the light is brightest, so don't plant them so that they turn backs on you.

The Jewel series, bred by Takii in Japan, was among the most impressive, especially 'Jewel Blue' and 'Jewel Yellow'. Also 'Sorbet Yellow Delight', although that shows signs of distress in warm weather. It is a mistake to view pansies and violas as year-round bedders - they dislike summer heat and there are many better alternatives for that season.

The biggest and most prolonged splash of colour in last summer's trials came from the annual rudbeckias. Giving the most prolonged display was one called 'Toto' - bright yellow with a black cone, smallish flowers on a rather dumpy plant of pretty uniform 30cm height. Plant breeders worship uniformity and density of colour above all virtues. Many of us actually prefer a bit of variation, and 'Toto' gradually achieved something of this, and its cheerful persistence won me over in the long run.

For a combination of height (1m) and a big, bold bloom that is interestingly shaped, 'Indian Summer', again in yellow and black, has my support, although there is some variation in the seed strain. A most unusual cone flower that well deserved its Award of Garden Merit (AGM), I thought, was the species Rudbeckia amplexicaulis (1m). Its black cone stands well above down-drooping rays of a softer yellow than most, while the oval leaves are soap-smooth - most unusual in this genus. It is sometimes, incorrectly, listed as ratibida.

As with most annual seed strains, mixtures do not compare well with single-colour strains. In rudbeckias, bronzing in zones or mixed with yellow also detracts from their overall impact.

The trial of annual sunflowers was sown direct, which is the easiest way for many gardeners. And it was sown quite late - May 15, to be exact - so flowering was also lateish, at its height in late August to early September. You must, of course, have your sunflowers facing the sun, or at least against a darker background. Those growing above 3m tall (fun for children) must have flowers that condescendingly look downwards. For youngsters, the types with one enormous flower to each plant will be the most popular, but their flowering season is short, generally a mere fortnight. F1 'Sunrich Lemon' was one of the best of these and a convenient 1.5m in height.

For general border usefulness, a well branched plant is best because it gives an extended flowering season and blooms of moderate size. 'Valentine' (1.8m) has long been a favourite with us, and it won the AGM. The black disc is highlighted by pale yellow rays. 'Pastiche', a small-flowered mixture, is useful for border work.

Examples of perennial coreopsis grown from seed were generally rather unsatisfactory, but the current trial of perennial kinds grown from plants will prove more serviceable. From seed, a number of strains, such as 'Early Sunrise' and 'Sunray', albeit brilliant yellow semi-doubles at their best, flower unevenly, with some plants remaining totally vegetative in their first year.

In most strains, a major fault is that they die ungracefully: the faded blooms, unless removed at weekly intervals, spoil the display made by blooms in their prime

webTitle: Kevin Toolis meets Unionist MP Jeffrey Donaldson

fields.headline: Marching as to war?
fields.standfirst:
Unionist MP Jeffrey Donaldson wants to depose his leader David Trimble for failing his own people. He knows that, if he succeeds, he might well bring down the Northern Ireland Assembly - and risks reigniting sectarian violence in the process. Kevin Toolis asks him why

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Unionist MP Jeffrey Donaldson wants to depose his leader David Trimble for failing his own people. He knows that, if he succeeds, he might well bring down the Northern Ireland Assembly - and risks reigniting sectarian violence in the process. Kevin Toolis asks him why.
fields.body:
It's nearly midnight, and after a full day of meetings conspiring to destroy Ulster's peace deal, Jeffrey Donaldson MP is still on his feet in the local Orange hall. Tonight is supposed to be a celebration of Scots-Ulster culture, with a bit of Lambeg drumming, but instead it's the same old rendition of Orangeism's history. The walls of the Royal Black Preceptory Hall are lined with fading masonic symbols and pictures of the young Queen Elizabeth. At the back is a photographic display of Orangemen in their finest, strutting down the ages from Portadown in the 1910s to the Gulf War of 1991. Plans to walk the "Queen's Highway" can't be far below the surface chatter. Tea and sandwiches are laid out on a central table and some of the mainly middle-aged company have brought in beer and drinks in plastic carrier bags.

Donaldson takes the microphone: "I say, let's break out of this siege mentality, let's be proud of our culture, our identity, our tradition." The speech, like the event, never quite catches. The crowd claps halfheartedly, as if no one is quite sure how to react.

The whole evening has an air of dowdiness. Donaldson unashamedly labours on, praising "our culture" again and again, and the ossified mind-set it represents. A drummer appears and bashes away for five ear-splitting minutes on a Lambeg drum, favoured by Blackmen, another sort of Orange Order, for its booming sound that's reputed to scare the living daylights out of Catholics.

For Donaldson, on the surface at least, the evening is "a relaxed expression of the culture rather than what might be seen as the rather more intense expression of the Orange marches".

Orangemen don't like Catholics and they don't like the press, so Donaldson makes a point of publicly introducing the photographer, Keith Bernstein, and me to this most loyal of loyalist companies: "This is Kevin from the Guardian," he says, with just a fraction of a pause after the "Kevin".

Afterwards, everyone we spoke to was suitably polite and correct, although I must be one of the few Kevins, an identifiable Catholic name, to ever have crossed the threshold of the Lagan Valley Royal Black Preceptory Hall. Genuine or not, Donaldson's endorsement of the Royal Blackmen will do him no harm at the ballot box. He may be a non-smoking, non-drinking Presbyterian, but Donaldson's true religion is politics.

Ulster is once more lurching into crisis and the peace process falling apart. David Trimble is sabotaging the vital all-Ireland institutions because the IRA won't decommission its weapons. Martin McGuinness is denouncing Trimble for reneging on the Good Friday agreement. The SDLP is supporting Sinn Fein but attacking the Provos for failing to disarm and thus playing into the hands of Unionist hardliners who want Trimble to pull out of the Ulster executive. Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) just hates everyone else. The entire Northern Ireland Assembly is teetering on the verge of collapse, and with it the peace of Ulster. It is Jeffrey Donaldson's hour.

For the past two years, ever since he walked out of the Unionist team in the final hours of the 1998 Good Friday agreement negotiations, Donaldson has strived to make "terrorism a thing of the past" by undermining, co-agitating and generally seeking the downfall of Unionist leader and Nobel Peace Prize winner, David Trimble, who leads the Ulster Unionist party. Donaldson, Enoch Powell's one-time election agent, is the uncrowned king of the "No" wing of Ulster Unionism and has been the main instigator of the five failed internal coups, one every three months since 1998, to unseat Trimble. Two more potential coup attempts are already planned for the spring.

Donaldson may have been a Deputy Orange Grand Master, but he is not a Bible-thumping Paisley-style bigot who can easily be dismissed. He is a player, a potential contender, a man to do business with, someone who appears on BBC1's Question Time and who can walk the corridors of the White House.

His language is carefully coded, laced with nuance, and keeps within the pre-ordained bounds of television soundbites, but the implication is clear: Trimble is weak, a failure, who is betraying the Unionist cause by letting the IRA run rings around him. Donald-son has an alternative strategy - to secure the leadership for himself - but to get Trimble out, he has to break him on the rock of IRA decommissioning. Beneath their forced smiles and first-name addresses, "David" and "Jeffrey" must hate each other's guts.

None of this internal feuding should matter to the outside world, but for the consequences. The rock that Donaldson is using against Trimble is composed of IRA guns buried deep in the bogs of Donegal. In private, everyone in Northern Ireland's political class accepts that there will be no IRA decommissioning. It is politically impossible for the Republican leadership to hand over guns without provoking a split in their own ranks. Short of issuing a press release to that effect, the IRA has made it as clear as is humanly possible that there is never, ever, going to be a unilateral hand-over of weapons.

Under pressure from a Unionist walkout of the Northern Ireland executive last spring, the IRA did relent and allow two independent observers to inspect two IRA arms dumps earlier this year and seal them with an electronic device. But it was only a symbolic political gesture, not the start of a decommissioning process in which actual guns are handed over.

But to keep the Stormont show on the road, everyone, particularly Unionist politicians, has to pretend to their electorate that meaningful IRA decommissioning will still happen. Everyone, that is, except Donaldson, who now has a loaded political gun to Trimble's head. To save himself from Donaldson, Trimble has promised his activists progressively to exclude Sinn Fein ministers from the Northern Ireland executive unless the IRA decommissions.

Any deadline imposed by the Unionists is guaranteed to provoke an IRA refusal, and hence a political crisis. Trimble will not be able to deliver, and will then either be forced to resign or crash the executive council that acts like a cabinet for the Northern Ireland Assembly. In any event, excluding Sinn Fein ministers will itself soon provoke the collapse of the agreement. "Donaldson has got Trimble to box himself in against the IRA," says one seasoned Northern Ireland commentator. "We all know the IRA don't like deadlines. The box Trimble is building is in his own political coffin."

Soon, possibly even as early as Christmas, the whole elaborately constructed Stormont pack of cards is going to hit the deck. "There is no doubt that Trimble has stepped on to Jeffrey's escalator," says Mark Durcan, the SDLP minister of finance on the Northern Ireland executive. "Jeffrey Donaldson is a significant threat. As long as there is no progress on the decommissioning front, then he has ready ground to rally people to his point of view." These days of peace in Northern Ireland, it seems, are numbered.

For a man who is set on destroying Tony Blair's greatest political triumph, Donaldson has a surprisingly low profile on what he would term the mainland. He was born in Kilkeel, a Protestant-dominated fishing village on the coast of County Down, in 1962, the first of eight children in a large Presbyterian family. Kilkeel, near the mountains of Mourne, is close to the IRA's border heartlands, but was then, and still is, a backwater where Catholic and Protestant communities live uneasily together. The Troubles struck the Donaldson family early in August 1970, when an older cousin, Sam Donaldson, an RUC policeman, pulled on the door handle of an abandoned car in the village of Crossmaglen. It was an IRA booby trap and the car exploded, killing Sam and a fellow officer, Robert Millar. Sam was the second of 300 RUC men to be killed during the latest wave of Troubles, and the first of 277 to die at the hands of the IRA.

Donaldson was seven at the time, but remembers the funeral well. Fifteen years later, another cousin, Alex Donaldson, was killed in the 1985 IRA mortar attack on Newry police station in which nine officers died. When he was 18, Donaldson joined the Ulster Defence Regiment (UDR) and the Young Unionists. "There are family traditions," he says, "and we had a tradition of serving. But there was an absolute strict adherence to law and order; paramilitarism was totally anathema to my sense of morality."

Donaldson's family, once farming stock, was committed to the British Crown and its security forces; he, his father Jim and brother James served in the now notorious Ulster Defence Regiment. Officially, the UDR was part of the British Army, but in reality it was a locally recruited Protestant militia that was hated and feared by the Catholic community, not without reason: several members of the UDR have been convicted of serious terrorist offences, including murder, against Catholics. Joining the UDR was not a morally neutral act; it was taking sides in the war for Ulster.

"I do not buy into this argument that the RUC is a Protestant police force," insists Donaldson. "I do not buy into the republican slur that the UDR and the RUC were the armed wings of Unionism. It was republicans who embarked on a sectarian campaign of the murder of Protestants in border areas right across Northern Ireland. How more sectarian can you get? The IRA have killed more Catholics than the UDR ever did," he states patiently, his voice never breaking from its almost dispassionate monotone. "My experience of the UDR is that they went out to do a job and that job was to protect the community against the terrorists, regardless of who the terrorists were." I ask if he had ever once seen an act of sectarianism by a fellow serving UDR member. "No," came the surprising reply.

Being in the UDR was dangerous - the IRA targeted and killed more than 200 UDR men, usually ambushing them on their days off as they went about their ordinary working lives. One of Donaldson's former UDR comrades, Alan Johnston, was shot dead in 1988. "Alan lived just around the corner from me. Alan was in my local Young Unionist branch. Alan was murdered, shot in the back as he carried his lunchbox into work one day. Alan was a joiner. Obviously, when I lost a comrade in the UDR, you were angry. There was grief as well, that sense of loss. The experience of losing family, comrades, people you represent, it does leave a mark."

When he wasn't flying around in British Army helicopters with a rifle across his lap fighting IRA terrorism - he never shot a round in anger - Donaldson devoted the rest of his energies to the Ulster Unionist party. He is a devoted "pol", that strange extract of humanity, like William Hague, who collects electoral scores as teenagers rather than football programmes and whose idea of ecstasy is a lectern and an attentive audience. Also like Hague, Donaldson is a tactician. He does not read books, quote philosophy or have political heroes. He is an Orange political geek with no real interests beyond tactical politics, media interviews and electoral counts.

Donaldson is only 37 years old, but he has been a full-time political activist since the age of 18, and in that time has fought an endless series of internal and external elections. fields.bodyText: It's nearly midnight, and after a full day of meetings conspiring to destroy Ulster's peace deal, Jeffrey Donaldson MP is still on his feet in the local Orange hall. Tonight is supposed to be a celebration of Scots-Ulster culture, with a bit of Lambeg drumming, but instead it's the same old rendition of Orangeism's history. The walls of the Royal Black Preceptory Hall are lined with fading masonic symbols and pictures of the young Queen Elizabeth. At the back is a photographic display of Orangemen in their finest, strutting down the ages from Portadown in the 1910s to the Gulf War of 1991. Plans to walk the "Queen's Highway" can't be far below the surface chatter. Tea and sandwiches are laid out on a central table and some of the mainly middle-aged company have brought in beer and drinks in plastic carrier bags. Donaldson takes the microphone: "I say, let's break out of this siege mentality, let's be proud of our culture, our identity, our tradition." The speech, like the event, never quite catches. The crowd claps halfheartedly, as if no one is quite sure how to react. The whole evening has an air of dowdiness. Donaldson unashamedly labours on, praising "our culture" again and again, and the ossified mind-set it represents. A drummer appears and bashes away for five ear-splitting minutes on a Lambeg drum, favoured by Blackmen, another sort of Orange Order, for its booming sound that's reputed to scare the living daylights out of Catholics. For Donaldson, on the surface at least, the evening is "a relaxed expression of the culture rather than what might be seen as the rather more intense expression of the Orange marches". Orangemen don't like Catholics and they don't like the press, so Donaldson makes a point of publicly introducing the photographer, Keith Bernstein, and me to this most loyal of loyalist companies: "This is Kevin from the Guardian," he says, with just a fraction of a pause after the "Kevin". The SDLP is supporting Sinn Fein but attacking the Provos for failing to disarm and thus playing into the hands of Unionist hardliners who want Trimble to pull out of the Ulster executive. fields.headline: West 175 Media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: West 175 Media was feeling bullish yesterday. The self-styled world-wide media company announced it had secured a deal with Union Pictures to produce television programmes in the UK.
fields.body:
West 175 Media was feeling bullish yesterday. The self-styled world-wide media company announced it had secured a deal with Union Pictures to produce television programmes in the UK.

This marks West 175's first foray into production in Britain, and provides it with an immediate entry point into the British TV production market. The Surrey-based and AIM-listed company already has production arms in New Zealand and the United States.

MasterChef USA, hosted by the chef Gary Rhodes, and an award winning Equinox documentary for Channel 4 are among Union Pictures' productions.

The venture is a good move, say City analysts. TV is a burgeoning area and niche productions will do well. West 175 should be able to marry its print content with Union's TV expertise, in say, cooking.The link-up also provides West 175 with access to the BBC, ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5, relationships that Union Pictures has already established.

One analyst described the venture as a "marriage of skills" that would make West 175 an even "busier" company, not only in terms of productions but also with the merchandising, publishing and life events the company puts on.

But despite positive analyst reactions the share price yesterday moved up only slightly on the news, 2.5p to 189.5p, suggesting the market is still waiting for the company to deliver before it is convinced of the importance or significance of this deal.

The joint venture company, Union 175, formed by West 175 and Union Pictures, will be able to develop, produce and distribute TV programmes in the UK and for sale all over the world but the focus initially will be on the British market.

Rated by many City analysts as a company to watch and buy a stake in, the future looks positive.

But it's one to hold until you see more evidence of programmes produced by Union 175 coming to a television near you.

West 175 should be able to marry its print content with Union's TV expertise, in say, cooking.The link-up also provides West 175 with access to the BBC, ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5, relationships that Union Pictures has already established. One analyst described the venture as a "marriage of skills" that would make West 175 an even "busier" company, not only in terms of productions but also with the merchandising, publishing and life events the company puts on. But despite positive analyst reactions the share price yesterday moved up only slightly on the news, 2.5p to 189.5p, suggesting the market is still waiting for the company to deliver before it is convinced of the importance or significance of this deal. The joint venture company, Union 175, formed by West 175 and Union Pictures, will be able to develop, produce and distribute TV programmes in the UK and for sale all over the world but the focus initially will be on the British market. Rated by many City analysts as a company to watch and buy a stake in, the future looks positive. But it's one to hold until you see more evidence of programmes produced by Union 175 coming to a television near you.

webTitle: Mail ponders Hello! deal to fight Express-OK! link

fields.headline: Mail ponders Hello! deal to fight Express-OK! link
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Britain's two main mid-market tabloids are squaring up to fight for the biggest celebrity exclusives with the might of the top two star magazines behind them.
fields.body:
Britain's two main mid-market tabloids are squaring up to fight for the biggest celebrity exclusives with the might of the top two star magazines behind them.

After the publisher of OK! magazine took over the Express and promised to boost its celebrity count, its arch-rival Hello! yesterday said it was in talks about a tie-up with the paper's main competitor, the Daily Mail.

In recent years, the Mail has dominated the middle market, but the new Express chief, Richard Desmond, has promised to bring the success of OK! with him. "I will spend whatever it takes," he told Express staff. However, a Mail-Hello! deal would be a formidable weapon in the newspaper circulation war.

Sally Cartwright, publishing director of Hello!, said she had held preliminary talks with the Mail to share celebrity exclusives."We don't have any specific plans at the moment but we have discussed the fact that we now have a common enemy," she told the Guardian's media website.

Hello! scored a major victory over its rival this week when the court of appeal in London lifted an injunction banning the publication of unauthorised pictures of the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones. Northern and Shell, publishers of OK! and the Express, had sought to protect their exclusive deal with the actors by preventing Hello! from printing the unofficial images.

Evidence of closer co-operation between the Express and OK! appeared yesterday when the newspaper published pictures of the footballer David Beckham at home with his wife Victoria. Previously, the Express would have not been in the running for such pictures. More official pictures of the Douglas-Zeta Jones wedding will appear in the Express on Monday.

Some observers believe the tie-ups may backfire: celebrities have been keen to sign exclusive deals with OK! and Hello! because they receive more favourable coverage than from newspapers.

But Ms Cartwright said:"Although celebrities do have a certain amount of control with Hello! and OK!, there have always been things they have no control over. They have never been able to prevent people taking photographs in a public place."

Over the past few years the price of star deals has soared. For the Douglas-Zeta Jones deal, OK! is reported to have paid £1.2m into a charitable trust set up by the actors. Ms Cartwright said the newspaper tie-ups might bring prices down. "If this helps to bring down the market rate for celebrity exclusives I'll be very happy."

webTitle: Labour increases lead as euro antipathy heightens

fields.headline: Labour increases lead as euro antipathy heightens
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Public opposition to the single currency has jumped sharply and is now close to record levels reached in late 1996, during the height of the "beef war", a new survey showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Public opposition to the single currency has jumped sharply and is now close to record levels reached in late 1996, during the height of the "beef war", a new survey showed yesterday.

Those in favour of Britain joining the euro have fallen from 27% of the population to 22%, according to a Mori poll undertaken for Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.

Meanwhile those opposed have risen from 56% to 62%, giving a balance against the euro of 40%, the highest level since November 1996 when it stood at 42%. "Public opinion has become even more heavily eurosceptic," said analyst Michael Saunders. "We doubt that the UK will join EMU during the next five years."

Mr Saunders said the government's attempts to downplay its pro-EMU stance had helped increase Labour's lead over the Tories from 2% to 16% in the polls.

While the euro was buoyed by intervention rumours in the markets yesterday, it was the pound's turn to come under pressure. Sterling slid close to a 14-year low against the dollar, below $1.40 at one point before closing at $1.4017.

Neil Parker, market strategist at the Royal Bank of Scotland, said sterling was like a cartoon character, "clinging on to the cliff by its fingertips".

He warned that if sterling broke through resistance at $1.395, it could plummet as far as $1.36. This time last year, sterling was trading at $1.66.

fields.headline: A tale of two journeys
fields.standfirst:
How Britain's collapsing railways compare with India
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText:
How Britain's collapsing railways compare with India
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.body:
John Vidal

Mrs G is a broken woman. She has come to central London from the suburbs and wants to get to Hatfield, a 40-mile journey that used to take an hour. She has missed two cancelled commuter trains and one that was too full to squeeze on to. Now, at 10.45am, she has taken 135 minutes to get to King's Cross.

"Sorry, ma'am," says the enquiries man. "You'll have to start at Farringdon Road."

"But how? Why? The trains start here."

"You'd be better off there."

"I don't understand ..."

"Neither, exactly, do I," he says, looking Hatfield up in a big fat book.

Mrs G puts her bags down, and stares up at the electronic board. It clicks and whirrs. Hatfield comes up. "Ooooh, goodness ... it's here," she says, running off. Three minutes later, she is back and the sign has gone, too.

In India there might be a riot. In the United States, verbal abuse would fly. The Germans would find it hard to imagine, but a zen-like calm - or a dull acceptance - is now falling on British rail travellers.

My intention is to take a 250 mile loop through middle England, to Birmingham via Peterborough. Once it would take four hours. No one will guess today, but Railtrack staff say there should be "no problem".

The plan hits the buffers immediately. There is no train for at least an hour. By 11.30, 200 of us have boarded the Leeds express, which has three empty first class coaches and three overflowing standard ones. Soon we are dawdling through fields and stopping at nothing in particular. We pay £4.30 for a cup of coffee and a sandwich.

Coach three admires the floods. We pass time in sidings, we watch the rain, read and swap tall train tales. Mrs Giling from Brighton has "rations" - sandwiches and a flask - because she knows it could be a long haul to Leeds. Mr Edwards says he spent eight hours instead of four getting to Edinburgh last week. Mr Jones says he took 12 hours and a bus.

The normal 63-minute journey to Peterborough takes 145 minutes. Mr Edwards remarks that he saw some men working on lines near Birmingham last week, but no-one else has seen any evidence of repairs being done. "They come out at night," the ticket collector says. "Just like moles. So we don't disrupt the service."

Peterborough is chaos with the tannoy blaring apologies, but three young GNER workers say things are improving. Victor Kuch, acting as today's flakcatcher with a special enquiries stall at the station, says he was asked 10,846 questions about what's happening. "In old BR days we would have told people to piss off. Now we do it with a smile," he says, adding that GNER has lost half its travellers since the "troubles".

"We got a lot of abuse to start with, but it's normal now," he says. "They (the customers) know there's no use jumping and screaming." He reckons the service in Britain is still far better than in the US. "They say we have the best trains in the world. They love us."

In the waiting room, Candy, a student from southern China, does not love the railways. It has taken two hours to get the few miles from Grantham and she has missed an interview in Cambridge: "Trains here are very late and very, very, very expensive," she says. "In China they are like buses."

On platform five, Mita Devli, an Indian from Tanzania, has been saying goodbye to her Auntie Mina. "Where is the train?" she asks. "I must get to Bath. Trains in India were much more reliable," she says.

A grubby one-coacher grandly named The John Constable arrives. In a few seconds it is standing room only. "We're on time," says the guard, but it leaves 10 minutes late.

The 2.15 to Brum is 30 minutes late arriving, but it is quite possible, says a well-seasoned traveller, that it is a later one which is actually early.

We grind slowly past bleak, empty sidings and acres of polluted former industrial land. "Mustn't grumble," says a woman near Leicester. "You can't expect them to sort out these problems without a bit of inconvenience. We have to support them."

In the main hall in Birmingham New Street station hundreds of commuters are craning necks to the noticeboard. Many more are lying down, picnicking or asleep.

Once there was a fast Virgin train to London every half hour. The emergency timetable says there is now one every hour which takes roughly twice as long. Finding them is hopeless. The "customer reception" desk says there is one in 50 minutes. The inquiry office says it is leaving in 20. But then the tannoy says that there is one on platform four. We rush. Too late. The train is there but the Virgin staff refuse to let latecomers on. In fact the 4.45 to London has been delayed just 12 minutes. Sixty-four exhausted people squeeze into coach six. The usual 1hr 40 min journey is predicted to take an extra 20 minutes.

John, our train manager, tells us a preceding train has got a dodgy door and needs to be examined. But few people hear him because they are mostly asleep. We arrive in Euston at 7.45pm, after almost 10 hours. Is it getting any better, we ask the ticket collector. "You tell me," he says. Smiling.

Luke Harding in Agra

If Gerald Corbett had boarded the 7.15am Taj Express to Agra yesterday, he might have been pleasantly surprised by the journey. The train was clean and left just three minutes late. Only a few people had to stand in the corridor.

As the Indian countryside whizzed by, and the coffee wallah came round offering another cup of sweet Indian coffee for the paltry sum of five rupees, the former Railtrack chief executive might have usefully pondered what he did wrong.

Unlike Britain's train system, India's still works. It was, of course, the British who built India's railways 150 years ago, in an epic feat of engineering which would connect the beaches of south India with the Khyber Pass. In total, the British laid 23,000 miles of track, in what turned out to be the biggest construction project ever carried out by a colonial power. But since then Britain seems to have lost the knack of managing railways. In India the trains continue to run with reasonable efficiency, despite the vast distances.

Arriving at Nizamuddin station in New Delhi in the early morning gloom, I was reassured to see my name on a list of passengers with seats to travel. The platform was crowded. Some of the people on it were going on a journey; the rest live permanently in the station.

There were plenty of diversions - tea stalls, phone booths, newspaper sellers, and a man frying pakoras in a giant pan of oil.

The trick with Indian trains is to make a reservation first. With a population of 1bn, there is no point in turning up in the hope you will get a seat. With this in mind, I dropped into my local station two days beforehand. The queues are long, there is a tea break at 11.30am, but eventually you get there.

My ticket to Agra from Delhi cost a mere 156 rupees (£2.40), not bad for a round trip of about 300 miles. The train rolled in on time. I found my seat, S2 71. Amazingly, there was no one in it. Soon, though, a row erupted next to me. A young man was refusing to give up his seat to the old man who had actually reserved it. As the train clattered through Delhi's unlovely industrial southern suburbs, Vijay Menon, on his way to see his family in Agra, told of his brother, who was once stuck on a train to Bangalore for three days. "He went to sleep and woke up to find he was still at the same station. There had been an oil spill."

Most passengers with experience of British trains, however, agreed that the ones in India were more reliable.

"The Central Line is horrible. I do a lot of commuting by tube and they are always breaking down," said Veena Chauhan, a civil servant from Ealing, west London, visiting relatives in India. "Indian railways are very good considering how vast the country is."

Gradually, the suburbs gave way to countryside, a flat expanse of scrub, thatched farm buildings and cattle egrets.

Inside the carriage a sock-wallah was trying to sell nylon socks at 10 rupees (13p) a pair. She was followed by the crisp-wallah, the newspaper-wallah, the ticket inspector, a blind singing beggar, and the peanut man. Finally the breakfast wallah came round. I bought two veg cutlets and a slice of bread for 15 rupees.

Travelling by train in India is still a genuinely demotic experience. You might sit next to a cabinet minister or an illiterate cowherd.

The Indian railway is also the world's largest employer, with 1.6m staff and 11m passengers a day. That the system works at all is miraculous. The fact that we arrived in Agra 15 minutes late was forgivable.

"In India we are not so worried about time. In the western world everyone is running around all the time. We just want to enjoy ourselves, go out for dinner, that kind of thing," said one of the passengers, Squadron Leader Ashok.

Gerald Corbett, as he disappears from the fray into India for a month, might just agree.

webTitle: US supreme court gives Bush fresh hope

fields.headline: US supreme court gives Bush fresh hope
fields.standfirst: Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: The US supreme court stepped into the struggle for the White House today, agreeing to consider George W Bush's appeal against the hand-recount of ballots in Florida that has seen Al Gore's vote-tally inch closer to the lead.
fields.body:
The US supreme court stepped into the struggle for the White House today, agreeing to consider George W Bush's appeal against the hand-recount of ballots in Florida that has seen Al Gore's vote-tally inch closer to the lead.

The court's action could mean that the closest US presidential contest in 124 years will not be settled before early December, nearly a month after Americans voted on November 7. Acting just as final votes were being tallied, the top US court ordered lawyers for the Republican party candidate, Mr Bush, and his Democratic party rival, Mr Gore, to "brief and argue" their cases next week.

By late yesterday, recounts had whittled down Mr Bush's lead in Florida by about 200 votes, to 724 out of about 6m cast. The tallies went into the weekend under a state court's order that was meant to allow the Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris - a strong Bush supporter - to certify a winner tomorrow evening.

Ms Harris said she was prepared to certify the election tomorrow night regardless. "The department of state is prepared for the earliest contingency, which would be certification Sunday evening," chief of staff Ben McKay said. "This will be done publicly regardless of the outcome, which is, of course, unknown at this time."

Aides of Mr Bush, the Texas governor, and Mr Gore, the vice president, say they are prepared to contest the Florida results if they feel votes have been improperly invalidated.

The supreme court's decision to take the Bush appeal was a surprise in some quarters because elections are often seen as state, not federal, business and an earlier Bush challenge had been turned back to the state by a federal circuit court.

The court set up a breakneck schedule for next week: legal briefs are due on Tuesday and responses Thursday, then 90 minutes of arguments starting at 10am Friday.

Mr Bush sought the court's intervention after the Florida supreme court ruled unanimously to continue the state counting deadline from November 17 to November 26, and to allow election officials to consider a voter's intent in the case of disputed ballots. County votes were to have been accepted until 5pm tomorrow.

Mr Gore's lawyers had argued that the Florida process of recounts, punctuated by state court disputes over how to conduct them and whether to include disputed military ballots from abroad, was a state matter, not one for supreme court intervention.

The court did nothing that would deter Ms Harris from certifying the outcome of the election Sunday, scheduled for sometime after 2300 GMT. The US presidential election is decided not by the popular vote but by the electoral college system. Under this system, when candidates win in a state, they win all that state's electoral votes. The candidate who wins at least 270 electoral votes wins the presidency.

Both candidates are just a few votes away from that margin, meaning that whoever takes Florida - which offers 25 electoral votes - also takes the presidency.

Meanwhile yesterday, canvassers sifted contested ballots in Broward and Palm Beach Counties, and Democrats accused Republicans of sending paid demonstrators to try to intimidate election officials.

Mr Gore gained votes in a recount in heavily Democratic Palm Beach and Broward counting, while Mr Bush picked up in a recount of absentee ballots from servicemen and women abroad.

Dick Cheney, the Republican vice presidential candidate, was released from a Washington hospital after two days of treatment for a mild heart attack. He said doctors told him to take the weekend off, then "return to a fairly normal schedule."

The court's decision to hear Bush's appeal came after aides to Mr Gore said they were planning to challenge any Bush victory in Florida on the grounds that some Democratic votes had not been validated.

"We believe we stand on both strong political and legal ground for fighting beyond Sunday," said Ron Klain, a Gore adviser. He pointed to the decision of the Miami-Dade County canvassing board to stop its recount for lack of time to finish by tomorrow. The Gore camp had expected to gain in the 10,000 ballots disputed there.

Democrats said Republican protesters were disrupting the recount process, and accused them of intimidating Miami recounters into quitting.

Joe Lieberman, the Democratic vice presidential nominee, stepped out of Mr Gore's residence in Washington to denounce demonstrations he said had been orchestrated by Republicans "to intimidate and to prevent a simple count of votes from going forward."

Both parties had demonstrators in the recount cities yesterday. Six Democratic members of Congress demanded a Justice Department investigation on Friday, saying civil rights had been violated in "a shocking case of undermining the right to vote through intimidation and threats of violence."

"The Republicans are out of control," said Jenny Backus, spokeswoman for the Democratic national committee. She accused them of using paid agitators to "create mob rule in Miami."

fields.headline: Turks dismiss Cyprus talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The Turkish Cypriot president, Rauf Denktash, said yesterday that further talks with the Greek Cypriots over the future of the divided island of Cyprus were a "waste of time".
fields.body:
The Turkish Cypriot president, Rauf Denktash, said yesterday that further talks with the Greek Cypriots over the future of the divided island of Cyprus were a "waste of time".

The Turkish government strongly supports Mr Denktash and criticised European Union interference in Cyprus and its bid to link Turkey's EU membership with a resolution of the dispute.

United Nations officials have held five rounds of talks with Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders this year but, after meeting Turkish leaders in Ankara, Mr Denktash said there was no point in going any further if the UN refused to recognise the breakaway Turkish republic's sovereignty.

Only Ankara recognises that sovereignty - the rest of the world views the Greek Cypriot regime as the legitimate ruler, even though the island has been split since Turkish troops invaded the north 25 years ago.

The Turkish prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said yesterday that international pressure would have no effect on its policy. "If the EU had not tried to deal with the Cyprus issue an agreement could have been reached sooner or later," he said. "No one has the right to impose sanctions on us."

On Wednesday, Mr Ecevit said the EU had "deceived" Turkey by imposing new conditions on its membership bid. On Thursday, he said plans for a European defence force had trampled on Turkey's rights.

As a Nato member, Turkey is being offered a consultative role in the new defence structure. But Ankara wants a say in decision making and planning.

Turkey has the second-largest army in Nato and has offered nearly 6,000 troops to the new European defence initiative if its demands are met. If not, Ankara has threatened to veto any use of Nato assets.

webTitle: Leader: Paedophilia went too long unconfronted

fields.headline: The penalties of neglect
fields.standfirst:
Paedophilia went too long unconfronted

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The reports by Nick Davies which we carry today make chilling reading. It defies belief that a paedophile ring can flourish for decades, unchecked by any kind of effective police action.
fields.body:
The reports by Nick Davies which we carry today make chilling reading. It defies belief that a paedophile ring can flourish for decades, unchecked by any kind of effective police action, as this one did in Bristol until 1999. John Gay's conviction last month in Swindon crown court brought to an end his twenty year history of abusing boys, which deeply damaged the lives of probably dozens of children. And there were 11 more convictions involving this ring besides his.

Paedophilia is a hugely under-reported crime; victims fear they won't be believed or feel too ashamed. Few police forces have a dedicated proactive unit which is the only way to unravel carefully concealed paedophile rings. Disturbingly, Davies' report reveals the lack of importance attached to policing child abuse from the Home Office right down to the policeman on the street. Child protection is dismissed as "women's work".

That the Bristol-based ring is now behind bars is almost entirely due to the dedication of a small group of police officers and a barrister to buck the institutional bias. Because resources were lacking, they never finished their work. The Avon and Somerset force, like any other in the country, is assessed according to the Home Office's 37 performance indicators ranging from domestic burglary and efficiency savings through to ethnic balance. But not child abuse.

Unless the police demonstrate they can, and do, break paedophile rings, we're left with the mob hysteria of naming and shaming whipped up by tabloid newspapers. That requires a shift of priorities. As Davies points out, Avon and Somerset had a Horsewatch, Caravanwatch, Boatwatch and a Farmwatch scheme before the detective responsible for the successful Bristol convictions set up a comparable proactive scheme to protect children, Child Safe. It is outrageous that our criminal justice system prioritises the protection of private property over the protection of children.

webTitle: Leader: Attacks on Tony Blair signal desperation

fields.headline: Fighting dirty
fields.standfirst:
Attacks on Tony Blair signal desperation

Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText: There was a time when byelections were a potent, even occasionally lethal, political event. Thursday's three byelections seem on the face of it damp affairs. Labour held all four seats: most voters stayed away.
fields.body:
There was a time when byelections were a potent, even occasionally lethal, political event. Ten years ago, the Conservatives, having already lost Mid Staffs to Labour in the shadow of the poll tax, surrendered Eastbourne too, to the Liberal Democrats, fomenting among backbench MPs a desperation to save their own skins which led less than six weeks later to the toppling of Margaret Thatcher. Thursday's three byelections - four when you count the contest to fill Donald Dewar's Holyrood seat as well as his seat at Westminster - seem on the face of it damp affairs. Labour held all four seats: most voters stayed away.

But they may even so have been potent. The story they tell seems to be this. There is no great popular enthusiasm for Tony Blair and his works: see the slashing of Labour's majorities. And yet there is no great lust to turn him out either. Where in the days when the Tories were sinking the Labour and Lib Dem votes were well up on the previous election, here the various challengers failed to drum up the support which might have demonstrated positive faith in them. The mood of the people is so volatile nowadays that predictions are always dangerous, but there is little evidence here to suggest that Labour is on its way out.

That context perhaps explains some of the more lurid excitements elsewhere on the political battlefield now, and especially the vicious exchanges over Europe's new rapid reaction force. To take Britain into this project could never have been simple and uncontroversial. Some of the questions raised are fair and necessary. Are we clear how far the remit would go beyond straightforward peacekeeping? Could this force, while not designed as a basis for a European army, begin to evolve that way? Some old defence hands, not all of them violently anti-Labour, think it may be a mistake. Some former American heavyweights, like Caspar Weinberger, fear for the future of Nato. But others of equal authority, on both sides of the Atlantic, applaud it. Yet that is not the impression the unprepared voter would get from the hysterical behaviour of some of the tabloid papers, which have so far presented the issue as if only those bent on blindly subordinating our national interest to Europe's, or even intent on treason, could possibly have subscribed to this reckless adventure. Whatever the tactical value of Tony Blair's assaults on rabid anti-Europeanism and plain old-fashioned dishonesty, he is clearly right on both counts. And it is heartening to see these events begining to drive the party out of its previous unwillingness to offend and into the sort of clear commitments, on Europe and public spending for instance, for which some of its truest friends have long thirsted, and at times have despaired of seeing.

In this context, some of the charges launched against Mr Blair in the past few days shriek of desperation - of a readiness to play the nationalist card, the patriot card, almost any old card, as a way to shake the electorate out of its present apparent refusal to contemplate the return of the Tories. Mr Blair, the Mail suggests, is the new Harold Wilson. The chief of the defence staff, who dares to defy their advice, is accused of having a schoolboy crush - yes, they truly said this - on the prime minister. The headlines running just now - on Europe, the price of petrol, the state of public transport, the new meat crisis - are not happy reading for any prime minister planning a general election in six months time. But so far, Thursday's results suggest, the voters decline to be panicked. Long may it stay that way.

webTitle: Leader: Britain slows to a crawl

fields.headline: Britain slows to a crawl
fields.standfirst:
Mr Prescott has a fight on his hands

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott spent the past week in the Netherlands, looking out over polders when he was not negotiating at the climate change conference. Trying to secure Kyoto and cut greenhouse emissions is vital work. But in his absence confusion swirls around his department's central but belatedly recognised responsibility - keeping the country moving.
fields.body:
John Prescott spent the past week in the Netherlands, looking out over polders when he was not negotiating at the climate change conference. Trying to secure Kyoto and cut greenhouse emissions is vital work. But in his absence confusion swirls around his department's central but belatedly recognised responsibility - keeping the country moving. The fastest-growing source of those planet-threatening emissions is cars and lorries, yet there is good evidence that, dismayed by increased journey times, people are taking to the roads in their legions. They sit in traffic jams, their exhausts pumping carbon into the atmosphere. When they do move they may hit people. Every day since the Hatfield crash - which killed four - 10 people have died on the roads; since October 17, some 13 children have been been killed by cars.

It is not government's job to educate people in comparing risk. That, in part, belongs to the media, even if they tend to prefer sensation to enlightenment. Rail travel is safe, was safe before Hatfield and would still be safer than road travel (in terms of gross averages) even if Railtrack were not slowing trains around the country, extending journey times and bringing at least some of the train operators close to commercial collapse. Yesterday it was plausibly suggested that rail works may themselves bring danger, leading drivers confusedly to run danger signals, albeit at slower speeds. Here the state does come in. It is the Health and Safety Executive which regulates Railtrack on safety, the Strategic Rail Authority that approves its operations.

What ministers need to do is offer a despairing public the longer and the wider view. We should not have to rely on an executive of Virgin, who necessarily has all sorts of commercial calculations to make, to tell us things will not be back to "normal" for another year. Instead, Mr Prescott - however able Gus Macdonald may be, he is fatally handicapped as a transport minister by being an unelected peer - should speak, not to spin empty reassurance, but to exhibit some plan. Of course there is no quick fix. Safety checks after Hatfield will cause disruption for months to come. Travellers are a patient bunch - they have to be - but what enervates and exasperates is the fear that there is now no fat controller, that the division between Railtrack and its sundry state regulators has itself become part of the problem.

fields.headline: Bloomsbury set
fields.standfirst: Publisher thrives on Atwood's Booker win
fields.trailText: Bloomsbury, the publishing group, yesterday basked in the success of writer Margaret Atwood, whose novel The Blind Assassin won the Booker prize at the start of the month.
fields.body:
Bloomsbury, the publishing group, yesterday basked in the success of writer Margaret Atwood, whose novel The Blind Assassin won the Booker prize at the start of the month.

A trading statement from Bloomsbury said sales of the book had soared since Ms Atwood took the prize at her fourth attempt. Around 120,000 copies of the hardback have been sold.

Nigel Newton, Bloomsbury chief executive said Ms Atwood's novel had been the retailer's choice because her work does not come with an impenetrability health warning.

The Blind Assassin tells the story of an industrial and political dynasty in Canada.

"The Booker prize is a big driver of sales," Mr Newton said. "But it also depends on the general verdict on whether the novel is readable. Winning can certainly lead to a more than doubling of sales."

Ms Atwood's back catalogue was also benefiting with a pick-up in sales. Her previous Booker shortlisted titles are The Handmaid's Tale (1986), Cat's Eye (1989), and Alias Grace (1996).

Shares in Bloomsbury rose 22.5p to 847.5p following the statement which said trading would be "signficantly" ahead of market expectations.

The company is already riding high because of its Harry Potter series of books which have become a worldwide phenomenon. The statement said there were also strong revenues from its US division.

Analysts have increased their full-year profit forecasts from £4.5m to £5.5m.

webTitle: Review:  Irish Classics by Declan Kiberd

fields.headline: Grievance and its cultures
fields.standfirst: Terry Eagleton  considers great Irish writing in Declan Kiberd's  Irish Classics
fields.trailText: Terry Eagleton considers great Irish writing in Declan Kiberd's Irish Classics
fields.body:
Irish Classics

Declan Kiberd

715pp, Granta

£25
Buy it at BOL

The mayhem in Northern Ireland has done wonders for Irish literature. Not that it has stirred whole schools of poets to eloquent lamentations, or inspired a major fiction of pity and terror. On the contrary, most Irish writers have reacted to the Northern Troubles as writers usually react to political events, by reaching defiantly for their artistic integrity. Rather than pen epics of the Bogside or sonnets of the Shankill, Irish authors are more likely to write essays on how the artistic imagination can't be vulgarly enlisted for political ends. And this may be all to the good. Writers are sometimes expected to speak out in a crisis; but since they are often an impractical, narcissistic, rampantly individualist bunch, allergic to analytical thought, it is hard to see quite why. The fantasies that fuel their art are also what unfit them for membership of the sanitation committee.

What the Troubles have done, with grisly irony, is help put Ireland on the international map. There are healthier ways of going global, but the Irish have long been dab hands at the less desirable methods of attracting world attention, such as mass emigration. Hard on the heels of the Troubles prowled the Celtic Tiger, as an economic boom in the south of the island accompanied the steep decline of the north. This, too, bent the world's eye on this inconsiderable "afterthought of Europe", as Joyce called the place. For the first time in centuries, it was cool rather than corny to be Irish. English youth swarm over to Dublin for boozy weekends, while their elders holiday more sedately in the small towns of west Cork. The Irish had long been used to impressing the world more by their cultural products than their balance of trade or military hardware. But now this is happening on the cosmopolitan scale of Riverdance, U2 and Paddywood (the country's thriving film industry), rather than just at international James Joyce symposia.

It is hardly surprising, then, that almost every English publisher now seems to want its Companion to Irish studies or Encyclopaedia of Eire. In the wake of both Troubles and Tiger had poured a torrential flood of Irish anthologies, cultural dictionaries and bluffer's guides. Among the finest of these on the literary front was Declan Kiberd's Inventing Ireland, a blockbuster of a book that he has now followed up with the equally door-stopping Irish Classics. Kiberd is a Dublin academic, but he has the talent for popularising of the public intellectual. Witty, astute, and compulsively readable, he knows how to shape a critical narrative and where to slide in a comic aside.

This extravagantly ambitious book takes us all the way from the decline of the Irish bards in the early 17th century to the Belfast Agreement of 1998, pausing en route to discuss such luminaries as Swift, Sheridan, Burke, Wilde, Shaw, Synge, Flann O'Brien and a good deal besides. The English, by contrast, had to import most of their modernism from Europe and the US, as they import most of their cultural theory today.

Some of his other judgments are less sure-footed: W B Yeats hardly initiated the cult of the Big House, and it's far too simple-minded to see Burke as a stiff-necked English traditionalist with a big-hearted Paddy struggling to get out. Kiberd writes as though Burke was a Tory reactionary, rather than a Whig in an honourable 18th-century liberal tradition. Nor did he denounce the idea of the sublime, as this book oddly seems to think.

At one point, Kiberd takes an English commentator to task for seeing Oliver Goldsmith's charity as displaced vanity. The critic in question actually does no such thing; but the word "English" here carries faint derogatory overtones. This is Kiberd the nationalist speaking, as opposed to Kiberd the pluralist, who is also much in evidence throughout the book. Indeed, the two hats can be switched in the course of a few pages. The narrative culminates in a slightly starry-eyed account of the Belfast Agreement, with its notion of multiple political identities, and the book finds the seeds of this generous pluralism in the literary heritage it explores. Swift, Burke, Sheridan, Maria Edgeworth, Wolfe Tone: all these writers were adrift between cultural identities, but it is hard to see many of them as patrons of Peter Mandelson.

In a venerable Irish tradition, Kiberd runs culture and politics too quickly together. The Irish question is indeed about cultural identities, just as the British question is. But no particular politics follows from this fact. These days, the cannier kind of Ulster Unionist is impressively well-versed in the language of the cultural studies departments. He will jaw on about multi-ethnicity with positively post-modern fervour. It is just that he also sees this as an argument for keeping Northern Ireland British. If there are questions of cultural identity, there are also issues of political democracy; and the two do not translate easily into one another.

This is not a book with intricate theoretical depths, or one greatly sensitive to the subtleties of literacy form. Indeed, it tracks the course of Irish writing with brilliant lucidity and unflagging energy hard to match on the current Irish-studies scene. It is the prose of a brilliant teacher, whose powers to expound, amuse and exhilarate are second to none. One can predict, even so, a few edgy reviews in Dublin, as there were for Inventing Ireland , since nothing embarrasses the self-consciously modernising Irish more than reminders of their opulent cultural heritage. It just doesn't cut any ice in Brussels.
