webTitle: Review: Smoking in Bed: Conversations with Bruce Robinson, ed Alistair Owen

fields.headline: Studio knives and FBI plots
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  touches the hem of Bruce Robinson's coat while Robinson is Smoking In Bed
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard touches the hem of Bruce Robinson's coat while Robinson is Smoking In Bed
fields.body:
Smoking in Bed: Conversations with Bruce Robinson, ed Alistair Owen (Bloomsbury, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

Beyond the fact that it is one of my favourite films and I have seen it about twelve times, Withnail & I does little for me, and I suspected that a book-length series of interviews with its director would do less. An amusing diversion for a rainy day, perhaps, but hardly anything of lasting worth.

Well, it's raining now, and the book is holding up well on its second re-read. Principally, this is down to Robinson's winning garrulity, but it is also a matter of asking the right questions; and very often the right questions involve a serious risk of offending the interviewee's amour propre. Let us look over Robinson's career, leaving aside the early high points of the script for The Killing Fields and Withnail. There is How to Get Ahead in Advertising (clumsy, didactic); Jennifer Eight (seen by few and hacked about by the studio to boot); screenplays for Fat Man and Little Boy (about Oppenheimer and the bomb; hacked about by studio), Return to Paradise (not even Robinson has seen this one) and In Dreams (another disaster).

This is not an impressive roster. And that is part of the point: how Robinson copes with being the creator of one film for which people will be touching the hem of his coat until doomsday, and a few turkeys. Robinson seems to be completely honest with himself about this. And it helps that Owen's questions have been phrased tactfully enough to get answers, but pertinently enough to get significant ones. And there is nothing like a frank admission of failure to get an audience on your side. Robinson on In Dreams: "It was a complete and utter mess from top to bottom. I thought Jennifer Eight was a low point, but Christ almighty, this hit the floor and dug."

This is, some of the time, a How Not to Get Ahead in Hollywood book. But it's more than that: it's alive with Robinson's voice, his turn of phrase, his passionate digressions. It's as if it has sneaked up on literature by not ever considering itself as such; you feel that Robinson's fiction - a couple of novels' worth, one of them being Withnail - would be clunky and mannered in comparison. (I would prefer to be wrong about that.) Talking, he is fully engaged, driven by an endless compulsion to entertain: his conversation is a work of art. And you can see why this might be so, given that so much of the book is about setting the record straight, saying how certain films of his should have been before the studios got their knives out.

Robinson also researches his subjects properly - so, for example, the chapter on the making of Fat Man and Little Boy contains information about the Manhattan Project that was new to me: it would appear that he uncovered an FBI plot to murder Oppenheimer's lover. Which you wouldn't know unless you'd seen the film - and you haven't seen the film, have you?

webTitle: Review:  The Creation Records Story by David Cavanagh

fields.headline: Reading the label
fields.standfirst: Keith Cameron  on David Cavanagh's Creation Records Story: My Magpie Eyes Are Hungry for the Prize
fields.trailText: Keith Cameron on David Cavanagh's Creation Records Story: My Magpie Eyes Are Hungry for the Prize
fields.body:
My Magpie Eyes Are Hungry for the Prize: The Creation Records Story
David Cavanagh
584pp, Virgin
£20
Buy it at BOL

When news of the closure of Creation Records broke on November 26 1999, one person at least must have been grateful. David Cavanagh now had an ending for his book. Doubtless conceived as an orthodox rags-to-riches account of how Alan McGee's stewardship of the most celebrated independent record label in the world took him from a Glasgow housing scheme to 10 Downing Street, accruing vast wealth and narcotic-fuelled notoriety along the way, Cavanagh's project got overtaken by events.

Most obvious of these was the souring of Creation's always problematic relationship with its prized asset Oasis, but the book's gestation also coincided with the British music industry's slide into recession and McGee's disillusionment with what his company - and by definition he himself - had become.

Moreover, in the course of three years of research, the author glimpsed a bigger picture: that Creation's rise and fall was a metaphor, not just for the unfeasibility of true independence in a corporate era, but for social and cultural changes in Britain over the last 25 years, in which the adversarial post-war certainties of "them and us" were replaced by an uneasy new consensus based on unfettered materialism and the co-option of art by commerce. For all New Labour's self-serving attempts to claim him, Cavanagh suggests that the intuitively left-wing McGee is really a vindication of the Thatcherite era, and consequently riven with confused impulses.

My Magpie Eyes Are Hungry for the Prize transcends the parochial concerns of most rock biographies, although it comes steeped in them too. Indeed, the strength of this well-written book is in the details. The tale begins with a richly evocative depiction of mid-1970s Glasgow, a wasteland in many aspects but especially for disgruntled punk zealots like the young Alan McGee, who unsuccessfully auditioned for a formative version of Simple Minds before taking a mundane job as a British Rail stores clerk.

Where less assiduous biographers might have jumped straight for the hedonistic jugular, Cavanagh dwells on these bleak times, following McGee down to London and charting his fervent efforts to stir life into the capital's moribund music scene. "The key to understanding Alan McGee is not the years when he roared with vindication," he explains. "It is the decades of disappointment and frustration that went before."

Throughout, Cavanagh's wry, unsensational tone imposes much-needed perspective upon the mania that informed Creation's mission to wreak pop-art havoc upon the music establishment. Gorging on the book's anecdotal feast, one struggles to comprehend not only how Creation survived its hand-to-mouth existence long enough to become a potent force, but just how its cast of eccentrics, egotists and sociopaths eventually triumphed in such a brutal environment without one of them dying.

Not that they didn't come close. The House of Love's swift disintegration from potential superstars into basket cases who spent £10,000 in a year on taxi fares is played out with excruciating fastidiousness, while McGee's own drugged-up arrogance would be funny were it not for the dreadful personal price it eventually exacted. "McGee took so much cocaine that his behaviour became Napoleonic," writes Cavanagh of a visit to New York in 1993. "He threatened to beat up the concierge in his hotel when the plastic door-key to his room didn't work (until he realised he was on the wrong floor)."

Coupled with the phenomenal success of Oasis, McGee's 1994 nervous breakdown is presented as the catalyst for Creation adopting more conventional business practices, thereby losing the anarchic energy on which its aesthetic had thrived, and setting in motion a series of events that resulted in its eventual demise. Cavanagh reveals internal politicking worthy of Millbank, painting the sober McGee as gentler but no less paranoid, an increasingly distant figure, ill-at-ease with the market-led impulses of the new quasi-corporate company, although perfectly happy to accept the accompanying financial benefits.

Ever prone to short-sighted outbursts of hubris, McGee has already denounced My Magpie Eyes Are Hungry for the Prize as "the accountant's tale", presumably because it represents him in an inconveniently candid light. And possibly also because Cavanagh has chosen to put Creation into its proper context, as merely the latest in a series of maverick attempts to take on the corporate music business, which happened to succeed (for a while) thanks to a combination of luck, Oasis and the sheer bloody-minded determination of its founder to persevere where others had given up. Creation was a definitive rock'n'roll fable, a story of high art and low cunning. Thanks to David Cavanagh, it now enjoys a worthy epitaph.

webTitle: Let Derry rot, FO man advised

fields.headline: Let Derry rot, FO man advised
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: A senior British diplomat has expressed regret for an embarrassing secret memo written shortly after Bloody Sunday, in which he suggested that the no-go areas of Londonderry should be "encouraged" to rot from within by the spread of disease.
fields.body:
A senior British diplomat has expressed regret for an embarrassing secret memo written shortly after Bloody Sunday, in which he suggested that the no-go areas of Londonderry should be "encouraged" to rot from within by the spread of disease.

The memo, released by the Foreign Office to the Saville inquiry into the Bloody Sunday killings, was handwritten by the then 29-year-old Adrian Thorpe, now the British ambassador to Mexico.

In 1972, when the Paratroop Regiment shot 13 unarmed civilians dead in Londonderry, he was a desk officer in the FO department dealing with the Irish Republic.

At the end of a two-page note about the British government's options, he wrote: "As you know, I have always been in favour of encouraging the no-go areas to rot from within. There is no reason why we should not encourage the breakdown of essential services and the spread of disease etc."

The note was briefly referred to at the inquiry last week by Arthur Harvey QC, representing the families of three of the victims, but was not publicised nationally.

Mr Harvey merely said it was from a "policy body dealing with Derry". He commented: "It shows contempt for human beings at a level which it is difficult to imagine, in particular a contempt for the people of Derry which it is difficult to imagine: that really they should be left to rot by the spread of disease.

"It is an affront to the conscience of any rational human being, but it appears that certainly, whatever the background at that time, it is an indication of the mentality of those persons and their attitudes to Derry."

A senior FO official said Mr Thorpe had not been formally asked for an explanation, but had indicated his "regret" to his own officials. He will remain in his post, but that will be reviewed if Lord Saville singles him out for criticism.

In an attempt to place the remarks as a historical indiscretion and an irrelevance, the FO pointed that out his superior had written on the top: "This is now comatose, if not dead."

However, that appears to refer to the main body of the memo, which discusses six options, the preferred one being "forcible occupation".

Events in the province had moved on by then. The day before Mr Thorpe wrote the memo the Provisional IRA called a ceasefire in anticipation of the secret talks in London the following month between its leaders, including Gerry Adams, and William Whitelaw, the Northern Ireland secretary.

Mr Thorpe's superior added that military moves against Londonderry were inevitable if the ceasefire did not hold.

Cambridge educated, Mr Thorpe joined the diplomatic service in 1965 and became a Japanese expert.

He has had a number of sensitive postings, including Beirut just before the outbreak of the civil war in 1975, Bonn, and Kuala Lumpur. For three years in the early 1980s he headed the FO information department. His first ambassadorial post was the Philippines in 1995. He was appointed CMG (Commander of St Michael and St George) in 1994.

In Who's Who he lists his recreations as "opera, travel, bookshops and comfort".

A spokeswoman at the British embassy in Mexico City said last night that the ambassador was not available for comment.

He was appointed CMG (Commander of St Michael and St George) in 1994. In Who's Who he lists his recreations as "opera, travel, bookshops and comfort". A spokeswoman at the British embassy in Mexico City said last night that the ambassador was not available for comment.

webTitle: Straw driver will not face speed charges

fields.headline: Straw driver will not face speed charges
fields.trailText: An armed police driver stopped for speeding on the M5 in a car carrying home secretary Jack Straw will not face prosecution, Avon and Somerset police said last night.
fields.body:
An armed police driver stopped for speeding on the M5 in a car carrying home secretary Jack Straw will not face prosecution, Avon and Somerset police said last night.

The Vauxhall Omega was stopped on the southbound carriageway of the M5 near Taunton in July, travelling at well over 70mph.

In a statement, police said the driver had "believed that there was a potential risk to the home secretary's security, and decided to use speed to create distance between the risk and the home secretary, in line with his training".

Police said the chief crown prosecutor for Avon and Somerset had reviewed all the evidence and advised there was "insufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction against the Metropolitan police service driver". The statement said: "The home secretary is among a very small number of people known to be at significant risk of lethal attack who receive round-the-clock armed police protection."

According to the statement the car contained Mr Straw, his armed driver and an armed protection officer.

Glen Smyth, chairman of the Metropolitan branch of the Police Federation, said: "We are pleased that the CPS has come to the right decision under all the circumstances."

webTitle: Easy riding, as long as you've booked your ticket in advance

fields.headline: Easy riding, as long as you've booked your ticket in advance
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: If Gerald Corbett had boarded the 7.15am Taj Express to Agra yesterday, he might have been pleasantly surprised by the journey. The train was clean and left just three minutes late. Only a few people had to stand in the corridor.
fields.body:
If Gerald Corbett had boarded the 7.15am Taj Express to Agra yesterday, he might have been pleasantly surprised by the journey. The train was clean and left just three minutes late. Only a few people had to stand in the corridor.

As the Indian countryside whizzed by, and the coffee wallah came round offering another cup of sweet Indian coffee for the paltry sum of five rupees, the former Railtrack chief executive might have usefully pondered what he did wrong.

Unlike Britain's train system, India's still works. It was, of course, the British who built India's railways 150 years ago, in an epic feat of engineering which would connect the beaches of south India with the Khyber Pass. In total, the British laid 23,000 miles of track, in what turned out to be the biggest construction project ever carried out by a colonial power. But since then Britain seems to have lost the knack of managing railways. In India the trains continue to run with reasonable efficiency, despite the vast distances.

Arriving at Nizamuddin station in New Delhi in the early morning gloom, I was reassured to see my name on a list of passengers with seats to travel. The platform was crowded. Some of the people on it were going on a journey; the rest live permanently in the station.

There were plenty of diversions - tea stalls, phone booths, newspaper sellers, and a man frying pakoras in a giant pan of oil.

The trick with Indian trains is to make a reservation first. With a population of 1bn, there is no point in turning up in the hope you will get a seat. With this in mind, I dropped into my local station two days beforehand. The queues are long, there is a tea break at 11.30am, but eventually you get there.

My ticket to Agra from Delhi cost a mere 156 rupees (£2.40), not bad for a round trip of about 300 miles. The train rolled in on time. I found my seat, S2 71. Amazingly, there was no one in it. Soon, though, a row erupted next to me. A young man was refusing to give up his seat to the old man who had actually reserved it. As the train clattered through Delhi's unlovely industrial southern suburbs, Vijay Menon, on his way to see his family in Agra, told of his brother, who was once stuck on a train to Bangalore for three days. "He went to sleep and woke up to find he was still at the same station. There had been an oil spill."

Most passengers with experience of British trains, however, agreed that the ones in India were more reliable.

"The Central Line is horrible. I do a lot of commuting by tube and they are always breaking down," said Veena Chauhan, a civil servant from Ealing, west London, visiting relatives in India. "Indian railways are very good considering how vast the country is."

Gradually, the suburbs gave way to countryside, a flat expanse of scrub, thatched farm buildings and cattle egrets.

Inside the carriage a sock-wallah was trying to sell nylon socks at 10 rupees (13p) a pair. She was followed by the crisp-wallah, the newspaper-wallah, the ticket inspector, a blind singing beggar, and the peanut man. Finally the breakfast wallah came round. I bought two veg cutlets and a slice of bread for 15 rupees.

Travelling by train in India is still a genuinely demotic experience. You might sit next to a cabinet minister or an illiterate cowherd.

The Indian railway is also the world's largest employer, with 1.6m staff and 11m passengers a day. That the system works at all is miraculous. The fact that we arrived in Agra 15 minutes late was forgivable.

"In India we are not so worried about time. In the western world everyone is running around all the time. We just want to enjoy ourselves, go out for dinner, that kind of thing," said one of the passengers, Squadron Leader Ashok.

Gerald Corbett, as he disappears from the fray into India for a month, might just agree.

webTitle: Firms in north lose as delays drag on

fields.headline: Firms in north lose as delays drag on
fields.standfirst:
Businesses say growing problem pushing some to breaking point

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Development agencies in the north have warned ministers that businesses face mounting losses as a result of Railtrack's failure to restore full services on the busy east and west coast main lines.
fields.body:
Development agencies in the north have warned ministers that businesses face mounting losses as a result of Railtrack's failure to restore full services on the busy east and west coast main lines.

Operators are unlikely to resume normal operations until later in January, although the managing director of Virgin Trains said it could be well into next year before the chaos caused by track repairs and flooding finally eases.

The patience of business people snapped with the chairman of the government-funded Yorkshire and Humberside development agency, known as Yorkshire Forward, firing off a letter to Railtrack's new chief executive warning that some companies are at breaking point.

Graham Hall, who is also head of Yorkshire Electricity, told the beleaguered track and signalling company: "Business people in Yorkshire and the Humber are being directly affected by the state of the network, particularly travelling to and from London. The efficiency of individual businesses and perceptions of the region are being damaged."

Reciting a common complaint of northern businesses, Mr Hall said that while disruption across his region showed little sign of abating, "other parts of the network, notably London and the south-east, are returning to normal ... has there been a dif ferent urgency and priority attached to other regions?"

A survey by the Institute of Directors has found that 37% of respondents in Yorkshire alone said their business was being hit by chaos on the rail network.

This is largely because the east coast line, supposedly the most modern in the country, has at least 100 speed restrictions - a fifth of the total in Britain - with 125mph trains frequently reduced to 20mph. As a result, businessmen and women are either turning to air travel or cancelling meetings.

Although some services resumed on the east coast this week after the fatal crash at Hatfield four weeks ago and a lengthy blockage caused by flooding near Doncaster, the train operator GNER placed advertisements in local papers saying it hoped to resume normal services by mid-January.

On the west coast line, however, the picture was bleaker. Chris Green, managing director of Virgin Trains and a former head of British Rail's InterCity subsidiary, said it could be a year before services returned to normal.

Business people have warned ministers that they must exert pressure on Railtrack to rescue the network. While only 7% of freight goes by rail - ministers had hoped to increase this to 10% - heavy industry uses the network to transport many products.

With businesses deserting rail now that journey times are doubling, airlines are putting on extra flights and larger planes to cope with demand.

Newcastle airport has seen ticket sales for flights to London increase by almost 50% in the first two weeks of November. A local operator, Gill Airways, which has added an extra flight to its Stansted service, says ticket sales have increased by 150% in the last month. British Airways, with 13 services daily from Newcastle to Heathrow and Gatwick, says it has introduced larger aircraft.

With journey times back to the Victorian era - well over seven hours from Edinburgh to London, for example - business leaders fear that disruption will have a growing impact on new investment in outlying regions.

Hugh Morgan-Williams, chairman of a north east electronics company, and a member of the government's regional development agency, said: "The most serious impact is that it exposes the isolation of regions like this, which poses problems for overseas investment ... but it also raises questions about the expansion plans of British businesses in the north."

He fears the disruption could force more companies to locate in the south, nearer their markets - further deepening the north-south divide. Only last week the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, warned that extra measures were needed to bolster the economies of less favoured regions. On a recent visit to the north-east, the prime minister came close to acknowledging that further measures were needed. He was presented with a report from civil servants showing that GDP per head in the north-east was 21% below the UK average, "the lowest in England".

Derek Foster, MP for Bishop Auckland and Labour's former chief whip, who chairs the Commons employment committee, warned yesterday that the current chaos could have electoral implications.

He had given up travelling by train after using the east coast mainline for 21 years. "I have always resisted flying, but now I have no alternative and that goes for a lot of people."

webTitle: Nick Davies looks at the evils of paedophilia

fields.headline: A terraced street in suburbia that shrouded a guilty secret
fields.standfirst:
Award-winning journalist Nick Davies begins a series looking at the evils of paedophilia and asks whether a more proactive approach should be used to stop its spread. Today: The West Country Web

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: A little way south of the centre of Bristol, there is a neat and peaceful patch of suburbia called Brislington. In among its redbrick rows of Victorian terraced homes, there is Churchill Road - an ordinary collection of two-storey houses with patches of grass out back and a couple of For Sale signs in the front. The door to number 49 is painted cream.
fields.body:
A little way south of the centre of Bristol, there is a neat and peaceful patch of suburbia called Brislington. In among its redbrick rows of Victorian terraced homes, there is Churchill Road - an ordinary collection of two-storey houses with patches of grass out back and a couple of For Sale signs in the front. The door to number 49 is painted cream.

In October 1997, a woman telephoned the police in Bristol to say that she was worried about her nephew, Ricky. He was 15, he had had some trouble in his family, and he kept going off for a day or two at a time. When he came back, he had new clothes or little gifts and he wouldn't say how he had got them. Was he stealing, was he mixed up in drugs? It worried her, and all she knew was that Ricky was going to a house at 49 Churchill Road.

As a result of that call, the police opened the cream-coloured door and uncovered a rats' nest of child abuse - a full-blown paedophile ring. The house was a honey trap, fitted out with a gaming machine, a sauna, plenty of videos and drink and drugs and anything else that might persuade a wandering boy to come in off the streets. Inside the house, some of the boys had been slowly groomed for the sexual pleasure of men who lived there. Others had been simply raped. Some had been given heroin to keep them compliant. Several had been forced into prostitution. Some of the abusers had been busy for 20 years in one location or another.

Three years on, the officers of Avon and Somerset's Child Protection Team have identified 89 boy victims, aged between six and 16. They have run four major trials at which victims have told stories of unmitigated pain and exploitation. Twelve men have been convicted of rape, forced buggery, indecent assault, supplying heroin and living off prostitution. Many of the men admitted their guilt and they have been jailed for a total of 66 years. The police found links between the house in Bristol and addresses in south Wales as well as Holland and France. All this conceals a deeper story.

This other story begins four years before that phone call - with other phone calls, other alarm bells ringing. By October 1994, social services and police in Bristol had been warned repeatedly that vulnerable boys were being sexually abused at 49 Churchill Road.

The loudest warning had come from a gay social worker, whose boyfriend was living in the house. Neither the social worker nor the boyfriend had any interest in child abuse. The social worker was worried about a 14-year-old boy who had run away from a children's home and returned in an agitated state.

Through the boyfriend, he discovered that the runaway had been staying at 49 Churchill Road and that there were clear signs of paedophile activity there. The social worker went to the social services department. The police interviewed his boyfriend, who told them all he knew about the honey trap and the boys and the drugs and the sexual abuse. Other social workers had reported separately that a 13-year-old boy, who was on their register of children at risk, was believed to have become embroiled in Bristol's rent boy scene: he was disappearing for days at a time, he was believed to be using strong drugs and he was found to be carrying a piece of paper with a phone number - traced to 49 Churchill Road.

Two other boys who had been living in a children's home had been reported to be visiting the house; one had been caught up in an earlier inquiry into child pornography. Worse still, a social worker who was based at the children's home was said to have introduced a vulnerable boy to the men in the house.

On October 7, 1994, Avon's Child Protection Committee held a special meeting to discuss what they described as "a potential paedophile ring" at 49 Churchill Road. Three social workers and a police inspector reviewed all the clues and agreed to check all their records and to interview the children they believed to be involved; the social workers sent a minute of the meeting to their area manager; the police inspector said he would talk to his superintendent and to the Crown Prosecution Service ... and essentially nothing happened. Two years later, two more boys made allegations about the house. The rape and seduction and all the rest of it continued unabated.

There is nothing unusual in that kind of failure to uncover and prosecute child abuse. Paedophilia is the least effectively policed crime in Britain. It is grossly under-reported by its victims: like the adult victims of sex abuse, they suffer from shame and the anticipation of disbelief in court; in addition, they are far more easily confused and intimidated by their abusers. Police generally make almost no attempt to go out and uncover unreported abuse: while every police force in the country pours resources into fighting drugs and robbery and burglary, only a handful of the 32 forces have proactive paedophile units.

The operation which finally destroyed the Bristol ring broke through this wall of inaction, not because anyone in the Home Office or the Association of Chief Police Officers finally had the courage to address the scandal, but because of the chance involvement of several unusual individuals.

In the autumn of 1996, a young detective sergeant named Rob Jones had moved to Avon and Somerset's Child Protection Team. The unit did not investigate cases at all. They just supplied back-up for social workers and advice for families and children who found themselves in police hands. It was no place for a real detective. But Rob Jones is one of nature's outsiders, a black belt in karate, a discipline which has given him unusual strength of will.

He was joined by two experienced detective constables, Pete Mainstone and Phil Brown, and together they determined to go out and actively look for abused children. It was Pete Mainstone who took the call from Ricky's worried aunt in October 1997. And instead of merely processing it, he pushed to find out more. He arranged to meet Ricky with his aunt and he checked intelligence records and found that the house in Churchill Road was already suspect. Jones prepared for the possibility of a full-scale inquiry.

Almost every step was a struggle against inertia. Ricky was reluctant to talk, but slowly he agreed to tell what he knew. He spoke of rent boys coming to the house; there was a suggestion that pornographic films were being made; he spoke of a stream of men who visited; he broke down and described eventually how he had been buggered relentlessly by two men; and he named them. One was Christopher Leek, now 44, a costume dresser who had worked on The Bill and who owned the house. He had been using it as a honey trap for years, but Avon and Somerset police had no intelligence on him. The other man, however, was notorious: Tony Stevens, now 45, had a long history of abusing boys. He had previously called himself Mark Underhill, but he was better known to under-aged rent boys in Bristol and south Wales as Fat Tony, and, although he had never been convicted in Britain, he had been arrested and jailed in Portugal in 1993 with two other British men after being caught paying local children to make pornographic videos.

Rob Jones knew he was on to something important, but he and the two DCs could work on the case only part time, while they continued with conventional child protection work. They needed extra resources: surveillance officers to watch the house in Churchill Road; technical support so they could video those coming and going; more officers to follow up on the leads which Ricky had given them. Jones managed to borrow three officers from other units, but that was all.

After months of part-time frustration, Jones decided to take a chance: he got a warrant to search the house and persuaded his bosses to give him proper back-up for just one night. He was taking a risk: Ricky had now disappeared without signing his statements, and if they found nothing in the house, the officers would have no evidence with which to charge the paedophiles and they would have squandered the tiny credibility they enjoyed with their bosses. On the night of February 3 1998, Avon and Somerset police finally opened the door at 49 Churchill Road.

They found the whole place had been sanitised: no boys; no drugs; a computer hard disk that had been professionally wiped; photographic equipment stowed away. It turned out that during the months of delay, Ricky had told the men in the house that he had been talking to the police, and they had covered their tracks.

There was no evidence there to justify a charge. But, by sheer persistence, the detectives had managed to track down Ricky only hours before the raid, and he had signed his statements. On that basis, they now arrested Christopher Leek and Fat Tony Stevens. As they searched the house, a boy named Andrew arrived. He started to talk, painting the same picture as Ricky, describing indecent assaults which he had suffered, and crucially he added the names of other boy victims and other men.

Now, Rob Jones had a full-blooded investigation. But he was running it out of a shoebox. He needed more detectives to carry out interviews; he needed an incident room and he needed administrative officers to run it. But all he was given a single terminal and a part-time data inputter. At least one senior officer was actively arguing for the whole inquiry to be stopped immediately. And Jones had a more immediate worry: if Leek and Stevens got bail, he would have no chance of getting their victims to talk. Ricky had told them that the two men had taken him to a solicitor to file a complaint that the police were harrassing him.

At this moment, another unusual individual joined the inquiry. Brendan Moorhouse is a barrister, working for the Crown Prosecution Service in their New Bridewell office in Bristol. He had grown up in apartheid South Africa with a real drive for justice and, when Rob Jones asked for his help, he made it his business not simply to act as a CPS case worker but to guide the police inquiry.

From the first day, he organised a special strategy. They would build a big picture for the jury, aiming where possible to keep different offenders together in the same dock with a collection of their victims as witnesses. Wayne described how Williams asked him to stay behind after stamp club and introduced him to an old man, who smelled bad. They took it in turns to bugger him. Then they threw him out, and Wayne recalled how he wandered off in panic. Wayne never even tried to tell what had happened. He knew no one would believe him if he did.

From that day, Wayne became a plaything for Alan Williams and his adult friends. They told him, if he ever betrayed them, they would kill his dog and hurt his sister and tell his family he was queer. Sometimes, they gave him cannabis and LSD. If they wanted him during the day, they would send the school forged letters from his parents to justify his absence. This had been going on intermittently for four or five years, when Alan Williams first introduced him to Fat Tony. Wayne said he was coming out of school when Williams came up beside him in a car with a man. They gave him some dope to smoke and some Pernod and drove him to a house in Roath on the edge of Cardiff. They took him to other paedophiles and swapped him for their boys for the night.

It was clear that not all the men who lived at 49 Churchill Road were involved or even aware of the child abuse there. The house became a magnet for Fat Tony and his friends - Army John, Rob the Van Man, Kevin the Gerbil, Gerry the Dog, Peter the ice-cream man, who was too obese to act out most of his fantasies, a 61-year-old dope dealer called Alan Tanner, and Alan Williams.

For senior officers at Avon and Somerset police, the big problem was the Home Office, which now steers police activity with a list of "best value performance indicators", on which each force is judged. There are 37 of them. But there is nothing anywhere in any of them about child abuse. By diverting resources into Operation Panorama, Avon and Somerset was risking its corporate neck.

By December, without a single word of national publicity, all 10 defendants had pleaded guilty or had been convicted by a jury. He was 15, he had had some trouble in his family, and he kept going off for a day or two at a time. When he came back, he had new clothes or little gifts and he wouldn't say how he had got them. Several had been forced into prostitution. Some of the abusers had been busy for 20 years in one location or another. Three years on, the officers of Avon and Somerset's Child Protection Team have identified 89 boy victims, aged between six and 16. They have run four major trials at which victims have told stories of unmitigated pain and exploitation. Twelve men have been convicted of rape, forced buggery, indecent assault, supplying heroin and living off prostitution. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Prostate fear for Mandela
fields.body:
Prostate fear for Mandela

Nelson Mandela's doctors say they have detected an abnormality in his blood but that it is not life threatening.

"We have found a rare protein that indicates some form of problem," said Dr Michael Plit. "It does suggest that there is something going on in the prostate."

Mr Mandela, 82, who had a prostate cancer scare in 1990, will undergo tests in the next week.
Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

Protests halt Zimbabwe court

Proceedings at Zimbabwe's supreme court were halted yesterday when more than 100 war veterans flooded the courtroom, shouting that the judges had no right to rule on Robert Mugabe's land seizures.

They were demonstrating against a recent ruling that the confiscation of around 2,000 mainly white-owned farms was illegal.
Andrew Meldrum, Harare

Gang shootout in Cambodia

Cambodian police shot dead eight men and arrested more than 50 after a gang went on the rampage in Phnom Penh yesterday in what one official said was an attempt by an anti-government group to take over the capital.

One civilian was killed during an hour-long shootout at a police station.
Reuters, Phnom Penh

Finn's £50,000 speeding ticket

The Finnish internet millionaire Jaakko Rytsola admitted yesterday he had been fined 500,000 markka (£50,440) for driving at 70mph in a 40mph zone, the country's largest ever traffic ticket. Finns caught driving too fast are fined according to income and speed.
Reuters, Helsinki

fields.headline:
French right 
bids for unity
fields.trailText: Four-fifths of France's opposition MPs published a petition yesterday calling on the fractured and squabbling right to set aside its destructive divisions and unite to win a rash of forthcoming elections.
fields.body:
Four-fifths of France's opposition MPs published a petition yesterday calling on the fractured and squabbling right to set aside its destructive divisions and unite to win a rash of forthcoming elections.

More than 360 parliamentarians, from the Gaullist RPR party, pro-European UDF and free-market Liberal Democrats, declared in the conservative daily Le Figaro that "the secret of union exists. We do not have to go far to find it. It is there, right under our noses, but we don't see it - or rather, we refuse to see it".

Dubbed by some of its own supporters as "the stupidest right in the world", the French right has been racked by infighting ever since its catastrophic defeat in the 1997 general election, and is now made up of a clutch of mini-parties headed by rival political egos.

But with local, parliamentary and presidential elections looming over the next 18 months, pragmatists are convinced that unless it fights under a single banner, the right is again set for defeat.

The signatories, who included the leaders of all three main opposition parties, made much of the success of Jose Maria Aznar's Partido Popular in Spain and Helmut Kohl's combined CDU and CSU.

But they will probably have been more inspired by France's unified Socialist party, forged by François Mitterrand two decades ago and now able to co-opt both the Greens and the Communists into government on its own terms.

While the conservative president, Jacques Chirac, retains a high individual approval rating, his RPR party as well as the UDF and the Liberal Democrats, have not made any inroads into the lead held in opinion polls by the Socialist-led coalition government of prime minister Lionel Jospin.

webTitle: From hero to zero in a mere nine months

fields.headline: From hero to zero in a mere nine months
fields.standfirst:
New economy golden boy treated like a villain

Net news
fields.trailText: It is turning out to be another terrible week for Yasumitsu Shigeta in what has already been a spectacularly bad year for the former golden boy of Japan's new economy.
fields.body:
It is turning out to be another terrible week for Yasumitsu Shigeta in what has already been a spectacularly bad year for the former golden boy of Japan's new economy.

On the Tokyo stock exchange, his company, Hikari Tsushin, fell to less than 1% of its peak value nine months ago - a slide from being one of the country's ten most valuable corporations to a basket case that investors cannot sell quickly enough.

In the US, former business partners pressed on with a lawsuit claiming that they were deceived about the firm's financial health and prospects.

And, at an annual shareholders' meeting on Wednesday, the 36-year-old president was harangued by angry investors who accused him of everything from deception and incompetence to rudeness and inexperience.

Shigeta's fall from grace is far from unique in Japan, where the dot.com rollercoaster has hit higher peaks and lower troughs than in the US or Europe.

The often reckless entrepreneurial spirit of the global new economy has mixed dangerously with some of the worst aspects of Japan's old economy, such as a lack of transparency, a tendency to put expansion before profits and persistent rumours about ties with the criminal underworld.

A year ago, Shigeta could do no wrong. Hikari Tsushin, meaning "brilliant communication" was the shining light of Japan's new economy.

The cash registers were ringing non-stop at the company's chain of 2,000 mobile phone retail franchises and the dynamic young businessman was investing heavily in the internet start-ups that were expected to create a new generation of millionaires. Shigeta was the cover boy for business magazines; he was listed by Forbes as one of the 200 richest men in the world; his comments on the internet were treated with respect.

After Hikari Tsushin shares were listed in September 1999, their price quadrupled within months. By February, a single share was worth ¥241,000 (£1,500), putting the company into the same league as Toyota, Sony, Honda and NTT in terms of value.

On Wednesday, the share price fell to a dismal ¥2,370 and Hikari Tsushin's investors were treating their former hero like a villain. "We feel cheated," said a shareholder who gave his name as Mr Yano. "Last year, you seemed a wonderful manager, full of confidence. I bought more shares and advised my friends to do the same. Today, you look worn out and miserable and my shares have lost 99% of their value. This is an outrage."

"You have fallen from heaven to hell in just half a year," complained a Mr Kobori. "What happened?"

Shigeta blamed the state of his company on a weak economy and a global loss of confidence in dot.com investments.

But several "old economy" factors have also played a role in the company's decline.

Hikari Tsushin's obscure accounting practices have turned investors away in droves. In March, the company said it was on course to meet a half-year earnings forecast of a ¥6bn profit. A fortnight later, the company admitted it was actually on course to lose ¥13bn. Now, whenever Shigeta promises that Hikari is about to turn the corner, the markets refuse to believe him.

In the US, Hikari Tsushin faces a class-action suit by shareholders of its partner and email service provider, Crayfish. The plaintiffs are seeking more than ¥5bn for Hikari Tsushin's failure to reveal the deterioration in its finances.

Shigeta's web of investments have also linked him - albeit unknowingly - to organised crime. Hikari Tsushin was a leading investor in Liquid Audio, whose president - a former associate of the Yamaguchi gumi crime syndicate - was arrested last month on charges of kidnapping a business rival.

Numerous other start-ups are rumoured to have fallen prey to yakuza mobsters, who have long played a parasitic role in Japanese firms. In response of such fears, new bourses, such as Nasdaq Japan and the Tokyo Stock Exchange's Mothers market, have tightened their listing requirements for new economy start-ups.

In September, Tokyo was awash with speculation that Shigeta's company was on the brink of bankruptcy. Since then, the company has staved off creditors by cutting more than 60% of its 1,400 headquarters staff.

At the shareholders meeting this week, Shigeta looked drained. His platitudes sounded like the words of an old economy salary man.

"We promise to do our best next year," he said in a reply to one of his many critics. It may sound less than convincing, but a year ago it would probably have been hailed as a sure sign of the new economy's bright new future.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Cases of email privacy violations

fields.headline: When a cheap shot can cost you dear
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: There are plenty of email disputes that end in staff being "flamed" by their employer:
fields.body:
There are plenty of email disputes that end in staff being "flamed" by their employer:

In one case, related by a lawyer, a female employee accessed a male colleague's PC to answer emails while he was on holiday. She did it to make sure they were all up to date and replies had gone out. But she came across one that was unflattering about her and complained. In response, the company sacked her for unauthorised access to an employee's emails.

Policeman Dave Eggleton was also on the wrong end of a defamatory email, but with a different end result. He discovered meat bought from Asda was rotten after he started cooking a Sunday dinner for his family. He bought a Chinese takeaway instead.

The following day he took the joint back and demanded a refund plus the £18 cost of the takeaway. Staff at the store in Derbyshire paid up after he threatened to show the meat to environmental health officers.

Later, however, other Asda stores were emailed details of his complaint, a personal description and his car registration under the heading: 'Refund fraud - urgent, urgent, urgent'. PC Eggleton found out about the message through a contact and issued a writ for libel in the High Court. He reached an out-of-court settlement, believed to be more than £10,000.

In the US, oil giant Chevron was successfully sued for $2.2m when lawyers hunting for evidence in a sexual harassment case found an email containing a joke about a beer being better than a woman. It revealed a laddish culture that supported the harassment case.

In the summer, 15 traders and staff at the City bank Merrill Lynch were asked to leave within hours after they were allegedly caught circulating offensive and racist material on the internal e-mail system.

The eight men and seven women were ordered by the management to leave the premises after a routine screening of emails, many of them transferred between two of the bank's offices.

The bank, which had dealt with similar incidents before, said in a statement: "As per Merrill Lynch policy, the firm will not tolerate any abuse of its business email system, particularly when extremely offensive material is involved. When the abuse was discovered, after proper investigations had taken place, the individuals concerned were dismissed."

A few weeks later mobile phone company Orange sacked 30 staff it accused of downloading and circulating pornographic material.

Michael Simmonds, the Tory party's head of marketing and membership, leaked a speech by William Hague's deputy leader via email to journalists. The move wasn't appreciated by the top brass when the email was found in his 'out' box and he was asked to leave Conservative central office.

An employee at the TV production company Planet 24 was dismissed after a memo about Big Breakfast presenter Kelly Brook's alleged difficulty with long words appeared on a celebrity gossip website. In this case, there was no proof of an email containing the memo. After a trawl through all their employees' old emails, the employer found one member of staff had been in regular electronic contact with the owner of the website.

webTitle: Saharan leader tries to recruit EU to freedom cause

fields.headline: Saharan leader tries to recruit EU to freedom cause
fields.standfirst: Its allies dwindling, his movement wants Brussels to lean on Moroccan occupiers
fields.trailText: It has been a long march for Mohammed Abdel-Aziz, president of the Saharan Arab Democratic Republic. But he still believes - in the face of repeated reverses - that his people will win independence.
fields.body:
It has been a long march for Mohammed Abdel-Aziz, president of the Saharan Arab Democratic Republic. But he still believes - in the face of repeated reverses - that his people will win independence.

Marking the 25th anniversary of the occupation of his desert homeland by Morocco, the leader of this phantom state refuses to acknowledge that the years of struggle have been in vain even as world support slips away and the status quo solidifies.

Mr Abdel-Aziz, now 51, was a founder of the Polisario Front, formed in 1973 to oppose the claim of King Hassan of Morocco to the then Spanish colony. Two years later, General Franco pulled out, the king got his chance, and instead of independence, the Sahrawis got Moroccan occupation.

He has been president of the notional Saharan republic since 1982, but still has to live in exile in neighbouring Algeria, long at odds with Morocco and thus Mr Abdel-Aziz's staunchest backer.

Now seeking to regain lost ground after what really does seem to be the final collapse of a UN plan for a referendum on the future status of the disputed Saharan region, Mr Abdel-Aziz blames Morocco for the impasse. He argues that the late King Hassan's successor, King Mohammed, though a liberaliser in some ways, is his father's son on the Sahara.

"We had hopes of cooperation with the new king, but he is not dealing with the issues in a new way," he said yesterday.

Mr Abdel-Aziz, a powerfully built man, speaks passionately - in careful classical Arabic with a distinctive Sahrawi Hassaniya accent - of the right to self-determination of a small people it sometimes seems has been simply forgotten by history.

"No, nothing has changed," he says defiantly. "Twenty-five years of sacrifices and hardship have made us more determined than ever to win our legitimate rights." But much has changed. Back in the mid-70s and early 80s, Polisario fighters made the Moroccans pay a heavy price for taking over the phosphate-rich territory along the Atlantic seaboard.

Using language inspired by the Palestinians, the Sahrawis attracted wide support as a Third World liberation movement betrayed by a world that preferred to look the other way.

Morocco, like Indonesia, mattered more to the US and its allies than the fate of a few hundred thousand nomads who happened to believe they were a distinct people with their own identity.

In their refugee camps in Tindouf in remote south-western Algeria, the Polisario fighters impressed visitors with their high morale and motivation as guerrillas in all-terrain vehicles scoured the gravel plains to mount hit-and-run raids on Moroccan forces.

Yet fighting stopped under a ceasefire nine years ago, and last month the UN as much as admitted that referendum plans were stalled after years of Morrocan procrastination over how to register voters.

Support dwindles

Diplomatic recognition of the would-be republic has dwindled, too, though its leader said that India, a big player in the non-aligned world, had only "frozen" links. And Nigeria remained loyal.

The phantom state is still a member of the Organisation of African Unity. But Algeria - anxious to mend its fences with Morocco - leaned heavily on its leaders not to insist on attending the EU-Africa summit in Cairo earlier this year. They stayed away.

Mr Abdel-Aziz insists he will not accept autonomy under Moroccan rule - an idea quietly encouraged by the US and France. He has urged the EU to make its relations with Morocco - the largest single recipient of aid from the union - conditional on movement on a referendum. But the fact is that none of the 15 want to upset the new king, praised for reforms since assuming power last summer.

"European countries decided from the start not to use their influence to bring about a settlement and instead they are bolstering a colonial enterprise," said Mr Abdel-Aziz. "But they should convince the Moroccans to support the referendum."

fields.headline: Without prejudice
fields.standfirst: Denise Kingsmill, deputy chairman, competition commission
fields.trailText: Aided by her stylish three-inch heels, Denise Kingsmill sprouts more than six feet from the ground. Her reputation is formidable: from lawyer to George Walker, the boxer turned leisure tycoon, to more recently the "motorist's champion" during the competition commission's controversial investigation into overpriced cars.
fields.body:
Aided by her stylish three-inch heels, Denise Kingsmill sprouts more than six feet from the ground. Her reputation is formidable: from lawyer to George Walker, the boxer turned leisure tycoon, to more recently the "motorist's champion" during the competition commission's controversial investigation into overpriced cars.

She relished her title as the most feared woman in Britain. "You don't want a wimp, you want a tough lawyer," she says. Many legal battles are actually settled in corridors rather than courts; this is when height counted most. "It's the gladiatorial battle of the courts, that's when you need height."

Slim, blond and elegant, she admits to having used her striking appearance to her advantage.

That is now all behind her. In Ms Kingsmill's role as deputy chairman of the competition commission, where she has tackled issues as diverse as the price of raw milk and the intricacies of how City financiers set their charges for underwriting debt issues for companies, such adversarial tendencies are less important.

"We are interlocutive rather than adversarial," she says. Giving companies a fair hearing and making the laborious process more accessible to the public is now her main goal. Her public hearing into car prices was boycotted by the manufacturers but she still concluded that the way they sell cars - the block exemption - is leading to higher prices, which she hopes will start to fall dramatically in 2002 if the EU's competition watchdog takes action to break the mould.

In the coming weeks, the resulkts of her latest investigation, into the electricity industry, are likely to be made public by Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary. She says with a laughthat the most she knew about electricity before starting the inquiry was turning on a light.

Now she knows much more. "I've seen these huge turbine halls, this sense of industrial power. It's fantastic, it's romantic." Striking a balance between competition in former state-owned monopolies and regulation is her task. "Fair and rigorous competition is the cornerstone of economic growth. It is through this strong economic growth we can afford the social justice we should aspire to."

Breaking the mould

She is fiercely aware of being a woman in a what still is a man's world. She is passionate about breaking the mould in Britain's boardrooms. She attended the release of a survey this month that showed of all 1,247 non-executive directorships in the 108 biggest companies just 65 are held by women.

It is not that she wants to catapult women into the boardroom for the sake of it but she would like to see an end to the uniformity of the boardroom - of public school-educated men of a certain age who have worked their way up through the ranks. "There are too many non-executive clones."

She speaks from experience. After years advising companies and sacked executives about how to get a good deal, Ms Kingsmill waded in to her first non-executive position with gusto. After what she recalls as a "seriously bloody" boardroom battle, she became deputy chairman of MFI. Her fashion sense is behind the invigorated image of MFI on the high street. She set up a "design leadership group" to put the glamour back into frumpy kitchens and insists her home in Holland Park has an MFI kitchen.

"[MFI] put in the reach of ordinary people glamorously glossy kitchens which at the time it was set up were out of the reach of ordinary people."

Born in New Zealand, she moved to her mother's native south Wales at the age of eight. It was a shock. She was tall, lanky and spoke oddly. "It has made all subsequent changes in my life a doddle," she says. Her accent now dulled, she admits she was glad to get out of Wales. But she left her mark in the small town of Croesyceiliog where her name is on the wall of the grammar school as the first pupil of either sex to go to Oxbridge.

Girton, Cambridge, was the setting in what she describes as the vintage years of 1965-68. Again gender was an issue. Ms Kingsmill remembers being one of six woman in a class of 300 men, studying economics and anthropology.

With hindsight she has concluded it was not really her world. It gave her a taste for tackling prejudice. A life-long member of the Labour party, she is at pains to point out her appointment to the competition commission was made by the previous government. Her Blairite credentials and perceived ambition also led to speculation that she would be next head of the office of fair trading, a job she did not get and says now she never wanted. "I was very flattered to have been considered to be a candidate and mightily relieved I didn't get the job."

She wants to be able to keep her foot in the commercial world, holding on to her non-executive positions. Since joining the competition commission she has turned down new non-executive positions but lends her support an initiative to highlight the absence of woman from boardrooms.

"One wants more diversity, we need a different kind of man as well. Diversity is a good thing in itself but, more to the point for modern companies, they need to recognise the diversity of the society they are serving and the range of shareholders they are serving and therefore have a boardroom which is more responsive to those requirements," she says.

The answer is to find "people who've got different backgrounds, different educations, who have come up through a different route, that's why women would be very valuable because many of them haven't had the classic 'start at the bottom and work your way to top' career. Many women have gone off on tangents, they've taken career breaks, they've made changes in the careers have to take alternative routes to the top and been successful in different areas."

Much of this reflects Ms Kingsmill's own journey through life. After leaving Cambridge she joined ICI. It was 1968 and, with a choice of paints in Slough, chemicals in Billingham or fibres in Knightsbridge, she perhaps unsurprisingly chose the last and ended up at fashion shows in Paris, sitting on, as she puts it, "little gold stools".

The right track

She married David Kingsmill, a banker, and moved to Manhattan where she had her epiphany. This was the swinging 1970s and New York gave the 20-something Ms Kingsmill her dose of feminism and burning desire for the law. "I was child of the 60s and had a sense of wanting to make the world a better place and realised that I was not going to do that in the fashion industry. So I became a lawyer."

After returning to London she went back to school. She sat one of her final exams on the day her son Ben was due. In 1980 Ms Kingsmill qualified to become a lawyer. At a time of huge industrial strife, she became a trades union lawyer, later setting up her own firm - Kingsmill & Co - to tackle equal opportunities law.

After making a success of her own business Kingsmill sold the firm to DJ Freeman, the respected City lawyers.

While she admits to being pretty good at professional aggression she is a peacemaker in private. Any disputes with her two now grown-up children - she is no longer with their father - upset her.

Breaking dysfunctional boards, reaching settlements for ousted executives or taking companies to task over anti-competitive behaviour, however, are all part of professional life. "When it got nasty I just get cooler and cooler."

Such coolness means Ms Kingsmill is regularly described as pushy and aggressive, adjectives she acknowledges would only be applied to a woman. "Men use different language to describe women. Behaviour that would be described as authoritative in men is aggressive in women. You never hear about pushy men. A lot of men find it difficult to relate. One of my big tests is whether they have working wives. Then they understand about the role."

Outside the corporate world, Ms Kingsmill and her partner, Richard Wheatly, the Jazz FM boss and Cambridge contemporary who sought her out after 25 years, spend their spare time fly fishing. "We set out about five years ago to learn to fish, to do something together where his great physical prowess didn't make him better than me." Even in her private life she does her bit for equality.

Her reputation is formidable: from lawyer to George Walker, the boxer turned leisure tycoon, to more recently the "motorist's champion" during the competition commission's controversial investigation into overpriced cars. She relished her title as the most feared woman in Britain. "You don't want a wimp, you want a tough lawyer," she says. Many legal battles are actually settled in corridors rather than courts; this is when height counted most. "It's the gladiatorial battle of the courts, that's when you need height." Slim, blond and elegant, she admits to having used her striking appearance to her advantage. That is now all behind her. In Ms Kingsmill's role as deputy chairman of the competition commission, where she has tackled issues as diverse as the price of raw milk and the intricacies of how City financiers set their charges for underwriting debt issues for companies, such adversarial tendencies are less important. Her public hearing into car prices was boycotted by the manufacturers but she still concluded that the way they sell cars - the block exemption - is leading to higher prices, which she hopes will start to fall dramatically in 2002 if the EU's competition watchdog takes action to break the mould. webTitle: The price was £1. But ING is still paying for Leeson

fields.headline: The price was £1. But ING is still paying for Leeson
fields.standfirst: Rogue trader's celebrity might outlast Barings after a deal done in haste
fields.trailText: Nick Leeson has certainly had more than his 15 minutes of fame. The rogue trader bounced back into the press this week with the news that the plug might be pulled on the merchant bank his misdemeanours almost destroyed in 1995. Now packing them in on the rubber chicken circuit, it seems that Leeson's celebrity might outlast the venerable house of Barings.
fields.body:
Nick Leeson has certainly had more than his 15 minutes of fame. The rogue trader bounced back into the press this week with the news that the plug might be pulled on the merchant bank his misdemeanours almost destroyed in 1995. Now packing them in on the rubber chicken circuit, it seems that Leeson's celebrity might outlast the venerable house of Barings.

Dutch bank ING picked up Barings for a quid in a deal chaperoned by the Bank of England. The true cost to ING was far greater, for the losses squirrelled away by Leeson in Singapore created obligations to the financial community that needed to be squared for Barings to continue trading.

There was much talk of systemic risk in the short period between the Barings crisis emerging and the Dutch rescue completing. With hindsight it would appear that - as so often with deals completed in haste - the buyer had little idea of what or indeed why it was buying.

ING's ownership of Barings has seen strategic reviews, restructurings, new management, purchases of stockbroking firms on both sides of the Atlantic, and now a decision to dismember the investment bank along with the abandonment of its global ambitions. ING's chairman has reportedly been horrified to discover how much more his investment bankers were being paid than his commercial bankers. One suspects much more also than his senior management and fellow main board directors. If so, he won't be the first retail banker to choke on the rewards in the corporate finance world.

The corporate finance world allows no shades of grey. Deals are won or lost. Beauty parades might contain a string of aspirants but only one winner. The margins on transactions are enormous, which explains the competition for the plum deals. In such an environment it is hardly surprising that those individuals perceived to be deal closers are highly prized.

The problem for the owners of the investment banks is that assembling a team of potential prize winners is no guarantee of success.

But it is still expensive. Over the past decade a string of second tier investment banks have been swallowed by bigger rivals or have retrenched into specialist positions as they have lost the appetite or the wherewithal to stay in the race for supremacy. Only this year Chase has acquired both Flemings and JP Morgan, Salomon Smith Barney has snaffled Schroders and CSFB has subsumed DLJ.

The question of the ideal parentage for investment banks remains unresolved. Old partnership structures have dissolved as the financial resources required to compete at the highest level have outstripped the assets of employees. The last great partnership, Goldman Sachs, capitulated and floated on the New York stock exchange last year. The major players are now either quoted companies or part of larger banking giants.

The challenge for owners is to align employee interests closely with shareholders so as to recreate the old self-correcting mechanism of partnerships - that in bad years staff rewards are lower than in good years. This week Deutsche Bank indicated that it intends to increase substantially the proportion of its equity owned by employees so as to get closer to the American model. However, as technology compa nies have discovered, employee share ownership counts for little when times are tough and share prices falling.

ING emerges from this week's events with precious little credit. It bought UK broker Charterhouse Securities for £127m only a few months ago. One can only presume that Charterhouse will be up for sale once again - which is hardly the best way to cement the goodwill inherent in a people business.

The Dutch also walked into the classic trap of being hustled by employees it wishes to retain. Within days of announcing its strategic review, ING was rumoured to be offering golden handcuffs to staff. Another lesson in investment bankers' remuneration for the chairman.

A small but significant shift in the investment environment has occurred. Interest rate futures are now indicating that the next move in UK rates will be downwards. This does not square with the minutes of the monetary policy committee, published data on economic activity or pre-election fiscal priming. But it is absolutely consistent with today's real world.

The weather, the fuel price dispute and the aftermath of the Hatfield rail crash have hobbled the UK economy. Papers like the Evening Standard may rail at the crisis on the capital's roads, but this is not an indicator of an economy at full stretch.

Business bookings have slumped. Travel on a long distance train - you will find it near empty. Listen to the construction industry and it will tell you storms have crippled activity. Throw in the knock-on impact of the slump in tech shares and the economic barometer points to depression, in the psychological sense. Although the hiatus in activity is a consequence of "one-off" factors, it could easily shake confidence within the economy and trigger a slowdown. In America the presidential impasse must have had a similar effect on economic activity. A nation staring at itself through its TV screens is one unable to focus on its work. A growth hiccup is possible, adding to pressure on share prices.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Email in the workplace

fields.headline: Email? You've got the elbow
fields.standfirst:
For film fans cyberspace corespondence between Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan meant electricity on the screen. But, as Phillip Inman reports, send out the wrong messages at work and sparks fly

Net news
fields.trailText: For film fans cyberspace corespondence between Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan meant electricity on the screen. But, as Phillip Inman reports, send out the wrong messages at work and sparks fly.
fields.body:
All it takes to get the sack is a bit of malicious gossip, an email and a manager keen to use some of the latest software for snooping on staff. Any manager can do it. And if an employee finds out and complains, the employer can draw on a raft of government endorsed excuses to support their surreptitious activities.

According to civil rights groups and trades unions, ministers last month handed employers nearly all the tools they need to spy on staff in the form of regulations attached to the regulation of investigatory powers (Rip) act.

Along with organisations like the Industrial Society, an employment think tank, they say employers already paranoid about pornography and viruses circulating on their systems might use the regulations to extend their tentacles and snoop on all electronic communications.

Industrial Society chief executive Will Hutton comments: "Employers are increasingly aware of 'cyberliability' and email abuse and are using more covert and intrusive methods of surveillance. While employers have legitimate interests to protect, over zealous monitoring can undermine employees' dignity and autonomy within the workplace."

A measure of the growth in snooping can be found on the London stock exchange where Baltimore Technologies has become one of the fastest growing companies of recent times on the back of a suit of internet security software including Minesweeper, one of the most popular snooping software products. Even Hollywood noticed the impact of email when Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan created the hit film You've got Mail.

The Rip Act seemed at first as if it may offer staff some protection from anxious employers when it appeared earlier this year. It talks about the need for privacy and stressed the need for mutual trust and confidence. The act says employers need to devise a policy that states how they intend to monitor emails, telephone calls and connections to the internet. Employers also need to tell staff about the policy, the act says.

But on October 24 a series of detailed rules that put flesh on the bones of the legislation came into force, which critics argue give employers most of the excuses they need for monitoring the electronic activities of staff when they see fit. The Interception of Communications regulations override the privacy clauses in the act, protecting the employer from complaints by staff.

But hang on a minute, the regulations don't just contradict a central plank of the Rip Act. While the DTI was busy watering down its original legislation, the government brought in the Human Rights Act, which talks about the privacy of "communication". The Data Protection Commissioner, emboldened by new data protection legislation, also issued draft guidance that recommended employers must gain the consent of employees if they want to access emails and other electronic communication.

The Rip legislation and the regulations that go with it give a clearer picture of the legal landscape, given that the recommendations of the data protection commissioner are only in draft form and the Human Rights Act is as yet untested in this field. That's why civil liberties groups and trades unions are up in arms and fear tribunals.

"The government has defined particular circumstances when employers can intercept electronic information, but it is hard to think of anything employers might do that is not covered by the regulations," says TUC spokeswoman Lucy Anderson. Snooping, says the TUC, can go on "almost without restriction and with no duty to consult or negotiate with trade unions or worker representatives". Civil rights campaign group Liberty says: "The whip hand is with the employer."

Unions point to an instance last year when a college secretary claimed she was put under surveillance by a manager who monitored her emails, internet use and the length of her telephone calls. She says the manager even contacted people she phoned to check what the call was about and who they were. The college said checking up on staff was reasonable, but failed to produce a policy that detailed when and how managers could snoop on their staff.

She lodged a grievance alleging harassment and, with the support of Liberty, her case, which pre-dates the Rip legislation, is being taken to the European Court of Human Rights. Mark Taylor of City law firm Lovell White Durrant recalls another female employee who was sacked after her boss decided she had spent too long surfing the net to book a holiday.

A spokesman for the DTI denies the new rules fail to protect employees, and says the department believes they dovetail with the data protection rules and Human Rights Act. "The regulations don't give employers carte blanche to do whatever they like. They still need to comply with the Human Rights Act, and you'll find the data protection commissioner is very supportive."

Philip Jones, an assistant data protection commissioner, agrees that an employer will have difficulty spying on staff without an agreed policy. "They still need to comply with the Data Protection Act which says that employees should know what information is being collected on them and how it will be used. They must also respect an employee's privacy under the Human Rights Act.

Employees would probably take more comfort from these statements if they believed that most employers complied with the Data Protection Act. "If you went to every company and asked if they complied with the act 90% of them would fail to satisfy all eight principles," says solicitor Kit Burdon of Barlow Lyde Gilbert."

Worse, Theo Blackwell of the Industrial Society says about half of its member organisations conceded they lacked a policy governing electronic communications at the last time of asking. And of members that have contacted the society in recent weeks, "most said their policy was inadequate to meet the changes in the law".

Mr Burdon believes the regulations are an improvement and codify an area that was previously unregulated. "During a hunt for porn by an employer, a member of staff who was quite junior was found to have stored minutes from a board committee on their system. He shouldn't have had access and it was an obvious case of gross misconduct."

But he says out that employees remain extremely vulnerable to employers keen to use the new regulations to get rid of them.

"An employer could use instances of alleged misuse of the e-mail system to build up a case of gross misconduct." An employer might decide that some messages are "harmful to the smooth running of the business that an internet user would consider inconsequential, like circulating a round robin joke".

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Email surveillance and the law

fields.headline: Swamped with anomalies
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Everyone connected with employment issues agrees that employers should draft a policy governing how staff can use email systems, but there any consensus ends. What the policy should say and how it should be implemented are highly contentious issues.
fields.body:
Everyone connected with employment issues agrees that employers should draft a policy governing how staff can use email systems, but there any consensus ends. What the policy should say and how it should be implemented are highly contentious issues.

The legal situation governing what is allowed and what isn't has the clarity of a Mississippi swamp. Trade & Industry Secretary Stephen Byers, and his minister Patricia Hewitt who oversees telecommunications, stand accused of muddying the waters.

Employers are as much in the dark as their staff. The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act, which came into force earlier this year, calls on employers to have an agreed policy. The Human Rights Act says public bodies must respect privacy and Article 8 could be used in unfair dismissal cases to help assess the reasonableness of an employer sacking a worker for sending an email which is critical of a manager.

An EU directive that tackles the issue of snooping on telecommunications messages that took effect in October says a "non-consensual interception" is not allowed unless national laws allow for it. The contentious regulations governing emails that came out last month were in response to the EU directive. Without the regulations, employers would have been prevented from looking at anything their staff sent or received via email, over the internet or on the telephone.

The regulations state when an employer will be able to record all communications without the consent of the employee, says the TUC. These are in addition to an employer being able to monitor their employees' use of email in order to determine whether the use is business related. It is not unlawful for an employer to mount an investigation:

* to establish the existence of facts relevant to the business;

* to ascertain compliance with regulatory or self-regulatory practices or procedures;

* to ascertain or demonstrate standards which are or ought to be achieved by the employees;

* to prevent or detect crime;

* to investigate or detect the unauthorised use of the businesses' systems;

* to ensure the effective operation of those systems.

The DTI is adamant that the new rules still insist on employers agreeing a policy with staff. It argues that its rules offer a good deal of protection. "If the employer wanted to change the circumstances in which he would intercept employees' communications without their consent for any of the [individual regulations], he would have to inform them of the changes. If he wanted to intercept for any other purposes, he would have to get the consent of the employee."

Industrial Society, 0870 400 1000 or Industrial Society
