fields.bodyText: Everyone connected with employment issues agrees that employers should draft a policy governing how staff can use email systems, but there any consensus ends. What the policy should say and how it should be implemented are highly contentious issues. The legal situation governing what is allowed and what isn't has the clarity of a Mississippi swamp. Trade & Industry Secretary Stephen Byers, and his minister Patricia Hewitt who oversees telecommunications, stand accused of muddying the waters. Employers are as much in the dark as their staff. The Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act, which came into force earlier this year, calls on employers to have an agreed policy. The Human Rights Act says public bodies must respect privacy and Article 8 could be used in unfair dismissal cases to help assess the reasonableness of an employer sacking a worker for sending an email which is critical of a manager. An EU directive that tackles the issue of snooping on telecommunications messages that took effect in October says a "non-consensual interception" is not allowed unless national laws allow for it. The contentious regulations governing emails that came out last month were in response to the EU directive. Without the regulations, employers would have been prevented from looking at anything their staff sent or received via email, over the internet or on the telephone. The regulations state when an employer will be able to record all communications without the consent of the employee, says the TUC. These are in addition to an employer being able to monitor their employees' use of email in order to determine whether the use is business related. It is not unlawful for an employer to mount an investigation: * to establish the existence of facts relevant to the business; * to ascertain compliance with regulatory or self-regulatory practices or procedures; * to ascertain or demonstrate standards which are or ought to be achieved by the employees; * to prevent or detect crime; * to investigate or detect the unauthorised use of the businesses' systems; * to ensure the effective operation of those systems. The DTI is adamant that the new rules still insist on employers agreeing a policy with staff. It argues that its rules offer a good deal of protection. "If the employer wanted to change the circumstances in which he would intercept employees' communications without their consent for any of the [individual regulations], he would have to inform them of the changes. If he wanted to intercept for any other purposes, he would have to get the consent of the employee." webTitle: CSFB offers offshore hedge fund to small investors

fields.headline: CSFB offers offshore hedge fund to small investors
fields.trailText: Hedge funds, long the preserve of superwealthy people, such as George Soros, are to be sold to small investors for the first time next year by Credit Suisse First Boston.
fields.body:
Hedge funds, long the preserve of superwealthy people, such as George Soros, are to be sold to small investors for the first time next year by Credit Suisse First Boston.

The move comes just two years after the $5bn Wall Street collapse of Long Term Capital Management sparked a global financial crisis. Regulators remain fearful of the systemic risk that hedge funds pose. In Britain, the financial services authority bans companies from selling hedge funds directly to small investors, and refuses to authorise retail hedge funds.

However, CSFB says it has found a way to overcome the rules by structuring the hedge fund as a Dublin-listed company, allowing the fund to be marketed in Britain as authorised and regulated. It is seeking approval for the fund from the central bank of Ireland and is already pre-marketing the fund to British independent financial advisers.

Hedge funds are traditionally private partnerships used by the super rich and banks to achieve very high returns on their cash. Using financial tools like derivatives and arbitrage, the funds bet on certain market movements, often moving billions of dollars in one swoop.

Unlike hedge funds offered by private banks to wealthy in dividuals, which tend to have a minimum investment of £150,000 or more, the CSFB fund will start at just £7,000, and will be able to be placed in a tax-free individual savings account.

CSFB vice-president Adam Habib said: "This is a first in many ways for the retail market place. It is likely to have a minimum investment of £7,000, which is really bringing it to the smaller investor for the first time. It will be authorised, regulated, Isa-able and Pep-transferable."

CSFB insists that the fund will not be the highly-leveraged variety run by LTCM or the "global macro" style run by George Soros. It will focus on low risk and low volatility, in the style of the £1bn hedge fund run by Coutts bank since 1998. Coutts says it has averaged returns of 10-12% for investors in its low risk portfolio, although it is restricted to customers who can meet Coutts' minimum £500,000 balance.

In recent years several City investment house fund managers have quit to set up hedge fund boutiques, attracted by the possibility of making money from "shorting" falling shares, and by the huge performance fees - often 25% of the value of the fund - that can be earned.

CSFB says fees will be kept to a minimum.

fields.headline: Sema triggers new tech sell-off
fields.standfirst: Profits alert causes 44% fall in software firm's value
fields.trailText: The technology sector suffered another rout yesterday after a profits warning from Anglo-French computer services company Sema Group caused its shares to collapse by 44%.
fields.body:
The technology sector suffered another rout yesterday after a profits warning from Anglo-French computer services company Sema Group caused its shares to collapse by 44%.

The slump in Sema shares by 274p to 346p was one of the worst one-day falls experienced by a FTSE 100 company. It wiped more than £1.7bn from the value of the business and almost guaranteed its exit from the FTSE 100 at the next review of constituents, in 10 days' time.

In Sema's wake, CMG closed 121p lower at 925p, Logica down 108p to £15.30 and Sage off 11p at 408p, although in New York the tech-laden Nasdaq index recovered 5% after a six-day run of heavy losses.

Sema warned that profits in the second half of the year would be "broadly in line" with those in 1999 - well below market forecasts. It blamed regulatory delays in its £3.4bn acquisition of the US mobile phone billing software group, LHS, which had led to a poor performance in that business during the third quarter.

Of wider concern to industry analysts were Sema's mention of a downturn in the outsourcing market and the postponement of a number of contracts in Europe. The statement from Sema appeared to underline fears that a hoped for pick-up in spending on IT after a lull at the start of the year had failed to materialise.

Sema said growth in 2001 would be 12%, also lower than market expectations. "Delayed integration probably has the biggest impact on the results. But we are doing much better in the fourth quarter," said Pierre Bonelli, the chief executive.

HSBC Securities changed its "'buy" to "reduce" while Nomura moved back to "hold" from "long-term buy".

"There are just no signs of a real pick-up in the market," said one IT analyst. "It's clearly a tough time."

The statement followed similarly bleak comments from two of mainland Europe's largest IT groups this week, Sagem in France and Dutch group Getronics.

Dealers described the Sema drop as the worst ever one-day collapse but, according to Datastream, Sema's fall from grace is not without precedent. Celltech dropped 45% on one day in May 1997. Sema shares peaked at £18 in February and have suffered from the change in sentiment towards technology and media shares.

The IT industry had become used to growth rates of up to 20% during the last decade. It expected to pause at the beginning of 2000 as companies assessed their compliance with the milennium date change. But the anticipated pick-up has not appeared.

Analysts in part blame changing attitudes to the internet which prompted many companies to curb their IT spending. "The pressure just isn't there on companies to turn themselves into e-businesses as soon as they can," said one. They have cut profits forecasts for Sema from around £130m to £105m.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Fayed snaps up local heliport
fields.body:
Fayed snaps up local heliport

Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of Harrods, has bought London's last commercial heliport.

Mr Fayed, understood to be a regular user of the London Westland Heliport, acquired it through his company Metro Business Aviation. Engineering group GKN said yesterday it sold the site in south-west London to MBA on on November 16.

The land comes with planning permission to build a new terminal, GKN said.

A decision on whether Mr Al Fayed should be allowed to land helicopters on the roof of his Knightsbridge store has gone to a public inquiry.

KLM takes a look at Go

KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday its low-cost airline Buzz had requested the prospectus on the sale of British rival Go. But a spokesman said this did not mean Buzz was necessarily interested in buying Go, which British Airways has put up for sale.

"Buzz has asked for the prospectus but there is nothing to conclude from that," KLM spokesman Youssef Eddini said. "At this point we are concentrating on making a study on our long-term view of the low-cost market. It is a very dynamic market at the moment."

Duisenberg told to quit

François Loncle, chairman of France's foreign affairs commission of the national assembly, called for the resignation of European Central Bank president Wim Duisenberg, following comments made by Mr Duisenberg in a speech last night.

Mr Duisenberg said it was too early to confidently say that the euro has been a success, and the commentsaffected the currency, foreign exchange dealers said.

"As soon as he opens his mouth, the euro plunges," Mr Loncle said."Let him leave his place to an undisputed authority who, instead of trying to sink the euro, will give priority to the defence and the promotion of the single currency."

Wates accepts Pillar offer

Wates City of London Properties yesterday announced it had agreed a cash offer from Pillar Property which valued it at £373.3m. Pillar is paying 141p for each Wates share - a 25.9% premium on the company's share price before it said it was in talks.

Separately, British property investment firm Frogmore Estates has agreed to a cash bid from management valuing it at £292.6m. The management team, backed by Royal Bank of Scotland and Trefick, will pay 612p for each Frogmore share - a 16.8% premium on the share price before the bid announcement.

Bug blacks out Amazon

The website of online retailer Amazon.com crashed briefly yesterday, on one of the US's busiest shopping days, one day after Thanksgiving.

The site crashed for about 30 minutes, Amazon spokesman Bill Curry said.

"It was totally internal, it was a bug in the system that is now exterminated. It had nothing to do with holiday traffic," Mr Curry said.

webTitle: Byelection victories mean May 3 at polls

fields.headline: Byelection victories pave way for no-delay campaign and May 3 date at the polls
fields.standfirst:
Special report: elections 2000

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: A general election on May 3, preceded by a lengthy campaign including high profile TV debates, appeared to be on the cards yesterday as Labour examined the implications of its three byelection victories on Thursday night.
fields.body:
A general election on May 3, preceded by a lengthy campaign including high profile TV debates, appeared to be on the cards yesterday as Labour examined the implications of its three byelection victories on Thursday night.

Millbank officials said there would have to be very good reasons now for the prime minister to be knocked off course and delay beyond May 3. "The Tories are desperate for delay, but it seems less and less necessary," one official said.

Although all three seats could be regarded as safe Labour territory, ministers had said they expected difficulty holding them, especially West Bromwich West, the seat previously held by the former speaker, Betty Boothroyd.

The result has generated optimism within government and prompted Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's spokesman, to indicate the viability of TV debates in order to generate voter enthusiasm; all three byelections were marked by low turnouts. The TV companies have put forward a joint proposal to secure the agreement of the political parties, but there are already difficulties over the treatment of the Liberal Democrats

The Conservatives have yet to gain a seat in the 16 byelections held during this parliament, a rare failure for an opposition party. Although the Conservatives enjoyed swings of more than 10 % on Thursday, they were tiny in comparison with the byelection swings away from the Conservatives during the Thatcher and Major years. In 1996 Labour enjoyed a swing of 22% on a 60% turnout in South East Staffordshire, while in February 1997 it won Wirral South on a turnout of 73%.

The Conservative chairman, Michael Ancram, claimed the Tory share of the vote had gone back up to the levels of the 1992 general election. He claimed the Tories had not gained byelections in this parliament because none had been held in any winnable territory. William Hague described the results as "steady progress on what we have achieved in elections earlier this year".

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said the results showed "no enthusiasm for Labour and no hope for the Conservatives".

Millbank officials admitted the turnout on Thursday night was again worryingly low: 27.6% in West Bromwich, 29.39% in Preston and 38.42% in Glasgow Anniesland. But they said the figures, which beat the desultory 19.6% turnout in Leeds Central byelection in June 1999, were about 5% higher than their canvass returns had been suggesting. Officials said voters had no reason to turn out in such safe seats and that canvass records tend to be better in swing seats, making it easier to get the core vote out.

Mr Campbell claimed Mr Hague was running a backdoor strategy to win Downing Street, trying to stir up apathy, depressing turnout and then winning off the back of his core vote.

He said the Tories were trying to create the impression that voting does not bring about reform. The Tories had nothing to offer voters apart from "bandwagons and Europhobia", he said.

Labour officials have already launched Operation Turnout in an effort to galvanise the core vote in the coming election. The strategy is based on retaining regular contact with voters by local parties before the election. The recent thank you poster campaign is also designed to push home the message that voting does make a difference.

Labour officials were also taking heart from the turnout among older voters. They claimed their canvass returns showed the pensions issue was no longer a negative for the government after the big rises in the basic pension in the pre-Budget report three weeks ago.

Millbank claims the Conservatives are now in difficulty over their own pension policy, which includes a commitment to remove the £200 winter fuel allowance and roll it into the basic pension. Labour ran strong messages claiming the Conservatives would have taken the £200 away.

webTitle: Israel and Palestine resume security links

fields.headline: Israel and Palestine resume security links
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Palestinians and Israelis agreed to resume joint security arrangements yesterday after the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, spoke to the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak for the first time in three weeks.
fields.body:
The Palestinians and Israelis agreed to resume joint security arrangements yesterday after the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, spoke to the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak for the first time in three weeks.

The apparently impromptu phone conversation was arranged by the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, during a visit by Mr Arafat to Moscow.

The security arrangements, established in the Oslo peace agreement in 1993, have been disrupted by the violence, which began two months ago and has resulted in more than 250 deaths.

The heads of the Israeli and Palestinian security organisations are to renew links as will officers in the field, and a joint co-ordinating office in the Gaza Strip is to be reopened.

Mr Arafat, who has told US and Turkish diplomats that he is keen to resume negotiations, also promised to renew his call for an end to violence but both sides cautioned against optimism given the fierceness of fighting in the past few weeks.

fields.headline: The bitter end
fields.standfirst:
The one good thing about the Thatcher years was that people fought for their principles

Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText: One of the abiding myths about the early days of alternative comedy is that a comedian only had to slag off Margaret Thatcher and the whole place would fall about laughing. In fact jugglers were alarmingly popular and Thatcher provoked more anger and distress than amusement.
fields.body:
One of the abiding myths about the early days of alternative comedy is that a comedian only had to slag off Margaret Thatcher and the whole place would fall about laughing. In fact jugglers were alarmingly popular and Thatcher provoked more anger and distress than amusement.

Another notion is that alternative comedy was a specific reaction to Thatcher's victory, that the left was so horror struck it adopted an entrist tactic whereby the most militant and dedicated cadre was hastily uniformed in jumble-sale suits and ordered to infiltrate the world of light entertainment.

It is easy to forget that Jim Callaghan lost the 1979 election because he took on the unions and lost. Labour politicians never seem to learn that there is neither a need nor an expectation for them to take on the unions. They are supposed to be on the same side. That's the whole point. That's how Labour got its name. Otherwise it would have been called the Slightly Better Than the Liberals party. Sadly, the day that organised labour put its faith in a parliamentary strategy was the day it lost the class war, but anyway ...

Part of the Callaghan-Healey strategy for tackling inflation was public spending cuts and punishing the low paid. There was another bit of the plan I never quiet understood which involved singing Marie Lloyd songs instead of calling the election while it was still winnable, but I don't pretend to have a firm grasp of psephology. At any rate, by the time Thatcher took over, public services were already under attack, there had already been privatisation and there was a lot of talk about restricting the money supply. So 1979 wasn't exactly a shock on the scale of Chile in 1972, although Thatcher was clearly inspired by that. She shared Pinochet's close attention to the ravings of Milton Friedman and still seems to have a soft spot for mass murder and torture as an anti-inflationary strategy.

Labour had come into power with radical promises, moved to the right and lost power again. Ever since then, the fine brains who pronounce upon these things have told us that moving to the right is a sure-fire way for Labour to win elections, but never mind.

However bad Labour governments used to be, they compare with the present one as Peter Cook's talent does with Liz Hurley's. And although Callaghan opened the door for Thatcher, nothing could really have prepared us for the devastating misery she and her simpering sidekicks brought to our country.

When Tony Blair speaks of the good things done by her administration, one should remember that there were none. None whatsoever. There is nothing disproportionate about the contempt in which she is still held by all people of conscience and integrity. It is true that there was at times some misogyny directed at her, but no matter how many people hated her more for being female, they still couldn't have hated her as much as she deserves.

The only caveat I would sound when people remember the joy of her departure is that her legacy is still with us, both in the privateering policies of New Labour and in the shape of all those cringing underlings of hers still in circulation. We are supposed to have warmed to Michael Portillo now that he admits to experimenting with mild paella in his youth. We are supposed to be jollied along by the Euroenthusiasm of "Ken" Clarke, who, as Kenneth, ruined the health service.

There was no let-up when Thatcher's own dumped her. It could be argued that the Tories' palace coup won them the 1992 election, which gave us five years of John Major, during which privatisation galloped ahead and Mr Blair was activated by the mother ship. The fact that Mr Major is now as forgotten as Bryan Gould, and that Thatcher can put the fear of God into both Hague and Blair gives her, I'm sure, much satisfaction.

And she is no doubt delighted that her record has been built upon. She came to power inciting and feeding off racial prejudice, and brought an almost complete end to immigration from the Commonwealth. Now she sees this government bowing to the racism against refugees. She sees all the worthless consultants and PR folk she spawned doing well. Her old mate Tim Bell got the Pinochet account and is doing good enough business to shine favour upon a disgraced wretch like Chris Woodhead.

Small wonder that Thatcher still grabs headlines. But she is over-mystified. The poll tax was her undoing and reminds us that someone who was revered and feared almost to the point of superhuman status wasn't actually that clever. It also reminds us that it was not Neil Kinnock's Labour party but people who were prepared to be jailed for their principles who curtailed her reign. The good that came from the Thatcher years was the fight against her.

Jeremy Hardy's column will now appear on Tuesdays.

fields.headline: Belgrade sets border deadline
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Serbia set a 72-hour deadline, starting from last night, for sending military-style, special police into the disputed Presevo valley on the border with Kosovo, where armed Albanian gunmen have been carrying out attacks on Serb security forces.
fields.body:
Serbia set a 72-hour deadline, starting from last night, for sending military-style, special police into the disputed Presevo valley on the border with Kosovo, where armed Albanian gunmen have been carrying out attacks on Serb security forces.

In a surprise ultimatum, Bozo Prelevic, Serbia's joint interior minister, warned that unless Nato-led K-For peacekeepers prevented further ethnic Albanian incursions, he would send in heavily armed reinforcements.

The threat follows an upsurge in activity by Albanian gunmen inside the valley in south Serbia. The gunmen, who have been infiltrating the region from inside Kosovo, are determined to detach the territory from Serbia and join it to Kosovo.

In a major assault on Tuesday and Wednesday, the rebel group - which models itself on the Kosovo Liberation Army - killed four Serb policemen and injured a dozen others. They captured a police checkpoint and the main road leading back into Kosovo.

About 600 people have fled the region this week, said Astrid van Genderen Stort, spokeswoman for the UNHCR. Ethnic Albanian refugees who sought safety in Kosovo reported shooting and shelling of their villages, she said.

If Serb reinforcements move in without the permission of the commander of the K-For peacekeepers, their arrival would violate a three-mile buffer zone - agreed last year - inside Serbia in which only lightly-armed local Serb police are allowed to operate.

The ultimatum from Serbia's coalition government is a stronger step than anything taken by the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, in the year since the end of the war in Kosovo and his election defeat last month.

webTitle: Storm clouds gather at Balkan summit

fields.headline: Storm clouds gather at Balkan summit
fields.standfirst:
Pledge on regional dialogue despite major problems over war crimes and Kosovo

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Tensions between leaders of the various parts of former Yugoslavia and the potential for renewed bloodshed cast a cloud over the unprecedented summit of Balkan and European Union leaders in Zagreb yesterday.
fields.body:
Tensions between leaders of the various parts of former Yugoslavia and the potential for renewed bloodshed cast a cloud over the unprecedented summit of Balkan and European Union leaders in Zagreb yesterday.

As Serbia and Montenegro clashed over the shape of a new rump Yugoslav state, regional politicians moved to put a decade of war and disaster behind them, committing themselves to a new era of cooperation and reconciliation in the Balkans.

The scene of improbable promise was set for yesterday's summit after an astonishing year of democratic change in the former Yugoslavia - starting last December with the death of the Croatian strongman, president Franjo Tudjman, and culminating in the overthrow of the Yugoslavpresident, Slobodan Milosevic, last month and the recent victory by moderates in Kosovo elections.

But Kosovo and its eventual status remains the biggest bone of contention in former Yugoslavia. The Kosovo Albanians were not directly represented at yesterday's summit, a glaring omission designed to placate Serbian sensitivities. Mr Kostunica attacked the United States, criticised past EU failures in the Balkans, and talked tough on Kosovo and Montenegro.

For the Europeans as for the Croats, Bosnians, and Albanians who have been at war with the Serbs over the past decade, Mr Kostunica's appearance was keenly awaited and closely watched.

European officials were disappointed by his performance, aggrieved at his toughness on Kosovo. The other former Yugoslavs were even angrier, searching for some signal of remorse on behalf of the Serbs but finding none.

The Croatian president, Stipe Mesic, said that Mr Kostunica's presence in Zagreb did not mean he was making an official visit to Croatia. If he had been, said Mr Mesic, "we would have set totally different demands for him".

The summit's final declaration committed Croatia, Bosnia, Macedonia, Albania, and Yugoslavia - comprising Serbia and Montenegro - to a new era of "political dialogue, regional free trade, and close cooperation in the fields of justice and home affairs".

"It is a matter of priority to develop regional cooperation," the declaration read.

The EU pledged €4.65bn (£2.8bn) in reconstruction aid for the shattered region over the next six years, although that is hundreds of millions of pounds less than was promised last year when Serbia was still ineligible to gain the funds.

In an indirect attack on the preferential treatment that Serbia under Mr Kostunica is seen to be getting from the international community, Mr Mesic stressed the imperative of cooperating with the United Nations war crimes tribunal in the Hague and handing over indicted war criminals such as Mr Milosevic, Serbian president Milan Milutinovic, and the former Bosnian Serb leaders, Radovan Karadzic and General Ratko Mladic.

"It would be illusory to discuss any normalisation without full cooperation with the Hague tribunal, without the individual assignment of guilt which will prevent the creation of myths of collective guilt of any nation," said Mr Mesic.

Mr Kostunica derides the tribunal as a toy of US policy and has said he will not hand over Mr Milosevic. Several hundred aggrieved Croatian war victims marched outside the conference hall, clutching pictures of Mr Kostunica brandishing a Kalashnikov and calling him a war criminal. But the small protest was vastly outnumbered by riot policemen ordered to contain the slightest hint of trouble.

While Mr Kostunica's less-than-conciliatory tone surprised European officials, they pointed out that Serbia faces crucial polls on December 23 and suggested that Mr Kostunica will be given the benefit of the doubt until the political landscape in Serbia is clearer.

It was clear that the tense relationship between Serbia and Montenegro could present a flashpoint in the months ahead. President Milo Djukanovic of Montenegro said the two were de facto separate countries, that the international community should recognise this, and that he was pushing ahead with laying the ground for an independence referendum.

Mr Kostunica, however, warned that any "unilateral move" by Montenegro would prove "disastrous".

But with renewed killings and bombs in the Kosovan provincial capital Pristina this week, and Albanian attacks in the Kosovo buffer zone which left four dead and forced hundreds to flee, the upsurge of violence in Kosovo has overshadowed talk of peace.

Bernard Kouchner, the United Nations' administrator in Kosovo - the closest the Kosovo Albanians have come to representation in Zagreb yesterday - warned that the international community was in too much of a hurry to resolve the conflict there.

The Montenegrin president agreed that Kosovo would need to be "an international protectorate" for years. In the international eagerness to embrace post-Milosevic Serbia, Mr Kouchner warned that the Kosovo Albanians were afraid of becoming "history's forgotten people".

"We should remain aware of another political fact," Mr Kouchner said. "The Kosovo Albanians are resolved to never again fall under the former rule."

fields.headline: Fibernet directors offload shares
fields.trailText: Senior executives at Fibernet, the fibre optic telecoms operator, sold stakes in the business on the same day they asked for shareholders' help in raising £77m to build a network in France, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Senior executives at Fibernet, the fibre optic telecoms operator, sold stakes in the business on the same day they asked for shareholders' help in raising £77m to build a network in France, it emerged yesterday.

Shares in Fibernet sunk almost 23% to £10.25 on Thursday's announcement of a deeply discounted rights issue which priced new shares at 600p - 55% lower than the previous day's close.

Company's chairman David Anslow and finance director Ted Hailey risk the wrath of investors after simultaneously selling shares hours earlier for £11.25 each. Mr Hailey made £337,500 from selling 30,000 shares, around 23% of his total holding, while Mr Anslow received £22,500 after offloading 2,000 shares.

Mr Anslow's wife Angela made £2,500 from the sale of 225 Fibernet shares.

Mr Hailey defended his decision, which was contained in the rights issue documentation, saying he was even tempted to buy the shares back after they lost another 14% yesterday to close down 145p at 875p.

He said his commitment was illustrated by the fact he is bound to £500,000 personal liability as part of the rights issue underwriting agreement with Old Mutual. "There was no special reason (for selling) except there's so few opportunities to do so," he said. "It's an impossible situation but I think I'd have been criticised if I'd waited until the end of the rights issue."

Mr Hailey said the company had been rocked by the reaction to the rights issue and said the share price drop meant this week contained "some of the worst few days in my career at Fibernet".

Mr Anslow echoed his comments and when asked if he thought the sale of the shares sent out the wrong message to shareholders, Mr Anslow admitted: "Perhaps it did, but it was a minor holding (0.02%)."

Analysts believe Fibernet's poor share price is a result of a sweeping dissatisfaction across the sector. Milan Radia, technology analyst at UBS Warburg, said Fibernet was very much a victim but predicted it would see a rerating soon.

fields.headline: Byers seeks easy switching
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, yesterday stepped up pressure on the banks, mortgage lenders and other service providers to promote competition by making it easier for their customers to switch suppliers.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, yesterday stepped up pressure on the banks, mortgage lenders and other service providers to promote competition by making it easier for their customers to switch suppliers.

His call came as government-sponsored research found considerable inertia among consumers, particularly among those with current and savings accounts and mortgages, and a "staggering" degree of loyalty to their present supplier.

Mr Byers is to join forces with regulators and consumer groups to demand greater price transparency, a wider range of directly comparable information and bigger access to quotes via the internet and telephone.

Senior government sources denied that Mr Byers was to embark on a "naming and shaming" campaign but some consumer groups have already indicated that they intend pinpointing companies offering high prices and poor quality of service - and make it hard for customers to switch.

"What we are doing is keeping up pressure on the companies to innovate and compete," the sources said. "We don't want cosy companies coasting along but world-class groups able to compete on a global scale and well-informed consumers acting as the driving forces for innovation."

The survey, carried out by FDS International for the department of trade and industry this summer, found that banks had the lowest level of switching, with just 6% of customers switching their current accounts in the last 5 years and a further 16% considering doing it.

Inertia - or loyalty - applied right across the board, with only 2% of over-55s switching and 10% of under-35s changing banks and just 4% of social class AB consumers switching. Four out of five current account holders have stayed with their bank for more than 10 years.

The survey authors suggest that this loyalty makes it hard for new entrants to wean customers away with fairer charging and better service and the Big Four, with a 64% market share, are likely to increase their dominance through mergers.

The DTI research found that of those who had considered changing 48% claimed it was "too much hassle" and 21% were simply happy with their bank. Even if switching were simple and free, 62% would refuse to do so and, though 59% believed they could make savings, this was not enough to make them change.

The survey found that switching rates were highest in insurance, with 53% of motorists and 30% of homeowners changing supplier - largely because it is easy to get comparative quotes and there is no one brand leader.

But only 12% of borrowers have switched mortgages in the last five years even though nearly a third of those surveyed considered the option - with the majority deterred by early redemption penalties, high legal costs and the difficulty of comparing the 4,000-5,000 deals available.

Switching in energy is growing, with the survey finding 37% in gas and 26% in electricity changing supplier - compared with the 28% and 20% identified by the regulator, Ofgem.

The survey puts renewed pressure on telecoms watchdog Oftel to get tougher with BT after finding that just 11% of fixed-line subscribers had switched in the past five years. Cable, however, is seen as a lower quality option.

Senior government sources denied that Mr Byers was to embark on a "naming and shaming" campaign but some consumer groups have already indicated that they intend pinpointing companies offering high prices and poor quality of service - and make it hard for customers to switch. "What we are doing is keeping up pressure on the companies to innovate and compete," the sources said. "We don't want cosy companies coasting along but world-class groups able to compete on a global scale and well-informed consumers acting as the driving forces for innovation." The survey, carried out by FDS International for the department of trade and industry this summer, found that banks had the lowest level of switching, with just 6% of customers switching their current accounts in the last 5 years and a further 16% considering doing it. Inertia - or loyalty - applied right across the board, with only 2% of over-55s switching and 10% of under-35s changing banks and just 4% of social class AB consumers switching. Four out of five current account holders have stayed with their bank for more than 10 years. The survey authors suggest that this loyalty makes it hard for new entrants to wean customers away with fairer charging and better service and the Big Four, with a 64% market share, are likely to increase their dominance through mergers. The DTI research found that of those who had considered changing 48% claimed it was "too much hassle" and 21% were simply happy with their bank. Even if switching were simple and free, 62% would refuse to do so and, though 59% believed they could make savings, this was not enough to make them change. The survey found that switching rates were highest in insurance, with 53% of motorists and 30% of homeowners changing supplier - largely because it is easy to get comparative quotes and there is no one brand leader. But only 12% of borrowers have switched mortgages in the last five years even though nearly a third of those surveyed considered the option - with the majority deterred by early redemption penalties, high legal costs and the difficulty of comparing the 4,000-5,000 deals available. Switching in energy is growing, with the survey finding 37% in gas and 26% in electricity changing supplier - compared with the 28% and 20% identified by the regulator, Ofgem. The survey puts renewed pressure on telecoms watchdog Oftel to get tougher with BT after finding that just 11% of fixed-line subscribers had switched in the past five years. Cable, however, is seen as a lower quality option.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Ford puts clean-cut image into reverse

fields.headline: Ford puts clean-cut image into reverse
fields.standfirst: Being green is compatible with the long term interests of the company's shareholders. But they are not convinced, reports Roger Cowe
fields.trailText: Being green is compatible with the long term interests of the company's shareholders. But they are not convinced, reports Roger Cowe.
fields.body:
Bill Ford, chairman of the family car company, has embarked on the immense challenge of turning Ford into an environmentally friendly company since he took the chair two years ago. While his sincerity is not in doubt, the challenge has been growing since he took the reins, mainly because of the company's success with Sports Utility Vehicles (SUVs) - the gas-guzzling "off-roaders", bought in increasing numbers by American families and to a lesser extent by Europeans.

Mr Ford has acknowledged the embarrassing contrast between his rhetoric and the fact that SUV sales are driving up his company's impact on the environment rather than the reverse. But his defence is that customers want these polluting vehicles, so Ford must simply try to make them cleaner.

A more rigorous analysis has been made by two students at London Business School, in an essay which has just won a competition organised by Ashridge Management College aimed at encouraging MBA students to examine "the changing role of business in society".

John Warburton and Nick Cardoza, who shared £3,000 prize money, began by asking two crucial questions: Is Bill Ford's green image just a public relations veneer or have Ford made hard choices where protecting the environment is concerned? Does Ford's dilemma with the SUV challenge one of the most popular assumptions in business ethics: that being ethical is not incompatible with the long term interests of a company's owners?

These are serious questions, not just for Ford managers, but for others struggling with questions of corporate responsibility. And this is a serious environmental issue. Almost half of all new car sales in the US are now SUVs or light trucks (which have similar emission levels).

With engines of up to 8 litres and fuel efficiency as low as 11 mpg this popularity has helped to drive down the average fuel efficiency of all cars on the road in the US since the end of the 1980s. The prize-winning students point out the difficulty for Ford of making the right environmental choices on this issue without damaging the financial bottom line.

Last year SUVs represented a fifth of Ford's new vehicle sales. The average profit on them is $12,000 - a 40% margin compared to between 5% and 10% on a typical saloon car. As a result SUVs pulled in $5 billion in profit for Ford last year, more than half the group total.

This no doubt explains the group's reluctance to adopt a truly green stance on the issue, rather than the superficial measures which have been taken. For example, the vehicles have been made more recyclable, and emission levels have been reduced. But Ford is reluctant to support US government initiatives to price in the environmental "externalities" in an attempt to reduce customer demand, especially for the most polluting models.

In fact, on the contrary, the group continues to be a member of a body called the Coalition for Vehicle Choice (CVC), which lobbies against increased emissions and fuel efficiency obligations and against US participation in the UN global climate treaty negotiated in Kyoto three years ago.

Warburton and Cardoza say Ford is ducking the issue by being satisfied with a better environmental position than its rivals. What it should be doing, if its environmental rhetoric is serious, is to pull out of the market, or at least the most damaging end of it. "By adopting a relative rather than absolute set of measures of its environmental impact, Ford is therefore able to develop an ethical stance that does not require it to make the difficult decision to withdraw from the most inefficient SUVs," they say.

They outline a programme for Mr Ford to rescue his environmental image. The first step would be to withdraw from the CVC and any other lobby groups that seek to obstruct Federal or State level anti-emission and fuel efficiency initiatives. Then Ford should seek out and support groups or researchers who are examining the social and political barriers to greater fuel efficiency. Most fundamentally, the group must work on depressing consumer demand for the most damaging SUVs. While difficult, these steps are not impossible, and could be justified in financial terms

Supporting lobbies against greater fuel efficiency leaves Ford open to charges of hypocrisy, which could damage its reputation, while turning its back on the most inefficient vehicles could help build a potent brand image. But the authors conclude with a realistic assessment of the likelihood of such a strategy being adopted: "The SUV dilemma is challenging but not intractable for Ford.

"Within the current paradigm of business ethics (that ethical behaviour is in the long term interests of shareholders) there is more that the company can economically do to manage their environmental impact. In the absence of the foresight that these types of initiatives require, real change will probably have to wait until the SUV fad is over."

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Philip Crawford Group chief executive of InterX, which specialises in providing internet-based  marketplaces for businesses and consumers
fields.trailText: Philip Crawford Group chief executive of InterX, which specialises in providing internet-based  marketplaces for businesses and consumers.
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

In 1977 when I moved to the US as a commercial manager.

What has been your best moment in management?

Being offered President of EDS International, an $8.5 billion operation.

How would you describe your management style?

Open and collaborative with an emphasis on strong leadership and delivery of commitments.

What was your greatest mistake?

Believing that results always count in your favour above company politics!

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Virgin/Singapore Airlines. This was a magnificent effort from Richard Branson.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Failure to deliver on commitments.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

The importance of leadership over management.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

Customer acquisition/retention with new routes to market and entirely new relationships being made possible with technology.

What one lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Surround yourself with a great team and lead them effectively.

Which management guru do you believe in?

Charles Handy.

Who is your management hero?

I respected Ray Lane at Oracle immensely, as did all people in the field.

What is your view on British membership of the EMU?

There should be clearer distinction between the economic and monetary issues and the political concerns. I would also suggest that in global markets building fortress Europe now seems to be pointless.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

The conservative attitude towards growth.

Who is your favourite politician?

Michael Portillo.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

What you have to understand is...

Apart from your family, what makes you happiest in life?

Letting my hair down with friends after watching rugby.

What annoys you most?

People who are not loyal

How do you relax?

With a good book.

What was your last cultural experience?

Opera at Glyndebourne and the Sydney Olympics.

Do you have a favourite website?

Unmissable.com

What is your greatest regret?

Not having the time to enjoy Unmissable.com

What is your biggest fear?

Not being a good enough parent.

What would you really like to have been?

An actor.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: From the top

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: The US elections have shown that it requires more than a little courage to walk away from the possibility of success. What holds true in Washington is equally true within work.
fields.body:
The US elections have shown that it requires more than a little courage to walk away from the possibility of success. What holds true in Washington is equally true within work.

Some people will do whatever is necessary, fair or foul, in order to gain career advantage. Others cannot let go of a goal, even if it is unattainable and inappropriate. Then there are the rare few who take brave decisions based on an awareness of what success really means to them, even if the consequences are unpredictable.

What holds most people back from being able to do the things which would really increase their own sense of achievement is the lack of courage.

Most adults know what they are good at. They may even understand what really motivates them and what they value most, but the gap between possessing that knowledge and acting on it is the "bravery bridge".

I constantly see people who hover on one side of the bridge convinced that the gap is unsurpassable for them.

They believe that those who do manage to make changes to their lives have inherent advantages.

They were either born with the bravery gene which prepares them to recognise risk, or they have the buffer of money which removes risk: it is not difficult to be brave if you have the naivete of a two year old in ignoring the danger ahead; and it is easier to launch a low cost airline, if you have access to the Haji-Ioannou millions as a safety net against business failure.

Such beliefs provide a logical but misguided justification for not leaving a comfortable and familiar yet unsatisfying job. Any individual accorded the label "brave" will tell you that they do not see themselves as heros. The concept of bravery is an externally defined label.

Outside of literature, individuals who take certain actions are not driven by any conscious show of bravery, whether it is climbing Mount Everest, saving someone's life or continuing a normal job while living with a terminal disease.

It is the observers of the act who accord the motive. To those involved in the act there is no other choice. They are doing something which they consider true to themselves.

It is, however, by trusting that they can act in a way which is true to themselves that they show their bravery.

Bravery is not captured in DNA, but it exists within every individual. Instead of asking yourself if you have ever showed courage, ask yourself when you have acted out of a sense of compulsion and how you feel about that experience.

The examples may be unrelated to work, but they will illustrate that within every coward's body there is a brave soul waiting to be unleashed. Get the circumstances right, and those qualities cannot be held back.

Recognise the qualities that were used and they look less than spectacular on paper: persistence; getting information; finding the right people; taking small steps; picking yourself up after a setback; and knowing when to stop. Nothing that reeks of heroism, yet it leads to success when combined with conviction.

Unpicking bravery and exposing that it is made up of skills which everyone has accessed at some time, moves it away from myth and into the realms of practicality. Research has shown that career success, interpreted as getting to the top, requires risk taking decisions. In the same way career success, translated in its many other manifestations, requires the confidence to accept risk.

 Carole Pemberton, Managing Consultant, Career Matters carole.pemberton@careermattersconsulting.co.uk

fields.headline: Macs and wax are flooding the market
fields.standfirst: Storms have brought misery to many, but Eileen Sheridan reports that wet gear manufacturers are singing in the rain
fields.trailText: Storms have brought misery to many, but Eileen Sheridan reports that wet gear manufacturers are singing in the rain.
fields.body:
From sophisticated weather watchers at the Met Office down to amateurs with a bit of seaweed hanging in their kitchen window, everyone with an interest in the British climate is promising us lots and lots of lovely rain this winter.

And gloomier forecasters are also promising a few more floods to remind us of global warming and the general helplessness of human kind in the face of a force 10 gale. So we're talking wet weather gear here - waxed jackets and lots of lovely rubbery things to keep the water from your tender 21st century skin. This is not about those 'showerproof' garments that pass as raincoats in the fashion world, this is about keeping dry.

SCATS Countrystores, which has 21 outlets from Canterbury to Dorset, reports a 127% rise in rubber boot sales this year after the heavy rains. Buyer David Herbert says: "It has been staggering. The countryside and country things are once again fashionable." And the company has recently extended its range of waxed jackets and coats. SCATS sell 15 different types of welly boots from £8.99 up to £89.99.

Ordinary black wellies are okay but you'll find - as farmers did before the introduction of the classic green Hunter boot in 1956 - that they are not comfortable for long periods of wear. Made in Dumfries, Hunter boots are designed to grip the ankle and fit the calf and have a buckle at the top for a snugger fit. The boots are hand built and use up-to-date technology for lightness and comfort. Most are available in blue, as well as the classic green. And this year, says marketing director Mark Trueman, the company produced 500 pairs in red, most of which have already walked from the shops.

Hunter wellies start at £47 a pair, but you can indulge yourself with the leather lined Sovereign at £200. The range also includes wellies for children from shoe size 12 at a cost of £31. And for people faced with Noah's Ark conditions there are fisherman's waders from Hunter at prices from £53 to £99.

French manufacturers Aigle make boots with soles based on hiking boot technology - the Parcours, which was launched in 1998, is now the company's best selling boot in the UK. Like Hunters, these boots are designed to grip the ankle and hold your foot firmly. Real trendsetters can splash out on the Parcours Advantage - the first camouflage boot on the European market which costs £75. The Parcours Prestige leather lined boot costs £195 and there are waders at £95.

Colour lovers can buy Aigle boots in funky red, yellow or blue and there is a kid's version - My Boot - which retails at £17.50 and has a neat little window for a name or picture for quick identification.

Aigle is not only boots, it is rainwear as well. The Falster for men costs £89.95 and is a light breathable fabric. For women, Aigle recommends the Acadia in Goretex costing £189.95. It has a half-quilted lining, a fleece collar and comes in red, ecru or silver. Both styles come with hoods for complete cover. Another option is the Nelson full length unisex coat in PVC coated Polyamide. This costs £49.95 and packs into its own pouch which can be carried on a shoulder strap. The Nelson is available in khaki, black or navy.

The Royals' favourite wax jacket manufacturer, Barbour, has recently launched into High Street fashion with its Urban jacket, which was originally designed for motorcycling. The Urban jacket is made in waxed cotton, and features the traditional storm flap, bellows pockets, brass press studs and moleskin lined pockets which are standard with all Barbour jackets. It is designed for riding scooters and has an inner waterproof skirt and drip strip to keep your lower bits dry. Cyclists will love it, too. It costs £149.

Not everything that Barbour makes is green either. There are plenty of jackets in trendy black - the Beacon at £159, the International jacket at £149, the new classic Black Wax Jacket at £189 and the Beaufort Jacket which also comes in sage, navy and rustic and costs £159. They can be ordered on-line and the company offers a re-proofing service at £18.75.

Barbour also makes a range of rubber boots in green and blue and fishermen's waders in three styles for those flooding emergencies.

Other jacket makes to look out for are Musto, which has the Stormbeater at £159, and Toggi which does a classic brown Stockman coat at £129, both available from SCATS. Outdoors types already know about Rohan, which makes clothes for rugged wear and travel, but are also popular in town. Their Intercontinental Coat for women costs £199, is waterproof and lightweight with a detachable quilted lining and hood. Rohan's Globetrotter Mac for men and women also costs £199 and is so lightweight it can be packed into its own pocket.

But if you want a more traditional coat you will find the classic British Mackintosh at Rainmac in West Sussex. The company was set up seven years ago by Michael Orr when he realised how difficult it was to buy a proper rubberised raincoat. Since then the company has taken off and is a big exporter.

The coats are made in Scotland in the traditional way, developed in the early 19th century by Charles Mackintosh - who gave the garment its name. The process involves two layers of cloth being glued together with a solution of rubber. A classic trenchcoat for women costs £215, a riding mac £235, a hooded cape £195. Men's coats range from £183 for the Rochester to £265 for a riding mac. There is a good choice of colours, a wide range of sizes, and the coats have detachable toning plaid linings made from lambswool.

If you can't afford these prices, Rainmac sells a popular lightweight, waterproof coat for £39.99. Waterproof Teflon-coated raincoats for schoolchildren are one of Rainmac's specialities, available in traditional school uniform colours for ages from four years and upwards. Smaller sizes are £14 unlined and £24, lined, for children aged 12 and over coats cost £16 unlined and £27 lined.

For him and her: Aigle sells a range of hooded and quilted rainproof jackets

Splash out: Aigle's footwear doesn't come cheap

But if you want a more traditional coat you will find the classic British Mackintosh at Rainmac in West Sussex. The company was set up seven years ago by Michael Orr when he realised how difficult it was to buy a proper rubberised raincoat. Since then the company has taken off and is a big exporter. The coats are made in Scotland in the traditional way, developed in the early 19th century by Charles Mackintosh - who gave the garment its name. The process involves two layers of cloth being glued together with a solution of rubber. A classic trenchcoat for women costs £215, a riding mac £235, a hooded cape £195. Men's coats range from £183 for the Rochester to £265 for a riding mac. There is a good choice of colours, a wide range of sizes, and the coats have detachable toning plaid linings made from lambswool. If you can't afford these prices, Rainmac sells a popular lightweight, waterproof coat for £39.99. Waterproof Teflon-coated raincoats for schoolchildren are one of Rainmac's specialities, available in traditional school uniform colours for ages from four years and upwards. Smaller sizes are £14 unlined and £24, lined, for children aged 12 and over coats cost £16 unlined and £27 lined. webTitle: Jobs and Money: Classical instruments auctions

fields.headline: Classical cash hits high note
fields.standfirst: While the auction of guitars once strummed by rock musicians hit the headlines, Stewart Dalby finds that violins and cellos are often sold for considerably more
fields.trailText: While the auction of guitars once strummed by rock musicians hit the headlines, Stewart Dalby finds that violins and cellos are often sold for considerably more.
fields.body:
When a guitar once owned by Sir Paul McCartney or the late Jimi Hendrix sells at auction for tens of thousands of pounds or sums well above the intrinsic value of the pieces, and certainly much more than they would have fetched if sold 10 years ago, it makes headlines in the newspapers.

Yet each November in London there is a crop of auctions of fine classical items where prices can be in excess of that paid for rock memorabilia, but it rarely seems to attract publicity. London remains the world centre for fine musical instruments. The reason for the rash of sales in November is that it gets all the relevant potential buyers in one place at one time and gives them a choice.

For while those who attend the pop auctions are primarily collectors with one eye on the investment value, the fine musical instrument auctions are patronised mostly by musicians who want to own the best. Kerry Keane at Christie's says: "There are a lot of well funded orchestras around the world so there is a steady demand."

Some musicians are very well remunerated so they can afford to pay good prices for the finest instruments. Dealers do attend these auctions. But this is because some of the instruments need work done on them and the dealers can fix them up and sell them on. Non-playing collectors, although they exist, are thin on the ground, apparently.

This year first out of the starting block was Phillips whose sale on Monday November 13 was advertised as 400 years of violin making. Phillips held another sale last Monday, this time of antique and modern pianos and keyboard instruments.

At its auction on November 14, Bonhams & Brooks was hoping to break its own record for a cello. The instrument made by Michele Deconet and dating from 1769, was expected to fetch £300,000, beating the cello price of £243,000 which it set last year when it was just Bonhams.

However, it did sell an impressive violin by John Rocca made in Turin in 1851 above the estimate. It went for £128,000. Sotheby's, in its sale on November 16, also suffered a disappoint ment. It had hoped that an important harpsichord produced by one of the most prolific makers, the Kirckman family, would fetch a good price.

The Kirckmans, from Alsace, were the leading makers of harpsichords from the 18th to the 19th centuries and their output is represented by around 170 surviving instruments. A two manual English harpsichord in the sale was estimated to fetch £60,000 to £80,000, but in the event did not get away. Sotheby's did manage, however, to sell a violoncello by Jean Baptiste Vuillaume for £91,500, against an estimate of £80,000.

Similarly at the Christie's, South Kensington, sale on Wednesday November 15 (yes it was a very busy week), a rare Cremonese violoncello, circa 1778, attributed to Lorenzo Storiori sold for £80,750, against an estimate of £70,000.

Cellos are very popular at the moment. According to Phillip Scott, the specialist at Phillips, they are much easier to play for the elderly and there are number of enthusiasts in this category who want to improve their skills.

It is string instruments, not only cellos but also violas and violins, which fetch the best prices. Arguably the most famous violin maker of all time was Antonio Stradivari (1644-1737) and many maestros have or had Strads. The late Sir Yehudi Menuhin used to swear by them.

In 1998 Christie's sold the Kreutzer Stradivarius for £947,500, a record. Rudolph Kreutzer came from a French family of musicians and between 1784 and 1810 he was one of the leading concert violinists in Europe.

But he was not the only violin maker of genius. Others favour Giuseppe Guarneri del Gesu. There are also violins made by the Amati family who, like Stradivari, came from Cremona in Italy. The Frenchman Nicholas Lupot is also highly favoured.

Nigel Kennedy, having originally favoured Stradivari, now apparently has a Guarneri. Tim Ingles, Sotheby's musical instru ment specialist, feels the day is not far off when we will see a £1m Guarneri sell at auction. They are more rare. Stradivari was very prolific. He made 15 violins a year for 70 years - of the 1,000 he made or so 500 are thought still to survive. Guarneri, on the other hand, made only 50 or so in 20 years.

Ingles says: "The Guarneris are throatier - somehow they project better and this is what you need in the big concert halls of today.

Meanwhile, for those who do not have the odd million to spend, Sotheby's is holding another sale at Sotheby's South in Billingshurst in Sussex aimed at music students and enthusiastic amateurs. This inaugural sale will be on December 7 and feature 137 violins, six of which are specifically for children. All are estimated under £1,000.

Tim Ingles says: "The development of printed music in Victorian England enabled the work of great composers to become more accessible. Workshops making instruments sprang up in France and Germany, particularly in Mirecourt in the Vosges mountains and Markneukirchen in Saxony. Many of the instruments produced bore facsimile labels of the great Italian makers.

For further information:
Phillips, 020 7629 6602 Phillips
Bonhams & Brooks, 020 7393 3900, Bonhams & Brooks
Christie's, 020 7581 7611 Christie's
Sotheby's 020 7293 5000, Sotheby's
South, Billingshurst, 01403 833500.

fields.headline: Flying the flag
fields.standfirst: Tony Levene turns the spotlight on Standard Life, where fund managers are celebrating two years as a stand-alone operation
fields.trailText: Tony Levene turns the spotlight on Standard Life, where fund managers are celebrating two years as a stand-alone operation.
fields.body:
Standard Life - boring name, boring company ?

This is standard as in flag waving, not middle of the road. And the firm had more than its fair share of excitement and colour earlier this year as chief executive Scott Bell and staff fought to ward off carpetbaggers, including a convicted wife-beater who reported the board to Edinburgh police claiming fraud.

What was the fuss about?

Some policyholders wanted Standard Life to become a plc; Bell and the board wanted the status quo. Bell won - but not by much.

Would conversion have made a difference to investment performance?

It would have increased pressure on short term performance. But it would have caused little change to investment charges.

Does it manage much? How about £80bn? But only £10bn is non-life insurance money of which just £1.5bn is OEIC cash from the public.

Away from the battleground, what does it offer?

There are 15 funds in an OEIC, plus a cash fund. Standard covers most of the investment angles.

Which ones does it ignore?

There is no emerging markets fund - it is still building up expertise in this area - and, strangely for a firm which has low cost CAT-marked funds, there are no trackers, although one is authorised and ready to roll if the Footsie recovers in the New Year.

Does it run ethical funds?

Yes. It's not been going long and the one year record won't feature in adverts, although it is now climbing up the table. It mainly appeals to those who put negative criteria first. It has an ethics committee of unit-holders - investors can volunteer for duty so fund parameters can vary over time. Standard Life is keen on keeping boards in line on corporate governance issues, and threatens to name and shame directors whose greed conflicts with management responsibilities.

Do IFAs like the firm?

Yes and no. Yes, because it has a name that inspires investor confidence and you can't run into too much trouble for recommending it. But many ignore Standard, blaming zero-commission funds sold direct to the public.

What is the performance profile?

Good over the long term, but not so hot during the past three years and pretty awful over the past 12 months.

What's the excuse?

Technology. Standard Life missed out on the boom this time last year.

But they were correct eventually!

Too right now. By doing nothing, recent performance has looked up as the tech-heavy funds started to sink, although this did not help with last spring's Isa sales push. The majority of funds are above the average over the past few months. But the high income fund continues to look low - the blame lies with a lack of expertise. Standard Life intends to hire new bodies and give them greater freedom.

Are there bright spots?

The UK Smaller Companies fund is the one they like to advertise - it's been a top position fund over three years and pretty good more recently. But European Equity Growth and the non-junk bond fund have also attracted plaudits.

What about star fund managers?

In the wings for the moment. If performance improves, they'll build up UK equity specialist Amanda Forsyth for starters.

Is there a style?

It starts with a "house view" from investment boss Keith Skeoch which is then adapted by individual fund managers who use a "multi-factor approach" that ex ploits market inefficiencies to produce consistent long term outperformance".

But isn't that contradicted by recent not so bright figures?

Long term is what it says - Standard Life has been around for the best part of two centuries so it can afford to be laid back. And two years of freedom from the insurance straitjacket is not long to turn the operation around from caring about 25-year endowments and 40-year pension plans.

What about a website?

Go to standardlife.com. It has all the usual features and hopes to offer individual investor portfolio valuations online before Christmas and electronic Isa purchases by February.

And the unique selling proposition?

The public perception of its brand values - despite the demutualisation onslaught, it remains Europe's biggest mutual finance sector company.

Standard Life is keen on keeping boards in line on corporate governance issues, and threatens to name and shame directors whose greed conflicts with management responsibilities. Do IFAs like the firm? Yes and no. Yes, because it has a name that inspires investor confidence and you can't run into too much trouble for recommending it. But many ignore Standard, blaming zero-commission funds sold direct to the public. What is the performance profile? Good over the long term, but not so hot during the past three years and pretty awful over the past 12 months. What's the excuse? Technology. Standard Life missed out on the boom this time last year. But they were correct eventually! Too right now. By doing nothing, recent performance has looked up as the tech-heavy funds started to sink, although this did not help with last spring's Isa sales push. The majority of funds are above the average over the past few months. But the high income fund continues to look low - the blame lies with a lack of expertise. Standard Life intends to hire new bodies and give them greater freedom. Are there bright spots? The UK Smaller Companies fund is the one they like to advertise - it's been a top position fund over three years and pretty good more recently. But European Equity Growth and the non-junk bond fund have also attracted plaudits. What about star fund managers? In the wings for the moment. If performance improves, they'll build up UK equity specialist Amanda Forsyth for starters. Is there a style? It starts with a "house view" from investment boss Keith Skeoch which is then adapted by individual fund managers who use a "multi-factor approach" that ex ploits market inefficiencies to produce consistent long term outperformance". But isn't that contradicted by recent not so bright figures? Long term is what it says - Standard Life has been around for the best part of two centuries so it can afford to be laid back. And two years of freedom from the insurance straitjacket is not long to turn the operation around from caring about 25-year endowments and 40-year pension plans. What about a website? Go to standardlife.com. It has all the usual features and hopes to offer individual investor portfolio valuations online before Christmas and electronic Isa purchases by February. And the unique selling proposition? The public perception of its brand values - despite the demutualisation onslaught, it remains Europe's biggest mutual finance sector company. Standard bearer: Chief executive Scott Bell masterminded the defeat of the carpetbaggers

fields.headline: New twist to silent drama
fields.standfirst: A television playwright adds his voice to concerns over whether Equitable Life will find a buyer in time. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: A television playwright adds his voice to concerns over whether Equitable Life will find a buyer in time. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
Equitable Life is facing growing protests from its 'silent majority' of annuity holders as concerns grow about whether the troubled insurer will find a buyer within the timescale it promised earlier this year.

Peter Ransley, a Play for Today television writer, this week wrote to his MP, Clive Soley, and to financial regulators to force Equitable to release more information about the outlook for thousands of with-profit annuity holders. He also asks why Equitable is continuing to advertise its products when the company is up for sale.

People with annuities are not normally affected by sales or takeovers; annuity contracts provide a monthly income fixed at the outset of the plan. But thousands of Equitable personal pension holders were instead offered a hybrid annuity contract, called a with-profits annuity.

With-profits annuities work by leaving the money invested in a with-profits fund, made up of equities, bonds and property. The person taking the annuity opts for a level of income from his or her investment, and each year Equitable awards a bonus, depending on how the underlying investments have performed.

Except this year it didn't. Following the £1.5bn House of Lords ruling against the company earlier this year, Equitable suspended growth on the policies from January 1 to July 31. In effect this has reduced the value of annuity income by 1%, but it is only slowly taking impact on policyholders, as income levels on each individual policy are calculated at different dates during the year, depending on when the policy began.

Mr Ransley, who continues to write for film and television, began taking the benefits of his annuity policy four years ago, and until recently was very happy with the returns. The policy gives him a gross income of more than £40,000 a year. But now he is not so sure about its future, yet the contract, like all annuity contracts, does not allow him to transfer to another provider.

"I always assumed my annuity was ring-fenced. The pamphlets say it is low risk, which is the reason why I chose it. Now I don't know what I am going to get."

In a letter to policyholders in August, Equitable said: "It is intended that the loss of the seven months of growth will be made good from the proceeds of the sale of the business," which it hoped to announce by the end of this year.

But after an initial flurry of interest, potential buyers have slipped away, and now it is believed that only Prudential remains in the frame. Analysts say that concerns about potential future liabilities have scared off many buyers, including CGNU.

Mr Ransley says communications by Equitable to policyholders have been at best "opaque." "Last year they made a great play about smoothed returns. The stock market was very high, they discounted that but still gave us a reasonable rise. Now there is no guarantee of an increase whatsoever, or whether they really will be able to restore the lost bonus. Everybody has been writing about the personal pension holders, but it's much worse for us if things go wrong, because we are locked in."

"The worst thing is not knowing where you are with your policy. Things could drift on for another year. I'd like to see members calling for an emergency general meeting. I also think it's highly questionable that Equitable is continuing to advertise for future business while giving no indication whatsoever of the position they are currently in," says Mr Ransley.

No one is suggesting that Equitable will be unable to meet its liabilities, although future bonuses are likely to be less attractive than those in the past. In the highly unlikely event of a failure of an insurance company - and there has not been a collapse for more than 20 years - policyholders have the safety net of the Policyholders Protection Act. It gives security to 90% of the policy value if an insurer defaults, paid for by a levy on other insurers. Market participants say that the De partment of Trade and Industry is likely to intervene before a company failure to ensure an orderly transfer of business to another insurer.

Jobs & Money also received calls this week from Equitable policyholders who bought offshore policies through its Jersey arm. Equitable this week confirmed that all its Jersey policies are part of the UK with-profits fund and therefore subject to the same loss of seven months growth which it hopes to restore once a buyer is found.

Last week we said that Equitable had made cuts in its annual bonus. We would like to make clear that the cut in the bonus referred to the growth allocated to policies between January 1 and July 31, not the annual bonus.
