fields.headline: Sweat it out in the theatre of dreams
fields.standfirst: Enterprise Investment Schemes involve the highest risks but can also provide the most fun, reports Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: Enterprise Investment Schemes involve the highest risks but can also provide the most fun, reports Robin Stoddart.
fields.body:
As share prices sink under concern about the viability of new technology companies and profitability of older suppliers, fundraising by new enterprises continues apace. All sorts of businesses are offering shares in start-up operations that may help to galvanise the economy. That is if they survive.

Valuable income tax incentives and capital gains tax reliefs are available to venture capitalists willing to take high risks. Single company investment in Enterprise Investment Schemes involves the highest risk. Most investors go for the spread of investment provided by venture capital and development capital trusts.

One of the most popular recent issues with small investors was Old Vic Productions, where well-heeled punters were prepared to cough up several thousands to help out the theatre. The main incentive was tickets and invitations to dress rehearsals and functions where they might meet the stars. As with the single film projects that have raised EIS money, returns will be slow and doubtful. Only enthusiastic "angels" willing to suffer total loss may tread such boards.

Investment in an EIS business, as in any new company, should be long term. The tax relief of 20 per cent against income tax in the current tax year and exemption from capital gains tax, along with deferral of tax on gains invested in the venture, depends on retention for three years (five years before the last budget).

Shares in unquoted traded companies should also qualify for business property relief from inheritance tax. Increasingly EIS companies seek an early listing of shares on the Ofex dealing facility, enabling investors to track their value, though the market may be narrow and erratic.

Current EIS issues include e-go systems, one of the largest by value when the funding is completed next week after the previous flotation and takeover this year of Telemesser, an Israeli company in the same business communications field. As an internet operator it might have been affected by the present doubts about the sector, but with nearly a three-year history in messaging and revenues running at over £5m a year, the shares cost three times the figure at which institutions, including VCTs, subscribed a year ago. Telemesser's founders may qualify for a further 10m shares.

Timberweb is also established as an internet company providing information and aiming to trade in wood on behalf of users and world-wide suppliers. There are already over 500 members for a modest subscription charge. The shares are on offer at 80p to raise over £6m, making the total capital value £25m. A listing on the Alternative Investment Market will be sought. Golf enthusiasts may be drawn by the small EIS offer of shares in Golf Projects, which provides internet coaching services with a base in three international golf academies. Swing analysis will be a main feature so PC links as well as the outdoor ones will be a preoccupation.

The company is well-connected through arrangements with the sports management group IMG and leading players. Just £1m is being sought at 20p a share. In tennis, Sweatband is offering equipment and similar services, with subscription at 40p a share to raise £1m.

Pubs, restaurants and hotels have been part of the EIS scene almost since its inauguration and Close Brothers' sponsorship of English Country Inns to raise an initial £6m at 100p a share keeps up a well-trodden path as the big brewers disintegrate. Although leisure investments have not been among the more successful venture trust investments, the property element should be a safeguard. Sites will be acquired in prosperous southern areas.

Quality cheese and Jersey milk products will be produced by Amelca, a new company being sponsored by Matrix Securities, which is also behind many of the other large EIS issues. Nearly £10m is being sought to set up a top-notch Derbyshire plant and farmers, whose quotas have often proved unprofitable or unwanted, will be given some priority. Another natural resource company StrataGas, which aims to produce methane from coalmines, extending from existing operations in Staffordshire, has recently raised a few millions and will be back for more if US extraction methods prove successful.

Medical offerings are fairly numerous in the EIS field and Specialty Scanners has raised a small amount at 15p a share recently to finance smaller magnetic resonance equipment. Government funding is available on a 50-50 basis. Ruegg, the sponsor, previously raised funds for ReGen Therapeutics, a sheep-milk project in Poland that has the potential to provide relief for victims of Alzheimer's disease. After initial enthusiasm the AIM listed shares have fallen well below their issue price and stand at a third of their 48p peak.

Among the most volatile EIS shares have been MILS Technology, an emergency plastic strip lighting supplier for cruise liners. The shares are also now down at 18p in the Ofex list, having been as high as 72p in the year since the launch at 25p. In the flat TMT sector, the tiny PC Medics is also suffering as the Ofex price is half its 25p issue cost. But servicing continues for local PC users. Croma, the location device developer, keeps rebounding above its 15p issue price and other electronics specialists mostly report favourably on early progress, but defer the expense of listing.

fields.headline: Trust plans to house key staff
fields.standfirst: Starter homes may be answer to mayor's World City vision, reports Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: Starter homes may be answer to mayor's World City vision, reports Elizabeth Langton.
fields.body:
Plans to halt the rush of people abandoning the cities for a better life in the country were unveiled last week, when environment secretary John Prescott announced the publication of the government's Urban White Paper.

The report contained a package of measures to encourage greater investment in the cities, including five more Millennium Villages with a new one in Manchester's Cardroom Estate

At the same time a debate over the future of the capital's housing stock was kicked off by London mayor Ken Livingstone. He called for 15% of new homes built in the capital to be targeted at people on moderate incomes currently priced out of the housing market.

Homes for a World City is the final report from a Housing Commission set up by Mr Livingstone to identify the capital's housing problems. According to the Commission, led by Chris Holmes, director of homeless charity Shelter, the population of London is set to soar over the next 20 years, rising from 7.1m people to more than 8m by 2016.

The Commission says an estimated 31,800 extra homes are needed each year for the next 10 years to meet rising demand. A further 11,200 are needed for those without homes or living in poor or overcrowded conditions. Out of this total, 28,000 affordable homes are needed for those on low to moderate incomes.

A great deal of publicity is secured by the developers of swish dockside developments aimed at high rollers with six figure salaries, while those on average incomes of £20,000 are forced to take overpriced rented accommodation or more often live many miles from their place of work.

When the grind of commuting finally gets them down they abandon any idea of working in London and head for the capital's provincial sister towns and cities or the countryside. The net result is that London's schools and hospitals struggle to retain the staff needed to keep them operating. In recognition of this problem the report recommends that half of all new homes should be for those who cannot afford full market costs.

Thirty five per cent should be for those on low incomes and 15% should be part of a new intermediate housing sector. The problems outlined in the report are considerable. Richard McCarthy, chief executive of the Peabody Trust (which for years has provided Londoners with low cost housing) believes they are far from insurmountable.

At the Murray Grove estate in Hackney, the Trust has made its mark in two ways. The development is the country's first modular housing development. This means the individual modules were made in a factory in York before being transported to East London, complete with fixtures and fittings, ready for assembly within days.

The development of 30 properties was available for rental to people on moderate incomes who earn too much to qualify for social housing but have trouble meeting market rents. Murray Grove apartments are let for about 70% of the market rent in the area, says Mr McCarthy.

Affordable rented accommodation allows workers to get themselves established until they are able to move on to the housing ladder.

In the Urban White Paper, the government reiterated its promise to help key workers find homes with its Starter Home initiative, a commitment made in the Housing Green paper earlier this year.

Mr McCarthy believes that many key workers are far more likely to be attracted to rented accommodation they can afford, rather than leaping in to buy somewhere which, even if the purchase is subsidised in some way, is still more than many residents are paying.

He points out that in the capital £160,000 buys very little. The developers' constant complaint is the dearth of suitable land for residential developments. The government wants house- builders to reuse land that once housed commercial developments or factories.

The Urban White Paper promises tax credits to developers who clean up contaminated land.

Mr McCarthy believes the recent moves to tackle the capital's housing problems are proof that planners and providers are moving towards a consensus - one he believes will cater for a wide range of workers.

fields.headline: Near the mark
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the limitations on freedom of speech
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the limitations on freedom of speech
fields.body:
This week the editor of Guardian Unlimited ordered the deletion of a thread, a "conversation" between registered users of our website, about paedophilia, bringing down upon himself accusations of stifling legitimate debate, or, more strongly, of censorship.

He took the extraordinary step of posting on the site an explanation of his reasons for bringing the debate to an abrupt end and deleting the record of it. This is what he said, "I'm sorry, talkers, but this thread - while a generally intelligent discussion - isn't something we're happy to continue on our site.

"The reason, more pragmatically, is that this thread [in which the question was posed, 'Paedophilia: good or evil?'] is causing a great deal of offence to a number of other users, and is not something that I can comfortably defend on the website of a national newspaper - just as I cannot imagine a similar unmediated debate taking place on a professional radio station or in a mainstream magazine (or even the Guardian).

"Thank you," he concluded, optimistically perhaps, "for your understanding."

Among the responses to his decision were the following comments: "Debate brings things into the open. And you can only face up to a problem if you know what the problem is"; and "So we can't talk about murder, rape, burglary, the despoliation of the environment, etc, because by simply discussing it, we legitimise it?"

Between the calls for complete freedom of debate - and it is highly debatable whether such a thing has ever existed in the mass media - and the cries of distress from people deeply offended by aspects of the discussion, the editor acted swiftly, switched off the lights and told everyone to go home.

I did not see the thread before it was deleted and I was only asked for a view after that had happened. However, I have spoken to the website's user-help executive, who has among her duties the monitoring of the talkboards. She told me that it had been considered necessary to remove two postings from the paedophilia thread and to send warning emails to the individuals responsible for the deleted comments pointing out that they were in breach of the rules they had accepted when registering to use the site - more about those in a moment. She had no doubt of the genuine distress experienced by the people who called her to complain.

The editor of the website, who continues to believe that his decision in this case was the right one, is a keen advocate of free exchange on the Guardian talkboards, with as little intervention as possible. He likens a talkboard to a salon, or perhaps with even more ambition, to Dr Johnson's coffee shop, a place where you can drop in, listen to or participate in a civilised conversation about anything, and leave and return at will. Normally, the thing that determines the deletion of a thread is its exhaustion or abandonment. When no one has visited it for a week, it goes.

There are many thousands of these conversations or threads running on the web at any time and you can sample many of them at www.deja.com/usenet. The editor believes the standard of those running on Guardian talkboards is among the highest. The provision of a forum of this kind appears to be appreciated. "We get about 25,000 postings a week just on the news talkboards," he told me.

Slightly controversially, he believes that the reason this facility on the Guardian's website has been so successful is the lightness of touch employed in its monitoring. A second user-help person is about to be employed, one of whose functions will be to supervise the talkboards to see that nothing prejudices the reputation they are acquiring for civilised debate.

Before users of the website can participate in these debates they have to register, and the terms of registration, which require the name, address and email address of the person registering, are clearly set out. Section 6 deals with talk or discussion boards and one of the things it requires of those taking part is that they warrant that the material they submit "is not obscene, offensive, defamatory of any person or otherwise illegal".

What the Guardian is calling for, it seems to me, is what it has tried to practise itself since 1821, that is, the exercise of freedom with responsibility. Here is an extract from the paper's first leader: "When the influence of the periodical press upon the public morals and conduct is so great... he who connects himself with it, ought not to regard as an indifferent matter, the principles he may attempt to disseminate, or the conduct he may endeavour to induce. His first care should be that his pages are not stained by any thing offensive to correct moral feeling..."

We have loosened up a bit since then, but the general idea remains, and the Guardian is the Guardian, on paper or on a website. It should still be possible to have a decent argument.

He took the extraordinary step of posting on the site an explanation of his reasons for bringing the debate to an abrupt end and deleting the record of it. This is what he said, "I'm sorry, talkers, but this thread - while a generally intelligent discussion - isn't something we're happy to continue on our site. "The reason, more pragmatically, is that this thread [in which the question was posed, 'Paedophilia: good or evil?'] is causing a great deal of offence to a number of other users, and is not something that I can comfortably defend on the website of a national newspaper - just as I cannot imagine a similar unmediated debate taking place on a professional radio station or in a mainstream magazine (or even the Guardian). "Thank you," he concluded, optimistically perhaps, "for your understanding." Among the responses to his decision were the following comments: "Debate brings things into the open. And you can only face up to a problem if you know what the problem is"; and "So we can't talk about murder, rape, burglary, the despoliation of the environment, etc, because by simply discussing it, we legitimise it?" Between the calls for complete freedom of debate - and it is highly debatable whether such a thing has ever existed in the mass media - and the cries of distress from people deeply offended by aspects of the discussion, the editor acted swiftly, switched off the lights and told everyone to go home. I did not see the thread before it was deleted and I was only asked for a view after that had happened. However, I have spoken to the website's user-help executive, who has among her duties the monitoring of the talkboards. She told me that it had been considered necessary to remove two postings from the paedophilia thread and to send warning emails to the individuals responsible for the deleted comments pointing out that they were in breach of the rules they had accepted when registering to use the site - more about those in a moment. She had no doubt of the genuine distress experienced by the people who called her to complain. The editor of the website, who continues to believe that his decision in this case was the right one, is a keen advocate of free exchange on the Guardian talkboards, with as little intervention as possible. He likens a talkboard to a salon, or perhaps with even more ambition, to Dr Johnson's coffee shop, a place where you can drop in, listen to or participate in a civilised conversation about anything, and leave and return at will. Normally, the thing that determines the deletion of a thread is its exhaustion or abandonment. When no one has visited it for a week, it goes. There are many thousands of these conversations or threads running on the web at any time and you can sample many of them at www.deja.com/usenet. The editor believes the standard of those running on Guardian talkboards is among the highest. The provision of a forum of this kind appears to be appreciated. "We get about 25,000 postings a week just on the news talkboards," he told me. Slightly controversially, he believes that the reason this facility on the Guardian's website has been so successful is the lightness of touch employed in its monitoring. A second user-help person is about to be employed, one of whose functions will be to supervise the talkboards to see that nothing prejudices the reputation they are acquiring for civilised debate. Before users of the website can participate in these debates they have to register, and the terms of registration, which require the name, address and email address of the person registering, are clearly set out. Section 6 deals with talk or discussion boards and one of the things it requires of those taking part is that they warrant that the material they submit "is not obscene, offensive, defamatory of any person or otherwise illegal". What the Guardian is calling for, it seems to me, is what it has tried to practise itself since 1821, that is, the exercise of freedom with responsibility. Here is an extract from the paper's first leader: "When the influence of the periodical press upon the public morals and conduct is so great... he who connects himself with it, ought not to regard as an indifferent matter, the principles he may attempt to disseminate, or the conduct he may endeavour to induce. His first care should be that his pages are not stained by any thing offensive to correct moral feeling..." We have loosened up a bit since then, but the general idea remains, and the Guardian is the Guardian, on paper or on a website. It should still be possible to have a decent argument.  Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. webTitle: Jobs and Money: Know your banking rights

fields.headline: Know your rights at the bank
fields.trailText: Last week Jobs & Money highlighted the amounts some banks charge for providing duplicate statements.
fields.body:
Last week Jobs & Money highlighted the amounts some banks charge for providing duplicate statements.

Among the worst offenders were Lloyds TSB at £5 per sheet for a current account, and the Woolwich at £25 for a mortgage statement. However, the Data Protection Act can save customers, particularly those who need lots of old statements, a great deal of money.

Under that Act on payment of a £10 fee, anyone is entitled to information about them held on computer by a business. In divorce cases, where parties may be asked to disclose discarded bank statements, this is a useful money-saving device.

Surprisingly, some solicitors are not aware of it and their clients end up paying the banks' exorbitant charges. The Act can also be relied on by people who want statements for borrowing or tax purposes. All that is needed is a written request to the institution in question. The Act requires the business to comply "promptly" and, in any case, within 40 days from receiving the request.

If loss, such as a tax penalty, results from its failure to comply, compensation is payable. When asked about this, a spokesman for the Woolwich conceded that anyone paying the fee could save at least £15 this way. Lloyds TSB said its records were only kept on computer for one year. Since the Act was reintroduced in 1998 such records can be covered, as well as those on a computer's hard disk. Where there are particular difficulties accessing microfiche records, businesses won't have to comply until 2001.

Suitably embarrassed by the revelation that it charges most for duplicates, Lloyds TSB has said it will cap the charge at £10, regardless of the number of statements requested. In reality, complying with a request under the Act is much more expensive and cumbersome for a bank than producing a single statement. Someone who needs a statement may find it threatening to make a request for full information under the Act resulting in the bank agreeing to waive its charge.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Advice on mortgage

fields.standfirst:
In the clinic: Simon Battersby:
Age: 30
Occupation: Publisher
fields.trailText: Simon Battersby and his girlfriend, both aged 30, are about to start looking for a mortgage.
fields.body:
Simon Battersby and his girlfriend, both aged 30, are about to start looking for a mortgage.

At the moment they both rent, but the publisher and typesetter would like to buy a property in London - they are currently living in Ealing. "We have done a bit of research into all this and have checked out the terminology, for instance. We have been advised to stay away from endowment mortgages and to go for a capital and interest one instead, and I think we have settled on a fixed rate mortgage.

"We feel it could be a good investment and could even save on our rent. We've even made an appointment with one adviser. Nationwide is in many of the best buy tables, and as I have an account with them they know my savings history. But we still have more questions about the mortgage."

Simon has been in his current job for four months, but was with his previous employer for three years, while his girlfriend has worked for 18 months in her present position and was two and a half years in her previous post.

He says: "I have saved around £10,000 for a downpayment in Isas, Tessas and bank and building society accounts." His girlfriend is less solvent, however. "She has credit card debt of £2,200 with her Cooperative Bank card, although she has an Invesco Isa, worth around £1,800."

Apart from his main concern over the type of repayment method for the loan, he raises the issue of his girlfriend's credit card debt. "When we apply for the mortgage, I presume my girlfriend's credit card debt will be taken into account. I am debating whether it would be better to pay off the credit card debt with the money in her Isa, or whether we try to pay off the debt gradually," he says.

First you need to look at affordability. You are only four months into your present role: is there a probationary period? Often a lender will require a borrower to be out of this period to give them more security.

Next, the repayment method. You should bear in mind that whichever you choose it needs to reflect your attitude to risk: if you are risk averse, you may want to go with a repayment mortgage which will guarantee to repay the borrowing at the end of the term. But if you are happy with the risk associated with direct equity investment, then you could go for an Isa mortgage in a bid for a higher rate of return.

In terms of the deposit, the bigger you make it the better rate you can obtain. The level of risk being taken on by the lender in your case will be high and so detrimental to your chances of negotiating a good rate. It would be in your interest to avoid having to pay a Mig (mortgage indemnity guarantee). This is normally only charged to you when the loan is greater than 90% of the property's value.

A few lenders do not charge a Mig: Nationwide is one, and it has a 6.19% rate fixed for two years. For a longer period of security, look at the Cheltenham &Gloucester five year fixed loan at 6.59% with no Mig. Finally, the credit card debt. Each lender looks at this differently. Most assume a certain amount of interest is paid monthly and deduct this from the estimate of your total gross earnings. This can be anything from 3-5%, or £792-£1,320 a year. At present, the joint income of £40,000 would allow a borrowing of about £96,000-£130,000.

Is the investment return from the Isa (which is a long term investment) greater than the amount you pay each month towards reducing your credit card debt? If it is, then leave the card balance outstanding, but be aware that if you do this, the maximum amount you can borrow will be reduced by around £10,000.

 Johannes Kennard; Chase de Vere

fields.headline: More rapid reactions
fields.trailText: Has it ever occurred to the British government that there are some young people who would be eminently suited to, and who would welcome the opportunity to serve in an EU Rapid Reaction Force (General caught in Euro conflict, November 24)?
fields.body:
Has it ever occurred to the British government that there are some young people who would be eminently suited to, and who would welcome the opportunity to serve in an EU Rapid Reaction Force (General caught in Euro conflict, November 24)?

Our son, 19, is a British citizen and is currently a member of a British university army regiment, whilst studying medicine. He grew up in Luxembourg, speaks four languages fluently and his dream is to join an EU RRF. There are young people who wish to actively participate in European peacekeeping and for whom it is irrelevant whether orders come from Whitehall or Brussels.
Pamela Hill
Sandweiler, Luxembourg

 The rightwingers who oppose the creation of a Euro army need to wake up and smell the coffee. If Dubya finally claws his way into the Whitehouse, American interest in affairs overseas may well go into sharp decline and we'll be left to sort out our own problems. Isn't it touching that the Eurosceptics rely so heavily on the continued internationalism of Clinton and Gore? Unfortunately the US electoral system may frustrate them.
Phil Woodford
Teddington, Middx
king_copy@hotmail.com

 Has anyone told the Daily Mail that even a distinguished general with an SAS background cannot effect the physical contortions necessary to "stand supinely by"? Or maybe they would prefer the creation of a "European supine army".
Ian Schofield
London

fields.trailText:
Government exhortations to discourage drink driving at Christmas are commendable, but lack special enforcement measures (Sobering images to discourage drink-drivers, November 24). Perhaps, next December, they should be coupled with a major reduction in the blood-alcohol limit?
Laurence Collis
Banstead, Surrey

webTitle: Online auctions up the ante for Sony

fields.headline: Online auctions up the ante for Sony
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: As night follows day, the hapless Christmas shopper will be met each year with a point blank shortage of the must-have consumable.
fields.body:
As night follows day, the hapless Christmas shopper will be met each year with a point blank shortage of the must-have consumable.

This year, hype in full flow, it was Sony's turn to frustrate with the launch of its all-singing, all-dancing games console, PlayStation 2.

Practically unobtainable unless a forward-thinking buyer had pre-ordered months in advance, the PSX2, as it has been dubbed by the marketing people, had managed to create its own black market within hours of going on sale.

The internet, home to online auction sites, was the main culprit, with the entreprenuerial already posting their PSX2s for sale and receiving bids in excess of £500 for the £299 machine.

Supply has been outstripped by demand as the console, which can play DVD movies and surf the internet as well as play games, cannot be bought off the shelf.

The rush to reserve the 165,000 consoles available has meant that every one arriving in the UK between now and Christmas is accounted for. Consumers paid £25 to make a reservation.

David Wilson, head of PR at Sony UK, said pre-ordering was introduced after factories in Japan hit problems manufacturing the microchips for the console. In addition, the company underestimated the "truly staggering demand".

With demand outstripping supply, a "grey market" has already emerged.

Dozens of PSX2s were on offer to the highest bidder on auction internet sites yesterday. On the QXL site, eager buyers were bidding as much as five times the retail price for the console. One seller from Harrow, in north London, was prepared to ship the equipment anywhere in the world, if the buyer paid the shipping fee. On the ebay site, several consumers offered between £500 and £700 for the product.

In HMV on London's Oxford Street yesterday, one young shopper said his friend had bought four reservations at £25 each and sold each one at a 400% profit.

However, customers clutching their pre-order paperwork formed an orderly queue. Vince Gallagher, 32, placed his order in September after reading about the system months before in the PlayStation offical magazine. He took yesterday afternoon off work devote to his new toy.

Phil Evans of the Consumers' Association said: "It may be that Sony are focusing on the US market. If supplies are being diverted to the States, that may well backfire on Sony. The real money is made later on the software."

fields.headline: An agoraphobic nation
fields.standfirst:
Equating Britain with the 'third world' is offensive, and shows just how close we are to 
losing all notion of how the other half lives
fields.trailText:
Equating Britain with the 'third world' is offensive, and shows just how close we are to 
losing all notion of how the other half lives
fields.body:
I once heard Graham Greene being asked why his fictional landscape was so seedy, and where all that decay and dilapidation came from. He seemed baffled by the question. There was nothing made up about the world of decaying hotels, sleazy capitals and scrofulous villages, he said. This was how most of humanity lived, even if it was alien to western critics reading his novels in the comfort of their middle-class sitting rooms. What English Lit primers have taught us to call Greeneland, in other words, is not Greeneland at all - for most of the world's population, it is banal reality.

I have been reminded of this exchange in recent weeks. As thousands of homes have been evacuated, the fuel protest sputtered into new life, trains slowed to a crawl and the Phillips report reminded us of BSE, we've been told repeatedly that Britain has fallen to the level of a developing nation, no better than a banana republic. "Third world visitor arriving in Britain would feel entirely at home," declared the Sunday Times.

Well, hang on a moment. It's true that, as greyness takes hold after a missed summer, the relentless peevishness of Radio 4's Today programme strikes a chord each grim morning. But let's retain a sense of proportion. The four killed at Hatfield don't really stack up against the hundreds who regularly die in Philippines ferry sinkings. The number of Ugandans felled by ebola has already overtaken the toll from variant CJD. Two dead in flooding hardly compares with the numbers drowned in Mozambique. It's been a disaster for a generation of VCRs, microwaves and fitted carpets, but the cemeteries are hardly bursting. "Mrs Smith lost everything," we constantly hear. Everything except her life, her children, her savings, her insurance and her right to free hospital treatment.

I'm not sneering at the individuals involved. I spoke recently to the father of a CJD victim, and it was one of the most poignant interviews I've ever conducted. But equating Britain with the so-called third world is sloppy thinking. Verging on the offensive, it only shows how close we are to losing all notion of how the other half - more like five-sixths - actually live.

Before moving here, I spent six years in Africa. My time there reshaped my view of the world, an effect only now wearing off. Accustomed to negotiating potholed roads, I found myself admiring the smoothness of the Tarmac during visits to London. "This road surface is excellent," I'd enthuse, to general puzzlement. I still fight the impulse, when running a tap at a friend's place, to ask, "Is this water safe to drink?"

But the real difference between life in a banana republic and a country such as Britain isn't the amenities. It lies in the way an ordinary citizen regards the state and is treated by its supposed agents: policemen, customs officials, soldiers - pimply young men with guns, empty pockets and arbitrary powers.

Meeting up recently with my closest friend in Kinshasa, capital of what is now euphemistically called the Democratic Republic of Congo, we struggled to find words for the constant sense of apprehension that dogged our lives over there. "It was like swimming with sharks," she said. She was a diplomat, but that hadn't stopped her being mugged by a soldier holding a gun to her head. A journalist colleague who tried to cross a border post spent six hours driving around with several policemen who loudly debated whether to kill her and her companion because they thought they were spies. The last time I was in Kinshasa, I sat powerless in my car as soldiers took my driver, who had driven through a newly-erected road sign, to a shed and threatened to whip him unless he paid up.

Fear of the red-eyed man in uniform whose breath stinks of beer is what the third world is all about. It's the reason why the sight of some adolescent in Camden Town sporting military camouflage never fails to curl my lip. "If you like the army so much, why don't you sign up?" I want to say. Like a concentration camp survivor confronted with an "ironic" swastika, I'm incapable of getting the joke. And, like most people who've spent substantial periods of time in the real third world, I find I'm talking a language few here understand. Before flying to Congo on a research trip, I remember confessing to a friend that I was feeling very nervous, although I knew things would be fine once I'd got through the airport. "The airport?" she queried, wondering, perhaps, if I had a thing about conveyor belts. Yes, the airport, the place where you had to go through seven different customs, police and army checkpoints, each staffed by bullies wanting their bribe.

Such ignorance extends across the range. A dining companion recently politely asked me whether Congo had much of a tourism industry, a remark that made me splutter into my mineral water: "Actually, most people spend their time trying to get out, rather than trying to get in." A bright young colleague, writing about the environment, wondered why heavy rains cause diseases in the third world. "Because in most cities the sewers are open and run alongside the houses, so when there's a flood they overflow and you end up drinking sewage", is the simple answer.

But why should they know? My own profession has been responsible for a national battening down of the hatches, a withering of public curiosity. Each time I've returned to Britain in the past 15 years, the media porthole through which the country views the outside world seems to have got smaller. Now, it has telescoped to agoraphobic level, the perspective of a Darby-and-Joan couple who want to potter around the garden, do a little decorating and, to be honest, prefer their pets to the grandchildren.

The broadcast time allotted to foreign news has been steadily reduced. "You can't be pie-in-the-sky about these things," a television producer once told me. "The public simply isn't interested." But it's a self-fulfilling prophecy. People aren't going to be interested in things they know so little about. In many of the countries I've worked in, news that the army is being dispatched to deal with a natural disaster is enough to send the locals running, so sure are they it means the rape of their daughters and looting of their homes. Residents of the real Greeneland, many of whom would give their eye teeth to move here - BSE, fuel protests and floods notwithstanding - know what we too easily forget. Only when Mrs Smith is catching cholera and soldiers sent to lay sandbags are carting off the family television set will we have the right to call Britain a third world country.

 Michela Wrong is the author of In The Footsteps Of Mr Kurtz: Living On The Brink Of Disaster In The Congo, published by Fourth Estate at £13.99. Julie Burchill is away.

The number of Ugandans felled by ebola has already overtaken the toll from variant CJD. Two dead in flooding hardly compares with the numbers drowned in Mozambique. It's been a disaster for a generation of VCRs, microwaves and fitted carpets, but the cemeteries are hardly bursting. "Mrs Smith lost everything," we constantly hear. Everything except her life, her children, her savings, her insurance and her right to free hospital treatment. I'm not sneering at the individuals involved. I spoke recently to the father of a CJD victim, and it was one of the most poignant interviews I've ever conducted. But equating Britain with the so-called third world is sloppy thinking. Verging on the offensive, it only shows how close we are to losing all notion of how the other half - more like five-sixths - actually live. Before moving here, I spent six years in Africa. My time there reshaped my view of the world, an effect only now wearing off. Accustomed to negotiating potholed roads, I found myself admiring the smoothness of the Tarmac during visits to London. "This road surface is excellent," I'd enthuse, to general puzzlement. I still fight the impulse, when running a tap at a friend's place, to ask, "Is this water safe to drink?" But the real difference between life in a banana republic and a country such as Britain isn't the amenities. It lies in the way an ordinary citizen regards the state and is treated by its supposed agents: policemen, customs officials, soldiers - pimply young men with guns, empty pockets and arbitrary powers. Meeting up recently with my closest friend in Kinshasa, capital of what is now euphemistically called the Democratic Republic of Congo, we struggled to find words for the constant sense of apprehension that dogged our lives over there. "It was like swimming with sharks," she said. She was a diplomat, but that hadn't stopped her being mugged by a soldier holding a gun to her head. A journalist colleague who tried to cross a border post spent six hours driving around with several policemen who loudly debated whether to kill her and her companion because they thought they were spies. The last time I was in Kinshasa, I sat powerless in my car as soldiers took my driver, who had driven through a newly-erected road sign, to a shed and threatened to whip him unless he paid up. Fear of the red-eyed man in uniform whose breath stinks of beer is what the third world is all about. It's the reason why the sight of some adolescent in Camden Town sporting military camouflage never fails to curl my lip. "If you like the army so much, why don't you sign up?" I want to say. Like a concentration camp survivor confronted with an "ironic" swastika, I'm incapable of getting the joke. And, like most people who've spent substantial periods of time in the real third world, I find I'm talking a language few here understand. Before flying to Congo on a research trip, I remember confessing to a friend that I was feeling very nervous, although I knew things would be fine once I'd got through the airport. "The airport?" she queried, wondering, perhaps, if I had a thing about conveyor belts. Yes, the airport, the place where you had to go through seven different customs, police and army checkpoints, each staffed by bullies wanting their bribe. Such ignorance extends across the range. A dining companion recently politely asked me whether Congo had much of a tourism industry, a remark that made me splutter into my mineral water: "Actually, most people spend their time trying to get out, rather than trying to get in." A bright young colleague, writing about the environment, wondered why heavy rains cause diseases in the third world. "Because in most cities the sewers are open and run alongside the houses, so when there's a flood they overflow and you end up drinking sewage", is the simple answer. But why should they know? My own profession has been responsible for a national battening down of the hatches, a withering of public curiosity. Each time I've returned to Britain in the past 15 years, the media porthole through which the country views the outside world seems to have got smaller. Now, it has telescoped to agoraphobic level, the perspective of a Darby-and-Joan couple who want to potter around the garden, do a little decorating and, to be honest, prefer their pets to the grandchildren. The broadcast time allotted to foreign news has been steadily reduced. "You can't be pie-in-the-sky about these things," a television producer once told me. "The public simply isn't interested." But it's a self-fulfilling prophecy. People aren't going to be interested in things they know so little about. In many of the countries I've worked in, news that the army is being dispatched to deal with a natural disaster is enough to send the locals running, so sure are they it means the rape of their daughters and looting of their homes. Residents of the real Greeneland, many of whom would give their eye teeth to move here - BSE, fuel protests and floods notwithstanding - know what we too easily forget. Only when Mrs Smith is catching cholera and soldiers sent to lay sandbags are carting off the family television set will we have the right to call Britain a third world country.  Michela Wrong is the author of In The Footsteps Of Mr Kurtz: Living On The Brink Of Disaster In The Congo, published by Fourth Estate at £13.99. Julie Burchill is away.

fields.headline: No charm and plenty of offence is the railway response to a state of chaos
fields.trailText: I was on a commuter train at our local station. It had arrived 10 minutes late - pretty good going for South-west Trains these days - and a smartly dressed chap dashed down the platform and gratefully clambered on board.
fields.body:
I was on a commuter train at our local station. It had arrived 10 minutes late - pretty good going for South-west Trains these days - and a smartly dressed chap dashed down the platform and gratefully clambered on board. Five minutes later a two-man team of "revenue protection inspectors" arrived in our carriage. I waved my ticket, but the newcomer explained that he hadn't had time to buy one. He'd just seen the train and run for it.

The team - they included a good cop type, a morose bearded man, and a bad cop, who happened to be black - moved in on him as if he were a hooligan caught dragging breeze blocks on to the line. What right had he got to get on this train without a ticket? The booking office was open; they knew that. Did he realise that he now qualified for a £10 fine?

The bad cop was very aggressive. I chipped in and pointed out that for weeks now the service has been appalling, and that having waited up to half an hour for delayed trains, nobody was going to let one go by, especially if they were ready to buy a ticket on board.

With which the bad cop turned on me and barked: "We've dealt with you. You keep out of this. This is none of your business, understand?" before returning to harangue the other passenger, who made the point that the month's chaos had probably cost him hundreds of pounds worth of business. "I don't want to buy a ticket, then watch the train disappear knowing I might have to wait another hour."

They continued abusing him angrily for 10 minutes, gave him a £10 penalty ticket, then lost interest and marched down the train in search of fresh victims. I would give the bad cop's name, except I'm afraid the company would promote him.

I reflected that such people must often get a pretty awful time from loutish youths and that getting your retaliation in first might help matters, but then wondered why they didn't relax a little when faced with a clearly honest man.

And also I pondered on a privatised system which makes "revenue protection" so much more important than providing a decent service in the first place.

At a time when its unhappy passengers loathe Brian Souter's company, he seems to think it's a sensible idea to send aggressive toughs to act as their corporate face.

He's probably right to do so. As monopolies, the railways must be the only businesses in which it makes sound financial sense to leave your customers gibbering with rage and frustration.

Accepting his award for Survivor of the Year at the Spectator/Highland Park parliamentary awards this week (I'm one of the judges) Ken Livingstone gave a graceful little speech, full of that artificial modesty which makes him so endearing. At one point he said that he thought his becoming mayor of London had done the Labour party a great favour. "If someone hadn't stood up to them on London elections, what might they have tried next?" he asked rhetorically, and a voice from the room asked: "Florida?"

A week ago I got sciatica, probably from doing exercises in too vigorous and unplanned a fashion. I thought at first it would be a useful foretaste of the pains which will wrack my body in great age, but then I found myself envious of people 25 years older than me who seem perfectly capable of standing up and even walking without wanting to scream. Sciatica is not really a proper illness; it just means that something is wrong with the sciatic nerve, and is no more specific than a "headache".

That doesn't stop half the people you meet from sharing their experiences. Almost all are bad. "Sciatica? Oooh, that's agony. I really feel for you," said one friend, who then cheered me up by saying that two days in bed had cured him. The chap who came round to repair the dishwasher was much gloomier. "You'll have that for months," he said. "Months it took me. Bloody awful."

I'm lucky because when I'm sitting or lying down the pain is replaced by a mild discomfort, so at least I can sleep and work - though journeys have to be planned so that there is sure to be a seat on the train or bus. The odd thing is that when I do sit down the relief is so intense that a kind of euphoria sweeps through me.

It feels almost chemical in its strength. I feel strangely content, and think I could live very happily like this, just provided I never have to stand up again.

'What did the IRA learn from watching Riverdance?" I was asked the other day. The answer is that you have the arms, but you just don't use them. I was reminded of this by your letters and emails about Ulster-Scots, the dialect language whose supporters are demanding parity with the Irish language under the Belfast agreement.

Rather churlish, some of the letters, implying that only Irish culture is culture at all, and that anything the Prods come up with, apart from marching and assassination, must be fake. And it's true that when a an official advert appeared asking for an Ulster-Scots speaking sub-editor for Northern Ireland Hansard under a "leemited-tairm contraick" at a "sellerie of £13,737 tae £19,215" no-one could be found to use "this bizarre mixture of pidgin, gibberish and slang" as Kevin Casey puts it.

Still, I loved the recent news story about Ulster-Scots street signs being put up in Castlereagh, and then promptly ripped down by loyalists who thought they were Irish. Tullyard Way appeared as "Heichbrae Eirt", at the request of some Prods who presumably forgot to pass on the good news about this ancient traditional language to their more militant co-religionists.

Once again it's time for my round-up of your best Christmas circular letters.

What would be really helpful this year would be for you to mark the best bits before you send them in. Last year so many came - for which very many thanks - that I just didn't have time to plough through every single line for the most joyful nuggets.

fields.headline: BSE panic spreads across Europe
fields.standfirst:
First cases reported in Germany and Spain amid calls for UK ban on French beef

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The European Union was last night trying to contain consumer panic over beef as the first cases of BSE emerged in Germany and the Azores.
fields.body:
The European Union was last night trying to contain consumer panic over beef as the first cases of BSE emerged in Germany and the Azores.

Only 24 hours earlier, Spain discovered two cows infected with the disease while infection is spreading in France. Twelve European countries have now reported the disease.

Reports of the first suspected home-grown BSE case in Germany means the three largest EU herds have the disease. France's 20m cattle account for 25% of the 80m cattle in the EU. Germany has a herd of 18m and Britain 12m.

Only Austria, Italy, Sweden and Finland in the EU now have no recorded cases but the European commission in Brussels says this is no cause for complacency.

German authorities were last night promising to introduce new controls on animal feed on Monday in an attempt to shore up consumer confidence. Health minister Andrea Fischer admitted that the time for "sweet talking the situation in Germany is over".

The commission was putting a brave face on the latest crisis, saying cases in new countries came as no surprise. British sources advised against farmers rubbing their hands with glee at the misfortunes of those who questioned the safety of British beef in the 90s.

They fear the insidious spread of the disease through Europe can only undermine confidence in meat here and are nervous about a political backlash from European partners who are convinced that Britain exported the problem.

The EU health and consumer protection commissioner David Byrne said he would be pressing for "maximum control measures" when Europe's agriculture ministers meet on December 4.

Mr Byrne said the commission had warned for years of the probability of the spread of BSE to other states. Although parts of cattle most at risk had been removed from cattle in most member states, "it is only very recently that countries like Germany and Spain have agreed to do so," he said.

The German chancellor Gerhard Schröder said a full scale ban on feeds containing meat and bone meal was likely to take effect in Germany on Monday after it emerged that a cow born and slaughtered in Germany tested positive for BSE for the first time.

It was also announced that BSE had spread to Portugal's mid-Atlantic territory, the Azores through an animal imported from Germany.

The developments came amid growing calls in Britain to ban French beef after a claims that infected French beef has found its way into the UK. But the Food Standards Agency chief, Sir John Krebs, said there was insufficient evidence to support an unlawful ban on imports of French beef.

That decision is now likely to continue to be the subject of scrutiny following decisions by Spain, Austria, Greece, Italy and Holland to impose partial bans on French beef.

There is also some concern about what happens if cases of variant CJD rise across Europe. Eighty-one people have died of the disease in Britain while there has been one death in Ireland and two in France.

The commission said last night: "We think the measures we have in place are sufficiently rigorous but this reinforces the need to implement them fully. The commission never excluded the possibility that there would be cases in countries where there were none up to now. It is not a surprise."

Britain's beef consumption has been rising since it dived to 740,000 tonnes in 1996, when the link between BSE and vCJD was established. Consumption is up to 900,000 tonnes but prices have never recovered to pre-crisis levels, when consumption was well over 1.1bn tonnes. Germany exports about 1,300 tonnes of beef a year to Britain, 77,000 tonnes from Ireland and 4,800 tonnes from France.

British officials are visiting France next week to conduct safety checks on beef exported from there. EU-wide bans on the most risky parts of cattle have only just been introduced after years of wrangling and the testing programme is about to be stepped up.

Reported cases:

Britain 177,465

Ireland 546 (includes 10 imports)

Portugal 453 (includes seven imports)

Switzerland 364

France 179 (one import)

Belgium 18

Germany 7 (six imports)

Netherlands 6

Denmark 2 (one import)

Liechtenstein 2

Spain 2

Luxembourg 1

webTitle: After the revolution: a Christian report on Iran

fields.headline: After the revolution: a Christian report on Iran
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: I have just led a church delegation to the Islamic republic of Iran. It aimed to engage in inter-religious dialogue, monitor human rights and support Christian and other minority communities.
fields.body:
I have just led a church delegation to the Islamic republic of Iran. It aimed to engage in inter-religious dialogue, monitor human rights and support Christian and other minority communities.

Change is occurring in Iran; there is foreign investment, women are visible and, at least in the cities, the dress code has been relaxed. In some respects, the position of women is better than before 1979. Religious and ethnic minorities are also a little more relaxed, and appear to be freer than in the early revolutionary years. There seems to be a policy of fostering inter-faith dialogue.

But, it has to be said, the United Nations' special rapporteur has noted a worsening of the human rights situation, especially in relation to the trial of Jews for espionage, the situation of the Bahais - with some marginal improvements - and the press clampdown.

Most people we met were aware that the expectations of the early days of Khatami's presidency and the new majlis (parliament), had been unrealistic, and that change must come more cautiously and gradually. There is a struggle going on for the nation's soul between an old guard that wishes to preserve the purity of the revolution's ideals, and those who want the values of an ancient civilisation reasserted and who would like Iran, once again, to open up to the outside world.

We found an eagerness for this kind of contact. The deeply-rooted mystical and anti-clerical aspects of Iranian Islam are coming to the fore, once again, as is the desire for a diverse and tolerant society.

The meetings with those responsible for education, including clerical education, showed a deep awareness of western intellectual and social currents. Traditionally dressed ayatollahs and Hojjatul-Islams showed a lively interest in, for example, post-modernism and the deconstructionists. The implications for hermeneutics which this raised in relation to sacred texts, and the ways in which traditional exegesis was responding to these challenges, were matters of mutual interest.

Such attitudes could be very significant if they influence the study of the Koran and the traditions. There has been some translation of Christian theology, and a desire to do more. Scholars appeared open to advice, centres for interfaith dialogue are developing, and there was a desire that non-Muslim faiths should be taught by adherents of those faiths, and that research and teaching in this area should not be used for apologetic or proselytising purposes. Some scholars desire a view of plurality faithful to Islam, and open to dialogue and learning.

Lawmakers are interested in the moral basis for western law. They appeared well-informed regarding the dangers of merely following public opinion, crude forms of utilitarianism and the over-emphasis on the individual. Most wanted to affirm Islam's teaching, and for its principles to be embodied in law, but they were aware that such applications must take into account contemporary circumstances.

Senior figures suggested that parliament was the best forum for deciding how Islamic principles should be applied; the examples given were about the promotion of monogamy and the development of penal law. The role of reason in relation to revelation was stressed. It may well be that those traditions of Islam, both Shia and Sunni, which give reason a role in the interpretation of revelation, will be in the vanguard for the development of Shariah or Islamic law, on which so much else depends.

The suggested parliamentary role has implications for the clerically-dominated theocracy, with pressure on the council of guardians to take a more progressive view of Islamic law. Much depends on how tension between the majlis and the council of guardians is resolved.

Senior figures are now opening up conversations with religious minorities, and are conspicuous at these communities' events. There is even an acknowledgement that some movement of individuals between faith communities is inevitable.

At the same time, members of these communities continue to report intimidation. Some need to have their legal status recognised, and confiscated properties returned and repaired. Government needs to clarify the balance between community and individual rights; there is a tendency to privilege the former.

One reason for greater tolerance may be the emi- gration of skilled people - including Christians, Jews and Zoroastrians. To halt this brain drain, society has to be more open, rights respected and the press allowed to exercise its functions. Many of those who left Iran should be allowed to return.

Interest in an international dialogue stems partly from the desire of Iran's rulers to end the country's isolation. But we need to point out that no civilisation is entirely homogeneous, and a dialogue is needed also within civilisations. Iran has many ancient religious communities. Their contribution to Iranian culture should be acknowledged.

We saw much to suggest that both kinds of dialogue are beginning. But immediate improvement is needed in the situation of minority communities, the judicial system must be seen to be fair, punishment rehabilitative and the press free to investigate and criticise. Otherwise, dialogue will be fruitless and the country could return to the dark days just after the revolution. But there is also the possibility of much fruit both for Iran and for the rest of the world.

Those reformers are taking risks and need support. The slow pace of change may be frustrating for outsiders, but patience is an ancient value in Iran. As the country's premier poet, the 14th-century Hafiz of Shiraz, said: "Patience and success are old friends:/ From patience's sedate walk/ Comes victory's triumphal march."

The Rt Rev Michael Nazir-Ali is the Anglican Bishop of Rochester

Much depends on how tension between the majlis and the council of guardians is resolved. Senior figures are now opening up conversations with religious minorities, and are conspicuous at these communities' events. There is even an acknowledgement that some movement of individuals between faith communities is inevitable. At the same time, members of these communities continue to report intimidation. Some need to have their legal status recognised, and confiscated properties returned and repaired. Government needs to clarify the balance between community and individual rights; there is a tendency to privilege the former. One reason for greater tolerance may be the emi- gration of skilled people - including Christians, Jews and Zoroastrians. To halt this brain drain, society has to be more open, rights respected and the press allowed to exercise its functions. Many of those who left Iran should be allowed to return. Interest in an international dialogue stems partly from the desire of Iran's rulers to end the country's isolation. But we need to point out that no civilisation is entirely homogeneous, and a dialogue is needed also within civilisations. Iran has many ancient religious communities. Their contribution to Iranian culture should be acknowledged. We saw much to suggest that both kinds of dialogue are beginning. But immediate improvement is needed in the situation of minority communities, the judicial system must be seen to be fair, punishment rehabilitative and the press free to investigate and criticise. Otherwise, dialogue will be fruitless and the country could return to the dark days just after the revolution. But there is also the possibility of much fruit both for Iran and for the rest of the world. Those reformers are taking risks and need support. The slow pace of change may be frustrating for outsiders, but patience is an ancient value in Iran. As the country's premier poet, the 14th-century Hafiz of Shiraz, said: "Patience and success are old friends:/ From patience's sedate walk/ Comes victory's triumphal march." The Rt Rev Michael Nazir-Ali is the Anglican Bishop of Rochester

webTitle: Mood turns ugly as crowds pressure election officials

fields.headline: Mood turns ugly as crowds pressure election officials
fields.standfirst:
Fears of violence from disgruntled rightwingers

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Republican anger with Al Gore's efforts to win the White House through recounts and renewed legal challenges edged closer towards violence yesterday as the post-election struggle in Florida headed for tomorrow's next deadline.
fields.body:
Republican anger with Al Gore's efforts to win the White House through recounts and renewed legal challenges edged closer towards violence yesterday as the post-election struggle in Florida headed for tomorrow's next deadline.

A brick inscribed "We would not tolerate an illegal government" was thrown through the windows of Democratic party offices in Broward county, where one of the recounts resumed yesterday.

Republican supporters waving "Sore-Loserman" placards, some of them bussed in from outside Florida, jostled and heckled reporters and officials in both Broward and Palm Beach counties for a second day as the mood threatened to turn even uglier.

The anniversary of Elian Gonzales' ill-fated arrival in Florida brought a reprise of the ugly, hysterical scenes which became the norm at every twist of that legal saga.

As tempers deteriorated on both sides, Mr Gore's top lawyer David Boies alleged that a third county, Miami-Dade, had decided to abandon a count which could have been decisive for Democratic hopes after "mini-riots". As he did so, a prominent Republican, the Wall Street Journal columnist Paul Gigot, talked of "a bourgeois riot" that would save Mr Bush's presidential hopes.

Mounting Republican fury with Mr Gore bristled from the airwaves and on the internet yesterday, triggering accusations of mob rule from Democrats and a claim from socialist activists that Mr Bush's supporters were making "appeals of a semi-insurrectionary character" to members of the US armed forces. Republicans in turn accused the Democrats of hypocrisy.

"They bring in kids who yell and scream and try to stop things from moving forward," Jenny Backus of the Democratic National Committee said.

The recounts nevertheless went ahead in Broward and Palm Beach counties yesterday, helping Mr Gore to nibble away at Mr Bush's lead, which fell towards 700 again.

In Broward county, officials resumed counting after the Thanksgiving holiday, examining as many as 2,000 questionable ballot papers which had previously been excluded because of difficulties in establishing the voters' intentions.

In Palm Beach county, officials were focusing their efforts on some 6,000 questionable ballot papers, examining each one for evidence of intention. Figures were not updated from Palm Beach, although earlier published figures showed a net gain of 14 to Mr Bush.

At a hearing before the recount there resumed, William Rouverol, inventor of the controversial Votomatic machine used in the county, unsuccessfully urged the local supervisory board to count partially indented or "dimpled" ballots, which would add hundreds of votes to Al Gore's total.

Meanwhile, away from the spotlight, four smaller Florida counties published their own revised totals which gave a net gain of 60 votes to Mr Bush.

The two counties are aiming to complete their recounts and submit figures to the Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris by 5pm tomorrow. Ms Harris can then certify the results of the election tomorrow evening, allowing the victor to claim Florida's 25 electoral college votes and thus the White House.

If that man is Mr Bush, Mr Gore has made clear that he will make no concession either tomorrow or any time soon.

Lawyers for the Gore camp said they will immediately challenge the certified results in a "contest action" on the grounds that Miami-Dade was unable to conduct a legal recount. Such a move could keep the outcome in doubt until well into December.

Mr Gore's contest action is only one of a number of possible developments over the coming days which could significantly affect the final outcome in Florida.

On Monday, a state appeal court is conducting an emergency hearing on whether a new election should be called in Palm Beach county because some voters were confused by the so-called "butterfly ballots" used there.

Also on Monday, a court in Seminole county will decide whether to exclude 4,700 postal votes sent out at the instigation of Republican officials rather than of the voters themselves or their relatives, as required by law. A ruling favourable to Mr Gore could reverse the result in Florida, some observers believe.

fields.headline: US forces climate target climbdown
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Heated talks continuing in the Hague last night were expected to produce a watered-down agreement on cutting global warming gases - a backward step which might allow emissions to rise for the next 10 years.
fields.body:
Heated talks continuing in the Hague last night were expected to produce a watered-down agreement on cutting global warming gases - a backward step which might allow emissions to rise for the next 10 years.

As national delegations and green groups voiced their dismay, the French environment minister, Dominique Voynet, said on behalf of the EU: "This is a step backwards."

The conference of 180 countries abandoned the attempt to reach a detailed agreement and went on fighting over a broad-brush political statement which could be turned into a legally binding deal later.

Three years ago the developed countries agreed at Kyoto, Japan, to cut their emissions by 5.2%. If the Hague compromise is agreed this will become 3% or less.

The obstacle is the US insistence that it should be able to meet its target indirectly by growing trees to absorb carbon from the atmosphere rather than by cutting its consumption of carbon-based fuels.

Ms Voynet said: "This would turn the Kyoto agreement, which was negotiated under great difficulties ... into an agreement which would allow increases up to 2010. It will be very difficult to close the loopholes here at a later stage. This is not a step in the right direction."

The conference of 180 countries was intended to create a legally binding agreement setting maximum emissions from developed countries. Some are allowed increases, but the EU has agreed an 8% cut, the US 7% and Japan 6%.

Climatologists say that a reduction of at least 60% is needed to stabilise the climate.

Three years of talks were supposed to end at 5pm yesterday, but ministers continued meeting through the night in the hope of agreeing a 14 page political statement.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, heading the British delegation, said: "We are going to the wire to try and get a deal."

EU ministers are anxious to get a politically binding agreement, even a weak one, before the Clinton presidency ends. Trying to get any kind of meaningful agreement with a Bush negotiating team is seen as nearly impossible.

The talks last night focused on a series of compromises suggested by Jan Pronk, the Dutch environment minister and president of the meeting, who, a UN spokesman said, told delegates that no final deal was possible and he hoped for a political agreement setting out a broad outline of what countries sought to do.

The proposals disappointed everyone. Green groups were dismayed.

The US said it was "deeply disappointed" and considered the scheme "unacceptably imbalanced".

fields.headline: Eric Sharpe
fields.standfirst:
Prodigious scholar of world religions

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Eric Sharpe, who has died aged 67, was known, above all, for his Comparative Religion: A History (1975 and 1986), the standard English-language work which was translated into Chinese, Hebrew and Korean. Eric was fluent in several European languages, and the book showed a deep understanding of an enormous range of western thought.
fields.body:
Eric Sharpe, who has died aged 67, was known, above all, for his Comparative Religion: A History (1975 and 1986), the standard English-language work which was translated into Chinese, Hebrew and Korean. Eric was fluent in several European languages, and the book showed a deep understanding of an enormous range of western thought.

While criticised by some for not devoting more attention to sociological studies - a weakness of which Eric was aware - Comparative Religion was a masterly study of western approaches to the study of religion.

This was a constant theme of his writings and the subject of his Swedish doctorate (Uppsala, 1965), published as Not To Destroy But To Fulfill: The Contribution Of JN Farquhar To Protestant Missionary Thought In India Before 1914, (1965). He also published on AG Hogg, KL Reichelt and one of his heroes, the Swedish archbishop, Nathan Sonderblom (1984).

Eric's interest in Christianity in India inspired an interest in religion on the sub-continent, leading to the Universal Gita (1985). His years in Uppsala (1958-1965) bred an abiding love of Scandinavia's ancient history and religion, a subject on which he published a number of articles, including one in Man And His Salvation: Essays In Memory Of SGF Brandon (1973), which we edited together. He also translated nine books from Swedish into English.

Born in Lancaster, Eric was educated at the Royal Lancaster grammar school and Manchester University, where he read theology. He was a fine teacher, a side of his personality perhaps best reflected in Understanding Religion (1983).

But Eric's primary field remained interfaith dialogue. As someone quietly devoted to the Christian faith, yet with a great sensitivity to people and ideas, he was fascinated by the interface between religions, and it was this engagement of scholarship with faith that resulted in his focus on the belief - rather than the social dimensions - of religions. In his last piece of writing, completed a few days before his death, he revisited his history of comparative religion; this is a chapter for my forthcoming Penguin Companion To The Study Of Religion, a book which I am dedicating to his memory.

Eric achieved international respect, holding university posts at Manchester, Lancaster, a chair in Uppsala and visiting positions at Indiana, Manitoba, McMaster and the Yale University divinity school. He organised two congresses of the International Association for the History of Religion (Lancaster, 1975, Sydney, 1985), serving as deputy and then acting general secretary of that association (1970-1975).

His chair in religious studies at Sydney (1977-96) was the first in the subject in Australia. He was thus a pioneer, and was elected president of the Australian Association for the study of Religions (1983-85).

Eric was deeply honest, the embodiment of kindness and good will. He was also more creative than many realised, above all in the field of music. He conducted orchestras, played the flute and, with his wife, Birgitta, established choirs wherever they stayed. Even after a five-fold bypass heart operation, which restricted him for the last two years, he retained a warm and lively sense of humour.

He leaves Birgitta and many friends around the world.

Eric John Sharpe, academic, born September 19 1933; died October 19 2000

webTitle: Rail chaos puts car curb plans in jeopardy

fields.headline: Rail chaos puts car curb plans in jeopardy
fields.standfirst:
Government faces £180m bill as train companies seek compensation

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott's much-vaunted plan to curb car use with a railway renaissance partly backed by the train companies has been thrown into doubt by Britain's rail chaos, his senior transport adviser warned last night.
fields.body:
John Prescott's much-vaunted plan to curb car use with a railway renaissance partly backed by the train companies has been thrown into doubt by Britain's rail chaos, his senior transport adviser warned last night.

Professor David Begg, chairman of the commission for integrated transport, issued his warning as it emerged that rail companies would be pressing for £330m in compensation for the chaos and lack of revenue since the Hatfield crash.

This is more than double the £150m already allocated by Railtrack to restore the network to normal and pay back long-suffering passengers. It means the government will almost certainly be asked to make up the £180m shortfall.

A senior industry source said: "We have done our arithmetic and Railtrack's sums just do not add up. We will need more help to see us through the current crisis or we face meltdown. Some companies are in such a bad state that they may be forced to go to the wall."

Mr Prescott's difficulties were exacerbated by the intervention of Professor Begg. He warned that the government's plans for an integrated transport plan raised concerns about the ability of Railtrack and the companies to fund their share of the government's plan to revitalise rail.

With dramatically falling passenger numbers and the prospect of rail usage remaining low for a further 12 months, Professor Begg said he feared the forecasts for future growth could be wildly off the mark.

He said: "The real concern is that it is going to take years to get passengers back and the major concern is that this will affect the level of investment."

Professor Begg stressed that the government faced a "major headache" in getting the rail system on track with big companies, like GNER on the east coast and Virgin on the west coast, warning that they had suffered a 40% drop in trade.

With people spurning the railways in droves, Professor Begg said the transport crisis would undermine Mr Prescott's targets of reducing car use as well as pollution from exhaust fumes. "There is a big shift away from rail to the biggest polluters - cars and aircraft."

The train companies say they will be struggling without more money, even though some of the larger companies like FirstGroup and National Express have been making reasonable profits from the railway with the help of a declining subsidy from the Treasury.

Railtrack yesterday announced that it had made substantial progress towards improving the network by relaying a third of track which needed repair.

Steve Marshall, its new chief executive and former chief financial officer, said it was working "flat-out" to restore the network to normal. But Mr Marshall, who took over from Gerald Corbett a week ago, is likely to hold the job only temporarily.

Several candidates from within the industry were last night mentioned as potential replacements, including Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Trains and Richard Bowker, its chief operating director.
