webTitle: Patten backs Blair on rapid reaction force

fields.headline: Patten backs Blair on rapid reaction force
fields.standfirst:
EU commissioner dismisses media coverage as fabricated and fatuous

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The prime minister yesterday returned to the offensive over European integration and military cooperation, winning unequivocal support for his stance from Chris Patten, the EU's commissioner for external affairs, who declared that the Tory leader William Hague was wrong about the so-called "European army".
fields.body:
The prime minister yesterday returned to the offensive over European integration and military cooperation, winning unequivocal support for his stance from Chris Patten, the EU's commissioner for external affairs, who declared that the Tory leader William Hague was wrong about the so-called "European army".

Mr Blair used a summit of EU and Balkan leaders in the Croatian capital Zagreb to blast his critics in the bitter row over European security as narrow-minded nationalists and misguided patriots.

He pointed to the joint military peacekeeping missions in Bosnia and Kosovo as positive examples of the kind of work which would be taken on by the new and controversial European rapid reaction force.

Mr Patten also attacked parts of the British media, describing some coverage of the European military row as "fabricated and fatuous".

Appearing to target Mr Hague, Mr Blair railed against "narrow-minded nationalism and misguided patriotism" and offered a robust defence of government policies on Europe.

He went on from Croatia to neighbouring Bosnia to visit British soldiers on peacekeeping duty in Banja Luka, in what appeared to be a calculated attempt to disarm his opponents on the issue of the new 60,000-strong rapid reaction force.

Visiting the Princess of Wales's Royal Regiment and the Queen's Dragoon Guards, Mr Blair said that the force gave Britain the option to use it where it wanted.

"All the soldiers here are working alongside servicemen of other countries," he said. "It's important people realise what this is all about. In circumstances where Nato does not want to become involved and yet we have a need to do peacekeeping operations as we did here in the 1990s, it allows us the option to do so.

"It has been agreed by Nato, it's been agreed by the USA and it simply allows us to do these peacekeeping operations in circumstances where Nato doesn't want to be involved."

Earlier in Zagreb, the prime minister assailed the Eurosceptics. He said: "The threat we face is a retreat into narrow-minded nationalism which in the name of misguided patriotism takes our countries backward ... Europe, the present EU and the EU of the future is the standing example that the past need not repeat itself.

"All this is possible provided an enlightened patriotism which sees cooperation and partnership as strength, not weakness, replaces the fear and prejudices of that narrow nationalism."

Mr Blair won unalloyed backing on the military row from Mr Patten, who told the BBC in Zagreb: "I disagree with William Hague on this. I think the Conservative party has made a considerable mistake on this."

Mr Patten also attacked British media coverage of the rapid reaction force specifically and of the EU generally. "On some front pages these days you see propaganda and not news," he said. "I think what is damaging is that sometimes any attempt to be constructive in Europe is regarded by some newspapers as tantamount to treachery.

"I think the whole debate is quite extraordinary. It's been whipped up by some of the press ... Much of the reporting is fabricated or fatuous." Mr Patten said that claims that European military cooperation was undermining the 51-year-old Nato alliance and would result in a full withdrawal of American troops from Europe was nonsense.

"We are not undermining Nato. Nato has made it perfectly clear it supports what European ministers are doing," he said. "The American administration has made it perfectly clear it supports what we are doing."

Mr Patten added: "It's crazy to suggest this is the creation of a European army or an attempt to kick the Americans out of Europe. Nothing could be further from the truth."

fields.bodyText: The prime minister yesterday returned to the offensive over European integration and military cooperation, winning unequivocal support for his stance from Chris Patten, the EU's commissioner for external affairs, who declared that the Tory leader William Hague was wrong about the so-called "European army". Mr Blair used a summit of EU and Balkan leaders in the Croatian capital Zagreb to blast his critics in the bitter row over European security as narrow-minded nationalists and misguided patriots. He pointed to the joint military peacekeeping missions in Bosnia and Kosovo as positive examples of the kind of work which would be taken on by the new and controversial European rapid reaction force. Mr Patten also attacked parts of the British media, describing some coverage of the European military row as "fabricated and fatuous". Appearing to target Mr Hague, Mr Blair railed against "narrow-minded nationalism and misguided patriotism" and offered a robust defence of government policies on Europe. He went on from Croatia to neighbouring Bosnia to visit British soldiers on peacekeeping duty in Banja Luka, in what appeared to be a calculated attempt to disarm his opponents on the issue of the new 60,000-strong rapid reaction force. Visiting the Princess of Wales's Royal Regiment and the Queen's Dragoon Guards, Mr Blair said that the force gave Britain the option to use it where it wanted. "All the soldiers here are working alongside servicemen of other countries," he said. "It's important people realise what this is all about. In circumstances where Nato does not want to become involved and yet we have a need to do peacekeeping operations as we did here in the 1990s, it allows us the option to do so. "It has been agreed by Nato, it's been agreed by the USA and it simply allows us to do these peacekeeping operations in circumstances where Nato doesn't want to be involved." Earlier in Zagreb, the prime minister assailed the Eurosceptics. He said: "The threat we face is a retreat into narrow-minded nationalism which in the name of misguided patriotism takes our countries backward ... Europe, the present EU and the EU of the future is the standing example that the past need not repeat itself. "All this is possible provided an enlightened patriotism which sees cooperation and partnership as strength, not weakness, replaces the fear and prejudices of that narrow nationalism." Mr Blair won unalloyed backing on the military row from Mr Patten, who told the BBC in Zagreb: "I disagree with William Hague on this. I think the Conservative party has made a considerable mistake on this." Mr Patten also attacked British media coverage of the rapid reaction force specifically and of the EU generally. "On some front pages these days you see propaganda and not news," he said. "I think what is damaging is that sometimes any attempt to be constructive in Europe is regarded by some newspapers as tantamount to treachery. "I think the whole debate is quite extraordinary. It's been whipped up by some of the press ... Much of the reporting is fabricated or fatuous." Mr Patten said that claims that European military cooperation was undermining the 51-year-old Nato alliance and would result in a full withdrawal of American troops from Europe was nonsense. "We are not undermining Nato. Nato has made it perfectly clear it supports what European ministers are doing," he said. "The American administration has made it perfectly clear it supports what we are doing." Mr Patten added: "It's crazy to suggest this is the creation of a European army or an attempt to kick the Americans out of Europe. Nothing could be further from the truth." fields.headline: PM goes to war over Euro army
fields.trailText: The first in a regular series of columns by professor of journalism Peter Cole in which he examines British reporting of Europe.
fields.body:
The first in a regular series of columns by professor of journalism Peter Cole in which he examines British reporting of Europe.

What a long time it seems since we weren't debating Europe. Gordon Brown did not want to, Tony Blair was going along, and soon there would be an election in which Europe would not be an issue.

If in doubt, cite the five conditions and since nobody could remember what they were - Gordon could, but he wasn't telling because he wasn't discussing Europe - the debate continued not to happen.

That was less than two weeks ago, since when the sound of the marching European army, the Euro-offensive by senior cabinet ministers, and hectares of coverage in the press have demonstrated daily that as an issue Europe is not for hiding.

Whether it is an issue for understanding is another matter. For those who seek to follow the debate, reading the newspapers is not necessarily helpful. This column will seek to track the unfolding debate as presented in the press. It will be mindful that most readers do not take a range of newspapers but usually the one or two that reinforce their own prejudices. It will be aware too that the nuances of spin, from politician to press, from press to reader, are not transparent to those outside the Westminster to neo-Fleet Street corridor.

The present Euro-frenzy began before last weekend when Peter Mandelson said, somewhat uncontroversially, that pro-Europeans were making a mistake if they failed to appreciate that political as well as economic arguments had to be won if the case for joining the euro was to prevail. It was certainly controversial to Nos 10 and 11 Downing Street, and within hours the Northern Ireland secretary was backtracking, claiming his remarks had been given "unwarranted prominence".

However, it was the Eurosceptic Daily Mail that, before last weekend, was trailing the Euro-issue that would put the currency and cabinet strategy into the shade within days. "EU picks German to lead forerunner of a new Euro army", said an inside page headline. By Saturday the equally Eurosceptic Daily Telegraph was on the case: "Britain commits 24,000 troops to EU army" ran its front-page headline.

However, first there was a new cabinet row as the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, already in the third day of a pro-Europe offensive went ballistic about Gordon Brown. The Sunday Telegraph reported that Cook was furious about Brown interfering in policy areas that were nothing to do with him.

But enough of arcane disputes in cabinet. Feet were marching, probably jackbooted, about to attack Nato. This was traditional, jingoistic, you-take-your-corner-I'll-take-mine stuff. And the anti-European newspapers did not hang about.

The Sun drafted General Sir Peter de la Billière, commander of the British forces during the Gulf war, to write of "this threat to the safety of Britain". Margaret Thatcher was on the same page: "Lady T: PM puts us all in peril."

The Daily Mail had "Blair faces a blitzkrieg." It too had Sir Peter, as well as Major General Julian Thompson to give us a Falklands perspective.

The Daily Telegraph, the third prong of the committed Eurosceptic movement, gave us former US defence secretary Caspar Weinberger to add his voice to the crescendo of antagonism.

Tony Blair was incandescent. Speaking in Moscow, he savaged the newspapers that had attacked the Euro-force. He ranted about "fundamentally dishonest" reporting, saying: "I'm used to the British media being impossible on the topic of Europe, but I hope the public will be given the facts."

The Labour-loyalist Mirror had a modestly displayed column headed "The Facts." But the author was Robin Cook, leader of the government's Euro offensive.

Over at the Daily Mail, Mr Weinberger was appearing again; but the real fire was being aimed at Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, a "crony general", and allegedly a supporter of the rapid reaction force. The next day the Mail had a "senior serving British military commander" attacking Guthrie and describing the rapid reaction force plan as "a bugger's muddle".

Blair has lost his rag as the forces of anti-Europeanism march forward. He has called sections of the press dishonest and attacked them for being horrid about General Guthrie.

The "Euro-army" has become a major EU issue in advance of the Nice summit. The newspapers, on either side of the argument, have been trading personal abuse. There has been precious little cool analysis of the issue.

The Eurosceptic press has seized it, milked it, spun it. The Euro-supportive press has, as in the case of the Guardian, led the paper twice in three days on Blair being very cross with the Eurosceptic press. Such pussyfooting will not staunch the blitzkrieg. It has been good week to understand why the public is confused about European issues.

Peter Cole is professor of journalism at the University of Sheffield

webTitle: Jonathan King denies child abuse charges going back 30 years

fields.headline: Jonathan King denies child abuse charges going back 30 years
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Jonathan King, pop promoter and TV personality, yesterday denied allegations of paedophilia against him made by three men going back 30 years.
fields.body:
Jonathan King, pop promoter and TV personality, yesterday denied allegations of paedophilia against him made by three men going back 30 years.

Mr King, 55, was arrested and charged with buggery, attempted buggery and indecent assault on Thursday night following a six month investigation by the serious sexual offences unit of the national criminal intelligence service (NCIS) into paedophile activity.

The men, who were aged between 13 and 15 at the time, came forward with allegations against Mr King during a wide-ranging investigation into alleged paedophile activity in the 1970s and 80s, according to a police source. It is understood that following publicity about his arrest a number of people contacted NCIS with further allegations against him.

Mr King, who ran a successful recording and publishing company during the period covered by the allegations, described the charges as "absurd".

"I categorically deny these absurd allegations about events from 28 years ago. I have great faith that the British legal system will vindicate me," he said on returning to his home in Bayswater, west London, after spending the night in a cell at Staines police station. Police earlier searched the mews house and removed a number of items for analysis.

Chris Poole, Mr King's spokesman, said the former DJ was shocked but regarded the allegations as "an occupational hazard".

"Last night when I spoke to him he was very shocked and disorientated but he was picking himself up today and he said it is business as usual," said Mr Poole.

"He also told me that he regards it as something of an occupational hazard for people in the public eye to have these sorts of accusations made against them. He is determined he is innocent and he will be proved innocent.

"I do not think Jonathan knows specifically who has made these allegations ... He is absolutely determined to defend himself and to continue with his work commitments."

Mr King works as a consultant to a number of record companies and the Eurovision Song Contest, and runs a music industry magazine, the Tipsheet.

Educated at Charterhouse school and Cambridge University, King was 21 when he recorded his first number one record, Everyone's Gone To The Moon. A year later he was appointed manager of Decca Records and aged 25 he founded his own label, UK Records.

He is credited with discovering major acts including Genesis, the Bay City Rollers and 10cc and has claimed to have had 20 records in the top 30 under 20 different aliases. The records include Una Paloma Blanca, Lick a Smurf For Christmas, Loop di Love and Leap Up and Down and Wave Your Knickers in the Air.

In the 1980s he moved into television, devising and presenting Entertainment USA, which he presented on BBC2, and music programme No Limits. He often appeared in jeans, white trainers, dinner jacket and large multi-coloured glasses. He has also written a novel, Bible Two, and worked as a pop columnist for the Sun newspaper.

webTitle: Shipyard left high and dry after £51m liner deal is halted

fields.headline: Shipyard left high and dry after £51m liner deal is halted
fields.trailText: The largest order ever taken to lengthen a luxury liner was revoked yesterday after the Italian owners of the Costa Classica pulled out of a deal, leaving 26,000 tonnes of steel beached on the docks of the Mersey.
fields.body:
The largest order ever taken to lengthen a luxury liner was revoked yesterday after the Italian owners of the Costa Classica pulled out of a deal, leaving 26,000 tonnes of steel beached on the docks of the Mersey.

The Cammell Laird shipyard, famous for building the aircraft carrier the Ark Royal, was told by Italian cruise operator Costa Crociere that it had postponed delivery of the ship because the work was behind schedule.

The people most surprised were the 30 Cammell Laird workers on the cruise ship Costa Classica, who were heading for home yesterday off the coast of Spain and looking forward to tomorrow's float of a huge new section for the ship at their yard in Birkenhead.

Suddenly, around 3pm, as they cruised off La Coruna, scene of one of Nelson's naval triumphs, they were told that the ship's owners, Costa Crociere, had cancelled the £51m contract for "jumboisation" and they would be put off the vessel in Spain while the ship turned around and headed back to Genoa.

Came the dawn, as they prepared to fly back to Merseyside, the shell-shocked crew members realised it was not only their own jobs that looked insecure but those of 1,000 colleagues at Birkenhead and the future of the company that employed them - a group reborn from the ashes of Britain's once-great shipbuilding industry.

Crisis meetings

Alerted by company executives, union leaders and local MPs began a series of crisis meetings late on Thursday to salvage the contract to build and fit a 45-metre extension to the 56,000-ton Costa Classica: cutting it in half and inserting the new section in the middle. It is billed as the world's biggest cruise ship conversion.

But by 8am, as he flew out from Marseille, where Cammell has recently acquired a stake in Europe's biggest repair dock, the company's deputy chief executive, Brett Martin, knew he had a fight on to save the entire company. The shares had been holed below the bottom-line and, as he landed in Luton, were down 36%; Cammell had lost £65m of its value, it was down to £112m and possibly ripe for takeover.

"We were shocked and surprised," he said, waiting for his flight to the north-west of England as he handled calls on his mobile phone from worried investors, fellow executives, MPs and union officials. Cammell had already lost out last month on the government's £1.2bn order for six ferries to transport troops overseas - because its order book was booming.

'Sick'

By the time he reached Birkenhead, the scene awaiting him resembled the industrial disputes of the 1980s. At 3.15pm, early finishing time on Friday, dockers marched out of the yard with woollen hats pulled down tight over furrowed brows and hands pushed deep into donkey jackets. "This is sick," said one shipyard worker, carrying his boots and overalls across the potholed car park to his car.

But this time the dispute was not between unions and governments. It was between Britain and Italy. The Italian ship-owners had applied for arbitration to find out whether they could postpone or even terminate the contract, arguing that the work was substantially behind schedule and efforts to resolve the dispute commercially had failed.

Behind Cammell Laird's giant metal dock bays sat the 26,000-tonne midsection. It was beached on the dry dock with its funnels lit with a string of lights like a stranded Christmas cruise ship waiting for a bow and stern. Across the Mersey, Liverpool's two vast cathedrals looked tiny in comparison.

"This is crisis time," said David Hulfe, GMB senior shop steward, outside the gates.

"It has just come out of the blue. We were in the yard today ready to accept the ship. Now the company is talking about this going to arbitration. Christmas is just around the corner and these workers don't know what the future holds. It's not just the shipyard jobs, it's the spin off for small local businesses. Taxi firms, pubs and shops all benefit from us and they would suffer without us."

Mr Martin embarked on a damage-limitation exercise, arguing that the alleged delays were little or nothing. "We believe we have got a robust defence and the group is performing well. I can't pretend this is not a big disappointment but it's not the end of the world."

But he was forced to concede that, with between 700 and 800 of the Birkenhead workforce employed on the disputed contract, lay-offs were inevitable. "The yard was completely committed to this project which is not going to happen and we don't have any bookings over the Christmas/New Year period ... There's a very big chance that a good proportion of them will be laid off."

Mr Martin and his fellow directors own 30% of Cammell and have expanded the group's activities to the north-east of England and to the west cost of the US, to Oregon.

But its core yard, Birkenhead, is now dependent on government aid for lucrative contracts to build two cruise ships for US group Luxus - the return of shipbuilding to the Mersey for the first time in many years.

"We have every reason to believe we can turn this company around and if we get the Luxus contract this will give us the security to go aggressively forward," he said.

Frank Field, Labour MP for Birkenhead, said: "It is very serious that the Italians have reneged on the contract. It is incredibly worrying for the workforce, as this is one of the most successful workforces in the country. It is very serious that a workforce like this should be so dependent on the capriciousness of the Italian firm."

Asked if there would be job losses, he said: "Well there obviously won't be any overtime worked."

Luxury line started as humble olive firm

Costa Crociere, the Italian cruise line which has scuppered Cammell Laird's Birkenhead yard, pitches unashamedly for the wealthy seafarer.

Its website proclaims the luxuries of cabin class to the growing wave of affluent baby-boomers and retired people. Despite now being part of an American company, the style is Italian. "Cruising is good. Cruising Italian-style is Magnifico," runs the sales patter.

Its origins can be traced to a humble olive-growing business set up by Giacomo Costa in 1860 in Genoa. His three sons, Federico, Eugenio and Enrico, took over the business and, in 1924, bought their first ship, a freighter, to transport olives more cheaply.

The bulk of its expanding freighter fleet was lost during the second world war. Costa's first passenger ser vices began in 1948. It now has seven cruise ships and in August placed an order with Kvaerner's Finnish yard for its largest ship, an 86,000-tonne vessel - the sister of CostaAtlantica, which carries 2,154 passengers.

The 54,000-tonne Costa Classica, originally due to be stretched at Birkenhead, was launched in January 1992 and carries 1,300 passengers. At $325m (currently £230m) it was the most expensive cruise ship, per passenger, at the time.

The business remained in the Costa family for more than a century but in 1990 they invited foreign investors in and, seven years later, it was bought by Carnival Corporation of the US and Airtours, the UK holiday operator. The British company sold its 49.96% stake - initially costing £25m - to Carnival in September this year, netting a profit of more than £230m.

webTitle: Bush borrows Democrat clothes to try to halt count

fields.headline: Bush borrows Democrat clothes to try to halt count
fields.standfirst:
Federal appeal reverses usual strategy for Republicans

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The US supreme court was deciding whether to enter the post-election fray in Florida yesterday in a case which sets Republicans and Democrats on the opposite sides of the argument to those that the parties have traditionally adopted.
fields.body:
The US supreme court was deciding whether to enter the post-election fray in Florida yesterday in a case which sets Republicans and Democrats on the opposite sides of the argument to those that the parties have traditionally adopted.

These days, the Democrats normally want the federal courts to step in and impose their views on the 50 states, while Republicans think states should decide their own rules.

But so much is at stake in the battle for the White House - waged by the two parties since the November 7 presidential elections - that some bizarre political cross-dressing is the result, with the Republicans pressing the federal courts to intervene and the Democrats telling them to keep out of Florida's business.

George W Bush's attempt to get the nine-member US supreme court involved is the third attempt by the Republican candidate to use the federal courts to close recounts of ballots in parts of Florida; these are supported by Al Gore and the Democrats..

Mr Bush wants the court to bar hand-recounted votes from the final tallies. On Wednesday, his lawyers filed written pleadings arguing that the use of "arbitrary, standardless and selective manual recounts" threaten to overturn the election and to violate constitutional rights.

Mr Bush's chief lawyer, Theodore Olsen, a close friend of the former special counsel Kenneth Starr, who investigated the financial, and personal, affairs of President Clinton, said the aim was to "challenge the chaotic, seemingly endless, constantly changing and highly subjective manual recount scheme as violating the rights of voters and candidates under the federal constitution".

Mr Gore's lawyers hit back with papers that claimed the case was "a bald attempt to federalise a state law dispute" and said intervention would "diminish the legitimacy" of the election outcome. The Bush side filed further rebuttal arguments yesterday.

The court could announce any time whether it is prepared to hear oral arguments in the case.

So far, Mr Bush has had no luck at all. He lost when his lawyers tried the argument in a Miami federal court on November 13. He lost again a few days later, when the 11th circuit federal appeals court in Atlanta threw out his attempt to reverse the Miami ruling.

Now, following the Florida supreme court ruling in Mr Gore's favour on recounts this week, Mr Bush is trying a third time, in the highest court in the land.

But while Mr Bush's recourse to the US supreme court is a milestone that makes good headlines, there is little indication that the justices in Washington will be any keener than the lower federal courts to step into what is normally a state's own business, providing that their procedures do not breach the US constitution.

Talk of a constitutional crisis is very premature, though in this dispute, the unexpected can never be excluded.

webTitle: Cost warning on plans for reform of home buying

fields.headline: Cost warning on plans for reform of home buying
fields.standfirst: Homebuying guide at: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A government scheme to take the stress out of buying a home could leave buyers and sellers out of pocket, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
A government scheme to take the stress out of buying a home could leave buyers and sellers out of pocket, it was claimed yesterday.

The criticism came after the housing minister, Nick Raynsford, unveiled a radical shake-up of the housing market with the possible introduction of sellers' information packs aimed at speeding up sales.

Under the scheme people would be required to put together a "seller's pack" containing a survey, a draft contract and search details before they put their home on the market. This would give buyers access to vital information when they viewed a property and avoid them having to pay for a survey.

Speaking yesterday in Bristol, where a government pilot study of the scheme involving 189 transactions has been carried out, Mr Raynsford said that he was convinced the package was a good way forward.

But housing market experts said the scheme could have disastrous consequences for home-owners and those seeking to buy.

At a likely cost of between £500 and £700, sellers' packs could make people in areas with low property prices more reluctant to sell.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) suggested the Bristol study had been flawed, with less than 100 homes actually being sold, of which 30 were new properties.

It also claimed that the small print of the study revealed that 30 buyers had been unhappy with the reports provided in the packs on the condition of properties, choosing to pay for their own survey instead.

The council added that the packs were likely to put off owners who simply wanted to test the market, and could effectively kill off the housing market in low income areas.

Michael Coogan, CML director general, said: "While we support the idea of buyers and sellers being more prepared early on, the evidence in support of introducing sellers' information packs is not robust and such packs could prove unpopular."

Dominic Toller, of the Bristol and West Building Society, said the pilot study was too narrowly focused and produced no evidence that the scheme would tackle the problem of gazumping.

"Some aspects of the scheme are quite worrying. The housing pack is a report produced by the seller, but actually is going to be used by the buyer and the lender," he said.

The Law Society said the seller's survey was not necessary, and was unlikely to be relied on by a mortgage lender or buyer. Michael King, chairman of its conveyancing and land law committee, added: "The seller's survey will not be regarded as impartial and will be viewed with suspicion by the buyer, as it will only provide a very basic review of the property."

Mr Raynsford said the government was determined to forge ahead with reform despite criticism from mortgage lenders, estate agents and the Law Society.

During the eight-month pilot, some 87% of accepted offers on properties with a seller's pack resulted in a sale compared with 72% under the present system.

Three sides of propery buying triangle

Buyer

Recruitment consultant Tracey Dando, 26. "My fiancee and I bought our flat in May last year in Redlands, Bristol, for £150,000 and we found the property pack gave us information you don't normally get as a buyer. It is very informative and you are immediately given a lot of information regarding the state of the property, council tax bands, what work needs carrying out, and the energy efficiency, so you can calculate your power bills.

"We bought a flat and there was a management company. It gave us an insight into the management company accounts and how much the likely spend was on a yearly basis for maintenance. They were painting the flats this year and if we hadn't known we would have been liable for the costs. We managed to get that written into the contract so the sellers paid.

"The seller's pack also is some sort of guarantee that the seller is serious and won't suddenly withdraw it from the market. The pack also speeds up the buying process because you don't have to wait for the survey."

Seller

Sam Watson, 31, and husband Leon, 33, sold a maisonette in Redlands, Bristol, using the newseller's information pack.

Mrs Watson said: "We went to one of the estate agents offering the seller's pack service and we sold our home within our four week deadline. The buyers were so impressed they made an offer immediately.

"The seller's pack and survey showed up potential problems with trees in the garden flat beneath our property.

"As a result we had one pruned and the other taken out, and we got the boiler serviced and the certificate was included in the pack too.

"We know that because we had been upfront about all the things that needed attention there would be no need for the buyers to haggle.

"The only ridiculous thing is that lenders still don't accept the validity of the pack and insist on a separate valuation.

Estate agent

Trevor Kent, former president of the National Association of Estate Agents, runs his own agency in Gerrards Cross, Buckinghamshire. He is against the scheme. "The independent estate agents will have to cover the cost of the pack.

"The big agencies, perhaps owned by banks, building societies or insurance companies, who already own every aspect of the housing transaction, will be able to do the pack for nothing.

"Small businesses won't be able to survive unless they form alliances."

He added that gazumping would be made easier. "At the moment, a buyer has to get a mortgage offer and a survey done before their higher offer can be accepted. Now all that information will be available to them so they can make that offer immediately."

webTitle: Fury as murder soldiers keep jobs

fields.headline: Fury as murder soldiers keep jobs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland's independent assessor for military complaints last night joined the parents of an unarmed Catholic teenager shot dead in Belfast in condemning a decision by the Ministry of Defence to allow the two soldiers who killed the youth to remain in the army.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's independent assessor for military complaints last night joined the parents of an unarmed Catholic teenager shot dead in Belfast in condemning a decision by the Ministry of Defence to allow the two soldiers who killed the youth to remain in the army.

The assessor, Jim McDonald, said he would be seeking a full explanation from the army as to why it was retaining two murderers while it sacked soldiers for taking drugs.

"I am dismayed at the decision of the army board in confirming the retention of [James] Fisher and [Mark] Wright, who have been convicted of murder," he said.

Jean and Peter McBride, the parents of Peter McBride - who was 18 - demanded an urgent meeting with the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon. They said they were devastated by the decision.

"If they think I'm going to give up, they have another think coming," said Mrs McBride. "They think Peter's life was worth nothing, shoot him in the back and forget him. We will fight on till these two murderers are kicked out."

The decision sparked fury among civil rights groups. Paul O'Connor, of the Pat Finucane Centre in Londonderry, said it would be demanding a full explanation from the Ministry of Defence. It was also considering new legal moves.

The decision to allow Scots Guards James Fisher and Mark Wright to remain in the forces was taken in secret by an army board consisting of John Spellar, minister for the armed forces, General Sir Mike Jackson, commander of land forces in Britain, and General David Judd, the army's quartermaster-general.

Queen's regulations allow convicted soldiers to remain in the army under "exceptional circumstances", the MoD said yesterday. It declined to elaborate.

Peter McBride was shot in the back after he was stopped and searched by an army patrol in north Belfast in 1992.

At their trial at Belfast high court in 1995, Lord Chief Justice Kelly described the soldiers' evidence as "untruthful". Though the soldiers had searched him, they claimed there were grounds for believing the youth was carrying a coffee jar bomb. The only item he was carrying when he was shot was a T-shirt.

The guardsmen were given a life sentence for murder, but after a campaign in military circles to release them, they were freed under licence in 1998. Shortly afterwards, the army board ruled that they could remain in the army, describing the shooting as an "error of judgment".

Mo Mowlam, then Northern Ireland secretary, was among those who called for the soldiers to be discharged. The McBride family subsequently won the right to a judicial review of the board's decision. In September last year Mr Justice Kerr ruled that a new army board must reconsider the guardsmen's future.

The MoD said yesterday that the new board - also meeting in secret - had backed the original board's finding.

Mrs McBride said later: "Tony Blair should be ashamed of himself. The anniversary of Peter's birthday is next week and if they think I brought my son into this world to have him murdered and forgotten then they just don't understand what it is to be a mother."

The Sinn Fein assembly member for north Belfast, Gerry Kelly, condemned the army's decision as a "slap in the face" for the McBride family and the nationalist people.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, insisted the decision was "entirely a matter for the army board". He had suggested to Mr Hoon, that "given the circumstances, it would be inappropriate for Fisher and Wright to serve in Northern Ireland and he agreed".

fields.headline: Softbank's profit fail to convince
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Internet investor Softbank yesterday reported a return to profit in the first half, but market doubts that it can generate earnings other than by selling its vast shareholdings sent the shares down to a year's low. Profits were a net ¥36.31bn (£240m) in April-September, a comeback from a ¥3.52bn loss in the same period a year earlier.
fields.body:
Internet investor Softbank yesterday reported a return to profit in the first half, but market doubts that it can generate earnings other than by selling its vast shareholdings sent the shares down to a year's low. Profits were a net ¥36.31bn (£240m) in April-September, a comeback from a ¥3.52bn loss in the same period a year earlier.

The Japanese firm which has made successful investments in enterprises such as Yahoo! owed its profitability to sale of part of its holdings to record a net ¥67.2 bn gain. During the first half, Softbank made ¥35.8bn from the sale of shares in Yahoo! that took its stake from 23.2% to 22.6 %.

Softbank president Masayoshi Son said the share price, which fell 3.08%yesterday, did not properly reflect the value of the company's investments. The shares have fallen nearly 90% from an all-time high in February.

"The more Yahoo! shares they sell, the less attractive Softbank becomes," said Nakako Kota, an analyst at UBS Warburg. "The fact that Softbank had to sell Yahoo! which is one of the most promising internet stocks, is a bad sign."

Declines in the US stock market have eroded the value of Softbank's portfolio and analysts question its investment strategy. Its subsidiary Softbank Investment plans to go public on Nasdaq Japan on December 15.

The investment company, which manages ¥88bn in venture capital funds, is set to issue 7,800 new shares ahead of the listing and to offer 5,200 existing shares mostly held by Softbank. Thomas Rodes at Nikko Salomon Smith Barney said that would make Softbank still more unattractive for investors. "They are letting go all the IPOs."

Softbank's investment in Nippon Credit Bank is also under scrutiny. It led a consortium to buy the failed bank after it came under government protection, but analysts have been wary since its president committed suicide in September, 19 days after being appointed.

The government injected ¥3.2 trillion into NCB before the handover on September 1 but analysts say 30% of the loan portfolio has a high credit risk. - Reuters

fields.headline: Of angels and villains
fields.trailText: How dare Des R Hub (Letters, November 24) write on behalf of "right thinking Geordies". I have never heard The Angel of the North refered to as anything other than "The Angel", and if Geordies had no affection for it why would they dress it in a Newcastle United top?
fields.body:
How dare Des R Hub (Letters, November 24) write on behalf of "right thinking Geordies". I have never heard The Angel of the North refered to as anything other than "The Angel", and if Geordies had no affection for it why would they dress it in a Newcastle United top? It is also a bit rich that a Sanddancer - someone from South Shields - should write on behalf of Geordies.
Steve Johnson
Newcastle upon Tyne

 I'm sorry Des R Hubb feels so angry about the angel. I have just paid yet another visit. To my eye it is a wonderful sight, and even more so as the metal mellows to a deep rust colour. Why does modern art arouse such viciousness?
M Sawbridge
Durham City

 I have no idea where I was when Margaret Thatcher resigned (Letters, November 22), neither did I watch the last episode of One Foot in the Grave or Judith Keppel's £1m win on Who Wants to be a Millionaire?
Bob Heys
Ripponden, West Yorkshire

 When most of her crimes and follies have been forgotten and perhaps forgiven, Margaret Thatcher will be best remembered for her success in linking Britain to Europe through the creation of the Channel tunnel. A deep irony indeed.
John Roberts
Littlehampton, West Sussex

 How odd that your supplement Space can reach New York (Letters, November 22) and still not get to the poor unstylish peasantry outside the M25.
Marian Nyman
Whitstable, Kent
Marian.Nyman@kent.gov.uk

 Re your news report (Juror bitten by police horse, November 24), is this a case of jury nibbling?
Helen Romaine
Hailsham, East Sussex
Helenr@onetel.net.uk

fields.headline: Quick cures
fields.trailText: Relenza was not "invented" by a pharmaceutical company, but resulted from basic research carried out in university departments (Costly flu drug only for high risk NHS patients, November 22).
fields.body:
Relenza was not "invented" by a pharmaceutical company, but resulted from basic research carried out in university departments (Costly flu drug only for high risk NHS patients, November 22).

Why does the government continue to fund basic medical research, when it refuses to make its results available to the people who paid for it (the taxpayer)? Relenza is very effective in treating influenza. If given before infection it appears to provide complete protection. But the later it is given after infection, the less effective it is. The national institute for clinical excellence should try to administer Relenza to people very soon after they are infected rather than banning it for the "non risk" group!
Prof Graeme Laver
John Curtin School of Medical Research
Canberra, Australia

webTitle: Letters: Breaking the silence on child abuse

fields.headline: Breaking the silence
fields.trailText: As someone who experienced the horror of repeated sexual and physical abuse as a child I was pleased to see your leader (November 23) acknowledge the frightening extent of the problem. Sexual and physical abuse of children cuts across class boundaries, and this fact needs to be fully accepted.
fields.body:
As someone who experienced the horror of repeated sexual and physical abuse as a child I was pleased to see your leader (November 23) acknowledge the frightening extent of the problem. While agreeing that child poverty in Britain is a terrible indictment, and that every effort should be made to irradicate it, I do not think that this will secure an end to child abuse. Sexual and physical abuse of children cuts across class boundaries, and this fact needs to be fully accepted.

The NSPCC should also be thanked for its attempt to talk about the high levels of abuse perpetrated by children. Dea Birkett (Why little boys are not sex offenders, November 21) seems determined to deny the possibility that children can, and do, physically and sexually abuse other children. Once again, the perpetrator and victim are most commonly living in the same house. It was my experience that a regime of sadistic abuse thrived in what would have appeared to the outside world as a happy household, and continued unchallenged in the culture of shame and silence that abuse so often seems to foster. The fact that my abuser was only five years, rather than 25 years, older than me, is of little comfort. Such things do go on - even in nice middle-class homes.

Now, when I look at my own children, I hope that with clear and straightforward guidance about themselves, their bodies and feelings, they may be able to reach adulthood without becoming either a victim or a perpetrator of abuse.

We need to find ways to explicitly teach our children how to respect themselves and those around them. The sense that my own experience leaves me with (and the tenor of much of the public debate on child abuse seems to confirm) is that we prefer to ignore or deny other people's (and our own) vulnerability and suffering rather than acknowledge it and take the necessary action that springs out of that.

 Dea Birkett appears to be exhorting parents to "be afraid... be very afraid" of some of the results emerging from the recent NSPCC survey on child maltreatment. Her article is doing exactly what she accuses the NSPCC's research of doing - misrepresenting facts and worrying parents unnecessarily. In fact the NSPCC survey has confirmed what has been known by professionals for some time, that at least 30% of all sexual abuse of children is perpetrated by other children and young people. Our experience with nearly 300 children and young people who are over sexualised or sexually abusive confirms that they are, indeed, usually well known to their victims, may be relatives and have many other emotional and behavioural problems which need professional help.

Parents and carers of persistently sexualised children need to know that they should bring children for professional help and advice as early as possible since treatment and advice on management will help to stop these behaviours and prevent the behaviour escalating into something more serious.

NSPCC Young Abusers Project

fields.headline: Trouble down below
fields.trailText: As a commuter for the past 25 years, the comments on London Underground (It's hell down there, G2, November 20) struck a chord - not for the stories of the crumbling infrastructure or rudeness of the station staff, but for the rudeness and ignorance of commuters.
fields.body:
As a commuter for the past 25 years, the comments on London Underground (It's hell down there, G2, November 20) struck a chord - not for the stories of the crumbling infrastructure or rudeness of the station staff, but for the rudeness and ignorance of commuters.

Our tube trains are not only treated as cafes, but people are happy to leave anything from half eaten yoghurts to apple cores, unwanted sandwiches to orange peel, on the train seats. Commuters believe that there is no need to take a newspaper with them when it can be dropped on the floor. They also no longer consider it necessary to move right down inside the car, or to step off the train for a moment to allow passengers to alight.

But as we recoil from someone's bad breath and body odour, as we avoid the sight of someone's tonsils as they yawn openly, and as we hope that we don't catch the germs of those sneezing and coughing without raising a hand to their mouths, at least we can rejoice in the fact that those around us are letting us enjoy their music as it leaks from their headphones.

Commuting is never going to be pleasurable but it would be a lot more tolerable if all commuters were a little more civilised. And London Underground staff? I don't envy you your job, but keep smiling and being polite. I for one appreciate it.
Richard Zygos
London
richard_zyg@hotmail.com

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Who wants a £1m home?

fields.headline: Who wants a £1m home?
fields.standfirst: Answering 15 questions correctly made Judith Keppel a television millionaire this week. But, as Liz Stuart reports, all that cash doesn't guarantee hitting the jackpot in the property market
fields.trailText: Answering 15 questions correctly made Judith Keppel a television millionaire this week. But, as Liz Stuart reports, all that cash doesn't guarantee hitting the jackpot in the property market.
fields.body:
Should Who Wants to be a Millionaire winner Judith Keppel want to move up in the world she could leave London and buy a plush family home or even a more palatial residence in keeping with her distant Royal connections.

But if she wishes to stay in Fulham, the west London area in which she currently resides in a three-storey terraced house reputed to be worth £500,000, she may have to set her sights a little lower.

In Fulham £1m buys nothing bigger than a good penthouse style apartment or maisonette. If, for instance, she wished to buy the five-bedroomed property in Fulham Park Gardens, with three bathrooms and a large roof terrace advertised by Winkworths, she would need to phone a friend with a disposable income, for the asking price is £1.25m.

Almost within her price bracket would be the property being promoted by FPD Savills in Stokenchurch St, also in Fulham. It is a five-bed "lion" house on the Peterborough estate. "If she were wanting to move upwards in the area, then the Peterborough estate is absolutely the place. It has the best roads in Fulham," says the estate agent. The asking price is just over £1m.

A penthouse apartment on Sulivan Road, which is a top-floor 1960s flat with south westerly views and a private courtyard in its centre, is £900,000, while an appartment in the new Kings development might meet her requirements. The flats, which should be completed by spring 2002, will vary in price, but £1m will net a three-bed, second-floor number with three bathrooms. If she decided to ask the audience for financial help, then she could move up to the fifth floor, where £1.15m buys a three-bed apartment with a terrace.

Having been thrown this lifeline of £1m, she might, however, decide to move out of the area. Were she to head to Hampstead, her cash would go little further. She could pick from an upper maisonette with three bedrooms on Eton Avenue, or another on Fitzjohn's Avenue with access to a communal garden or a four-bed penthouse apartment in The Tower, which is described in fluent estate agentese: "Conveniently located for Hampstead village with its wide range of restaurants, shops and transport facilities." All of the above cost £1m precisely.

But she may have tired of London. In Shrubb Hill in Chobham, Surrey, her winnings would buy a five-bed, three reception room house with garage parking. The location is described as "semi rural". On the Isle of Wight she could easily afford the £800,000 asking price for a three storey "marine residence" with panoramic sea views.

Up in the north, her £1m would go further in Macclesfield, as this would be the cost of the five bedroomed Mere Hall. Or she could go for a five bedroomed and four bathroomed bungalow set in two acres in Mottram St Andrew, near Stockport.

In Barnsley, Yorkshire, The Dean House is being offered for sale by agents Smiths. The proposition is a converted barn, again with five bedrooms, but this time with a conservatory too. It is set in 18 acres of land complete with ponds and woodland - "your own private environment", says the blurb. Although the asking price is £1.2m, this could probably be bargained down.

But it is to Scotland that the fortunate Ms Keppel will have to go for super luxury. FPD Savills is selling a "highly productive" farm in Angus for offers in excess of £980,000. The lots include a five-bed farm house, a three-bed bungalow, extensive farm buildings including grain storage for 1,000 tonnes and housing for 200 cattle, and a lot of land, which could be a perfect location for her to practise her chosen career of garden designer.

Top drawer: A £900,000 penthouse in Sulivan Road

Close to home: Stokenchurch Street would cost £1m-plus

Wait for it: The Kings development is still being built

webTitle: Tension over EU rapid reaction force

fields.headline: Greece and Turkey add to tensions
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: New problems have emerged over the EU's rapid reaction force because of tensions between Greece and Turkey.
fields.body:
New problems have emerged over the EU's rapid reaction force because of tensions between Greece and Turkey.

As controversy rages in Britain, diplomats in Brussels continue to pore over details of how the force would cooperate with Nato.

Key arrangements are supposed be nailed down by the EU's summit in Nice in less than two weeks, but Greece, a member of Nato and the EU, has indicated it is not happy with the demands of Turkey, a Nato ally.

Britain joined its 14 EU partners on Monday in committing troops and equipment to the 60,000-strong force.

Greece's objections are linked to demands by Turkey for a clear role in decision-making, arguing that its rights as a Nato member have to be respected.

Turkey fears that EU forces might one day be deployed in Cyprus or the Aegean, and insists on having a veto on such action.

webTitle: £18m deal puts Ridsdale on the defensive

fields.headline: £18m deal puts Ridsdale on the defensive
fields.standfirst: Leeds' decision looks reckless
fields.trailText: Peter Ridsdale, chairman of Leeds Sporting, the parent of Leeds United, was in sporting form himself this week, providing us with a bit of a financial forecast for the current year as he sought to justify the £18m splashed out on West Ham defender Rio Ferdinand.
fields.body:
Peter Ridsdale, chairman of Leeds Sporting, the parent of Leeds United, was in sporting form himself this week, providing us with a bit of a financial forecast for the current year as he sought to justify the £18m splashed out on West Ham defender Rio Ferdinand.

"Our annual income has gone up from £20m to £57m and this year it should be more than £70m. That's not because of transfer dealings, it's because of our success on the pitch and the finance that attracts," he said. "We generate our revenue from qualifying for Europe, the income of playing in the Champions League, the gate receipts, the sponsorship, everything that success brings. That type of money far outweighs anything we might lose in the transfer market."

Mr Ridsdale almost passes for a man running a successful business. But then he did not refer to the fact that Leeds' share price has halved since the spring. Whatever the success on the pitch, the City says this company is headed into a financial offside trap.

While it is true that Leeds' turnover reached £57m in the year to end-June (up from £37m), pre-tax profits were a measly £1.2m and would have disappeared completely but for the fact that net player transfer costs improved sharply during the period.

Mr Ridsdale should know that the Ferdinand deal has set off alarm bells at one or two of Leeds' biggest shareholders. They are concerned that the chairman minding their £50m firm has just bet a third of its market capitalisation on one trophy asset - whose future value remains clouded by the EU's move against the player transfer system. Throw in Ferdinand's salary and bonuses over the next five years and Mr Ridsdale's wager looks seriously reckless.

Where the cash is coming from remains unclear, though there's talk of a Sky payment landing in January. But Leeds' balance sheet is not going to be a pretty sight. The annual amortisation bill for players alone will jump 40% to £12m on current figures. Elland Road regulars aside, investors should kick this stock out of their portfolios - sharpish.

Long-term view

For the ordinary City onlooker, the name Beeson Gregory does not immediately conjure images of trail-blazing banking. But it does in Oxford. In what is being seen as a landmark deal, Beeson, a small broking and corporate finance operation, is providing Oxford University's chemistry department with £20m of funding to help finance new laboratories and other infrastructure, bolstering the department's boffins and, one hopes, helping to attract bright new talent.

At a time when hi-tech, in whatever form, is out of favour with investors Beeson's move looks brave. It is but only in the sense of being innovative. The underlying logic looks hard-headed since the chemistry department already has a track record of successful spin-outs: Oxford Asymmetry, Oxford Molecular, Opsys and Oxford Biosensors.

In exchange for its investment, Beeson will get equity stakes in spin-outs from the department for the next 15 years. Assuming the equity retention level of previous spin-outs, the new venture will only need tto bring to the market ventures with an aggregate value of around £250m for Beeson to be in the black. It is time other private sector investors (and academics) took a similarly long-term view.

No say

Employees at MG Rover are being offered 800 free non-voting shares each in a move to motivate the workforce at the struggling car-maker. It sounds a laudable gesture, although the workers will be aware that the stock will only have any worth if the company is floated, sold or makes enough money to pay a dividend.

Of course, under the deal with BMW it got a £500m dowry from the German car-maker provided it was not sold within two years. The chances of flotation are equally remote. The company has one new car in the Rover 75 and its survival depends upon the success of a string of new models due in the next couple of years. A glimpse this week of the first of its "sporty" MG saloons suggests that it will have an uphill struggle. In the meantime, it is unlikely to have spare cash to pay dividends.

The scheme leaves 40% of the company - and all the votes - with the four executive directors headed by John Towers. The remaining 60% is to be split between employees and dealers.

The 800 shares per worker only account for a third of the 25% set aside for the workforce. The rest are to be held in trust which will dole them out to new employees. Fair enough. But since the management team is against giving workers votes - and a say in the company's future - it could at least have set up an internal market on which the shares could be traded. Maybe they feared there would be a rush to get out.

But since the management team is against giving workers votes - and a say in the company's future - it could at least have set up an internal market on which the shares could be traded. Maybe they feared there would be a rush to get out.

webTitle: NatWest sales breaches incur £750,000 in fines

fields.headline: NatWest sales breaches incur £750,000 in fines
fields.trailText: City watchdogs have fined National Westminster bank £750,000 for breaching regulations on the sale of insurance and investments.
fields.body:
City watchdogs have fined National Westminster bank £750,000 for breaching regulations on the sale of insurance and investments.

The breaches occurred between January 1993 and June last year, and NatWest, now owned by Royal Bank of Scotland, has been forced to pay £2.35m in compensation to 4,500 investors.

The regulator Imro criticised NatWest's administration of its unit trusts and fined it £250,000. Imro said NatWest had failed to give agreed discounts to investors or carry out regular reviews of investments held in customer portfolios to ensure they performed in line with other portfolios.

The Personal Investment Authority, now part of the Financial Services Authority, fined NatWest £500,000.

The PIA said its fine, the second largest it has imposed, related to breaches including inadequate monitoring of sales staff and failure to provide proper training. It identified the faults during a visit to the bank in autumn 1997.

However, the PIA said no NatWest customers had suffered as a result of the breaches.

Both regulators said NatWest had put in place a programme of remedial work which should prevent a recurrence of the offences.

Yesterday's move follows a £100,000 fine imposed on Lloyds TSB bank by Imro on Thursday for a breach in its securities services division.

webTitle: The Bush at the heart of the matter

fields.headline: The Bush at the heart of the matter
fields.standfirst:
George W's running mate may be little more than a Trojan horse

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Because of the metaphorical significance of the vice-president's ticker - "a heartbeat away" from the Oval Office in the ancient phrase - vice-presidential candidates have traditionally been younger and healthier than the first man on the slate. When George W Bush broke this convention by hitching his own ambitions to an older guy who had endured three heart attacks and cardiac bypass surgery, the consensus among commentators was that this demonstrated Bush's stupidity and the influence of his father, the last-but-one president, whom Cheney served.
fields.body:
Because of the metaphorical significance of the vice-president's ticker - "a heartbeat away" from the Oval Office in the ancient phrase - vice-presidential candidates have traditionally been younger and healthier than the first man on the slate. When George W Bush broke this convention by hitching his own ambitions to an older guy who had endured three heart attacks and cardiac bypass surgery, the consensus among commentators was that this demonstrated Bush's stupidity and the influence of his father, the last-but-one president, whom Cheney served.

But let me try out a conspiracy theory, which raises the alternative possibility that the younger Bush, in choosing Cheney, was being extremely clever, but that his brilliant plan was threatened this week by the would-be Veep's closing artery.

This is how the theory goes: for most of the 1990s, the Republican party in America craved a particular presidential candidate. They wanted him to stand in 1996 and again in 2000 but, when he refused to run, made do with Dole and Bush. The absent contender was General Colin Powell, the one right-wing figure able to win over female and black voters from Clinton's core support. But the general ducked the ballots. It's generally reckoned that there were two reasons for this. Powell feared being shot in New Hampshire or Iowa by some racist crazy and resented press scrutiny, during a year-long campaign, of his wife's medical history and certain episodes in his own military career.

In short, the problem was that General Powell wanted high political office but did not want an election campaign. This is a common enough problem which leads to many potentially able people being elected only in their own heads. But it is my wild surmise that George W Bush saw a way of parachuting in the general without the irritation of primaries and campaign tittle-tattle.

Two years into a Bush presidency, Vice President Cheney calls reporters to the official residence. Flanked by wife and daughters, he explains that he could simply not refuse the call in 2000 to serve his nation but that the stresses of the job have proved greater than expected - there has perhaps been a recession or international crisis by now - and his family have urged him not to take foolish risks with his health. A non-specific "scare" might be cited. (A really extreme version of this conspiracy theory has Bush gambling that Veep Cheney would not even need to call a press conference on leaving office but I'm not yet that cynical about politicians.) President Bush nominates Colin Powell, who instantly inherits a presidential level of security protection and is nodded through by Congress and press in these emergency circumstances. A Bush-Powell ticket is Little George's best bet of getting the second term his daddy didn't.

But then, on November 7, it all went wrong. The presidential transition - in theory a time when candidates catch up on sleep - became as tense as 100 elections and Cheney's heart put him in hospital. He insists that he will be fit to take office if the Florida numbers work out but, if he does, every winter cold or changed engagement diary will crash Wall Street. Under Bush and Cheney, America would be in the hands of a recovering alcoholic and a crock.

If a new vice-presidential candidate is needed, Bush could nominate Powell now but the general would assume office amid the kind of media scrutiny and national attention he was desperate to avoid. But there are two intriguing alternatives to the anonymous throng of governors and senators who Cheney overcame during the initial pick.

Little George would be the first dynastic president of modern times and is a politician who has surrounded himself with his pop's friends. This trait at least partly led him to choose his cardiac patient running mate. Now, though, he could cut out the middleman and appoint the previous President Bush as his vice president. This Bush-Bush ticket would be the logical conclusion of Little George's political career, which has largely been motivated by working out patriarchal and Freudian confusions. There has also been considerable worry among TV viewers and journalists about whether future American elections can live up to the captivating lunacy of this one. It certainly would if the Republicans' Bush-Bush 2004 slate was challenged by the Democrats' Clinton-Clinton, with Bill as Hillary's running mate.

Leaning on Dad, though, might draw too much attention to the dynastic ambitions of the clan and Little George's status as the first genetically modified president. So, instead, the replacing of Cheney could be used to heal some of the wounds caused in America by the current electoral confusion. In this scheme, Bush would invite Gore to become his vice president on a national unity ticket. Many commentators have suggested that the virtual tie reflects the problem of succeeding Clinton. Each candidate had half of Clinton's skills - Gore impressive behind a desk, Bush happy in front of a crowd - but lacked the other half. The electoral dead-heat acknowledged the impossibility of having both. Well, now they can.

These last two proposals are more than half-joking. About the first, though, I am entirely serious. Dick Cheney's health broke for real a year or two before it was supposed to give him a tactical sick-note. He was the Trojan horse running mate.

fields.headline: Claims Direct in £5m peace offering
fields.trailText: Claims Direct yesterday blamed "adverse media coverage" for forcing it to set aside £5m to hand out to disgruntled customers.
fields.body:
Claims Direct yesterday blamed "adverse media coverage" for forcing it to set aside £5m to hand out to disgruntled customers.

News of the payments by the "no win, no fee" insurance compensation chaser drove its shares down 44p to close at 140p, well below the 180p price at which they were floated in July and their 353.5p peak in September.

Many Claims Direct customers thought they were entitled to reclaim the insurance premium they had to pay when the company agreed to act for them. They are able to do so under the Access to Justice Act passed last year - but only for cases which started after April 1 this year.

Claims Direct said yesterday that in some cases started before April 1 damages received by customers had been substantially reduced by the client's inability to fully recover insurance premiums from defendants.

The company is to make a £1m provision in its first half results for ex-gratia payments and expects to make a further £4m provision in the second half. The payments would leave customers no worse off than under its previous percentage fee arrangement.

Claims Direct is working with underwriters to improve the terms of its "after the event" insurance policy. "We are expecting shortly to be able to announce the introduction of enhanced insurance cover designed to ring fence a minimum amount of compensation for the claimant," a spokesman said.

The company hoped existing policyholders would switch to the new policy when it is introduced.

The Claims Direct franchise holders who handle the injury claims used to take 30% of any compensation recovered but the company later moved to a flat fee system.

The share plunge, which left the company valued at £265m, came after the board said that first half results would exceed market expectations. It forecast that turnover would rise from £9.8m to more than £42m, lifting pretax profit, before amortisation, interest credits and exceptional items, from £4.3m to more than £11.5m.

Claims Direct was set up in 1995 by Tony Sullman, a former taxi driver, and prospered as Britain increasingly adopted the American "compensation culture". When the company floated, Mr Sullman's 60% stake was worth £203m. He retained 30%.

webTitle: Lazard finds ally to beef up defence

fields.headline: Lazard finds ally to beef up defence
fields.trailText: Investment banking group Lazard yesterday strengthened its defences against possible predators through an alliance with one of the most powerful names in European banking.
fields.body:
Investment banking group Lazard yesterday strengthened its defences against possible predators through an alliance with one of the most powerful names in European banking.

Crédit Agricole has agreed to buy a stake in a key holding company within the complex family dominated ownership structure. It will acquire the 31% holding in la Rue Impériale de Lyon from French corporate financier Vincent Bolloré for Fr3.9bn.

Lazard's management, led by chairman Michel David-Weill, have been under pressure from shareholders, including Mr Bolloré and banking group UBS Warburg to simplify the ownership structure in order to reduce the discount to net asset value at which the shares trade. They are reported to be seeking asset sales and the return of cash to shareholders.

The group, traditionally one of the top names in the investment banking world, is also facing fierce competition as the business becomes increasingly dominated by big global houses such as Merrill Lynch, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.

Lazard has made some changes. The semi-independent investment banks in Paris, London and New York have been brought closer together and this month two of the companies which hold Lazard shares, Eurafrance and Azeo were merged. But Mr Bolloré's decision to bow out - having almost doubled his money - is seen as strengthening the hand of the management in the face of any pressure for further change.

Crédit Agricole is seen as a natural ally for Lazards as the two banks have existing commercial links going back to 1994. Though Crédit Agricole is a mutual organisation it is considering the possibility of a stock market listing.

Under the terms of the agreement between Crédit Agricole and Mr Bolloré, the French bank will be able to buy the stake at some point before the end of June next year. But though the purchase has not been completed the agreement allows Crédit Agricole to vote the la Rue Impériale de Lyon shares from now on.

The deal also includes an agreement that Crédit Agricole will not seek to increase its holding until the end of June 2019.

In a joint statement yesterday Crédit Agricole, which vies with BNP-Paribas for the title of France's top bank, and la Rue Impériale de Lyon said the deal would develop " a new and profitable co-operation".

Crédit Agricole will also appoint two members to the la Rue Impériale de Lyon board. If Crédit Agricole backs the incumbent management the combination should be sufficient to prevent other shareholders forcing through changes against the board's wishes.

"UBS now finds itself somewhat alone for going into battle because Michel David-Weill no longer has the pressure to simplify the structure," said one Paris based analyst.

UBS Warburg declined to comment but it is likely to draw at least some comfort from the fact that the price Crédit Agricole is paying for its shares is much closer to their net asset value than Mr Bolloré's original purchase price.

Family Fortunes

The complex control structure of the Lazard empire has two main strands. The families of four present and former partners, including Michel David-Weill, hold a 22.4% stake directly in the merchant banking group.

In addition the families speak through another 17% through a series of interlocking companies, La Rue Impériale de Lyon, Immobilière Marseillaise, Eurafrance and Azeo , which were merged this year.

Mr Bolloré bought into la Rue Impériale de Lyon, where a company called Société Civile Haussman Percier - which is controlled by the four families - owns 45.68% of the shares and speaks for 61.64% of the votes.

Lazard, too, owns a stake in Haussman Percier.

UBS Warburg, however, took a slightly different route, acquiring smaller stakes in the other three holding companies.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Dando trial date set
fields.body:
Dando trial date set

The man accused of murdering TV presenter Jill Dando will stand trial at the Old Bailey on February 26 next year, a judge decided yesterday.

Barry Michael George, 40, of Fulham, west London, was remanded in custody after a 15-minute hearing at the court. Miss Dando, who presented the BBC's Crimewatch programme, was shot outside her Fulham home in April last year.

Taxi drivers seek compensation

Thousands of taxi drivers are set to seek compensation from the Coventry-based black-cab manufacturer London Taxis International, which recalled vehicles because of a safety flaw.

Record month for refugees

The number of refugees arriving in Britain last month was the highest so far this year, Home Office figures showed yesterday.

In all, 6,970 asylum seek ers applied to stay in October, up 535 on September and 675 on the same month last year.

Soccer fan dies happy

A lifelong Sunderland fan died happy when he had a heart attack after seeing his team beat Newcastle by one goal in a highly-charged local derby, it emerged yesteday at the funeral of Ron Hutcheon, 71 - whose last words were "two-one".

Stubbs horse may net £3m

A racehorse painting sold for £360 just over a century ago is expected to fetch more than £3m at auction in London next Thursday.

A 17-word inscription discovered on the canvas during cleaning shows Euston, A Dappled Grey Racehorse was a favourite work of the 18th century animal painter George Stubbs.

New Tornados delayed

Deployment of upgraded Tornado bombers will be delayed indefinitely because of a problem with software for a new laser guided bombing system, the Ministry of Defence disclosed last night.

The Tornado modernisation programme is now estimated to cost over £900m, a third more than originally forecast.

fields.headline: A frightener for Labour
fields.trailText: Your report of the Preston byelection contained no serious discussion of why Labour's 18,000 majority had been slashed to just over 4,000, no attempt to explain "voter apathy", and dismissed the Lancashire Socialist Alliance vote with the suggestion that it was not as big as Labour feared.
fields.body:
Your report of the Preston byelection (Clean sweep for Labour in election test, November 24) contained no serious discussion of why Labour's 18,000 majority had been slashed to just over 4,000, no attempt to explain "voter apathy", and dismissed the Lancashire Socialist Alliance vote with the suggestion that it was not as big as Labour feared.

The LSA has been in existence for a mere 10 weeks. In that time we campaigned hard, put politics into the campaign and rattled a few New Labour cages. Our vote was in excess of our wildest expectations. To get 1,210 votes - and save our deposit - on a platform of wealth redistribution, ending Third World debt, environmental protection and increased welfare spending suggests to us that there is a significant minority looking for a socialist alternative to New Labour's Tory policies.

We will fight the Preston seat in the general election, will stand against Jack Straw in Blackburn and will continue campaigning to defend working-class communities from the attacks of the New Labour government. Labour should be afraid - we are coming after them.
Michael Lavalette
Lancashire Socialist Alliance

 Four byelections record regrettably low turnouts; voter apathy in all elections is increasing (Analysis, November 20). What's to be done? Step forward the National Lottery. If everyone who voted were to be given a free lottery ticket on leaving the polling station, and there was a decent jackpot of £100-200m for general elections, with proportionately less for local and byelections, would not more people make the effort to turn up?
Chris Miller
London

 I see that the BBC and ITV have agreed to show debates between the three main party leaders (Party leaders presented with terms for TV election debates, November 24). Pity that Channel Four isn't involved. I'm sure they would have devised a format that would have enabled us to vote all of them out.
Stuart Waterworth
Tavistock, Devon
