fields.headline: 'Cruise ship of the skies' unveiled
fields.standfirst:
Flying back to golden age of luxury

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The tinkling sounds of a pianist in evening suit should soothe any last remaining tensions from passengers as they lounge in the thickly carpeted salon, surrounded by bookcases and subdued lighting. A grand staircase leads to the upper dining area, where champagne will be served at the bar.
fields.body:
The tinkling sounds of a pianist in evening suit should soothe any last remaining tensions from passengers as they lounge in the thickly carpeted salon, surrounded by bookcases and subdued lighting. A grand staircase leads to the upper dining area, where champagne will be served at the bar.

The concept of the "cruise ship of the skies", to recapture the halcyon days of the great liners crossing the Atlantic, was conjured up yesterday by the makers of the world's largest jumbo, the A3XX, which unveiled a mock-up of the 555-seat airliner at the Airbus Toulouse headquarters in France.

The seats are well padded and can fold into beds, now commonly accepted as part of the deal for premier class travellers. A shower room is fitted, although the designers admit that water supplies will be limited because of weight.

Robert Lange, A3XX marketing director, said a casino and duty-free shopping area could be built into the huge belly of the 80 metre long aircraft, depending on the demands of the airline - Emirates, Singapore Airlines and Air France are already committed - or it could be turned into an expansive cargo area.

The A3XX mock-up did not extend to the upper deck, where 400 economy passengers will be placed. A dark void, more than half the size of a football pitch, stretched into the distance. The luxuries of first class will not be experienced by most passengers, but Airbus did promise an inch more leg room than its rival, the Boeing 747, to alleviate fears of "economy class syndrome". More videos were promised as well.

The A3XX will divide economy from premier class passengers, so that neither need see each other. "It's a bit like the upstairs, downstairs idea, and will be unique to the A3XX," said an Airbus official.

According to Mr Lange, the A3XX will be quieter than any other aircraft and will carry 35% more passengers than the Boeing 747.

Airlines who go down the budget route by dispensing with the niceties of the first class cabin will be able to cram in up to 850 economy travellers. The proposed stretch version of the aircraft can be designed to seat up to 1,000, but that is a decade away.

During the planning process, Airbus has been negotiating with the world's 50 leading airports to make sure that the A3XX will be able to land when it flies commercially for the first time in 2006.

Mr Lange said that the cost of adapting New York's JFK airport was around £80m, but that Heathrow might be able to include it in current costs and that its landing charges would remain unchanged.

The airport operator, BAA, said that it was planning to accommodate the A3XX by altering the airport. BAA said it was vital for the arrival of the A3XX that Terminal 5 was built, but that terminals 3 and 4 would be able to receive the aircraft.

fields.headline: Warning fails to curb trade
fields.trailText: All things considered, not a bad session. After all, when a high-flying technology company issues a shock profits warning and Wall Street is shut for half a day, leading shares tend to go down. But while the software sector was clobbered by a profits warning from Anglo-French computer services group Sema, off 274p to 346p, blue chips managed to finish the week on a positive note.
fields.body:
All things considered, not a bad session. After all, when a high-flying technology company issues a shock profits warning and Wall Street is shut for half a day, leading shares tend to go down. But while the software sector was clobbered by a profits warning from Anglo-French computer services group Sema, off 274p to 346p, blue chips managed to finish the week on a positive note.

Aside from a healthy early performance from Wall Street, the key factor pushing the FTSE 100 up 40.3 points to 6,327.6, was a strong showing from the telecoms and banking sectors.

With many stocks in the telecoms sector back to the levels they were trading at in October last year - BT, up 9.5p at 650.5p, for example is about 30% below - canny investors snapped up the likes of Energis, 11p higher at 476p, and Cable & Wireless, 19p stronger at 939p.

Vodafone was also in demand, rising 6p to 256p, after Schroder Salomon Smith Barney advanced the argument that the mobile phone firm could be the one natural defensive stock in a sector short of defensive names. Schroder believes Vodafone will outperform the market in medium term and has set a 340p price target.

Schroder said: "We believe that Vodafone is a natural target for growth money in this bear market for TMT stocks."

Nevertheless, there were some poor performers in the sector. Marconi slipped back 11p to 716p ahead of next week's interim figures. While profits are expected to be in line with expectation, dealers are bracing themselves for a gloomy outlook statement.

But this performance was more than offset by movements over in the banking sector. Barclays climbed 27p to £18.88, Lloyds TSB rose 6p to 700p and Royal Bank of Scotland put on 13p to £14.23 - all benefiting from the view that domestic interest rates have peaked.

In fact all yesterday's session lacked was a really juicy bid story but that was not for a lack of trying. Many tales were put forward but none really stacked up. Among the more convincing was RMC.

According to the gossips, the concrete maker is being stalked by a German financial consortium. And though the stock acted as if that were the case - the shares ended 23.5p higher at 550p - traders were not convinced. They pointed out that in the wake of the profit warning from Hanson, up 7.5p to 355p, RMC shares had dropped to a level last seen in 1993 and, with a large stock overhang cleared, a recovery back to the 600p level was almost a foregone conclusion.

Elsewhere, Freeserve advanced 8.25p to 157.5p on talk that an auction could break out for the UK's leading internet service provider. The feeling is both Germany's T-Online and Italy's Tiscali are both considering countering any offer from French group Wanadoo.

Buyers were also nibbling away at construction group Alfred McAlpine, up 5p to 225.5p and mining minnow Brancote, 6p better at 169.5p.

There was also some interest in the life assurance sector on the back of reports that German group Allianz is on the prowl for an acquisition. Predictably attention turned to Royal & Sun Alliance, up 27p to 552p, but once again no one was convinced. Allianz has not made a hostile bid in 20 years and as far as anyone knows Royal Sun has no intention of selling out.

On a more fundamental tack, tobacco group BAT, 23p higher to 515p, clawed back some of Thursday's losses after Merrill Lynch repeated its "buy" re-commendation, arguing that Wednesday's US court ruling had no significant implication for other tobacco law suits.

The FTSE Techmark 100 ended 99.17 points lower at 2,745.34 after the software and computer services sector was sold off in the wake of the Sema profits warning.

CMG fell 121p to 925p, Logica lost 108p to £15.30p and Misys slipped 30p to 568p.

fields.headline: Tom Kinsey
fields.standfirst: Painter who cast an impish eye on life from the counter-culture
fields.trailText: The painter Tom Kinsey has died of a heart attack, aged 73, a matter of weeks after his great friend, the peace campaigner Pat Pottle. With Pottle, during the 1950s and early 1960s, he campaigned, drank, and told stories in the Committee of 100, the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament and the Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation - making mischief and some history.
fields.body:
The painter Tom Kinsey has died of a heart attack, aged 73, a matter of weeks after his great friend, the peace campaigner Pat Pottle. With Pottle, during the 1950s and early 1960s, he campaigned, drank, and told stories in the Committee of 100, the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament and the Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation - making mischief and some history.

Tom was born in Czechoslovakia; his mother was of Austrian aristocratic descent, his father a Catholic doctor who devoted himself to the republican cause - specifically the anarchists - in civil-war Spain for two years. In 1939, his parents brought him to England. He spent his adolescence in the Welsh border country and was educated at Ellesmere College, Shropshire. In 1947, inspired by a passing van proclaiming "Kinsey, tripe dealers of Flint", he formally changed his name from Katz, his father's surname.

In the 1950s, he studied at St Martin's and the Royal College Of Art, where he moved into the milieu of the likes of John Minton, Jeffrey Bernard and Quentin Crisp. In 1953, Tom featured at the Young Contemporaries, and the Artists For Peace exhibitions. The latter was sponsored by John Berger, Josef Herman and Stanley Spencer. His early style was heavily influenced by the 20th-century Flemish painter Constant Permeke.

In 1958, Tom left the RCA and moved to Snowdonia to paint, work in the slate quarries and pursue his fondness for mountain climbing - he led local rescue teams. His subject became the north Wales hill-farmers, men with huge hands, hard faces and wonderfully expressive eyes, the pictorial equivalent of RS Thomas's poems - "simple, monumental people", in the words of a 1969 Guardian review. "These paintings are different," observed LS Lowry, who bought three of them. "They have life".

At the same time, Tom became involved in CND, the Committee of 100, and the Spies For Peace group. He was distinguished by his talent for organisation and his anarchic, mischievous sense of humour.

With Pottle, he was a secretary of the Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation. He travelled to eastern Europe as Russell's emissary, and, during the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, sent admonitory telegrams under Russell's name to the Soviet leader Nikita Kruschev and to President Kennedy - and another to Russell telling him that his name had been attached. The philosopher approved.

In the later 1960s, the home Tom shared with his then wife, Anna, and his sons, John and Tim, at Nantgwynant, became a haven for lost souls, pop stars and counter-cultural illumnati, with whom he plotted, informed by his interests in everything from Aneurin and Dafydd ap Gwilym to Jelly Roll Morton And His Red Hot Peppers.

For some years, he gave up painting because, he said, the people he had painted were no longer there. During this period, Tom became, to his amusement and the consternation of friends, the world's only anarchist master of foxhounds, a Snowdonian foot-hunt. When he began to paint again, in the late 1980s, the subject of one of his more striking works was of Leon Trotsky dressed as a foxhunter. Trotsky, Tom had discovered, was an enthusiast of the hunt.

During the last decade, Tom's paintings, spiced by his impish humour, reflected his interests in jazz and anarchism. His extraordinary work had become "deeply unfashionable", he was amused to be told by the critic Brian Sewell. One of these paintings, based on Christ's Entry Into Brussels by the late 19th-century Belgian expressionist James Ensor, depicted Margaret Thatcher leading a New Orleans marching band through London, followed by the homeless, the National Front and the various grey suits of her legacy.

In 1998, Tom sold up in Wales, and drove his elderly, four-wheel-drive Daihatsu off to a new, cheaper life in the Czech Republic. He could be eccentric, troubled as he was by an almost lifelong illness (about which he never complained) but he possessed an irrepressible love of life. He was, as someone described him, a gentleman and an anarchist who never sold out the contradictions in his character, a great raconteur, kind, loyal and generous.

He and Anna divorced; she survives him, as do his two sons.

fields.headline: Glynwed retains its glow
fields.trailText: Despite this week's profits warning and subsequent downgrades - most City analysts have cut their pre-tax profits forecasts by at least 15% - buyers can be found for Glynwed, owner of the Aga cooker brand.
fields.body:
Despite this week's profits warning and subsequent downgrades - most City analysts have cut their pre-tax profits forecasts by at least 15% - buyers can be found for Glynwed, owner of the Aga cooker brand.

Merrill Lynch yesterday repeated its "buy" rating on the firm, highlighting the potential upside in the stock at last night's closing price of 196p.

On Wednesday Glynwed, which is structured into two divisions - a core pipes operation and consumer and food service unit - signalled its intention to break itself in to two distinct businesses.

Merrill Lynch believes a break-up of the business could realise in excess of 300p a share, while on a sum-of-the-parts basis it reckons the group is worth at least 240p. Moreover, most analysts think Glynwed's intention to demerge will flush out offers for the company. After all, most of its businesses have market-leading positions.

fields.trailText: Ian Birchall writes: George Matthews recalls that Bill Wainwright (Obituary, November 16) "worked on publicity for the war effort" at Communist party headquarters. His most notorious effort was the 1942 pamphlet, Clear Out Hitler's Agents.
fields.body: Ian Birchall writes: George Matthews recalls that Bill Wainwright (Obituary, November 16) "worked on publicity for the war effort" at Communist party headquarters. His most notorious effort was the 1942 pamphlet, Clear Out Hitler's Agents. The "agents" were the small band of British Trotskyists - courageous and perceptive people who, three decades earlier than Wainwright, had become critical of the Soviet Union and its travesty of socialism. Wainwright's pamphlet urged readers, on encountering a Trotskyist, to "treat him as you would an open Nazi". This was a green light to every CP member to physically attack Trotskyists, and many such acts were committed. The surviving representatives of British Stalinism should not be allowed to erase such episodes from the record.

fields.headline: Kenya's Masai left in wilderness of dying cattle and red tape
fields.standfirst: Rains too late and aid too little for great herdsmen
fields.trailText: All over Kenya's parched south, hungry Masai are hoisting starving cattle to their feet. This cattle-rearing people has lost up to 80% of its herds in the past six months and unless the last boney animals can be goaded into eating the first new grass for months, the herders will lose them, too.
fields.byline: James Astill in Kajiado, southern Kenya
fields.body:
All over Kenya's parched south, hungry Masai are hoisting starving cattle to their feet. This cattle-rearing people has lost up to 80% of its herds in the past six months and unless the last boney animals can be goaded into eating the first new grass for months, the herders will lose them, too.

The Masai are among the hardest hit by east Africa's three-year drought. But the emergency relief operation, say the aid-agency people working among them, is in danger of passing them by.

Much of Kenya, including the Masai heartland of Kajiado, has had rain this week for the first time in months. But it is too little and too late for the 4m people surviving on food handouts. And in Kajiado, it has made things worse, the chilly showers doubling the death rate among the cattle.

"This rain is not going to be enough to change the food situation in Kenya," says Andrew Aho of Outpost Centres, the main relief group in Kajiado. "For the first month, rains are only hope, not solution. But it is too much for starving cows. They just die off."

And cows are all the Masai have; rearing and grazing cattle is what they do. "Before, when there was no rain we could sell our cows to buy food," said Nancy Pashile, a local leader, as food was given out in Kajiado this week. "But now they are dead we only have what we are given."

Six months ago, the cows sold for about 20,000 Kenyan shillings (£200); now they sell for 500 shillings (£5), the price of their hides. In the hope that one of his last surviving animals will one day have meat on it again, Lepapa Buibui hoists up its pitiful haunch, until the back legs are up. Then he tugs at its horns, until it rises and totters, glassy-eyed, towards a rare patch of green.

"We had 121 cows but all except 20 have died," he says. "In the daytime we could keep them standing, but at night they lay down and died. Those that are left will die any moment." Although most of the Masai's cows - 80%, according to Mr Aho - have died in the past five months, the level of food aid to Kajiado has not been revised since distributions began in July.

Moreover, what seems to have been a clerical error made even that original level low. The Kenya food security steering group, which is led jointly by the government and the UN World Food Programme (WFP), decided that 60% of Kajiado's people - "around 230,000 Masai" - should get food, though the figure assessed on the ground was 80%.

"The food security group thinks Kajiado is OK, but it needs more food," says Zippy Mbati, WFP's district monitor. In some areas, she says, food is being shared among twice the number of people it was intended for.

Mr Aho says that a report on the mistake has been submitted to the food security group three times since July, but without success. "I feel the bottom line is that the Masai haven't ever been really accepted in the overall scheme of running this country and I would say that other areas end up getting more food and more publicity."

And it is not just the number being helped, but the quality of the aid that is lower, too: those being fed receive 50% of the full emergency ration, a mixture of maize, pulses and oil. All the aid agencies actually working on the ground in the district agree this is not enough.

"For the people who have been hit hardest we need a 100% ration," says Imke van der Honing from the Semi-Arid Rural Development Programme.

WFP's Lindsay Davies disagrees. "Based on a rapid assessment done by multi-agencies, WFP thinks that 50% is adequate," she says.

But if that is so, ask the agencies in Kajiado, why is child malnutrition endemic? Maura O'Donohue, a nutritionalist with the Catholic agency Cafod, recently toured the district: "How can 50% rations be fine if people are dying?" she wondered.

Two months ago, Mr Aho asked the UN children's fund Unicef to distribute protein-enriched supplementary food to Kajiado's wasted children. Unicef responded by asking for a nutritional survey, and is still digesting its contents.

The survey results will show that 60% of Masai children need supplements, says Mr Aho, who organised the survey. "I'm saying to Unicef, 'What can we do to get food?' he says.

"I'm not a nutritionalist, I'm just trying to get the job done and today the job is to get food to the children." In Nairobi yesterday, Unicef's Maniza Zaman disagreed with his assessment. Of Kajiado's children, 20% are malnourished, although 8% severely so," she said. "Kajiado needs supplementary food but it needs to be carefully targeted."

The UN is reluctant to provide aid unless it can guarantee that the right people are getting it, with demonstrable results. But in an emergency, says Mr Aho, that means a lot of people go hungry while the bureaucratic wheels turn.

Mr Van der Honing, who has just received funding for emergency water wells after a four-month wait, says, "There is a lot of bureaucracy and that doesn't change when there is an emergency."

In Kajiado, it was clear that food aid intended for a specific - even if inadequate - number of people, was being distributed equally among all, diluting the effect.

In the aisle of Ellalai Methodist church, a lone building on the vast savannah signposted in Korean script by Korean missionaries now departed, community leaders portioned out maize. "They're not dividing it up as they've been told. They're dividing it up equally amongst everyone who needs it," says Ms Mbati. This may not please WFP, but for the Masai, it is the only way, she says: "Their culture tells them to share everything equally."

Kenya's food security group expects to extend the national emergency operation at least until June, when the next rains are due.

But for the Masai, the crisis will last much longer, regardless of what level of rations they are given. If there is pasture, it will take at least two years to rebuild the herds, says Mr Van der Honing. The Masai will need feeding for at least another year.

"This rain is not going to be enough to change the food situation in Kenya," says Andrew Aho of Outpost Centres, the main relief group in Kajiado. "For the first month, rains are only hope, not solution. But it is too much for starving cows. They just die off." And cows are all the Masai have; rearing and grazing cattle is what they do. "Before, when there was no rain we could sell our cows to buy food," said Nancy Pashile, a local leader, as food was given out in Kajiado this week. "But now they are dead we only have what we are given." Six months ago, the cows sold for about 20,000 Kenyan shillings (£200); now they sell for 500 shillings (£5), the price of their hides. In the hope that one of his last surviving animals will one day have meat on it again, Lepapa Buibui hoists up its pitiful haunch, until the back legs are up. Then he tugs at its horns, until it rises and totters, glassy-eyed, towards a rare patch of green. "We had 121 cows but all except 20 have died," he says. "In the daytime we could keep them standing, but at night they lay down and died. Those that are left will die any moment." Although most of the Masai's cows - 80%, according to Mr Aho - have died in the past five months, the level of food aid to Kajiado has not been revised since distributions began in July. Moreover, what seems to have been a clerical error made even that original level low. The Kenya food security steering group, which is led jointly by the government and the UN World Food Programme (WFP), decided that 60% of Kajiado's people - "around 230,000 Masai" - should get food, though the figure assessed on the ground was 80%. "The food security group thinks Kajiado is OK, but it needs more food," says Zippy Mbati, WFP's district monitor. In some areas, she says, food is being shared among twice the number of people it was intended for. Mr Aho says that a report on the mistake has been submitted to the food security group three times since July, but without success. "I feel the bottom line is that the Masai haven't ever been really accepted in the overall scheme of running this country and I would say that other areas end up getting more food and more publicity." And it is not just the number being helped, but the quality of the aid that is lower, too: those being fed receive 50% of the full emergency ration, a mixture of maize, pulses and oil. All the aid agencies actually working on the ground in the district agree this is not enough. "For the people who have been hit hardest we need a 100% ration," says Imke van der Honing from the Semi-Arid Rural Development Programme. WFP's Lindsay Davies disagrees. "Based on a rapid assessment done by multi-agencies, WFP thinks that 50% is adequate," she says. But if that is so, ask the agencies in Kajiado, why is child malnutrition endemic? Maura O'Donohue, a nutritionalist with the Catholic agency Cafod, recently toured the district: "How can 50% rations be fine if people are dying?" she wondered. Two months ago, Mr Aho asked the UN children's fund Unicef to distribute protein-enriched supplementary food to Kajiado's wasted children. Unicef responded by asking for a nutritional survey, and is still digesting its contents. The survey results will show that 60% of Masai children need supplements, says Mr Aho, who organised the survey. "I'm saying to Unicef, 'What can we do to get food?' he says. "I'm not a nutritionalist, I'm just trying to get the job done and today the job is to get food to the children." In Nairobi yesterday, Unicef's Maniza Zaman disagreed with his assessment. Of Kajiado's children, 20% are malnourished, although 8% severely so," she said. "Kajiado needs supplementary food but it needs to be carefully targeted." The UN is reluctant to provide aid unless it can guarantee that the right people are getting it, with demonstrable results. But in an emergency, says Mr Aho, that means a lot of people go hungry while the bureaucratic wheels turn. Mr Van der Honing, who has just received funding for emergency water wells after a four-month wait, says, "There is a lot of bureaucracy and that doesn't change when there is an emergency." In Kajiado, it was clear that food aid intended for a specific - even if inadequate - number of people, was being distributed equally among all, diluting the effect. In the aisle of Ellalai Methodist church, a lone building on the vast savannah signposted in Korean script by Korean missionaries now departed, community leaders portioned out maize. "They're not dividing it up as they've been told. They're dividing it up equally amongst everyone who needs it," says Ms Mbati. This may not please WFP, but for the Masai, it is the only way, she says: "Their culture tells them to share everything equally." Kenya's food security group expects to extend the national emergency operation at least until June, when the next rains are due. But for the Masai, the crisis will last much longer, regardless of what level of rations they are given. If there is pasture, it will take at least two years to rebuild the herds, says Mr Van der Honing. The Masai will need feeding for at least another year.

fields.headline: Machine has nose for truffles
fields.trailText: The legendary truffle-sniffing dogs of France and Italy could soon find themselves hounded out of a job by a hi-tech Australian machine.
fields.body:
The legendary truffle-sniffing dogs of France and Italy could soon find themselves hounded out of a job by a hi-tech Australian machine.

The electronic nose, or E-nose, will soon be tested in Europe by a Tasmanian truffle grower, Tim Terry, and scientists from the University of New South Wales.

Mr Terry was the first person to farm truffles in Australia last year, but he became frustrated with the two specially trained labradors he used to harvest the elusive delicacy.

"Using dogs is not only time-consuming but it's costly," he said. "They will only work for about an hour before they start to lose concentration."

Mr Terry helped scientists at the Centre for Chemosensory Research develop the E-nose, a combination of sensors fitted to an all-terrain vehicle.

After gathering air samples, satellite-positioning technology is deployed to detect the whereabouts of the pungent fungus, which grows 10 to 15cm underground.

In France, the scientists will pit the E-nose against the finely-honed olfactory organs of Europe's top truffle hounds.

Truffle hunting is a lucrative - and cutthroat - business, partly because truffles, which form on oak and hazelnut tree roots, are so hard to find.

Europe's truffle industry has been rife with tales of prize hounds being poisoned by business rivals.

Pigs are also used to snaffle the fungi, which emit a scent similar to the male pheromone released by boars before mating.

webTitle: Putting black, brown and yellow in those red, white and blue jokes

fields.headline: Putting black, brown and yellow in those red, white and blue jokes
fields.standfirst:
Race barely figured in the US elections, but comedians are tackling the issue, says
                              Duncan Campbell
fields.trailText: Race barely figured in the US elections, but comedians are tackling the issue, says Duncan Campbell
fields.body:
Kim Tavares is part white, part black and part Latino so when she goes into a nice house, she says, she doesn't know whether to buy it, steal from it or clean it.

Tavares is performing in the Comedy Store on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles, one of nine stand-ups on show tonight. What is remarkable is that every single one of the nine - black, white, Latino, male, female - talks about race. Bill Clinton is still very popular with black voters, says (black) Jimmy Walker, because he is the "baddest" president they have ever had and they can "identify with his philandering ways".

(Latino) Freddy Lopo used to get thrown out of restaurants in Texas by owners asking if he wanted bean-flavoured pancakes and he reckons that the nation is defined by the food it eats - "Latinos eat beans, black people eat water-melons and white people eat everyone else's food." May May (black/Asian) gets grief from her friends who say that black women shouldn't go out with white men and vice versa. Barry Diamond (white) imitates a black prisoner talking about how white people smell like "wet chicken".

Some of the comedians focus on a drunk in the front row whose racial identity they want to know - "you're Latino, you can't be called Sam", he is told. He turns out to be Japanese-Hawaiian so that at least half of him can be offended by a later imitation of a Japanese kamikaze fighter pilot. What is remarkable about the jokes - although there might have to be a steward's inquiry as to whether they all qualified as "jokes" - was that most depended on negative stereotypes: Latinos as lazy, dope-smoking cleaners, Japanese as sadists, Chinese as incapable of mastering the English language, Arabs as sexual predators, whites as uptight wannabes with no identities of their own.

In the last couple of months, three films which deal head on with racial stereotypes and comedy have come out. This month sees the US publication of One Drop of Blood: The American Misadventure of Race (Farrar Straus & Giroux) which I think is a remarkable exploration of race in America and one which examines, in its three-part history of the white, black and native American experience, the issue of racial comedy with all its undertones. (I add the "I think" because I have known the author, Scott Malcomson, for many years.)

Race and comedy are intertwined as never before in the US. What is the great unspoken of the political debate is now chief topic of conversation in the world of comedy. The most provocative of the films is Spike Lee's Bamboozled, starring Damon Wayans and Savion Glover, a very pointed and uncomfortable satire on black people in the entertainment industry. It tells the story of a rather precious, Harvard-educated black television executive told by his white boss to come up with a new programme idea.

He develops the notion of using black actors in minstrel "blackface", little realising that what he thought was a subversive idea will turn into a hit show. Just to demonstrate how delicate a subject this is, the ads for the film, which showed "pickaninnies" eating watermelon, prompted calls from some African-American groups in Los Angeles for a boycott because the images were so demeaning.

Thus Lee's angry protest against damaging stereotypes ran into its own angry protest against damaging stereotypes. The film, as Stephen Holden, reviewing it in the New York Times, put it, "poses unanswerable questions about black identity, assimilation and the give and take between white and black culture".

As he notes, "the laughter it provokes is the kind that makes you squirm. But that's what good satire is supposed to do. Out of discomfort can come insight." In Spike Lee's other new film, The Original Kings of Comedy, the documentary of four leading black comedians in concert, (released in Britain this week), many of the jokes told by Steve Harvey, DL Hughley, Cedric the Entertainer and Bernie Mac rely on a shared acceptance of racial differences.

When some of the few white people in the audience are spotted in the front rows, they are teased for coming early because they are frightened that black people will have pinched their seats and they want to avoid a confrontation. Blacks will be arriving late, the audience is told, because they hope that there will be a chance for just that kind of confrontation.

There are jokes about how white the film Titanic was, how no black band would have played on as the ship went down, how they would have been unplugging their amps and heading for the boats, how Jesus must have been black because he turned water into wine at a wedding.

The third film is I'm the One That I Want which stars Margaret Cho, who also produced it. She is probably the only Korean-American stand-up comedienne to have had her own primetime television show when still in her 20s, to have been forced to go on a crash diet to keep the show and then to have hit the path of booze and drugs before finding salvation as a stand-up once more.

She is certainly the only Korean-American stand-up to have dated Quentin Tarantino, to have been told she was a disgrace to her people and to have been hailed as the greatest gay icon since Judy Garland. Cho, the daughter of a couple who ran a bookshop in San Francisco, was partly inspired by Richard Pryor.

In 1994, she was cast in the lead role in a sitcom, playing herself. ABC hoped it would be the breakthrough Asian sitcom in a country where TV habits still divide substantially by race. But the network had its own ideas of what a nice Asian girl should be like. Initially, Cho accommodated them by cutting out the very rude stuff about her family. After the first show was aired, her then boyfriend, Tarantino, rang her to tell her: "You let them take your voice away!"

She was sent to an "Asian consultant" to help her be "more Asian". Finally, the show was cancelled and Cho took a familiar toxic escape route. Now, five years on, she has cleaned up and bounced back. In her new film, she recounts this whole adventure in the form of a stand-up stage act in front of her adoring fans.

She thinks it is no coincidence that much of the most innovative comedy is coming from outside the white world. "Stand-up comedy is an outsider art so it's natural that this should happen," she says. "Race is such a part of the cultural consciousness here that it always has to be addressed [in shows]." She talks in her act of what it was like travelling as an Asian woman in Tennessee and in Florida, where she felt that the only way to feel at home was to seek out the nearest dry-cleaner (often run in the US by Korean-Americans.)

There were few role models for her to grow up with - even the Kung Fu series had a white guy, David Carradine, in the main part. "There were a few in MASH - in the background." Where non-white performers had been allowed into the foreground in the distant past, it had been as white people blacked-up as minstrels.

In One Drop Of Blood, Scott Malcomson writes of 19th-century minstrelsy that "many thousands of people came to watch a blackened white man dance, dribble and drool like an infant . . . White Americans were helpless in many ways, not least of which was that they fought tooth and nail to preserve their racial supremacy while knowing somewhere that their whiteness was itself an empty vessel - a culture without content, a social position that depended on non-whites for its sense and therefore could never make sense in itself.

"Being white, in isolation, was senseless; the nonsense of minstrelsy proceeded from this psychological point and the babbling infant was its child." Nearly 150 years on, that "empty vessel" is still the theme of the white person in racial comedy. Malcomson recounts the strange history of the famous song Dixie, initially a nostalgic number about a free black person in the north returning to the slave south. "In as pure a paradox as history is likely to offer, the black homeland of bondage was understood as the land of freedom," he writes.

Dixie became the 1860s equivalent of a top 10 best-seller and both union and confederate soldiers sang it during the civil war. "In this way white men marched singing to their deaths under the flag of racial comedy." Hovering over the whole issue of race and comedy, of course, is "political correctness", that masterly invention by conservative commentators of a problem which does not exist.

When people say that comedy now is inhibited by "political correctness", what they mean is that they can no longer tell unfunny race jokes without feeling like the unfunny comedians they are. Comedy, as opposed to lame joke-telling, is not inhibited at all, rather it is inspired by the issue, as Lenny Bruce proved 40 years ago.

Spike Lee, Margaret Cho, the Kings of Comedy and the evidence from One Drop Of Blood add further proof. The US is just emerging from a presidential election that has run beyond any farce that Spike Lee or Margaret Cho could have invented. Race as an issue in the campaign was almost ignored, except by the Reform party's Pat Buchanan, who ran a commercial showing a man choking on a meatball after hearing an announcer say that English was no longer the official national language in the US; when the man rings the emergency 911 number he gets a choice of languages like Spanish and Korean and chokes to death before he hears English. (The commercial may explain why Buchanan got less than 1% of the vote.)

But the issue that still divides America most deeply was barely thought worthy of discussion; certainly it featured way below income taxes, prescription charges, education, social security and the role of the military. So the current intense interest in comedy that deals with race may reflect a desire, conscious or unconscious, to fill that vacuum left by a nervous mainstream. As Scott Malcomson writes: "Comedy points out folly so that folly can be avoided. It portrays deluded characters so that we may recognise our own delusions".

fields.headline: Dimpled and pregnant
fields.trailText: Like a kind of dyspeptic regurgitation, some words from Tony Blair's past kept coming up in my throat as I read his attack on tabloid anti-Europeanism and all-purpose mendacity.
fields.body:
Like a kind of dyspeptic regurgitation, some words from Tony Blair's past kept coming up in my throat as I read his attack on tabloid anti-Europeanism and all-purpose mendacity.

I wonder if he too remembered the kind of stuff he wrote in the Sun during the 1997 election campaign; how his heart leapt up when he beheld a pound sign in the sky; how his pulses raced at the very sound of the union flag, etc etc.

And last May, he gave up a bank holiday Monday to handwrite a self-exculpating piece to the Sun after it had accused him of losing his grip. The very boots he used to polish so eagerly are being used to kick him today. And will he now lose the allegiance of the Express? I thought I heard its new owner, asked on TV what his politics were, mutter that he might be a socialist: yet he seems to count Richard Littlejohn and Garry Bushell among his best friends.

Still, Smallweed has started to think that Richard Desmond may yet get this clattering train back on the rails. He's the publisher, I see, of something called Nude Readers' Wives. Anyone making a success of a product which offers no more than photographs of the wives of nude readers should surely find saving the Express a doddle.

While America continued to count, Smallweed was inundated all this week with information about chads. I'm not sure I yet understand about dimpled and pregnant ones. Reports from the US say they're the same, but that seems unlikely. It is one thing, as a general rule, to be dimpled, and quite another to be pregnant. I am also rebuked for failing last week to mention either the republic of Chad or the Chad Valley toy company.

The republic of Chad can speak for itself, but the Chad Valley toy company is far less equipped to do so, having long since disappeared, as I understand it, into the ravenous maw of Woolworth's. But what or where is the Chad Valley?It allegedly lurks in the Harbourne area of Birmingham, where some people called Johnson had set up a factory.

Today, any family bearing this name would have concentrated on getting jobs on the Telegraph or Spectator, but in those days (around 1820) the bookbinding business held a greater allure. Their early success encouraged them to switch to toys and relocate near a stream called the Chad, from which Chad Valley derives.

Teddy bears were their staple, and even today, Chad Valley teddies change hands at substantial cost on the internet. In 1938 Chad Valley were awarded a royal warrant as "toymakers to the Queen", though this was amended after the present queen was crowned in 1953 to "toymakers to the Queen Mother".

The Queen Mother, I note without comment, was 52 at the time. I hope this short history will have lulled my readers into the sort of contented stupor where they will not be too dismayed by the dreadful news which follows. It is this: the chad which appeared in his column last week was a phoney. Many outraged readers have written to say that it cannot have been authentic because the line of the top of the wall was straight rather than kinky, and because both its eyes showed pluses, when one should have been a minus.

Almost all agree that "Mr Chad" was based on a common diagram representing an electrical circuit, the plus and minus of its eyes standing for positive and negative. A letter from Beeston, Nottingham describes the moment when Chads may have been invented. In 1941, an instructor in a hut classroom at the wireless school at RAF Yatesbury, Wilts, John Hawksworth tells me, drew a diagram showing a circuit on the blackboard.

He was then called out of the room. During his absence, a man called Dickie Lyle drew a comparable diagram, but gave it a face and entered beneath it the words; "Wot, no leave?" The sign for resistance provided its fingers, and the vacuum exhaust glass pimple on the top gave the twirly bit of hair on the creature's head (see this week's new, improved portrait, below). The name Chad, he suggests, had not at this stage been applied to Lyle's figure.

That occurred later on when the format became familiar, first on the walls of RAF lavatories, and then, by natural progression, in newspapers. S ome have expressed surprise at the scenes in a Bristol courtroom where a judge who'd decided not to jail a man convicted of drunken driving burst into tears while delivering his sentence. Such people can never have heard of the celebrated jurisprudential eccentric Judge Arthur ("Gusher") Advowson, whose habit of weeping copiously in the court room was the talk of Gresley, Derbyshire in the 1920s.

Though normally the sternest of arbiters - he once sentenced to death a man found guilty of dropping litter and then, when the clerk of the court protested, pronounced the same sentence on him - Advowson was easily moved by any evidence which alluded to small children, frail young widows or most kinds of household animal. I'm told they still talk in Gresley of Advowson's contribution to reducing the townspeople's sufferings during the terrible drought of 1919, when the normally burbling river Grizzle was reduced to no more than a trickle.

One night, the clerk and his assistants cut away part of the desk where Advowson presided and inserted an inconspicuous porcelain basin through which his tears could be channelled into a bucket. They then staged a succession of cases involving small children and large-eyed dogs of the spaniel persuasion. fields.bodyText: Like a kind of dyspeptic regurgitation, some words from Tony Blair's past kept coming up in my throat as I read his attack on tabloid anti-Europeanism and all-purpose mendacity. I wonder if he too remembered the kind of stuff he wrote in the Sun during the 1997 election campaign; how his heart leapt up when he beheld a pound sign in the sky; how his pulses raced at the very sound of the union flag, etc etc. And last May, he gave up a bank holiday Monday to handwrite a self-exculpating piece to the Sun after it had accused him of losing his grip. The very boots he used to polish so eagerly are being used to kick him today. And will he now lose the allegiance of the Express? I thought I heard its new owner, asked on TV what his politics were, mutter that he might be a socialist: yet he seems to count Richard Littlejohn and Garry Bushell among his best friends. Still, Smallweed has started to think that Richard Desmond may yet get this clattering train back on the rails. He's the publisher, I see, of something called Nude Readers' Wives. Anyone making a success of a product which offers no more than photographs of the wives of nude readers should surely find saving the Express a doddle. While America continued to count, Smallweed was inundated all this week with information about chads. I'm not sure I yet understand about dimpled and pregnant ones. Reports from the US say they're the same, but that seems unlikely. It is one thing, as a general rule, to be dimpled, and quite another to be pregnant. I am also rebuked for failing last week to mention either the republic of Chad or the Chad Valley toy company. The republic of Chad can speak for itself, but the Chad Valley toy company is far less equipped to do so, having long since disappeared, as I understand it, into the ravenous maw of Woolworth's. But what or where is the Chad Valley?It allegedly lurks in the Harbourne area of Birmingham, where some people called Johnson had set up a factory. Today, any family bearing this name would have concentrated on getting jobs on the Telegraph or Spectator, but in those days (around 1820) the bookbinding business held a greater allure. Their early success encouraged them to switch to toys and relocate near a stream called the Chad, from which Chad Valley derives. Teddy bears were their staple, and even today, Chad Valley teddies change hands at substantial cost on the internet. In 1938 Chad Valley were awarded a royal warrant as "toymakers to the Queen", though this was amended after the present queen was crowned in 1953 to "toymakers to the Queen Mother". The Queen Mother, I note without comment, was 52 at the time. I hope this short history will have lulled my readers into the sort of contented stupor where they will not be too dismayed by the dreadful news which follows. It is this: the chad which appeared in his column last week was a phoney. Many outraged readers have written to say that it cannot have been authentic because the line of the top of the wall was straight rather than kinky, and because both its eyes showed pluses, when one should have been a minus. fields.headline: The last word on   Cooperation
fields.standfirst: Cooperation succeeds best when all parties benefit -  Euripides
fields.trailText: Cooperation succeeds best when all parties benefit - Euripides
fields.body:
From an objective point of view, the newly announced military cooperation among the members of the European Union makes excellent sense. A giant on the world stage in economic and cultural terms, the EU is a diplomatic and especially military pygmy because of its lack of cooperation in these spheres. The point of military cooperation is not aggrandisement or sabre-rattling. It is that Europe should be able to take armed humanitarian and peacekeeping action when required, as in the Balkans, where the disarray of its response was paid for in the lives, grief and misery of that region's people.

The advantages of cooperation depend on cases. Agatha Christie remarked that co-authors of books each believe they get all the worry for only half the royalties, which if true undermines the gain. Cooperation in small-scale endeavours often results in delay, inefficiency, and all the disadvantages commonly attendant on miniature democracy, encapsulated in those familiar but sterling truisms about what happens when committees design horses and too many cooks fill the kitchen. But these are precisely the cases where the parties are not benefiting from attempts at cooperation, as Euripides required, which of course means that they are not really cooperating at all .

But where there are clear advantages from joint endeavour, it is folly not to accept them. Some people place such high value on autonomy that they would rather be worse off alone than better off together. Such is the view of those who oppose closer ties in Europe. Their chief argument is that cooperative action in the diplomatic and military spheres constitutes movement towards loss of national self-determination and identity. But this argument and the assumptions it makes are equally flawed.

The argument is a so-called "slippery slope argument," which says that because there is a continuum between a given action performed now, and a possible state of affairs at the far end of a connecting chain - for example: beginning an addictive habit like smoking could end in heroin dependency - you should not take that first step. But it is immediately obvious that since not all first steps lead to the possible end result, it is a fallacy to repudiate the first step on the grounds that it might. The anti- European argument about military cooperation sees it as leading inevitably to a standing European army, which in turn requires a European state, the terminus of the process of European integration - the very thing to which its opponents are most bitterly hostile.

The assumption behind the argument, as these last points show, is that European integration is undesirable, the usual grounds being that it means the loss of national independence, which in turn (so anti-Europeans believe) means loss of "identity". But the idea of a "nation" is vague; there is no automatic reason why, if such things as nations exist, their being detached from one another is a good thing; and anyway cultural identities can happily flourish independently of the political arrangements they are associated with. These thoughts show that the argument's assumptions are at the very least questionable.

Yet even if one granted the anxieties that prompt people to accept this argument, the idea of cooperation is not affected by them, for it is quite another matter. Sovereign states can cooperate without losing their autonomy or identity - in fact, most of the states of the world do so all the time in respect of trade, tourism, air travel, health regulations, and very much besides, to everyone's benefit. If there were no such cooperation life would be poorer, infinitely more difficult, and much more dangerous - because when states are jealous of their own, and shun links with others, the only sure result is suspicion and tension.

It feels odd to preach the virtues of international cooperation when its advantages are so obvious. It is a measure of the influence of nationalists, and of the mindset of those who are swayed by them, that we find ourselves repeating truisms as if they were discoveries.

fields.headline: Spend! Spend! Spend!
fields.standfirst: In the course of her 34-year reign, Catherine the Great picked up 4,000 Old Masters, 10,000 gems and 16,000 antique coins and medals.  Phil Daoust  is dazzled and outraged
fields.trailText: In the course of her 34-year reign, Catherine the Great picked up 4,000 Old Masters, 10,000 gems and 16,000 antique coins and medals. Phil Daoust is dazzled and outraged
fields.body:
If you're stuck for Christmas present ideas, there's an unusual new shop you could check out. You must know someone who'd love a tote bag emblazoned with the Romanov dynasty's double-headed imperial eagle, or a sparkly little something inspired by the Russian crown jewels. Imagine how mum's eyes will light up as she unwraps a plate based on Wedgwood's Green Frog service, with its 1,222 views of 18th-century England.

These are some of the souvenirs on sale at the Hermitage Rooms, the gallery that opens today in London's revamped Somerset House. It is tempting to dismiss them as vulgar, but they are a fair reflection of the spirit of the inaugural show, Treasures of Catherine the Great.

Catherine II, Empress and Autocrat of All Russia, was the world's greatest shopper - or collector, as rich obsessives prefer to call themselves. Between the coup that put her on the throne in place of her husband in 1762 and the stroke that laid her out in her toilet in 1796 she picked up more than 4,000 Old Masters, 10,000 engraved gems, 16,000 antique coins and medals, at least 38,000 books, and many, many thousands of drawings. She had Rembrandts and Rubens and Watteaus; Lorrains and Murillos and Raphaels, most picked up in job lots abroad.

In 1779 Britain lost what might have become the core of a national collection when she struck a deal with the grandson of Sir Robert Walpole, the country's first prime minister. Despite protests in parliament, she spirited away 204 of the works that Walpole had acquired, including a number of Rubens and Van Dycks. One of the Poussins from that spree, Moses Striking the Rock, has returned to Britain as part of the show.

Money was never a problem: first Catherine stripped the clergy of their property and turned them into state employees, gaining a third of Russia's land and serfs, then she used diplomacy and conquest to expand her tax base by 200,000 square miles. When she played cards with her friends, the chips were diamonds.

It wasn't just objects that Catherine collected: generous, intelligent and well-read, she was popular with philosophers and writers such as Diderot and Baron von Grimm, both of whom acted as her art scouts, and Voltaire, with whom she corresponded for 15 years. She saw herself as completing the process begun by Peter the Great, a moderniser who liked to say that he had opened a "window on the west". A Wedgwood plaque in the exhibition depicts her as Minerva, Roman goddess of learning, "rewarding art and protecting commerce".

What she couldn't buy, Catherine had made, like the Green Frog dinner service, 14 pieces of which are on display in London. Russia was going through a Gothic phase when she commissioned it, so she asked Wedgwood to include ruins among the landscapes that decorate the full 944-piece set. Always keen to display her country's wealth to its snooty European neighbours, she must have been delighted when Queen Charlotte came to view the service just before it was shipped to Russia.

Between 1769 and 1787 Catherine had a series of galleries built beside the Winter Palace in St Petersburg. This light and airy complex was known as the Hermitage because it was a place where she could retreat from the pressures of state. London's Hermitage Rooms are an attempt to re-create a "lost wing" of that, with marquetry floors by a St Petersburg firm, replica crystal chandeliers, even ruched blinds sewn by the Hermitage's housekeeper. The first of the six chambers features a live video feed from Palace Square in St Petersburg, a film of the Hermitage's luxurious interior, and touch-screen computers offering a virtual tour. One pound of the £6 admission fee will go to the cash-strapped State Hermitage Museum.

The London outpost never had a hope of matching the grandeur of the original: Somerset House was built to the scale of civil servants, not imperial majesties. Yet the 500 objects on display provide a fasci nating and disturbing insight into 18th-century Russia.

Among many portraits of the empress is Vigilius Eriksen's Equestrian Portrait of Catherine II. She is on her horse Brilliant (Russian for "Diamond") on the summer's day in 1762 when she set out from St Petersburg to demand the abdication of her weak, stupid and unpopular husband, Peter III. Her backers included her lover, Count Grigory Orlov, and one of his successors, Prince Grigory Potemkin. Her sword is drawn, and she would clearly be happy to use it on her husband. Peter caved in, but within days had been murdered by his wife's supporters. She claimed he had died of one of "his habitual haemorrhoidal attacks, together with a violent colic".

Nearby hangs Potemkin, the best-known of Catherine's lovers, in armour for Johann-Baptist Lampi the Elder's portrait. An outstanding statesman and soldier, Potemkin annexed the Crimea for his sovereign. The pair were lovers for just two years but may have secretly married. When the relationship was over, he remained her closest confidant. After his death, Catherine described him as "brave at heart, brave in thought, brave in soul".

Potemkin's portrait rubs shoulders with several of Catherine's other lovers, including Orlov, who was with her for 12 years until she grew sick of his infidelities. As if to remind us that even imperial adultery has consequences, we have Carl Ludwig Christineck's portrait of their son, the mischievous-looking Count Alexey Bobrinsky, born while she was still married to Peter and smuggled away to be raised far from the court. The exhibition's excellent catalogue informs us that Catherine hid the pregnancy under the bulky mourning robes she wore after the death of Peter's aunt, the Empress Elizabeth.

But what steals the show is the dazzling display of gewgaws and trinkets and thingumabobs, just a tiny portion of what Catherine bought, was given or inherited. Enough dinner services that you'd think she didn't know crockery could be reused. Enough snuffboxes that you wonder she didn't sneeze to death. Enough hairpins and dangly bits of jewellery that you imagine her clanking in a high wind.

The craftsmanship is breathtaking, above all in James Cox's table clock of gold, silver, agate and crystal, set with jewels and resting on four gold rhinoceroses, and the Chinese hairpins in the form of phoenixes and songbirds. The lines of some of the cameos are so assured that it's hard to tear your eyes away. But it is harder still to forget that while the empress was flashing her cash, most of her subjects were little better than slaves. Catherine's conspicuous consumption is often portrayed as a means of raising Russia's status in the west, but even this glimpse of her fortune makes that seem like an excuse. Every brushstroke, every loop of filigree rings like a slap in the face of common humanity.

By Russian standards, Catherine was an enlightened ruler. She tried to end serfdom (though she ended up extending it). She tried to create a liberal constitution (though that was never implemented). Born and brought up in Prussia like the husband she ousted, she might easily have been seen as another foreign interloper, yet she was popular among her subjects. But the opulence of this show drives home how much more she could have done for them.

In 1777 Johann Gottlieb Scharff made Catherine a snuffbox featuring a beautiful enamel miniature of her favourite pet dog, a greyhound called Lisetta. The box is in London, alongside others bearing childhood portraits of Grand Dukes Paul, Alexander and Constantine. The dog is at the centre of not one but two circles of diamonds each as big as peas, surrounded by hundreds of smaller gems. It makes you think of that other great shopper, Imelda Marcos, and her shoe collection. As a spectacle it's thrilling; as a demonstration of priorities it stinks.

 Treasures of Catherine the Great is at the Hermitage Rooms at Somerset House, London WC2 (020-7845 4630), until next September. Website: www.hermitagerooms.com

fields.headline: Hemlock for pudding
fields.trailText: Channel surfing
fields.body:
'I've only got a minute," promised the girl better known as EastEnders' Maaahy Flaaaherty. She lied. For Maaahy - in a new incarnation as one Mayree Ellen - and her chums bore down on us like a sweaty suitor for another hour (though it felt like more) with the first episode of Catherine Cookson's A Dinner of Herbs (ITV). A sweeping, romantic saga set against grimy hardship in ye olde north of England, A Dinner of Herbs featured Mayree leaning on a wall, as all dreamy servants did in the 1800s, musing on the bond between herself and her friends, Roddy and Hal, and uttering the immortal words: "Nothing on earth will ever come between us."

This is a sure-fire way to ensure something will indeed come between them. While the rest of us hoped it might be an asteroid, A Dinner of Herbs then went into flashback and we were treated to murder, Tim Healy in breeches, barn-dancing and amnesia (and you thought that only happened in trashy American soaps). Then there were Roddy's drawings, of course.

Roddy was allegedly a great artist whose drawing of his mother "caught the likeness of her". If this were true, his mother really did have googly eyes that were far too close together and a Desperate Dan-esque overly prominent chin. Either she was not of this planet or she was from Sunderland. Whatever, she died. And so did Hal's da (face down in a gorse bush). And so did Roddy's da (off a cliff after an encounter with a shovel of which Alan Titchmarsh would not have approved). Roddy himself almost popped his clogs but the baddie who had killed the das didn't throw him far enough off the edge of the quarry.

Shame. That means next week we'll have to put up with Sam the Gay Nurse from Casualty in sideburns of Sir Rhodes Boyson proportions. Without that delight, it was left to Billie Whitelaw chopping nettles to amuse us. She was "a witch" (well, she was from Yorkshire) and it fell to her to look after the injured - and whining - Roddy. This meant chopping more nettles, putting her hands on people's faces in tender moments and walking like she had a dead chicken in the gusset of her old, knitted tights. It didn't mean - more's the pity - cutting his tongue out and sewing his eyes shut. Next week, they might burn her at the stake. If we're lucky. A Dinner of Herbs? Let's hope there's hemlock for pudding.

As a vehicle for Gwen Taylor, Barbara (ITV) is the equivalent of a hearse. She's there in body but the spirit has long departed. Appropriately, then, the first episode in this second series (yes, there is no God) began and ended with a funeral. Sadly, neither were for Barbara or any of her annoying brood, but for non-persons whose departures were merely devices for the exposition of hilarious scenes.

A young boy kicked his football into an open grave at the beginning of the sitcom and, at the end, Barbara parachuted into another one. I know! Such scenes are so side-splitting that, even in the retelling, you may well have wet your knickers already. Take that as a warning. Should you tune into Barbara next week, keep a bucket handy.

It's a shame that Barbara is so terrible since Gwen Taylor has always reminded me of my mum. And Duty Free was so very jolly - her finest moment, perhaps. This isn't remotely fine. Nor is it the finest moment for Sam Kelly (that would be 'Allo 'Allo), or Elizabeth Carling (pretending to be Dervla Kirwan in Goodnight Sweetheart), or indeed Mark Benton. He put in a star turn in Anderson, a new sitcom piloted in Channel 4's Comedy Lab, which, if there's any justice, will be given a series. A sweeping, romantic saga set against grimy hardship in ye olde north of England, A Dinner of Herbs featured Mayree leaning on a wall, as all dreamy servants did in the 1800s, musing on the bond between herself and her friends, Roddy and Hal, and uttering the immortal words: "Nothing on earth will ever come between us." fields.headline: Golden oldies
fields.standfirst: Extravagant pop stars pale by comparison with early masters of conspicuous consumption. Nicholas Wroe reports
fields.trailText: Extravagant pop stars pale by comparison with early masters of conspicuous consumption. Nicholas Wroe reports
fields.body:
The courtroom revelation that Elton John spent close to £40m in a 20-month period has seen the pop- star class reinstated to its rightful position as society's new aristocracy. Recent pretenders like footballers or dotcom squillionaires - perhaps always a little too interested in making it rather than spending it, anyway - have been put in their place by the sheer breathtaking extravagance of Elton's shopping list.

Fantastic amounts of money were spent on clothes, property, jewellery and, most strikingly, flowers, to which in one month he devoted £293,000 of his fortune. Sir Elton's unapologetic witness-box explanation for this catalogue of excess - "I like flowers", he said, displaying a stylish talent for understatement - precipitated a flurry of newspaper headlines, but his stance would have been little more than a bland stating of the obvious to some of the other great spenders of history.

It is, of course, to the Romans that one must look for real financial excess, as for every other type. Amongst his many depravities Caligula so loved his money that he would wallow in huge piles of gold coins. Nero, after a fire destroyed half of Rome, ransacked the rest of Italy and Greece to replace lost treasures. He began the construction of what became known as the Golden House in AD 64. It contained over 100,000 sq ft of frescoed walls and ceilings and more than a mile of colonnaded arcades decorated with gold leaf, marble, jewels and ivory. There were interior pools and fountains, although, a little surprisingly, no kitchens or toilets. It was still being built when Nero committed suicide and within a few decades it had been stripped bare of its treasures and buried under the foundations of another building.

Another conspicuous consumer who didn't see the final fruits of his spending was Augustus the Strong, 18th-century King of Poland and Elector of Saxony. He had imprisoned the inventor of porcelain, Johann Böttger, and therefore controlled the supply of this extraordinarily valuable new commodity. The resulting massive wealth saw Augustus turn into an unpredictable and self-aggrandising tyrant. He built a temple out of porcelain that measured over 4m high. His next project was to be the apotheosis of his spending spree; construction of his 9m high eques trian statue was stopped when Frederick the Great of Prussia invaded and proceeded to load Augustus's treasures on to ox carts and ship them back to Berlin.

In this country it is the old aristocracy - both temporal and spiritual - that set the standard for large-scale personal disbursement. When George IV, Prince of Wales, had to get parliament to pay his huge debts, his own father, George III, publicly claimed it was "a shameful squandering of public money to gratify the passions of an ill-advised young man". Earlier in the last century, Edward VII commissioned models of his farm animals, as well as his dog and his Derby-winning horse, from Faberge. Even Archbishop Thomas Becket, who was a wealthy financier before his career in the church, was not shy of opening his wallet and used to take 250 servants for trips to Paris. Once, it was claimed, he paid 100 shillings for a plate of eels, exciting a mixture of envy and sanctimonious horror. Perhaps his later trajectory was partly a means of compensating for his earlier spending habits.

More recently, the tycoon Robert Maxwell liked to play two roulette tables simultaneously, and it was said that Jackie Onassis could drop £100,000 in a couple of minutes when shopping for clothes.

The philosopher Anthony Grayling says there are two classes of people who spend in these quantities. "There are some who have little sense of taste and buy a lot of very expensive hit-and-miss objects. And then there are some who do have an idea of who they are and what they want and who can, by chance or otherwise, create something good that can last." The Medicis would fall into that category. Perhaps Charles Saatchi is a modern equivalent

Then there are the unclassifiable big spenders. Ludwig of Bavaria was undoubtedly insane and had far more money than sense. But he sponsored Wagner and laid the foundations of a great art collection in Munich. What category Elton John, and other modern exemplars of conspicuous consumption, fall into is more difficult to determine. But as the owner of several sumptuous wardrobes, he should be mindful of Thomas Gray's caution: "The loss of wealth is loss of dirt,/As sages in all times assert;/The happy man's without a shirt."

William of Warenne, an 11th-century lord, was recently judged to have been the the richest Briton ever in real terms - Rockefeller and Carnegie were, relatively, the world's richest - with the equivalent of £4bn more than Bill Gates has today. He fought for William the Conqueror at Hastings and was rewarded with land in Sussex, Surrey and the north of England. By the time he died, his wealth was roughly 6.66% of the total national income. What did he spend it on? A priory at Lewes and grants to the Cluniac religious order. His actions would have met with the approval of John Heywood, circa 1565, who observed "The boast of heraldry, the pomp of pow'r, And all that beauty, all that wealth e'er gave, Await alike the inevitable hour. The paths of glory lead but to the grave."

webTitle: Language that's as alive as Melvyn's hair

fields.headline: Language that's as alive as Melvyn's hair
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
Routes of English (Radio 4), a programme clearly destined to rival The Mousetrap for longevity, may pretend to be about changes in language use, but we all know it has other, more serious purposes. There's the common sense its contributors dish out ("It's no use talking about a horse's harness if you haven't got a horse"), all those ideas for cheap nights in (gather friends together and do the Northumbrian burr) and even cheaper nights out ("Go to Morpeth Main Street!").

And then we have the delicious image of Melvyn and His Hair hanging out in all these linguistically fascinating back-waters. You can see it - the words spoken this week in Ashington, south Northumberland, settling on his locks, finding a resting place on his quiff. "I can remember getting me lips nipped," one lady recalled, enigmatically. "I can tak or I can talk," added an obvious show-off.

These crucial things aside, the best thing about the programme is that it doesn't do what you might expect it to - wallow in nostalgia for dying dialects and languishing languages. Yes, it shows change and decline (Ashington, once a pit village, has been in "industrial meltdown" since its colliery closed in 1981), the loss of locally specific words and ways of talking, such as Ashington's "Pitmatic" dialect.

But its strength is that it celebrates language as a living thing - Bragg talks to schoolchildren as well as golden oldies. Most interesting of all were the kids, all wanting to be lawyers and teachers now that the pits have gone - with their own linguistic self-consciousness and, best of all, new words for the new things in their world. They probably have one now for Melvyn's hair.

Mark Ravenhill is best known as the playwright who got one particular word - the F-word - into the title of a play. I remember a linen-suited gent queuing next to me to see the play whispering: "Are you here to see Shopping and You-Know?", as if even a reference to the word might offend. Ravenhill also popped up last week in these very pages pleading for a silencing of some forms of words - cultural, artsy, review-type words - instead of the endless surfeit of comment and listings. Cleverly, he wants an embargo on reviews starting from January 1, thereby allowing reviews of his first radio play, Feed Me (Radio 3).

Kicking off a bold and welcome new series of 10 new dramas, Feed Me had the bravest of opening lines for a hard-hitting modern-day play: "This whole thing seems so unreal."

In fact, the play felt depressingly real in its social analysis, with four protagonists whose kind we have all encountered and even (shhhh) been before. The situations in which they meet - a casting for an advert, a date from a lonely hearts ad, a scary modern art gallery, a transferable-skills workshop - are all emphatically of our time, as are their desperate attempts through knowledge (especially cultural) to win friends and influence people.

The talk is worse than cheap; it is brittle and competitive. A woman on the blind date boasts of her passion for "fascinating dance companies from the Netherlands", then cannot bear the "immoral" idiocy of the play she goes to see. "It reminds me why I never go to the theatre any more," she lets slip, undoing the culture-vulture veneer she had so carefully worked up to impress.

The char acters steal words, phrases, attitudes and careers from casual encounters; they take drugs, they have depressing sex, they have their New Agey moments. They say "That's amay-zing" a lot, but not as often as they say "Please don't leave me on my own" - the thing Ravenhill thinks we fear most. In all this, the play felt true.

Less successful was its other dimension: the backdrop of a war and crimes against humanity, with more than a nod to Balkan conflicts. A haunting, mournful song (a woman crying out for her husband, taken by the authorities) punctuates the action, while our vacuous, vacant characters talk about the bombing, the camps. Fear and fascination of these grips; fantasies about the terror creep into everyone's lives. The characters make art and documentaries about it, propose films about it, talk about the horror post-coitally.

I think Ravenhill's point was that we are inured to reality, so caught up in narcissistic fascination that we forget others unless they can give us something we want. But the war narrative jarred and felt tacked on to give the rest of the play - which had some very fine observation in it, and was superbly acted - emotional depth.

Either we no longer have that, and writers will have to come to terms with this bleak new order - or we do and it needs to feel far more real than this.

fields.headline: The pint-sized Proust
fields.standfirst: Can Marcel's masterpiece really be shrunk to fit the stage?  Michael Billington  finds out
fields.trailText: Can Marcel's masterpiece really be shrunk to fit the stage? Michael Billington finds out
fields.body:
Talk about squashing quarts into pint pots! Remembrance of Things Past, at the National Theatre, is an adaptation by Harold Pinter and Di Trevis of Pinter's own Proust screenplay written in 1972; and that itself, was a distillation of the 3,500 pages of Proust's oceanic novel. Yet, despite my reservations about adaptations, it works. By the end of the evening, when all the characters inhabiting Marcel's memory assemble on stage, you feel you have gained valuable insight into the nature of Proust's obsessions.

It would be pointless to bang on about what is lost. Characters and episodes from the novel are sacrificed as well as Proust's essays on time, memory, etiquette and sexuality. From the screenplay, one also loses the dense web of visual and aural references: in the film script there are 35 shots before a word is spoken, during which Pinter establishes the crucial sights and sounds that form the matrix of Marcel's memory.

Rather than dwell on what is missing, it is more profitable to ask what a staging of Proust can possi bly add to our understanding. Two things leapt out at me from Trevis's fluid and inventive production. One is the sense that Proust's narrator, Marcel, is both a participant in and observer of his own life. Even when Sebastian Harcombe's Marcel is not physically engaged in a scene, you are aware of him as a silent watcher - as if everything is leading to the play's climactic line: "It was time to begin." The stage version also heightens the aspect of Proust most often neglected, his gift for Balzacian social comedy and astute awareness of the dynamics of class.

Mercifully, Pinter and Trevis eschew buttonholing, first-person narration. But, from the start, they make it clear that we are being admitted to Marcel's memory: we get a stumble in the street, a flurry of snow, the ring of a garden-gate bell. Even if this doesn't possess the richness of the screenplay, it establishes the basic convention. Marcel's constant physical presence also reinforces the point Pinter made in his introduction to the film script - that the events shown offer a contrasting movement towards disillusion and revelation "rising to where time that was lost is found and fixed forever in art".

But theatre depends on the interaction of human beings in a confined space. By staging Proust, one heightens his awareness of social comedy and historical time. He was writing about France during the Third Republic and about the showdown between an ascendant bourgeoisie and a declining aristocracy. It was a battle of rank and status being fought out in fashionable salons. And, while some see Proust as an elitist snob, Walter Benjamin was nearer the truth when he talked of "the hardness of his work, the intransigence of a man who is ahead of his class".

This Proustian hardness is what comes out most strongly here. The opening party at the Guermantes' house in 1921 represents the vindictive triumph of the bourgeoisie: aristocrats gossip on gilt-framed chairs about death and decay, and a haggard vicomtesse staggers by high on cocaine while the newly-risen hostess engages avant-garde dancers to provide a chic cabaret.

Proust, you feel, had an equal dislike for both the declining bluebloods and the emergent bour geoisie. In Time Regained, he writes: "I had seen enough of fashionable society to know that it is there one finds real illiteracy and not, let us say, among electricians."

This version also pinpoints the emotional coarseness in smart salons. One of the best scenes comes when Duncan Bell's wonderfully melancholic Swann tells the Duchesse de Guermante he will not be able to accompany her on an Italian holiday because of his impending death; her husband is far more horrified by the discovery that the duchesse is wearing black shoes with a red dress.

But adaptation is also a form of self-revelation; and one of the themes Pinter excavates in Proust is the ultimate unknowability of the sexually desired. Marcel is haunted by Albertine's possible lesbianism and Trevis's production makes this a dominant motif. The scenes at Balbec are beautifully done, with the band of sailor-suited girls forming a playful, caressing coterie. And, after Albertine's death, Marcel's interrogation of her friend Andrée about their putative sapphism is played from multiple angles. The emphasis on male insecurity and sexual ambivalence, while deriving from Proust, echoes Pinter's Old Times.

Inevitably in a stage adaptation, it takes time for the Proustian pattern to become clear: we get fragments of Marcel's memory, which only make total sense at the end - when he itemises the sights and sounds that unlock his past and when Alison Chitty's design reveals the complete version of Vermeer's View of Delft, which has haunted the evening. But each episode is rendered with clarity and there is a clutch of fine performances from David Rintoul as a floridly dignified Baron Charlus, Fritha Goodey as Swann's faithless but beautiful Odette, Janine Duvitski as the upwardly mobile Madame Verdurin and Jill Johnson as a succession of high-chinned aristocratic snobs.

It may not be the whole of Proust; but the evening offers a vivid, lovingly created theatrical epitome that highlights his ruthless social comedy and his obsession with what Beckett called "that double-headed monster of damnation and salvation - Time".

 In rep at the Cottesloe, London SE1. Box office: 020-7452 3000.
