No one had to prove their credentials, justify their past lives or explain their absences, which, for Georges, included living rough in Amsterdam and London. "Joe", as he called himself in homage to the malevolent Injun in Tom Sawyer, followed this mixed bunch of restless activists, junkies and misfits from temporary refuge to temporary refuge for more than two years, carrying his drumsticks in a back pocket, boasting of fabricated criminal exploits and expressing hatred of homosexuals and skinheads. Philippe Dusanter, a CNT militant and hospital psychiatrist who corresponds with Joe in La Santé prison, was completely taken in by Georges's "Belmondo-style attitude - the real cool small-time crook who said he had just been released from 13 years for a bank hold-up". "He was helpful, coherent, polite and easy-going, ready to arbitrate in disputes, particularly when our political activity was transferred to a block in the rue Saint Sauveur, a filthy squat near Les Halles," says Dusanter. "He didn't identify himself with average squatters - he saw them as human wrecks. No one suspected him of sexual crimes. But, on looking back, we remembered that he had wept on three occasions that coincided with murders. He told a friend that relatives had died." These incidents recall Georges's own remark to police that, "if a man killed a woman, he would probably weep". If no one asked "Joe" where he came from or where he disappeared to, they also ignored an unsuspected clue to his origins when he spoke admiringly of his father, supposedly a Nato general and war hero. The references were put down to fantasies over his "illegitimate" birth. Even after his arrest, the press referred to his origins as French West Indian and his father's real identity was not revealed until two years of interrogation ended - a disclosure that had a profound effect on Georges's personality and self-confidence. Much of my background on Georges's early life and criminal career comes from confidential records made during the mise en examen - the two-year inquiry led by a juge d'instruction , or examining magistrate, at the Palais de Justice - which form the basis of the charges. Of the 30 volumes of documents sent to the public prosecutor, the essence is summed up in a key procès-verbal d'interrogatoire - report on a verbal interrogation- by Judge Gilbert Thiel on May 28, 1998, lasting from 10.10am until 5.55pm, during which Georges confessed to all the killings. The unemotional style of questioning and the detailed recapitulation of previous statements, police evidence, post- mortem and clinical examinations, make the most apparently authentic fictional account of judicial activity in literature and TV seem hollow, invented and strained. Thiel's method comes through as coldly bureaucratic - earlier statements are repeated verbatim over and over again - and the postmortem detail is clinically precise. The last few hours of the murdered women before returning to their studio flats are routinely ordinary - an outing with friends, a drink in a bar, a telephone chat about wedding arrangements or shopping for brand-name clothes. By contrast, the narration of the crimes themselves is visceral and horrifying. Then Thiel patiently digs out the hidden clues to the making of a murderer, a child bureaucratically assassinated and subsequently resurrected under another identity. No public reference has yet been made to the fact that Guy Georges was first registered as Guy Rampillon after his birth to a single mother at Vitry le François, eastern France, on October 10, 1962. His birth certificate as recorded in all pre-trial documents shows, instead, that he was born in the central city of Angers on October 15 of the same year. His father is described as inconnu - unknown - although it is now established that he lived with Guy's mother for some time. The explanation for the little boy's lost identity is both simple and cruel. His mother, Hélène, abandoned him to state custody at the age of six because she wanted to marry a US serviceman and emigrate to California, where she lives today. She took with her another son, Stéphane, three years older than his brother and conceived with another American. The difference between the two boys is significant - Stéphane is white and Guy is black, the son of a US air force cook called George Cartwright serving at a French Nato base, who has long since returned to the US. Hélène's own military family - her father was a retired NCO - fostered Stéphane until their daughter emigrated, but refused Guy. It was enough that their estranged daughter had produced one child out of wedlock during a wayward fascination for Americans in uniform, but in her stuffy provincial home town of Angers there was intolerable social stigma attached to a mixed-race birth. After six years' delay, in which Guy was bounced between foster homes and his mother, his status as a ward of the state was finally settled when in the care of a temporary family. The condition of abandonment was the issue of a new birth certificate with false details to prevent him from discovering his origins - a procedure used in similar cases for decades until it was banned in 1996 as a deprivation of basic rights. I have a picture of Guy Georges at six, standing among the many members of his foster family outside a church. His curly hair is abundant and his mouth is set in a sulk. By then he may already have known that he had been chosen by Jeanne Morin, his surrogate mother, because she had previously looked after another black boy whose removal by the authorities made her weep. Guy was a substitute for a lost child. Georges told Thiel that he loved his authoritarian Catholic foster mother, who was decorated for bringing up 12 children in addition to seven of her own. But in pre-adolescence he began to steal from the family food store and, more significantly, acquired a knife to hunt and kill animals in the countryside behind his village home near Angers. By 16, he had attacked two of his foster sisters - neither for sexual reasons - and was packed off to a state orphanage for adolescents. At 17, he was jailed for stealing a woman's handbag after ripping her face open with a knife. Of the next 18 years, before his arrest for serial killing, he spent more than half in jail; every period of release saw a new flurry of sexual attacks. Psychiatrists made no secret about the underlying cause - disaffiliation. "It is among these subjects of a genealogical death that we most often meet children who transgress laws in a violent and aggressive fashion," Grynzspan's team reported, adding that, in Georges's case, "the real pleasure came from the hunt, the excitement, the wait of a man on his guard". Among many letters written to a girlfriend after his arrest, Guy Georges refers to his admiration for the tiger. His tidy writing, resembling small, faint print, underlines his fascination for an "intelligent, powerful, resistant animal, careful and adaptable"; he claims that he climbed into a tiger's cage as a boy and caressed a tigress "because it showed no hostility to me". The psychiatrists were particularly struck by this incident, pointing out that "hunting in the wild and matters of animal behaviour were constantly present in his conversation, and showed an atavistic identification with domination and predation". Knowledge of Georges's appalling childhood and the psychiatrists' references to an "uncontrollable Jekyll and Hyde personality" that flowed from it might point to extenuating circumstances; however, both medical and psychiatric analysis suggest that he was fully responsible for his self-confessed acts. Within 48 hours of his arrest in 1998, Georges had offered to "relieve his conscience" by giving police details of his first murder in 1991. Over the following months, he gave graphic details of the killings of five women in their Paris apartments - four of them around midnight - and of two other women who had been found raped with their throats cut in underground car parks. In describing the first murder - of Pascale Escarfail, a 19-year-old student who had dressed particularly carefully on her last day of life because she had an interview for part-time work in an ice-cream parlour - Georges said that he had been attracted to the young woman with long, blonde hair as she walked past the cafe where he was sitting. He followed her home, forced his way into her apartment at knifepoint, and then bound her hands with sticky tape. "I must say it was not really a sexual impulse that made me act like that," he said. "I had been with prostitutes just before, and I cannot say what force guided me." After raping Escarfail, he looted the flat; he was angered when she gave him a kick, and he then stabbed and suffocated her. The attack took place in 1991 while Georges was on parole for a 10-year sentence for a previous rape at knifepoint. His calm recollections of similar hunts, threats and savage endings are even more terrifying. In October 1999, Thiel, a lawyer of monk-like perseverance and courtesy, summoned all the families of Georges's victims to a courtroom in the Palais de Justice just after he recommended prosecution. Under French criminal law, survivors and relatives claim the status of partie civile, or plaintiff, which allows them access to files and opens the way to compensation. Parties civiles are usually seen as an irritant by examining magistrates, the overall strategists in criminal inquiries, so Thiel's initiative in informing the victims' families of his findings was a rare gesture. The gathering at the Palais de Justice provided one of the most striking instances of the subsidiary ravages of Guy Georges' serial killings. Elisabeth Ortega, a hospital nurse, greeted each arrival with a hug, consoling them as Judge Thiel read from the years of gathered evidence. Ortega had been threatened by Guy Georges carrying "the sort of knife you use to debone a leg of lamb", but she had escaped from the ground-floor window of her flat after a lengthy conversation before he could assault her. Unfortunately, her eye-witness description of the incident was so misleading that he remained free long enough to kill three more women. Ortega told police that her attacker was "of North African type, about 25 years old, athletic build, black shaved hair, about 1m 70, darkish skin, oval face, fine features..." In fact, Georges's appearance suggests African-European descent. Ortega spent weeks helping the police, but it was hardly surprising that she could find no one among thousands of criminal portraits to resemble Georges. A computer photofit picture using software developed by Scotland Yard confused the search even further by throwing up an image resembling an Asian. As the months dragged on, the North African trail grew stronger after the discovery of a bloodstained footprint that supposedly gave racial clues. Misleading evidence added to sloppy police work, in which rival Police Judiciaire (CID) squads - one trying to solve the murders in the flats and the other working on those in the underground car parks - failed to spot the link between the two series of killings, despite several striking similarities. When the killer was finally identified during a belated hunt through DNA records, neither families nor detectives had the heart to blame Ortega. At the meeting arranged by Judge Thiel, she was in a wheelchair, paralysed from the waist down. I thought this was a sequel to Georges's attack, until she recalled that she had gone on holiday in Greece to forget the ordeal and had broken her back when diving from a rock. Her story is only one account of what military men would call "collateral damage". Magali Sirroti's mother, Chantal, for instance, cannot sleep at night. The last recorded message she left on her daughter's telephone on September 23, 1997, the day she died, turns over and over in her head: "Bonjour, c'est maman. There's no need to call me back, there is nothing important. Gros bisous." The telephone had rung unanswered beside the bed where Magali had already bled to death a few minutes earlier. Since then, Chantal Sirotti has read Georges's own description of the killing. Magali Sirotti was killed in the late afternoon on her return from work to the flat where she lived with a garage mechanic. They were planning to get married in the spring, and her wedding dress was in the wardrobe. Magali's parents were a retired working-class couple in the Paris suburbs. Her father, Aldo, spends his days cleaning his daughter's grave or sitting in an armchair absently looking into nowhere. He developed something of a persecution complex, believing that his local town council was trying to drive him mad. After several rows, he found just cause: the theatre near his house had billed a concert. The main work was Schubert's Death And The Maiden. Furious, Aldo Sirotti confronted the mayor and forced him to cover up the posters. Another father slowly drowned himself in drink and died in a suspect car crash. Another refused to console his wife and walked away with all his daughter's personal possessions. Others planned a vigilante group to kill Guy Georges, buying guns and interrupting Thiel's meeting with shouts of "A mort, à mort." Anne Gautier, 60, a retired schoolmistress and divorced mother of Hélène Frinking, is the most outspoken critic of police failures in the Guy Georges affair. "It was not until I alerted the press on coincidences between the murders that there was an outcry," she said. "Journalists invented the description 'The Bastille killer', because two cases were located near the monument and the authorities were forced to accept that a serial killer was loose. Police had told me earlier that tueurs ensérie [serial killers] were an Anglo-Saxon thing. I think their stubbornness cost at least two lives. "I found that the Police Judiciaire didn't even question Hélène's neighbours until 23 months after she was killed," continued Gautier. "The Elisabeth Ortega identity portrait was drawn up 28 months after she was attacked, but accurate descriptions from other survivors and witnesses [in at least four other cases] were ignored. I was treated patronisingly, like a 'poor little woman', and was told that the links in the Guy Georges's case were missed because police were overworked. They were distracted by the 1995 terrorist bombings, and gave far more importance to the 1997 investigation into Princess Diana's death, when the entire force was mobilised to satisfy public opinion. "If you challenge the French police," she added, "they are arrogant and claim to be the best in the world, but they had Georges under arrest at least three times for related offences without linking him to the murders, even though he left several clues." Other parents have shunned Gautier's attempt to set up a lobby to expose police and administrative failures, which include at least 70 unsolved murders of young women in recent years, accusing her of profiting from her suffering to become a media star. But her lawyers told me that Gautier's apparent toughness was superficial, that she was the most resolute of the mothers in hiding her pain, and that she broke down and wept for days when Georges was finally arrested. Few people concerned by the murders seem to have escaped unscathed. A sense of shame hangs around the Police Judiciaire on the Quai des Orfèvres. The senior woman superintendent in overall charge of the police inquiry has been transferred to administrative work, and the interior ministry now blocks all requests to speak to her. The two detectives who led the field inquiry admit privately to an unbearable weight of guilt for their failures: one, with a daughter in her 20s, is so depressed that his colleagues believe that the setback will break his career; the other, who worked as a rival rather than a colleague, demanded a transfer to an obscure post in the provinces. Judge Thiel has joined the self-flagellation, although the case would never have been solved if he had not cut through regulations and ordered a search for DNA held in private clinics that finally linked Georges to sexual crimes more than 10 years before. He condemns police bungling in his final report, but finishes by officially blaming himself, as investigator-in-chief, "for lack of vigilance". The office of François Honnorat, Georges's first defence counsel, is typical of the profession, a huge, expensively-furnished bureau in a residential quarter remote from the ugliness of violent crime. He spoke in a curiously monotonous, haunted voice, like someone coming to terms with a bewildering experience. A family man in his mid-30s, Honnorat had been chosen by the Paris Bar from 12 stand-by counsels to defend Georges while still representing another multiple killer. "My first client was terrifying - at one moment calm and attentive, and the next moment extremely violent," Honnorat said. "But Georges is so reasonable and doesn't show any sign of aggression. Talking to him is like chatting to someone in the local cafe. He is extremely well-informed and talks about everything - sport, social questions, politics - in a calm and intelligent way. "He has been placed in a cell block with big-time criminals, and this has helped him push his own acts out of his mind and inflated his self-esteem. He is at home in prison. He has his television, reads the newspapers and receives visits from his friends in the squats, who give him pocket money. Even the warders like him." Georges told psychiatrists that it was "better I am in prison: outside, I am dangerous"; he has been diagnosed as "hyper-adaptable", colouring himself to his environment in the same way as he adapted his personality to night-prowling, arbitrating in squats, living rough and seducing any number of women. Honnorat found his behaviour so disconcerting that he was glad when he received a short, well-written letter from Guy Georges dismissing him as a lawyer. The decision is linked to the fact that Georges's cell neighbour is Carlos "The Jackal", the international terrorist whose real name is Ilich Ramirez Sanchez. Carlos, a Venezuelan, became notorious in the 70s for actions on behalf of the Palestinians, notably the kidnap of the Opec oil ministers in Vienna in 1975. He was arrested in 1994 and is currently serving a life sentence for the murders of two French policemen. His family is campaigning to have him released on the grounds that his imprisonment in France is illegal, and Carlos himself went on a hunger strike in 1998 in protest at ill-treatment by prison guards. Since then, in La Santé, Carlos has continued his incessant attack on the corruption of western society, and has persuaded Georges to take a more aggressive stance against the French state, as a personal revenge for all wrongs done to him. To this end, Georges has taken on another barrister with a reputation for turning hearings into show trials. "I don't see why I should be the only one to pay for this," Georges told Honnorat in his last letter, referring to appalling laxity in the French prison system that diagnosed him as "extremely dangerous" nearly 20 years ago and yet released him on to the streets without treatment, money or meaningful care. At the basis of this feeling of persecution lies Georges's resentment for a birthright that was stolen by officialdom, which obstructed all his attempts to find his father at times of great stress. "When he was finally told his father's name, it was as if he had been reborn," Honnorat said. "He leaped with joy. He had retrieved the identity that he had been running after all his life. Being American raised his self-importance and self-confidence. Before he heard the news, he was ready to admit his crimes at the assizes to save the families further anguish. Now, he wants to take on the whole system." Since meeting Carlos, Georges has invented a bizarre defence, claiming that he was framed by the French secret service because he supposedly stole an official limousine carrying confidential documents. Recent letters to his friends say that he will plead not guilty in what may be an attempt to impress his long-lost father. "Unfortunately, this will only antagonise the jury," Honnorat said. "He has no hope of escaping a lifetime in prison after confessing his crimes repeatedly to police and Judge Thiel in the presence of his own defence counsel." But the lawyer was clearly torn in his own judgment on the appropriate punishment for the criminal journey of a lost child whom society had treated as trash. "I asked the psychiatrists if they could find a solution to save him from perpetual confinement," Honnorat said. "Their answer was clear: Georges was not mad and was fully responsible for his acts. They said that there were two roads for a man of his type. He was pre-destined to become a murderer or a war hero." In a flash of black humour, the psychiatrists added: "And we have no intention of starting a world war to save Guy Georges."

webTitle: Christina Ricci's quest for the normal life

fields.headline: Escape from the weird
fields.standfirst: Christina Ricci began making films when she was nine. Her father was a primal scream therapist who taught his children that nobody really likes you. In comparison, Hollywood seemed like sweet normality. Still does. Has that helped her, still only 20, to become one of the most real, self-contained yet appealing actors around? Suzie Mackenzie finds out
fields.trailText: Christina Ricci began making films when she was nine. Her father was a primal scream therapist who taught his children that nobody really likes you. In comparison, Hollywood seemed like sweet normality. Still does. Has that helped her, still only 20, to become one of the most real, self-contained yet appealing actors around? Suzie Mackenzie finds out.
fields.body:
If Nicole Kidman and Julia Roberts represent the norm of what a Hollywood film star should look like - "fashioned" faces - then Christina Ricci is definitely abnormal. She is not tall, five foot one, her legs are short, and though her face is fresh and round as an apple, the forehead is broad and high and the eyes that look out from under it fix you with a deadpan take-it-or-leave-it stare. She resembles, shockingly, the sort of people that you stand next to in a bus queue. And, indeed, the day before meeting her I had stood beside her at a video store on Sunset Boulevard, as king for some of her films, without recognising her. It was only after she left that a slightly embarrassed guy at the counter informed me: "That, er, was Miss Ricci." (Incidentally, the films she rented were Dick and Felicia's Journey - both featuring actresses of a similar age to herself - 20. Homework for the conscientious.)

She arrives at my hotel bang on time - unusual to the point of deviant in Hollywood - wearing jeans, a sweater that she may have on inside out, extremely high shoes and no make-up. And immediately apologises for her appearance. The previous day, watching her shoot an upcoming film, Pumpkin, in which she plays a varsity cheerleader, she had looked pert and prim. "Today," she says, "I am sorry, you've just got me." And if I hadn't admired her already, consider her, in fact, not just the cliche "finest actress of her generation" but someone who within movie-making has pretty much invented her own style - this is the point at which I would have succumbed. The particular qualities she has are not hard to pin down - just unbelievably hard to act. A sense she gives that we are spying on unrehearsed reality. And, even more unusual this - as an actor she never asks for, or expects, our sympathy; she keeps us at arm's length, the comfortable distance.

She is currently appearing alongside her pal Johnny Depp in Sally Potter's The Man Who Cried, but it is for her role in The Addams Family, playing the stone-faced, psychotic Wednesday with a bewitching insouciance, that many of us came to admire her. But, as she says, when she made The Addams Family she was 10. "I did what I was told. Express no emotion. That is the only direction I received throughout the entire film." Then, in the late 90s, now in her teens, came the cluster of roles on which she is rightly judged - each of them a study in some kind of deviant adolescent survival technique, playing characters whose sense of their own "normality" is at variance with the norm. The classic adolescent, in other words. She was riveting as the 14-year-old Wendy in Ang Lee's The Ice Storm (1997), and not even Lee's first choice for the part. That honour went to Natalie Portman - but when Portman's parents turned the role down, "unsuitable" for their daughter, Lee cast Ricci.

He must have blessed the gods. No one else could have conveyed with such dispassion that fusion of amorality and innocence, the creative self-sufficiency of the young, as Wendy observes her parents' sexual antics with mixed tremors of pity and disgust. And never evincing surprise. Surprise is the one state you will never find in Miss Ricci. Just a shrug of resignation. Sure, rejection hurts she says - "that they wanted someone else instead of you".

Two more versions of adolescent alienation followed. She was hysterically funny, and again insouciant, as the hard-boiled Dedee Truit in Don Roos's The Opposite Of Sex, pregnant and packing her gun, paying not so much as lip-service to conventional values and not caring what anyone thinks. And then, her best role, Layla in Vincent Gallo's Buffalo '66. The part seems made for her, and certainly Gallo, who wrote, directed and acts in what is virtually a two-hander, must have thought so.

As Layla, naive, open-hearted, a kid abducted from her dance class by the bruised and crazed Gallo, who then falls in love with him, she is wanly haunting. She moves through the film like some phantom, untethered to reality, registering petulance where someone else would register terror, shrugging where others would weep, pulling down at the hem of her baby-doll dress. "That was me, I didn't want anyone to see my underwear." In the bright-eyed candour of her face a mute appeal - but to what? She was brilliant.

And how did Gallo repay her? He slagged her off in the press, "I don't like her." Mocked her weight, mocked her work. Called her "a puppet" and "an ungrateful cunt", when the gratitude should have been all his. "That's just Vincent," she says. "Always lashing out, always trashing someone. Yeah, I'd work with him again. He's very talented." Pain and pragmatism. Not as divorced as sometimes they seem.

She made lots of mistakes around this time, Ricci says - as how could she not? She gave interviews in which she said ridiculous things, things to shock. There was something about incest being "normal" - that word again. Something about a gun. Comments about the benefits of cruelly intensive diets. As though she were some character out of The Addams Family writ large, turning the world system upside down - which, in a sense, she was. "I thought I was being funny." She was 18. "I was called Goth. People made me sound weird. I think most people thought I was a freak. Someone dark, different... I know I am not average. But I am not dark. I am not even that odd." She thought she was being normal, playing out the normal disaffected kid.

Anyone could see her life had not been normal. Out of family life at the age of 10, working in an environment -the movies - wholly removed from reality. But, within that world, fashioning versions of her own adolescent isolation seemed normal to her - it is what adolescents do. Adolescents are soloists - they have this in common with artists - and, if they identify at all, it is with other misfits - viz Ricci's roles. It is this that gives adolescents their pathos and their quality of the appalling. Lee understood this well in The Ice Storm. While the adults are enacting cliches of aberrant behaviour - adultery, partner-swapping at key parties, vodka in the afternoon - it is the kids who are truly subversive. And we fear them, rightly, as the film shows. What the adults in The Ice Storm take for unhappiness is merely what is normal. Normal unhappiness. Until the end, and their discovery of grief. (You suspect also that the kids will be better equipped to deal with grief - yet another reason for fearing them. As Ricci says, "Children adapt the quickest.")

Ricci's background was normal, that is to say unhappy. Her dad was 56 when she was born - the last of four. It was his third marriage. And when asked if there were children by the previous marriages, Ricci replies, "Not that we are aware of" - the only time she gives a glib response. So begins the dispassion, questions you don't ask because you don't want to know the answer.

Her mum, she says, was a good mum, but busy, "Four kids" and so she was "mothered" mostly by her sister Pia, four years older and now a teacher in Chicago. Pia was the good one, the one who never got into trouble. Christina was, of necessity, naughty. The kind of bright but obstreperous child teachers slap down knowing full well they'll bounce right up again. "I think I knew from a very early age that there was nothing they could do to me. They couldn't put me in jail, so I could do what I wanted."

Ricci's background was also abnormal. Though, for the most part, she didn't perceive it as such. Her dad was a therapist, specialising in primal scream therapy, based in the basement of their home in New Jersey, and the kids would come home from school to all this wailing and bawling inarticulacy rising up through the floorboards. And ignore it. "It didn't have any impact on us at all. None of us took the slightest bit of notice. It wasn't a big deal."

Children, as she has said, are quick to adapt. "We were all very self-contained little entities who happened to live in the same house." As little entities they adapted, too, to his ideas of discipline. "By the age of 10, we'd have to do our own laundry. Bed time was adjusted upwards by half-an-hour every other year until the age of 17, when there was no longer a curfew." (In an interview she once gave, she talked of the pleasure of being 17: "No more curfew." By this time, she had been working for seven years, and was then living in her own flat with her boyfriend. Not that quick to adapt after all.) Family supper was at 5.30pm sharp. "It was very strict, we all had to be there." And their father would regale them with his life's philosophy. He was, she says, "a very paranoid man" who taught them there is no such thing as selflessness, no one ever really likes you, people are only out for themselves - inversions of basic human values masquerading as survival. That makes The Addams Family look, well, normal. At least they shared human attributes of love and trust.

What did her father think he was doing? "I think he thought that because he was like that, so was everybody else. He was passing on his little secret to his children." She didn't believe him. "I don't think it affected me because I decided it wasn't true. No way. Life couldn't be that way." But, like the curfew, these things are not so easily dispelled. To this day, she says, when hurt she makes very bad recoveries, but she's got a strategy for coping. "On the whole, I don't give people a second chance. They don't get to hurt me again."

When confronted she prefers to capitulate. "I'd do anything to avoid a fight." If challenged, "I apologise." Afraid, I guess, that if pushed to the line her father's miserable little secret just might prove to be true. People don't like you. It's no surprise that she repeats so painstakingly Gallo's remarks about her. They must have had a horrible ring of familiarity. And what did she do - just shrugged and let him get away with it.

She didn't let her father get away with it. She was 13 when her parents divorced and he left home. She had just finished filming the sequel to The Addams Family. For the next two years she saw him on and off, but since she was 15 they have had no contact at all. "And I don't expect to have again. I know it sounds cold, but it was one of the first things I ever did in my life - to take care of myself. Decide that only people who deserve it can be in my life." She loved her mum. "But I was awful with her, frightening. I just did whatever I wanted. Didn't come home if I didn't feel like it. Refused any sort of protection." She had become her own protector.

One of the great benefits of getting older, she says, is that you get to create another family for yourself. Film became her family. Quite literally. You can see how it would work. An enclosed, safe little world. "People who are kind to me." With "regular hours" - that would resonate. The crew are her brothers, looking after her. "They carry me around." The director is the authority figure. She does what she is told. "And I resent it." Naturally. Her mother always there with her - so she finally had the attention she must have been clamouring for.

She has often said that she is not interested in her characters' emotions. Doesn't question their motivation. "It seems very pretentious to me to talk about non-existent human feelings." She is not interested in inner reality. "I try to play the reality." It is something she learned as a child actor. "No one talks to you about emotions then. It is how I was trained. A technique I learned and have carried through." Funny how one world blends into another. You could almost think that she is talking here about what she learned in her childhood.

And the even funnier thing is, she says, that the moment she started acting, all the bad behaviour stopped. As if swapping "normal" family life for the abnormal world of Hollywood normalised her, saved her from becoming like the lonely, lost dysfunctional characters she plays. Finally, she had a peer group - not a very normal one for the adolescent, true - but a group of people engaged in the same thing. And, in this sort of weird version of the world, she finds suddenly she fits. So she can't be cynical about Hollywood, she says. It may be a fantasy. "All the glamour, the limos, the beautiful hotels." It's certainly not a reality. "That's not how you live your life, that only happens from time to time." But we are all implicated in it, she says. Fantasy is our escape.

All the time throughout the late 90s, when she was presenting herself as so tough, so cynical, she would go home to her apartment and there, under the bed, would be her scrapbook, in which she would paste pictures of her idealised life. "Just the dreams that all little girls have. How I wanted my house to look. The dresses I'd wear. The car I wanted. That kind of stuff. I suppose it's funny, really." She'd cut out of Martha Stewart's bridal magazines photographs of the perfect wedding she would have, right down to the flowers and table settings. "I liked to think I'd be engaged at 18, married at 20, have kids at 23. A perfect concept." But a bit of a constricted concept, because the problem was that it stopped at about 27. "That's as far as it goes. The tragic accident in which you and your husband never get old and live together forever and ever."

In her heart, she says, she never believed any of it. Neither the fantasy of the Goth, nor the fantasy of the little princess. She just wanted to get to play that part - for once. "You know, be a fairy, be luminescent, sparkle. I'm sorry." She was trying to resist, she says, the idea that "unhappiness is normal". Because it seemed to her pragmatic, or plain good sense, to assume the worst. "That something bad was going to happen. That happy people just aren't looking around them. They don't realise it is going to be their turn next." And then the realisation, and not necessarily a comfortable one - that most people are unhappy because their lives don't measure up to some fantasy of happiness that they have. That if you can accept unhappiness as part of life - then you may be well on the way to being happy.

You make your own world, she says - to a large extent but not the whole extent. You can't be held responsible for everything. And then, what seemed a non-sequitur, but isn't, she said, "Women have been taught shame about themselves over centuries." And, of course, it is obvious. That she has had to overcome all those insecurities of the adolescent girl, in public and on her own. "Because it is me up there. And it's a pretty isolated position. That's why, now, I accept any help that's on offer. I love people doing things for me. It makes me feel less vulnerable and exposed. That even if it's me up there, there are people around me who care about me."

She was seriously anorexic for a while, hated what she looked like - and that gave her a shock. She still chain smokes. "But I don't feel inferior to men any more, and I don't feel ashamed of being a woman. Certainly I did. I think that's why teenage girls are so angry. You reach puberty and your first reaction is embarrassment. And then rage about the embarrassment. And you feel so foolish because it's not your fault. And, anyway, why be embarrassed?"

The film she has just completed, Prozac Nation, deals with issues in this area of self-abuse. It was a comparatively short shoot, but when it was over she was physically and mentally exhausted. "My doctor asked me, 'Why would you jeopardise your mental state in this way?'" I can handle anything, she told him. I am emotionally impervious. There hasn't been anything I haven't been able to get over... And, somewhere here, the sense that suffering is normal while being also unbearable. As she says, the key to understanding other people is empathy. Imagining yourself in another's place. "It seems to me that this story is like every girl's fear of what and who they really are. A complete and total wreck." So making it, she says, was also a form of self-protection. "Because if you can understand why something has happened, why someone has done something, then you are less likely to be hurt."

Work has become her stability. "Every aspect of this business seems normal to me at this point." Over a period of 10 years, she has been in 29 films, 16 of these in the past four years. She loves it. Has grown up with it. But, unlike the adolescent turned young adult who leaves home, she is going to have to grow old with it. What she has to work out is how to develop within it and - Hollywood having its own strict set of norms - how not to get herself stuck.

She says she doesn't have many friends, but she does have good friends - professional and personal. Johnny Depp has been a mate over the past few years. Not in any romantic sense - she laughs at this as an absurd notion. It was Depp who got her involved in Tim Burton's Sleepy Hollow, where she finally gets to play a romantic lead who looks like a princess. Though, in fact, as she points out, there is a dark side. "That's why they cast me. To throw a little suspicion on the character."

Originally, the studios didn't want her, not because of her work, but because of her image - as a bit of a loose cannon - not always judicious in her choice of words. So she has learned to be more careful now, she says. A bit more "grown up". She used to make mistakes out of "arrogance and insecurity - two sides of the same thing". But, as she says, both inevitable. From an early age - she puts it as young as eight - she was "controlling" her life. What possible result but arrogance and insecurity?

When she says she is arrogant, she is not arrogant about her work. And she is generous. On the set of Pumpkin, I met her friend and assistant, Dave, an aspiring cinematographer, whom she met filming in New York and who couldn't get a way in to LA. So she brought him out, gave him a job, with a good salary, and a room. And, as he says, the time to look around and get known. "A lot of people helped me," Ricci says. "I think it's normal." It is normal - except a lot of people don't remember to behave as well.

She is the same about other young actors. I watched her on the set being thanked, swamped with ingratiation, by women more than five years older than her. It is the star system and she is used to it, but it's still salutary. "There are a lot of good people out there who never get the chance. I see so many amazing actors who never make it and for so many different reasons. If you are a woman, you have to have the whole package. It's one thing to be a great actor - but if you are not pretty, or if there is no angle - forget it. It's not good enough to be a good actor."

And, as far as insecurity goes, she is now on her own. Her three-year relationship, to the actor Matthew Frauman, ended five months ago, not bitterly. "Nothing dramatic happened. It was simply over. Sometimes things just end, and it's really sad. I think it may even be the saddest thing." And, though she would love to fall in love again, "I don't like dating, so I am just stumbling through. And I don't like being alone, but I can't go looking to fall in love." Maybe, she says, if she were more graceful. "I'd love to be graceful. More confident, more at ease with myself. Instead of falling into saying silly things, even nasty things, because I am embarrassed."

And Minnie saying to her audience that she wasn't confident, and please excuse her. "But she did it with such grace... I want to have that grace." fields.bodyText: If Nicole Kidman and Julia Roberts represent the norm of what a Hollywood film star should look like - "fashioned" faces - then Christina Ricci is definitely abnormal. She is not tall, five foot one, her legs are short, and though her face is fresh and round as an apple, the forehead is broad and high and the eyes that look out from under it fix you with a deadpan take-it-or-leave-it stare. She resembles, shockingly, the sort of people that you stand next to in a bus queue. And, indeed, the day before meeting her I had stood beside her at a video store on Sunset Boulevard, as king for some of her films, without recognising her. It was only after she left that a slightly embarrassed guy at the counter informed me: "That, er, was Miss Ricci." (Incidentally, the films she rented were Dick and Felicia's Journey - both featuring actresses of a similar age to herself - 20. Homework for the conscientious.) She arrives at my hotel bang on time - unusual to the point of deviant in Hollywood - wearing jeans, a sweater that she may have on inside out, extremely high shoes and no make-up. And immediately apologises for her appearance. The previous day, watching her shoot an upcoming film, Pumpkin, in which she plays a varsity cheerleader, she had looked pert and prim. "Today," she says, "I am sorry, you've just got me." And if I hadn't admired her already, consider her, in fact, not just the cliche "finest actress of her generation" but someone who within movie-making has pretty much invented her own style - this is the point at which I would have succumbed. The particular qualities she has are not hard to pin down - just unbelievably hard to act. A sense she gives that we are spying on unrehearsed reality. And, even more unusual this - as an actor she never asks for, or expects, our sympathy; she keeps us at arm's length, the comfortable distance. She is currently appearing alongside her pal Johnny Depp in Sally Potter's The Man Who Cried, but it is for her role in The Addams Family, playing the stone-faced, psychotic Wednesday with a bewitching insouciance, that many of us came to admire her. But, as she says, when she made The Addams Family she was 10. "I did what I was told. Express no emotion. That is the only direction I received throughout the entire film." Then, in the late 90s, now in her teens, came the cluster of roles on which she is rightly judged - each of them a study in some kind of deviant adolescent survival technique, playing characters whose sense of their own "normality" is at variance with the norm. The classic adolescent, in other words. She was riveting as the 14-year-old Wendy in Ang Lee's The Ice Storm (1997), and not even Lee's first choice for the part. That honour went to Natalie Portman - but when Portman's parents turned the role down, "unsuitable" for their daughter, Lee cast Ricci. He must have blessed the gods. No one else could have conveyed with such dispassion that fusion of amorality and innocence, the creative self-sufficiency of the young, as Wendy observes her parents' sexual antics with mixed tremors of pity and disgust. And never evincing surprise. Surprise is the one state you will never find in Miss Ricci. Just a shrug of resignation. Sure, rejection hurts she says - "that they wanted someone else instead of you". Two more versions of adolescent alienation followed. She was hysterically funny, and again insouciant, as the hard-boiled Dedee Truit in Don Roos's The Opposite Of Sex, pregnant and packing her gun, paying not so much as lip-service to conventional values and not caring what anyone thinks. And then, her best role, Layla in Vincent Gallo's Buffalo '66. The part seems made for her, and certainly Gallo, who wrote, directed and acts in what is virtually a two-hander, must have thought so. As Layla, naive, open-hearted, a kid abducted from her dance class by the bruised and crazed Gallo, who then falls in love with him, she is wanly haunting. She moves through the film like some phantom, untethered to reality, registering petulance where someone else would register terror, shrugging where others would weep, pulling down at the hem of her baby-doll dress. "That was me, I didn't want anyone to see my underwear." In the bright-eyed candour of her face a mute appeal - but to what? She was brilliant. And how did Gallo repay her? He slagged her off in the press, "I don't like her." Mocked her weight, mocked her work. Called her "a puppet" and "an ungrateful cunt", when the gratitude should have been all his. "That's just Vincent," she says. "Always lashing out, always trashing someone. Yeah, I'd work with him again. He's very talented." Pain and pragmatism. Not as divorced as sometimes they seem. She made lots of mistakes around this time, Ricci says - as how could she not? She gave interviews in which she said ridiculous things, things to shock. There was something about incest being "normal" - that word again. Something about a gun. Comments about the benefits of cruelly intensive diets. As though she were some character out of The Addams Family writ large, turning the world system upside down - which, in a sense, she was. "I thought I was being funny." She was 18. "I was called Goth. People made me sound weird. I think most people thought I was a freak. Someone dark, different... I know I am not average. But I am not dark. I am not even that odd." She thought she was being normal, playing out the normal disaffected kid. Anyone could see her life had not been normal. Out of family life at the age of 10, working in an environment -the movies - wholly removed from reality. But, within that world, fashioning versions of her own adolescent isolation seemed normal to her - it is what adolescents do. Adolescents are soloists - they have this in common with artists - and, if they identify at all, it is with other misfits - viz Ricci's roles. It is this that gives adolescents their pathos and their quality of the appalling. Lee understood this well in The Ice Storm. While the adults are enacting cliches of aberrant behaviour - adultery, partner-swapping at key parties, vodka in the afternoon - it is the kids who are truly subversive. And we fear them, rightly, as the film shows. What the adults in The Ice Storm take for unhappiness is merely what is normal. Normal unhappiness. Until the end, and their discovery of grief. (You suspect also that the kids will be better equipped to deal with grief - yet another reason for fearing them. As Ricci says, "Children adapt the quickest.") Ricci's background was normal, that is to say unhappy. Her dad was 56 when she was born - the last of four. It was his third marriage. And when asked if there were children by the previous marriages, Ricci replies, "Not that we are aware of" - the only time she gives a glib response. So begins the dispassion, questions you don't ask because you don't want to know the answer. Her mum, she says, was a good mum, but busy, "Four kids" and so she was "mothered" mostly by her sister Pia, four years older and now a teacher in Chicago. Pia was the good one, the one who never got into trouble. Christina was, of necessity, naughty. The kind of bright but obstreperous child teachers slap down knowing full well they'll bounce right up again. "I think I knew from a very early age that there was nothing they could do to me. They couldn't put me in jail, so I could do what I wanted." Ricci's background was also abnormal. Though, for the most part, she didn't perceive it as such. Her dad was a therapist, specialising in primal scream therapy, based in the basement of their home in New Jersey, and the kids would come home from school to all this wailing and bawling inarticulacy rising up through the floorboards. "We were all very self-contained little entities who happened to live in the same house." As little entities they adapted, too, to his ideas of discipline. fields.headline: The tiger vanishes
fields.standfirst: It seems unthinkable: one of the most beloved animals on earth, the acme of power and grace, faces extinction in the wild. The culprits are the old foes: poachers and despoilers of the tiger's habitat from Bangladesh to Siberia. Is it too late to save the tiger? Tania Unsworth investigates
fields.trailText: It seems unthinkable: one of the most beloved animals on earth, the acme of power and grace, faces extinction in the wild. The culprits are the old foes: poachers and despoilers of the tiger's habitat from Bangladesh to Siberia. Is it too late to save the tiger? Tania Unsworth investigates.
fields.body:
The tiger is being lost. Animal by animal, its footprints are vanishing from the world's forests. But perhaps "lost" is the wrong word; destroyed is a more accurate description. It's a difficult fact to absorb. The tiger is a friend from childhood, poets' inspiration, emblem of nationhood; a creature synonymous with power, in whom force and beauty appear inseparable.

The tiger is so much a part of our culture that its disappearance seems almost ridiculous. With it gone, how will we view Rousseau's famous image of the animal, or the stories of Kipling? What will it mean any longer to have "the eye of the tiger" or to "put a tiger in your tank"? In a million toy Noah's Arks, the animal will be as out of place as the dodo; and Blake's "tyger" will burn nowhere but in memory, his famous poem forever reading like a reproach. They were so plentiful that trigger-happy British sportsmen and maharajahs vied to make the biggest number of kills. Appalling as these massacres now seem, such hunting did not present an immediate threat to the tiger. In the 20s and 30s, when the hunter and naturalist Jim Corbett was tracking man-eaters in India, there were still plenty of the animals around.

Reading Corbett's immensely entertaining accounts of his adventures, one is struck by two things: first, the intimate knowledge and respect that he had for tigers; and second, the terror that the animals inspired, not only among the Indians who shared their living space but also in Corbett, despite his gun and legendary tracking powers. Here he is on the trail of a tigress in Muktesar that has killed 24 people. Seated in a small tree, barely 8ft above the ground, with his legs dangling down, Corbett realises that the tiger is only 20ft away; worse, it has spotted him: "The near proximity of a tiger in daylight, even when it has not seen you, causes a disturbance in the blood stream. When the tiger is not an ordinary one, however, but a man-eater and the time is 10 o'clock on a dark night, and you know that the man-eater is watching you, the disturbance in the blood stream becomes a storm."

Even more than half a century on, Corbett's stories have a fantastic immediacy. We are never going to feel this kind of fear; we are no longer frightened of tigers. Instead, we are frightened for them. And, in its own way, that's perhaps as terrifying as anything Corbett ever experienced. The facts make grim reading: of the eight subspecies of tigers, three - the Caspian, Javan and Bali - are already extinct. Experts put remaining tiger numbers at somewhere between 5,000 and 7,000, although this could be an overestimate. Tiger populations are notoriously difficult to evaluate, despite recent technological advances that help keep track of their movements. About half of the animals left are Bengal tigers, on the Indian subcontinent. There are also 400-500 Siberian tigers in the Russian far east, a similar number of Sumatran tigers, merely 30 South China tigers and between 1,000-1,800 Indo-Chinese tigers surviving in small pockets from Myanmar to Vietnam.

The area is potentially rich in sources of oil and gas; it is also the world's largest tiger reserve. And despite restrictions on the sale of tiger products, poaching continues. "Now they're being killed for their skin, teeth and claws," claims the WWF's Chapman. "There has been a market shift. Tigers are now fuelling the curio trade. You can buy small squares of skin in markets all over Asia."

It is the largest tiger in the world, standing five to ten centimetres taller than its Bengal relative, and in winter its fur grows thick and long, making it look even larger. It lives in the Sikhote-Alin mountains, in the far east corner of the one-time Soviet Union, a vast area sparsely populated by humans, where it must range far and wide to find prey. Thanks to extensive hunting, the number of Siberian tigers was down to a mere 50 or so in 1936. In the 40s, however, it began receiving state protection, which resulted in a gradual recovery, so much so that by the mid-80s it was estimated that there were more than 250 Siberian tigers in the wild. Then came the collapse of the Soviet Union and, with the breakdown of law and order, the tigers were once more open to attack. By 1992, more than a third of the population had been wiped out, and the animal was back on the critical list.

Since then, several wildlife organisations, working closely with Russian environmental ministries and scientific institutes, have managed yet again to haul the Siberian tiger back from the brink. New protected areas have been created, and poaching drastically reduced. Last year, estimates put the tiger population at upwards of 500. "It was one of the success stories of the 90s," says Chapman. Tiger experts as prominent as Dr John Seidensticker, chairman of the Save The Tiger Fund, were beginning to believe that the Siberian now had one of the best chances of survival of any of the world's tigers. Although there are far more tigers in India, many of these live in small, stressed groups, whereas the Siberian tiger lives in a more or less continuous habitat. "No other tiger population inhabits a vast and almost roadless area of forested mountains, very thinly populated by human beings," writes the novelist-explorer Peter Matthiessen in his book Tigers In The Snow (North Point Press). "Also, despite its dangerously low numbers, altaica (the Siberian tiger) is slowly increasing, while tigris ( the Bengal tiger), beset by Homo sapiens, continues its remorseless, slow decline."

Then, in May, came catastrophe: possibly in response to lobbying from Russian oil and timber firms, Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, announced that he was abolishing the State Committee for Environmental Protection and the Federal Forestry Reserve, the two agencies that helped protect the Siberian tiger. "The decision is a disaster for the tiger," says Igor Chestin, director of the Russian office of the WWF. "Without the help of the Forestry Reserve, it will be hard to avoid and contain forest fires, which regularly threaten the tiger population. Poaching will increase and core areas of the tiger's habitat are under threat from development. The minister for natural resources stated recently that certain protected areas contain some of the richest mining prospects. That really reveals his attitude."

Following Putin's announcement, many hundreds of letters from concerned groups and prominent individuals in Russia were sent to his office in Moscow, asking him to revise his decision. "There was no response," Chestin says flatly. "Nothing."

In a last-ditch effort to change the situation, Russian environmentalists are turning to drastic measures. They are trying to call a national referendum. "It's the only legal action left to us," says Chestin. According to Russian constitutional law, they have three months to collect two million signatures from people in at least 10 regions of the country. Not more than 10% of the signatures must come from any one region. "Once we get them," says Chestin, "they need to be validated, and then the president has 30 days to announce the date for a referendum." We can read stories such as this, absorb all the dire predictions, but denial persists when it comes to the tiger. How can the animal vanish? Only a tiny minority of us will ever see one in the wild, but few creatures are more familiar or easier to conjure up in the mind's eye. The great, blunt head, the golden eyes, the long, dappled body incapable, it seems, of a single ungraceful moment. The tiger is a core image, colouring the picture books and jigsaws of our childhood, friendly and sinister in equal measure, both Tigger and Shere Khan. Kipling used his tiger to go to the heart of man's uneasy relationship with the natural world. Instinctive enemies from the start, Mowgli and Shere Khan's fates are inextricably bound together, not simply as individuals but also as representatives of their species. It is the very first of the tigers, who, in The Jungle Book, introduces violence into the forest and who teaches man to kill. "O blind and foolish!" the first tiger is told. "Thou hast untied the feet of Death and he will follow thy trail till thou diest."

Others have appropriated the animal as emblem and metaphor, from Rocky Balboa to Blake, who famously found in the tiger an image of the sublime fury of creation. It has been woven into religious tradition, decorating temples throughout the Buddhist world. In Hinduism, the female deity Durga rides on a tiger. In China, every twelfth year is dedicated to the animal. It has appeared on banknotes and national crests, provided the symbol for the Seoul Olympics, given its name to the rapid economic advance of Asian countries, sold products ranging from petrol to frosted cereal flakes and stamps.

But there's a danger to this familiarity. Endowed with the mysterious substantiality of legend, the animal seems untouchable. It's easy to forget there's quite another kind of tiger, equally mysterious, perhaps, but far more defenceless: the real one.

Predicting how - or whether - the tiger can survive the enormous pressures facing it depends on understanding the animal itself. The tiger is both resilient and vulnerable by its very nature. In its favour are several important characteristics. One is its extreme secretiveness. Sightings of tigers in the wild are rare, even for those people who make it their mission to study them. This makes it harder for poachers to hunt and kill them. In terms of habitat, the tiger is also remarkably tolerant, managing to exist in a broad variety of terrains, from swamp and mangrove to tropical rainforest, to the chilly, coniferous-deciduous forests of eastern Russia.

As a hunter it is equally adaptable. The tiger hunts by stealth, stalking its prey before a sudden, explosive rush to make the kill. But not all prey are put to death in the same way. Methods vary according to the size and species of the prey and also among individual tigers who may change their technique with experience. This allows the tiger to capture a wide variety and size of animals.

In addition, the tiger is a phenomenal breeder. Unlike many other endangered species - the notoriously picky panda springs instantly to mind - the tiger mates readily and produces relatively large litters. And if one litter is lost, it is quick to start the cycle all over again. In captivity, the animal breeds so enthusiastically that adults need to be separated and contraceptives are commonly used to prevent unwanted cubs. This might help to explain why the widespread hunting of the animal in the 19th century did little to diminish its population. As long as habitat and prey remained intact, the tiger was able to recover fairly rapidly.

But the thing we most admire about the tiger - its sheer force - is also its downfall. The tiger is a super-predator, the biggest carnivore in Asia. A tigress needs 5-6kg of meat a day just to stay alive. To get this, she needs to kill upwards of 3,000kg of meat on the hoof every year. Depending on the availability of prey, each tiger requires vast expanses of territory. "Many people are unwilling to face the fact that tigers have very specific needs," maintains Dr Ullas Karanth, who, on behalf of the New York-based Wildlife Conservation Society, spends a large chunk of every year researching tigers and the conservation issues surrounding them in India's Nagarahole State Park. "In Nagarahole, among a population of 20 pairs of breeding tigers, each female needs 15 sq km. That's a total of between 300-400 sq km. But you can multiply that figure by 10 or 20 for the Siberian tiger, which has a much poorer quality of habitat." And the areas that tigers inhabit need to be intact, little used by humans - no logging, mining, farming or large numbers of livestock.

Tigers take up space. And they are dangerous. Corbett was always vehement in stressing that the vast majority of tigers do not prey on man. This could be from caution or simply a dislike for the taste of human flesh. But if they are too disabled to hunt their usual prey, or feel themselves under direct threat, tigers will attack people. When you combine this fact with the resentment that many who live in close proximity to the tiger feel about the way the animal has been afforded land needed by them and their families, the tiger can seem a murderous pest rather than a treasured asset. "Once confrontation between man and tiger is set up," says Karanth, "the tiger is always the loser."

"Curving oceans and the planet's wastes keep us apart in vain," wrote Jorge Luis Borges in his poem, The Other Tiger. "From here in a house far off in South America I dream of you, track you, O tiger of the Ganges' banks." When he wrote these words, Borges had no way of knowing that there could come a time in the not too distant future when the only wild tigers left would be those of the imagination.

What would it take to save them? Last year, Tigers 2000, the largest ever gathering of tiger experts, was held in the Zoological Society, London, to explore this question. The findings, though complex in discussion, came down to a few key issues: protective legislation needs to be stronger and properly enforced; there must be a shift of focus from counting tiger numbers to understanding and maintaining tiger habitat, not simply in terms of pockets of land but as part of the larger landscape; and, above all, we need to work out how tigers fit in with the people who live around them.

How can a sustainable relationship be created between tiger and man? Whether the tiger stays or goes depends to a great extent on the will of local people. Only if the value of a live tiger rises above that of a dead one will the species be saved. Locals need to be promptly and sufficiently compensated for loss of livestock to tigers. It must be made worth their while to relocate if necessary. And there should be real incentives for them to help fight poaching. Along with all this, communities living near tigers need to be given the opportunity to change their attitude to the animal. If they could be persuaded to view tigers with pride instead of resentment or indifference, they would become participants in the struggle to save them.

All this takes money. And it takes political will, both at a national and local level. Conservationists are not exactly optimistic about the tiger's fate. Their predictions are too hedged with "ifs" and "maybes". But they do have hope: "The beauty of working in conservation," says the WWF's Chapman, "is you see the ability of nature to bounce back. History is littered with examples of mammals reduced to tens of individuals making a comeback. Given the right circumstances, tigers could recover. Small victories add up."

"I see the tiger disappearing in certain areas," says Dr Paul Toyne, species conservation officer for the WWF. "Isolated pockets will probably go. But there are areas where commitment is strong and the environment is viable." Karanth is wary of making such predictions. "The tiger has been portrayed as a lost cause, but this is too simplistic. I still believe there will be a place for tigers, but only if we get our act together right now."

But should we be putting all this effort into saving the wild tiger? The question is not as irrelevant as it seems. After all, we have plenty of tigers in captivity. As the environmental journalist Cory Meacham effectively points out in his book How The Tiger Lost Its Stripes (Harcourt Brace, 1997), the animal is in no danger of extinction. As long as demand for them continues, there will always be tigers in captivity because they are so easy to breed. Why don't we simply concentrate efforts on sustaining genetically viable populations of tigers with a view to reintroducing them back into the wild if and when needed?

There are two main reasons why not: first, most tiger conservationists don't think it can be done - tigers learn how to hunt, avoid danger and look after their young from their wild mothers; and even if it could be done, as some believe, the process would be very costly. The second reason is that the tiger is what is known as an "umbrella" species: it needs a wide diversity of prey animals, and the vegetation to support them. Without the tiger, everything that exists in its habitat will be under threat. "If we want to reintroduce the tiger into the wild," says Dr Toyne, "there needs to be some habitat left. If we haven't got rid of the problems that caused the tiger's decline in the first place, there's absolutely no point to reintroduction."

The environmental arguments aside, the most compelling reason to continue to fight for the tiger is an emotional one. We may admire the animal for its looks, its power, but what we love about the tiger - what truly stirs our imagination - is something far harder to define: its wildness. In the open forest, the creature has an aura that even those accustomed to working with tigers find hard to describe. "All I know," says Karanth, "is that each sighting of a wild tiger is unique. I have seen hundreds in my life, but each time is like the first."

The zoo in the hill station of Darjeeling in north east India has a tiger. I was on holiday there, and went to see it. Three young men were clustered around the animal's small cage, poking at it with a stick. The tiger rumbled with irritation and the men jumped back, laughing to cover their momentary fear. The tiger paced back and forth close to the mesh of the cage and growled, and the men laughed again. The laughter was different this time. Although the tiger was unbelievably powerful, all colour and weight and anger, the men knew that the three of them, with their one small stick, were the ones with the real power. Perhaps of all animals, the tiger appears most diminished by captivity. Some essence - as fundamental as the stripes on its back - seems lost forever once it is put behind fences.

We need wild tigers. We need them because they are the closest we come to the creatures of myth - to unicorn or minotaur. There was a time when we barricaded our doors against the animals of the night. Now we sleep easier knowing they are still there

In captivity, the animal breeds so enthusiastically that adults need to be separated and contraceptives are commonly used to prevent unwanted cubs. This might help to explain why the widespread hunting of the animal in the 19th century did little to diminish its population. As long as habitat and prey remained intact, the tiger was able to recover fairly rapidly. But the thing we most admire about the tiger - its sheer force - is also its downfall. The tiger is a super-predator, the biggest carnivore in Asia. A tigress needs 5-6kg of meat a day just to stay alive. To get this, she needs to kill upwards of 3,000kg of meat on the hoof every year. Depending on the availability of prey, each tiger requires vast expanses of territory. "Many people are unwilling to face the fact that tigers have very specific needs," maintains Dr Ullas Karanth, who, on behalf of the New York-based Wildlife Conservation Society, spends a large chunk of every year researching tigers and the conservation issues surrounding them in India's Nagarahole State Park. "In Nagarahole, among a population of 20 pairs of breeding tigers, each female needs 15 sq km. That's a total of between 300-400 sq km. But you can multiply that figure by 10 or 20 for the Siberian tiger, which has a much poorer quality of habitat." And the areas that tigers inhabit need to be intact, little used by humans - no logging, mining, farming or large numbers of livestock. Tigers take up space. And they are dangerous. Corbett was always vehement in stressing that the vast majority of tigers do not prey on man. This could be from caution or simply a dislike for the taste of human flesh. But if they are too disabled to hunt their usual prey, or feel themselves under direct threat, tigers will attack people. When you combine this fact with the resentment that many who live in close proximity to the tiger feel about the way the animal has been afforded land needed by them and their families, the tiger can seem a murderous pest rather than a treasured asset. "Once confrontation between man and tiger is set up," says Karanth, "the tiger is always the loser." "Curving oceans and the planet's wastes keep us apart in vain," wrote Jorge Luis Borges in his poem, The Other Tiger. "From here in a house far off in South America I dream of you, track you, O tiger of the Ganges' banks." When he wrote these words, Borges had no way of knowing that there could come a time in the not too distant future when the only wild tigers left would be those of the imagination. What would it take to save them? Last year, Tigers 2000, the largest ever gathering of tiger experts, was held in the Zoological Society, London, to explore this question. The findings, though complex in discussion, came down to a few key issues: protective legislation needs to be stronger and properly enforced; there must be a shift of focus from counting tiger numbers to understanding and maintaining tiger habitat, not simply in terms of pockets of land but as part of the larger landscape; and, above all, we need to work out how tigers fit in with the people who live around them. How can a sustainable relationship be created between tiger and man? Whether the tiger stays or goes depends to a great extent on the will of local people. Only if the value of a live tiger rises above that of a dead one will the species be saved. Locals need to be promptly and sufficiently compensated for loss of livestock to tigers. It must be made worth their while to relocate if necessary. And there should be real incentives for them to help fight poaching. Along with all this, communities living near tigers need to be given the opportunity to change their attitude to the animal. If they could be persuaded to view tigers with pride instead of resentment or indifference, they would become participants in the struggle to save them. All this takes money. And it takes political will, both at a national and local level. Conservationists are not exactly optimistic about the tiger's fate. Their predictions are too hedged with "ifs" and "maybes". But they do have hope: "The beauty of working in conservation," says the WWF's Chapman, "is you see the ability of nature to bounce back. History is littered with examples of mammals reduced to tens of individuals making a comeback. Given the right circumstances, tigers could recover. Small victories add up." "I see the tiger disappearing in certain areas," says Dr Paul Toyne, species conservation officer for the WWF. "Isolated pockets will probably go. But there are areas where commitment is strong and the environment is viable." Karanth is wary of making such predictions. "The tiger has been portrayed as a lost cause, but this is too simplistic. I still believe there will be a place for tigers, but only if we get our act together right now." But should we be putting all this effort into saving the wild tiger? The question is not as irrelevant as it seems. After all, we have plenty of tigers in captivity. As the environmental journalist Cory Meacham effectively points out in his book How The Tiger Lost Its Stripes (Harcourt Brace, 1997), the animal is in no danger of extinction. As long as demand for them continues, there will always be tigers in captivity because they are so easy to breed. Why don't we simply concentrate efforts on sustaining genetically viable populations of tigers with a view to reintroducing them back into the wild if and when needed? There are two main reasons why not: first, most tiger conservationists don't think it can be done - tigers learn how to hunt, avoid danger and look after their young from their wild mothers; and even if it could be done, as some believe, the process would be very costly. The second reason is that the tiger is what is known as an "umbrella" species: it needs a wide diversity of prey animals, and the vegetation to support them. Without the tiger, everything that exists in its habitat will be under threat. "If we want to reintroduce the tiger into the wild," says Dr Toyne, "there needs to be some habitat left. If we haven't got rid of the problems that caused the tiger's decline in the first place, there's absolutely no point to reintroduction." The environmental arguments aside, the most compelling reason to continue to fight for the tiger is an emotional one. We may admire the animal for its looks, its power, but what we love about the tiger - what truly stirs our imagination - is something far harder to define: its wildness. In the open forest, the creature has an aura that even those accustomed to working with tigers find hard to describe. "All I know," says Karanth, "is that each sighting of a wild tiger is unique. I have seen hundreds in my life, but each time is like the first." The zoo in the hill station of Darjeeling in north east India has a tiger. I was on holiday there, and went to see it. Three young men were clustered around the animal's small cage, poking at it with a stick. The tiger rumbled with irritation and the men jumped back, laughing to cover their momentary fear. The tiger paced back and forth close to the mesh of the cage and growled, and the men laughed again. The laughter was different this time. Although the tiger was unbelievably powerful, all colour and weight and anger, the men knew that the three of them, with their one small stick, were the ones with the real power. Perhaps of all animals, the tiger appears most diminished by captivity. Some essence - as fundamental as the stripes on its back - seems lost forever once it is put behind fences. We need wild tigers. We need them because they are the closest we come to the creatures of myth - to unicorn or minotaur. There was a time when we barricaded our doors against the animals of the night. Now we sleep easier knowing they are still there For further information, contact: The Environmental Investigation Agency Wildlife Protection Society of India 5 Tigers: The Tiger Information Center Hornocker Wildlife Research Institute TRAFFIC International Global Tiger Patrol

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
Thanks to Cristina Odone for such a rewarding article on the creative work of Abbas (Faith, Hope, Charity, November 18). In beautiful, expressive prose, it captured perfectly the bittersweet nature of Christianity as it is interpreted and practised. All believers have been there.
John R Smith
South Petherton, Somerset
fields.body:
Thanks to Cristina Odone for such a rewarding article on the creative work of Abbas (Faith, Hope, Charity, November 18). In beautiful, expressive prose, it captured perfectly the bittersweet nature of Christianity as it is interpreted and practised. All believers have been there.
John R Smith
South Petherton, Somerset

Cristina Odone makes many disputable assumptions about people who live without religious faith. Most atheists/ agnostics are proud and happy not to be Christian. Like children who abandon their security blankets, we no longer need faith and hope. We retain charity - historically a gift Christianity has left us with. We do not suffer existential fears, most of us do not live in a state of perpetual anxiety, unless for everyday reasons such as poverty. We, too, ameliorate the lot of those worse off than ourselves. Death is a problem only insofar as it deprives us of the company of those we love.
Julian Rathbone
Thorney Hill, Hampshire

As a Guardian reader from the age of 14 (I am now 15), I find it desperately sad that Jon Bruton's daughter is unable to use a dictionary to look up words such as urophilia and bestiality (Dear Weekend, November 18). It is also upsetting that my parents had to ask me what these words meant.
Name withheld for the sake of parent's embarrassment

I am delighted that my teenage daughter shows an interest in reading broadsheet newspapers at all. Jon Bruton would be wiser to heed Julie Burchill's warning about the not-so-subliminal messages reaching our young people from the likes of pop idol Eminem.
Carolina Denning
Leeds

Paul Dennehy is wrong about aural sex adversely affecting one's hearing (Dear Weekend, November 18). Surely he knows aural sex is heard and not obscene.
Ian K Iles
Taunton, Somerset

I was very sorry to read Jeremy Lee's description of the sweet potato/ marshmallow casserole as 'a barking mad confection' (Food, November 18). As an American, the very words make my mouth water: the heavy buttery scent, the crisp top of the marshmallow, the way it melts into the sweet potato. This dish only ever appeared at Thanksgiving - which is why it instantly evokes my mother's eau de nil dining room, the thin open-weave curtains drawn against the California sun, the hearty, self-consciously festive voices.

Consider the madeleine. Without Proust, what is it? A dry, tasteless nothing. The sweet potato casserole needs its Proust to give it romance.
Kate Beswick
kbeswick@freeuk.com

So, Charlotte Abrahams uses three different implements to carry out the onerous task of putting Parmesan on her pasta, and urges us to do likewise (Style Slave, November 18). To think people say the Guardian is written by, and for, navel-gazing Londoners with no sense of the real world! Pah!
David Lea
London SW8

So, 'no sort of revolutionary ever goes into the entertainment business' (Julie Burchill, November 18). My image of her lies in shreds.
John Chappell
Canterbury

Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

Fax: 020-7239 9935.
