fields.headline: Big man
fields.standfirst: John Aspinall's unspeakable behaviour was of a kind that would have landed almost anyone else in prison, and yet, to some, he died a hero
fields.trailText: John Aspinall's unspeakable behaviour was of a kind that would have landed almost anyone else in prison, and yet, to some, he died a hero.
fields.body:
I only met John Aspinall a couple of times. The first was in 1974 when, as a TV reporter, I interviewed him about his great friend Lord "Lucky" Lucan, who had just disappeared after mistaking his children's nanny for his wife and bludgeoning her to death. There was a power cut at the time, and Aspinall had to be lit for the camera by candelabras clustered around his head in his Belgravia drawing-room.

In this surreal setting, Aspinall boomed on about Lucan's noble qualities, comparing him to the "old Roman" with his "dignitas and gravitas" and implying that such a giant among men could be forgiven for murdering the odd nanny. (The publisher Anthony Blond, a friend and admirer of Aspinall, described him in a newspaper article last Sunday as "an arrogant bore who enjoyed his own appearance and blue films".)

Aspinall left me in no doubt that he and his tight little circle of gambling friends, who included the late Sir James Goldsmith, would have tried to protect Lucan from the law, whatever he had done. Loyalty to each other was their supreme value; disloyalty their supreme vice, which was why the painter Dominic Elwes was sent to Coventry for selling a drawing he had made of them to the Sunday Times. Elwes later committed suicide.

The second time I saw Aspinall was a few years later, at the law courts in London, where Sir James was being sued for libel by the business journalist Michael Gillard. As we were leaving the court at lunchtime, Aspinall kindly offered us a lift in his Rolls-Royce. We were about to get into the car when a voice from behind bellowed, "Aspers, those people are scum and pus. They will give you an infection. They will give you eczema. You can't possibly let them in your car." Aspinall looked desperate, torn between his desire as a gentleman to honour his promise of a lift and his loyalty to his friend and benefactor, Sir James. We put him out of his misery by peeling off and taking a taxi.

Whatever his qualities - and I will allow that he must have been entertaining, charismatic, courageous and loyal to his friends - Aspinall was not what you would call a democrat or a humanitarian. As a believer in the superiority of wild animals over human beings - or, at any rate, those who lead ordinary lives - he wrote that "the concept of the sanctity of human life is the most damaging that philosophy has ever propagated".

As Blond recalled, Aspinall argued in his memoirs that "humans should be organised as hierarchic but tolerant groups (like gorillas) and be ruled by dominant 'alpha males' (like Aspinall). They should also be culled to stop them wrecking the biosphere - 200 million in a nuclear war would only be a start."

One could dismiss such views as mere eccentricity were it not for the evidence of heartlessness in Aspinall's own life. Five of the keepers at his two zoos in Kent were killed by animals because of his insistence that they fraternise with them, and he never blamed himself - let alone the animals - for their deaths. And last week, his lifelong disciple, Robin Birley, had an appalling tale to tell. Birley, the son of Mark Birley, a former friend and business associate of Aspinall, was disfigured for life when he was 12 years old after a tiger at Aspinall's Howletts zoo crushed his head between its jaws. In a privately printed book of tributes distributed to guests at Aspinall's memorial service, Birley recalled how the man who had directed him into the tiger's den came to visit him in hospital a few days later. Aspinall, he said, "seemed distinctly subdued and tense".

Birley went on: "After a slightly desultory and awkward discussion, he decided drastic action was needed to break the tension. Without any hesitation he pulled all his clothes off, facing away from me and, bending over, he then proceeded to do a 'ball swing', his balls being unusually attenuated. That cheered us both enormously, and after that it was hard to feel angry with him."

Really? Aspinall's unspeakable behaviour was of a kind that would have landed almost anyone else in prison, but he died a hero not only to poor Robin Birley, but to his mother, Lady Annabel Goldsmith (who left Mark Birley to marry Sir James), and to Lady Thatcher, Lord Tebbit, and Henry Kissinger, all of whom wrote tributes. Thatcher called his life a "celebration of the heroic virtues", Tebbit praised his "sheer bloody-minded disregard of the wisdom of the day", Kissinger called him the embodiment of Britain's ancient virtues, "reliability, courage, dedication and service". What is the matter with them all? They must pathetically believe that single-minded adherence to an unfashionable ideology, whatever its nature, is a virtue in itself.

fields.headline: Blessed is the peacemaker
fields.standfirst: Since he lost his job as US president in 1980, this born-again Christian and former peanut farmer has worked as a freelance mediator in international conflicts. Is he an exemplary elder statesman and future role model for Clinton or a power-hungry meddler who can't let go?  Jonathan Steele reports
fields.trailText: Since he lost his job as US president in 1980, this born-again Christian and former peanut farmer has worked as a freelance mediator in international conflicts. Is he an exemplary elder statesman and future role model for Clinton or a power-hungry meddler who can't let go? Jonathan Steele reports
fields.body:
There can be few jobs in the world more seductive for the ambitious than the presidency of the United States of America. And few can leave a bigger psychological vacuum when full-time is called. Compared to the surviving Republican ex-presidents- Gerald Ford, Ronald Reagan, and George Bush senior - Jimmy Carter is exceptional. "Look, this guy is not playing golf every day", says Patt Derian, who ran Carter's human rights policy in the State Department. "He refuses to sit on corporate boards. He is not on the lecture circuit making speeches for high fees. In setting a good image of what an ex-president can do, he's terrific". An American commentator once quipped that Jimmy Carter "used the presidency as a stepping stone to what he really wanted to do in life". Others have developed a special word for his 20 event-filled years out of power. They call it "the postpresidency".

Against powerful odds Carter has turned his presidential after-life into a whirlwind of mediation in international conflicts, defending democracy in preventing controversial foreign elections succumbing to fraud, and in pioneering medical and agricultural programmes in the Third World. "Waging peace", as he calls it, Carter has exploited his prestige to do good. Through his Carter Center he has negotiated with some of the world's most controversial men. As a private citizen who counts himself a friend of Cuba's Fidel Castro and the latest Washington bugbear, Venezuela's Hugo Chavez, and of North Korea's late dictator Kim Il Sung, Carter reaches parts that no serving American president has ever done.

Three years before the start of the so-called Oslo process, which brought Israel and the Palestinians to their first agreements, Carter met the Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and urged him to start negotiations and recognise Israel. When war almost erupted in the Korean peninsula in 1994, Carter brought both sides back from the brink by denouncing US plans for sanctions against North Korea and persuading the North Korean leader to freeze his nuclear programme and resume access for international inspectors. Carter even offered to step into the current Bush-Gore vote-counting crisis. He recognises that as a Democrat he could not act as a lone mediator, but he believes that, "if Gerald Ford agreed and we were invited by a higher authority, we could go to Gore and Bush and suggest a hand count in all of Florida's counties. We could have a Blue Ribbon Commission that spoke with a non-partisan voice".

So could Carter be a role model for Bill Clinton, another (soon to be) ex Democrat president facing life after the White House? Like Carter, Clinton will only be in his mid-50s as he leaves power. Faced with a possible quarter-century of good health, can he even begin to emulate the results of the other Democrat former governor from the Deep South who made it to the presidency?

Today younger Americans tend to know only four things about Jimmy Carter - peanut farmer, big smile, born-again Christian, the Camp David accords (which ended the state of war between Israel and Egypt). He had the ability not just to live by high moral standards but to turn them into a political plus. He promised the American public "never to tell a lie, and to do nothing of which you or I will be ashamed" and campaigned on a clean-up ticket, denouncing the crimes of the CIA, the lies of Watergate, and the folly of the Vietnam war. He attacked the primitive anti-Communism which had led the United States to empower a series of right-wing dictators in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. He promoted human rights as a guiding principle of US foreign policy in place of the balance of power cynicism of Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger.

Top politicians seem to need a hefty dose of blind self-confidence and Carter certainly had it. It irritated friend and foe alike. "He has no self-criticism. He'll say something self-deprecating with a sunny smile because he doesn't think it's true. He tries to be humble but he doesn't understand what the word means," says Patt Derian. "He's very hard to understand, because he doesn't have any counterparts in literature or the movies for people to compare with. He's wonderful and maddening and quite eccentric."

His many critics may overlook the fact that his laptop still opens to a picture of the Seal of the President of the United States and a few bars from "Hail to the Chief". More difficult is what one former senior employee calls "his regal style". "It's still like the White House in there [in the Carter Center]. It's very hierarchical, and focussed round him. Very few people who work there ever interact with him, or even see him". In the words of another ex-staffer, "He's quite vain about his rightness. He doesn't like to work co-operatively. He likes people to work for him".

Whatever the source of Jimmy Carter's sometimes grandiose manner, it was not evident in his early years. He was born in 1924 on a hardworking farm in Georgia, in the segregated Deep South. His mother was a registered nurse while his ferociously demanding father ran the farm. Carter was the eldest child, and his father expected him to work long hours on the farm and in their shop, which mainly served the 200 black men and women who worked their land, either as hired hands or sharecroppers. "My biggest ambition was to please my father", Carter says.

Home life was austere. With no indoor plumbing, theirs was no stereotypical Southern plantation. The elder Carters had few friends and saw relations rarely. During meals, family members were allowed to read to make up for the taut and limited conversation. When Jimmy Carter married Rosalynn Smith, a local girl, he was surprised by her family's long, lively, and cheerful mealtimes and the frequent visits from relatives.

The Carters' nearest neighbours were their black staff. The young Jimmy played, fished, swam, and hid in the woods with Afro- American children. "I was basically shaped by five people, only two of whom were white", he boasts. While this means that he alone of modern presidents except for Bill Clinton has "a high comfort level with blacks",Carter was slow to champion black political rights.

He accepts he could have done more in the 50s and 60s on civil rights. "I didn't march across the Selma bridge or do things of that kind", he says. "But I don't regret it. If I had done that it would have been absolutely impossible to be elected to office or become governor of Georgia and then president. When I finally became governor in 66 I said in my inaugural speech that the time for racial discrimination was over. Two months later I was on the front cover of Time magazine, which launched me into the national arena."

Andrew Young, Martin Luther King's close aide, who later became Carter's ambassador to the United Nations, defends Carter's initial caution on civil rights. "As governor he intervened privately in some very explosive situations. We had to support him in order to stop George Wallace (the racist Governor of Alabama). Carter was as quiet in his efforts at reconciliation as Wallace was vocal in polarisation."

On Earl Carter's death from pancreatic cancer in his 50s (Jimmy's three younger siblings were later to die at the same age from the same cancer), the future president had abandoned his career in the Navy to return to Georgia to look after what had become a large farm business. Earl Carter had pioneered new seeds and herbicides and, as a recognised local leader, had joined the state legislature. It was natural that Jimmy would later use the family money to follow in his footsteps and run for state office.

His vibrant Christian faith also set Carter apart from other public figures. While church-going is a necessary ritual for most presidents, he was genuinely devout. His "born-again" experience came shortly after he lost the race to become Georgia's governor in 1966. Apparently feeling betrayed by God, he went on a long walk in the woods near Plains with his younger sister, Ruth, who practised faith healing. She persuaded him to make a "total commitment" to Jesus, which he did. His optimism revived. For a time he became a door-to-door salesman for Jesus, handing out Bibles in various parts of the United States and Mexico. Even in the White House he continued to preach at Sunday School. He always said grace before meals, even at state dinners with foreign leaders. A close friend of the evangelist Billy Graham, Carter still regularly runs Bible classes at the Maranatha Baptist Church in Plains. "His faith is not a department of his life. It is the whole superstructure that holds his life together. Miss that and you miss who he is," says the Reverend Daniel Ariail, the church's pastor.

Nowadays, when he is not travelling or at home in Plains, the ex-president is ensconced in the spacious offices of his Carter Center on a hill overlooking Atlanta. He has almost immediate access to any foreign head of government as well as to multimillionaires like CNN's Ted Turner and Microsoft's Bill Gates, both of whom have financed his work. Thanks to the centre's health programmes, the guinea-worm disease which once afflicted three Asian and 19 sub-Saharan countries is almost eradicated. When the centre - which has also received funding from sources including major drug companies and the British government - took up the issue in 1986 there were 3.5m guinea-worm cases worldwide. Now there are only 86,000.

The centre is also tackling river blindness, which affects around 20m people in Africa and Latin America. Global 2000, Carter's agricultural programme, is trying - with only mixed success - to bring the Green Revolution to Africa.

At 76, and despite regular jogging, Carter's back is a little stooped, but the broad smile still switches on and off like a light. In angry moods, its sudden disappearance becomes a weapon. He is more relaxed and comfortable than he was in the White House, like a man who knows he has accomplished much and finally achieved recognition.

But the pain of his 1980 defeat still hurts. He expected to win a second term. "I was embarrassed to have lost. I was distressed because I felt Reagan was not qualified temperamentally or philosophically to be president. Being defeated as an incumbent is an extreme disappointment," he says. Carter also suffered heavily from 1979's year-long hostage crisis after the American embassy in Iran was blockaded by militant Islamic students. When in 1980 an effort to rescue the US diplomats collapsed after an American helicopter collided with a transport plane in the Iranian desert, killing eight US servicemen, the crisis became a symbol of the "weakness" which Reagan claimed was at the heart of the Carter presidency.

The irony was that, after 11 years in the Navy from 1943 to 1954, Carter had had a longer military career than any 20th-century president except Eisenhower. He also embarked on the massive increase in the US defence budget which Reagan continued. What was remarkable, however, was that no American soldier was killed by enemy fire throughout Carter's presidency, - a record of non-interventionism matched by none of his successors.

In deep depression, Carter and his wife Rosalynn returned to their farm in the tiny town of Plains (population0 600). Like Clinton, who will return to private life heavily in debt, Carter found his peanut-processing warehouse had gone downhill and was close to bankruptcy. But he is a man of many parts. He enjoys fly-fishing, hunting, birdwatching and car pentry, is a fan of Dylan Thomas and writes his own poetry. He picked himself up by laying a tongue-and-groove floor in his attic and liquidating his business. In seclusion, he embarked on his memoirs, "using the very meticulous diary I had kept as a fetish".

The idea for a conflict resolution centre emerged suddenly. "We were begging for money for the presidential library and I decided I didn't want to have a sterile place where people would come and look at the records. I woke up one night and thought we could have a place here in a congenial atmosphere, similar to Camp David, where people who were in dispute and didn't want to go to the UN or the US government could come," he recalls.

Naturally, he started in the Middle East but his first efforts were not very successful. He was invited to Iraq by Saddam Hussein in 1986 but quiet preparations for a role in brokering peace with Iran came to nothing and Carter never went to Baghdad. He did better in Syria, where he opened talks with President Assad, and he started the first overtures to Yasser Arafat. To continue the focus on human rights, Carter decided to add election monitoring to the centre's work. He set up a Council of Freely Elected Heads of Government, including several Latin American presidents, to focus on democracy in the hemisphere.

The breakthrough, which brought him a kind of rehabilitation in the American media after almost a decade in the wilderness, came in General Noriega's Panama in 1989. Carter demanded to be allowed to send observers to the elections, and watched in horror as voting records were changed and falsified in front of him. "Are you honest or are you thieves?", he shouted in secondary-school Spanish before calling a press conference to denounce the election. His stock in the United States rose again. But President Bush was planning military intervention against Noriega, and Carter put all his energy into trying to prevent it, hoping that a mediator, backed by powerful political pressure, could persuade Noriega to go into exile. The effort failed and US troops invaded Panama.

Ortega hoped a fair poll would persuade the US to end its armed support for the Contra rebels. On election night, when shock results showed the Sandinistas were losing, Carter and his wife rushed to Ortega's headquarters to prevent any recourse to force. "I've won an election, Daniel. I've lost an election. I can tell you from my own experience that losing is not the end of the world", he declared.

The arrival in Washington of a Democratic president, Bill Clinton, should have made Carter's life easier, but it had the opposite effect. "I have been to see Clinton about this personally several times. The cause for his attitude I have never understood".

Carter and Clinton could hardly be more different in their private lives. Rosalynn travels with him on almost all his foreign trips, and has developed several mental health programmes at the Carter Center. Though none of their four children has followed in Carter's footsteps, either as farmers, naval officers, or politicians, they remain a close family. His youngest child, Amy, was a student radical and was briefly arrested for protesting against CIA recruiting on college campuses. Now married and the mother of a small child, she and her husband live in Atlanta, close to the centre.

Carter first exhibited his negotiating skills at Camp David in 1978 with Egypt's Anwar Sadat and Israel's Menachem Begin. He still uses one of the techniques he developed there. He studies the subject thoroughly, tries to project himself into each protagonist's position, and then draws up "what I think is a reasonable final solution before I even see the parties. Then I use that single document and make sure both sides know I use the same document so that there is no distrust of me". Then he shuttles between them, trying to narrow the gap. He contrasts this technique with Henry Kissinger's. "I don't think he would disagree. He tells one side one thing, and the other something else, and then keeps them apart as he talks", Carter says. The key negotiating quality may be what Peter Bourne, a British doctor and longtime friend who worked in Carter's administration, describes as "his capacity to put aside any moral judgement about people. It goes back to his Baptist background - there is no such thing as bad people, only bad actions."

One of Carter's most successful missions was his trip to North Korea in 1994. He found himself quickly at ease with Kim Il Sung, the Communist leader of the world's most isolated state. "He was 82, but extremely knowledgeable about everything in North Korea. He was congenial and very grateful that I had come. He went out of his way to let me know he had a deep appreciation for Christianity. He claimed Christian missionaries may have saved his life when he was imprisoned during the Japanese wartime occupation", Carter remembers.

Carter acknowledges that he likes to seek out people whom no official American will touch, though he gently deflects the idea that he enjoys supping with the devil to see what he is like. "It is intriguing to meet Mobutu, Cedras (the former dictator of Haiti), and Kim Il Sung", he smiles. "They are pariahs, but my knowledge is that they are the key to the problem and without them no progress is possible".

Other leaders he meets are only pariahs in the US view. Carter wants to "de-demonise" them. The Venezuelan leader Hugo Chavez was in Atlanta last month (without going to Washington). He admired Carter's willingness, when he was president, to court rightwing anger and prepare the treaties under which the Panama Canal was handed back. Cynics sometimes say Carter is the "soft cop" who can do the delicate work which the "tough cop" in Washington cannot. But his fierce independence and Clinton's manifest hostility and nervousness about the ex-president's role make that impossible.

So is the Carter Center just a way of continuing his presidency and having the second White House term which fate denied him? Andrew Young vigorously denies it. "I get angry with people who say he's been the greatest ex-president, because this interferes with the effort to understand him as president. He sought to implement an almost theological agenda - world peace, controlling nuclear proliferation, and the reconciliation of race and class. Since then, he has demonstrated, like Martin Luther King and Gandhi, that people who are not office-holders can have a moral impact on society, which is very difficult when you're locked into the checks and balances of a politician in power."

Young says his main difference with Carter is the ex-president's relative lack of interest in macroeconomics to reduce poverty and inequalities. "As Martin Luther King said, 'I admire the Good Samaritan but I'm not one myself. I want to change the Jericho road and not just go on picking people up who've been assaulted and robbed'."

Within the growing community of non-governmental organisations which concentrate on conflict resolution in civil wars and failed Third World states, Carter is admired as a pioneer of so-called Track Two diplomacy - the effort by private individuals to broker settlements. But he is criticised for not having developed with time and experience.

"There's always been tension between Carter's role and his centre's ability to stand alone without him. He doesn't consult. He makes rash decisions," says the head of one London-based NGO. "He's given an extra twist to the elder-statesman role and been good at high profile end-game diplomacy. But he has a low threshhold of tolerance for building up a variety of stake-holders and for long-haul activities," says Kevin Clements, head of International Alert, which works in the Sudan, one of the Carter Center's main areas.

Ben Hoffman, director of the centre's conflict resolution programme, recognises the problem, especially as the staff is actually quite small, - only three full-time people and six interns from nearby Emory University. "We need to stay involved longer, and do fewer things but hopefully better. We want to go deeper than a diplomatic inter-state perspective. We don't see the centre coming in and just doing elite-level efforts which achieve an agreement and then leave it to other people on the ground to take it on. We want to bridge the two."

In recent years Carter has cut back his work load and now spends only one week a month in Atlanta. When they are not travelling, he and Rosalynn stay in their single-story ranch-style home in Plains. What the centre will eventually do without him, and his ability to raise funds and get high-level access to world figures, remains a thorny question. A $250m endowment is being built up to ensure the centre's future.

Carter doesn't want the conflict resolution programme to become a mere think-tank. Half-a-dozen studies have been commissioned for new models of the centre. They have all foundered on Carter's unwillingness to decide. "I doubt, and all our top trustee committees also doubt, that we can get one person to take my place. That is the general consensus which I don't challenge - or endorse," he says.

In retrospect, and particularly in light of this year's bland choice of presidential candidates, it seems extraordinary that this complex man could ever have been elected president. But he emerged on the scene at a rare moment of American introspection. With his rigorous rejection of military intervention in office and since - he opposed the Gulf war and the Nato war on Yugoslavia - he almost sounds like a pacifist, yet as a former naval officer he is inordinately proud that the latest American submarine, bristling with nuclear missiles, has been named the USS Jimmy Carter.

At a time when the danger of American unilateralism has never been greater, "Carter has a sense of multilateralism", says Robert White, the president of the Center for International Policy in Washington. "He has a sincere and sophisticated drive to help build a peaceful and orderly world. I don't think his motives are unworthy."

James Earl Carter Junior

Born: October 1 1924, Plains, Georgia.

Education: Plains High School; Georgia Southwestern College; US Naval College, Annapolis.

Married: 1946 Rosalynn Smith (three sons, Jack, Chip, Jeffrey; one daughter, Amy).

Career: US Navy 1943-54; managed family farms and peanut business 1954-62.

Political career: Senator Georgia State Legislature 1962-66; governor of Georgia 1971-74; US president 1976-80.

Some books: Why Not The Best (1975), Keeping Faith, Memoirs Of A President (1982), Everything To Gain: Making The Most Of The Rest Of Your Life (with Rosalynn Carter) (1987), Always A Reckoning (poetry 1995).

When war almost erupted in the Korean peninsula in 1994, Carter brought both sides back from the brink by denouncing US plans for sanctions against North Korea and persuading the North Korean leader to freeze his nuclear programme and resume access for international inspectors. Carter even offered to step into the current Bush-Gore vote-counting crisis. He recognises that as a Democrat he could not act as a lone mediator, but he believes that, "if Gerald Ford agreed and we were invited by a higher authority, we could go to Gore and Bush and suggest a hand count in all of Florida's counties. We could have a Blue Ribbon Commission that spoke with a non-partisan voice". So could Carter be a role model for Bill Clinton, another (soon to be) ex Democrat president facing life after the White House? Like Carter, Clinton will only be in his mid-50s as he leaves power. Faced with a possible quarter-century of good health, can he even begin to emulate the results of the other Democrat former governor from the Deep South who made it to the presidency? Today younger Americans tend to know only four things about Jimmy Carter - peanut farmer, big smile, born-again Christian, the Camp David accords (which ended the state of war between Israel and Egypt). He had the ability not just to live by high moral standards but to turn them into a political plus. At a time when the danger of American unilateralism has never been greater, "Carter has a sense of multilateralism", says Robert White, the president of the Center for International Policy in Washington. "He has a sincere and sophisticated drive to help build a peaceful and orderly world. I don't think his motives are unworthy." James Earl Carter Junior Born: October 1 1924, Plains, Georgia. Education: Plains High School; Georgia Southwestern College; US Naval College, Annapolis. Married: 1946 Rosalynn Smith (three sons, Jack, Chip, Jeffrey; one daughter, Amy). Career: US Navy 1943-54; managed family farms and peanut business 1954-62. Political career: Senator Georgia State Legislature 1962-66; governor of Georgia 1971-74; US president 1976-80. Some books: Why Not The Best (1975), Keeping Faith, Memoirs Of A President (1982), Everything To Gain: Making The Most Of The Rest Of Your Life (with Rosalynn Carter) (1987), Always A Reckoning (poetry 1995).

fields.headline: The joys of venison
fields.standfirst: Venison is one of the leanest,  healthiest meats around, says Elizabeth  Clift. It's also part of Britain's culinary  heritage
fields.trailText:
Venison is one of the leanest,
healthiest meats around, says Elizabeth
Clift. It's also part of Britain's culinary
heritage
fields.body:
You approach Woollas Hall Farm from a drive that runs beside farm buildings undergoing renovation. The house itself stands end on and, given the sodden wet weather, it is difficult to imagine the fine surroundings it obviously enjoys. It is neither grand nor a true working farmhouse; rather a comfortable family home full of life and warmth and children's chaos.

Mark and Caron Steele, along with Mark's father, farm 1,350 acres on the edge of the Cotswolds, on an outcrop known as Bredon Hill. Woollas Hall (Eckington, Worcester, tel 01386 750267; email topstag@hotmail.com) is mixed arable - sheep, cattle, grain and woodland - none of which is particularly profitable these days, so the Steeles, like many farming families, have been forced to look to less obvious activities to keep their business viable. As a result, the shooting rights on their land can be acquired for a price, and the same goes for the farm cottages; there is rental income, too, from mobile phone aerials and quad biking, which takes place for up to 15 days a year. And then there are the deer.

The meat of the fallow deer has been held in high esteem since Roman times, and in medieval days these same animals were reared on Bredon Hill for noble tables. Wild fallow deer still roam freely on Bredon Hill, so 10 years ago a move into deer farming seemed the most natural enterprise for Mark's brother to choose. But the original project did not flourish, the brother moved to Canada and the deer were less of a priority.

However, the herd that was left behind thrived on the farm's 100-acre deer park. Then, says Mark, "two years ago, we had to decide either to stay with the deer and make them pay, or to get out completely and turn the pasture over to yet more sheep".

Mark's father is a sheep man, so it was not the easiest decision to make, given that sheep still attract a subsidy. But the success of the Steeles' venison operation is testimony to the wisdom of going down that route. Not only that, Mark says that the experience of running the deer free range has restored his faith in farming. Watching him talk to his herd and seeing them respond to him, it is easy to see why.

On the farm, the venison year starts with rutting in September/ October, when the stags run with the herds in both the upper parkland and the lower paddock. "At this time, last year's fawns are still in with their mothers," says Mark. Then, the herd is enticed down to the lower slopes, ready to be sorted towards the end of November, when the stags return to the resting paddock for winter and the young does remain in the lower paddocks along with the younger males that are destined for the cull.

Culling begins in September and continues through to January. This represents the busy season in the venison year, when the usual laissez-faire is replaced with the more unpleasant side of the business, and it has taken Mark some getting used to. "We do this in the deer's natural habitat, which makes it stress-free for the deer." He also has to eviscerate and skin the carcasses himself, but only under sufferance and as a means of keeping down costs. "Then we hang the carcasses for a week at a local butcher, before they are cut to their requirements and returned to the farm, where Caron's expertise in marketing the cuts can take over."

Fallow deer meat has a finer texture than that of red deer, as the animal has shorter muscle fibre, and also boasts an arguably better flavour. The Steeles' approach to venison farming means they can both guarantee the age (15-18 months old) of the meat and that it is as near as dammit organic in origin - the deer forage for their own food on the mostly unfertilised parkland, with 5% of their diet supplemented by field beans that are sprayed just twice a year. As a result, the Steeles' deer probably consume fewer chemicals than their uncontrolled, wild counterparts, which are quite happy to munch on more heavily sprayed corn and other crops.

While the culling is reaching a conclusion, the mature breeding flock is returned to pasture for a little more benign neglect, their winter pasture supplemented with home-grown field beans, which has the advantage of keeping them a little tamer. Fallow deer, unlike their farmed red counterparts, cannot be properly domesticated - rather like a cat, you can feed and watch over them, but they do best with minimal human intervention.

The stags shed their antlers in May, and these are collected and sent to the US, where they are made into chandeliers. The fawns are born in June and July - the first few may be vulnerable to carrion crow or buzzard attack, but the does soon form a group to protect their young. The stags, meanwhile, get busy growing beautiful new velvety antlers, which they duly rub against any surviving tree or hard surface to remove the velvet before they get back to the serious business of rutting. And so the cycle begins again.

fields.headline: Three essential venison recipes
fields.standfirst: Venison burgers, a roast haunch and a venison stew: Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.trailText: Venison burgers, a roast haunch and a venison stew: Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.body:
All recipes serve six.

Venison burger

An oddity from the Guv'nor, who got the recipe from a great friend.

1.2kg venison, minced
300g belly pork, minced
1 thick slice white bread
30ml milk
1 small onion
1 dssp redcurrant jelly
2 juniper berries
A little grated nutmeg
Sea salt and pepper

If you don't have a mincer at home, ask your butcher to combine the meats for you. Peel and finely chop the onion. Remove the crusts from the bread and steep the slice in milk. Bash the juniper until fine. Squeeze the bread of any excess milk, place all the ingredients in a bowl and mix together thoroughly, seasoning generously. Form the meat into six burgers of a hearty depth, and refrigerate for at least an hour.

Heat a heavy-bottomed frying pan and pour in some oil. Place the burgers in the pan and fry both sides over a moderate heat until well-browned and crusted, and the inside retains just a blush of red.

The best accompaniments would be pickled plums (or a spiced plum chutney), chips and a bun split and fried in the pan in which the burgers cooked.

Civet of venison
Venerable and grand, this does require some effort, but, most importantly, it's delicious. It puts some contemporary cookery notions to shame.

1.5kg haunch venison

For the marinade
375ml good red wine
3 onions, peeled and chopped fine
3 tbsp cognac
3 tbsp olive oil
Black pepper

For the braise
250g very good streaky bacon, in one piece
3 onions
1 carrot
3 cloves garlic
60g unsalted butter
24 button onions, peeled
24 button mushrooms
2 tbsp flour
1 sprig fresh thyme
1 clove
1 bayleaf
Sea salt
Meat stock or red wine, if necessary

I prefer my meat cut into much larger pieces than most butchers, who favour smaller chunks, so buy a whole piece and cut it at home. Trim and discard any sinew, then cut the meat into 5cm cubes. Place in a bowl and cover with the wine, onions, cognac, olive oil and 12 grinds of a peppermill. Cover and refrigerate overnight.

The next day, an hour or so before warming the pan and setting this mighty braise on its way, drain the meat through a colander and collect all the marinade - the longer you allow the meat to sit and drain, the better. While the meat drips, set to with the vegetables and bacon, peeling, trimming and chopping all into fairly neat, small dice. Tie up the sprig of thyme with string.

In a large, heavy-bottomed pot, heat a thin film of oil, pop in a single layer of meat and some onion, and fry until richly browned all over. Transfer the browned meat to a warm bowl. Repeat until all the meat is done.

In a separate pot, fry the peeled button onions in a little butter and sugar until coloured a good mahogany, then do the same with the mushrooms, though this time omitting the sugar.

In the meat pot, fry the remaining chopped vegetables and bacon in butter until softened and a dark, rich brown colour. Stir in the flour, reduce the heat and fry until the mixture is restored to its dark hue. Stir frequently to prevent scorching.

Add the marinade, little by little, stirring all the while and scraping up any residue attached to the bottom of the pan. Put the meat into the sauce, and add the clove, bayleaf and thyme. Add the mushrooms and onions.

If more liquid is required at this stage to keep the meat and vegetables covered, add meat or venison stock, or simply let the wine flow freely (the latter would most definitely be my preferred choice). Season with a little salt, bring to the boil, then reduce the heat to the gentlest murmur and cook quietly, well covered, for at least two hours. The meat should be fragile and moist, though still intact.

As with all braised dishes, this is best eaten the day after cooking, but it's not obligatory. Serve straight from the pot with celeriac and potato mash and plenty of noble red wine.

Venison stewed in red wine

A considerably simpler affair, but just as satisfying. Elizabeth David always conjures up magic from simplicity, and this is her recipe.

1kg flank or shoulder venison
4 tbsp port
4 tbsp good red-wine vinegar
1 tbsp olive oil
4-5 onions, peeled and sliced thin
9 thin rashers streaky bacon
Sea salt and pepper

Roll the meat into a sausage shape, secure with string, and place in a glazed earthenware or china bowl. Tip in the port, vinegar and olive oil. Cover and refrigerate for 24 hours.

Preheat the oven to 150°C/300°F/gas mark 2. Remove the meat from the marinade, wipe it dry, roll it in flour, and place it in a small, oval, earthenware dish in which it will just about fit. Place a layer of sliced onions on top, and cover these with the bacon. Pour over the marinade, season, cover with greaseproof paper and a lid, and cook in the oven for four hours or so. Serve with redcurrant or rowan jelly, some pickled fruits or, once again, celeriac and potato mash

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: Shoppers warned over interest 'traps'
fields.standfirst: Free Christmas credit deals on the high street may not be all they seem, says consumer affairs minister
fields.trailText: Christmas shoppers are to be warned by the government today that some "interest free" high street deals can turn into expensive disasters, after complaints from people claiming they were cheated.
fields.body:
Christmas shoppers are to be warned by the government today that some "interest free" high street deals can turn into expensive disasters, after complaints from people claiming they were cheated.

Dr Kim Howells, the consumer affairs minister, is seeking an industry-wide agreement to end small print "traps" in credit agreements and clearer information on how much in-store loans can cost.

He is to warn shoppers that many interest free options are really long-term credit agreements and, if the full price is not paid within the interest free period, interest at up to 30% could be backdated on the entire sum.

The minister will advise consumers to shop around and compare bank loan and credit card rates with deals on offer in high streets before signing agreements in stores.

"If you don't pay the credit off by the lender's deadline you could find yourself paying interest of up to 30% APR over several years. Interest will also be backdated to include the interest free period," Dr Howells said.

"Overall, you could find yourself paying more than you would have done if you had bought the goods using your credit card up front."

The Department of Trade and Industry is to highlight the case of Josephine and Stuart Bowman, who faced interest charges of more than £400 after buying a fridge freezer and washer dryer from Comet for £1,429.95, including insurance, on what they thought was a 12-month interest free deal.

The couple, from north London, forgot to pay off the balance at the end of the year when they were moving house and tried to pay up two months later after realising their error.

But they were told they still had to pay interest for the entire 14 months of the deal, not just the two months following the end of the interest free period.

Mrs Bowman, 28, claimed that the position was never properly explained in the store, in the written agreement or in a letter received shortly before the end of the 12 months.

That letter from Comet and its finance partner stating the balance could be paid off, or £43.77 monthly payments continued for another three years, said: "Instead of paying in full now you can save your money for something far more important like a holiday."

Mrs Bowman, who had the interest charges waived after complaining to consumer groups, said: "This was no simple misunderstanding. Small print was used to manipulate us and demand huge interest payments that could not be justified."

Comet defended its deals and maintained that full details of the agreement, including interest, were explained to customers on signing the deal, in a "welcome pack" a month later and in the letter a month before the interest free option expires.

A spokeswoman said: "When customers select to purchase our products by credit agreement, there is an interest free option, provided the full amount is settled within 12 months.

"Customers are reminded of the interest free option on three separate occasions."

The DTI has set up a small-print taskforce due to report early next year on how information can be better presented to consumers, on industry-wide core principles and on guaranteeing that borrowers will be told in clear terms what the costs would be before the final payment is due.

Mike Naylor, a senior researcher on Which? magazine, said many of the major retailers used similar agreements. He urged shoppers to study the small print closely before signing.

"If the goods are offered interest free then often they are not the cheapest and you are paying a higher price in the first place," said Mr Naylor.

"Quite a lot of companies don't remind you in time to make the final payment and so as a result they are charged interest from the start at up to 30%.

"It could be better to take out a loan or use a credit card, both of which can be cheaper."

webTitle: Jobs and Money: My big break

fields.headline: Green light for mixing business with ethics
fields.standfirst: The campaign to promote socially responsible investment has gained ground thanks to the unstinting - and honoured - efforts of Penny Shepherd. Liz Stuart talked to her
fields.trailText: The campaign to promote socially responsible investment has gained ground thanks to the unstinting - and honoured - efforts of Penny Shepherd. Liz Stuart talked to her.
fields.body:
When Penny Shepherd was awarded the MBE last week she gave the usual modest recipient's response that it was awarded to her organisation and not to her personally. But in this case the modesty may have been well placed as the two are so closely entwined - Ms Shepherd was the first full-time employee of the UK Social Investment Forum, shaping it into one of the primary bodies promoting socially responsible investment.

She is the perfect example of the Forum's central idea that social responsibility and business can mix. Her professional background is with IBM, where she worked for 19 years. "Although I worked for just one company for so many years, later on in my career when I came to write my CV I realised just how many businesses I had worked with, because I had such a variety of clients. The whole point of my job was that I looked at what companies were doing, asking: 'What's the essence of this?' It was all about implementing systems."

She studied maths at Liverpool University and thought of becoming an accountant. But after graduation she went to work in a home for single mothers in London. "I wanted to do something worthwhile, but I very quickly discovered that it wasn't for me. So I started looking at graduate job advertisements and took a post with IBM."

By the end of 1994 her interest in green politics became a priority. "The Green Party addressed the spectrum of social and environmental issues, so I tried to get elected. The understanding I acquired of political strategy has held me in good stead in the business world," Ms Shepherd said.

Her next venture was with Business in the Community, a sister organisation to the Prince's Trust. "When IBM fell on hard times in the early 90s I succeeded in being made redundant. Two days later I found my perfect job advertised in the Guardian: Gifts and Kinds manager at Business in the Community, which meant facilitating companies giving anything other than money to charity, such as surplus stock or old computers.

"It's actually harder for companies to pass on goods than to make donations; it's all to do with logistics and legal issues. They have to ensure that the goods are safe and in the case of computers, that all information has been wiped from the memory."

Ms Shepherd eventually set up her own charity, Gifts in Kind UK, which acted as a broker between companies and charities. "I stayed for two and a half years, and then started looking round again. I had not at that stage had any direct involvement with the UK Social Investment Forum, but I knew a lot about it. It brought together everything I was interested in - green issues, business and the community. It is a place where people involved in socially responsible investment network share their skills, and we also promote the concept of socially responsible investment in the press and in parliament. There is, in fact, a diverse range of members - banks, investment houses, NGOs, consultants and IFAs."

The biggest move in SRI recently has been the changes to the pension regulation, increasing accountability in the industry. Pension scheme members will be able to know where their money is being invested. "I think that in the area of pensions there is still a belief that it is a choice between ethics and return and they still see ethical investment as a niche. But there is definitely a difference in attitudes between when I started this job and now - back then companies were seen as part of the problem whereas now they are perceived as part of the solution. The change is a gradual phenomenon, although high profile events such as Brent Spar have raised everyone's awareness.

"I became the Forum's executive director, but in fact I was their first full time employee. For me, this was my big break as the timing was perfect: I started in July 1997, just two months after the new government had appointed the first ever pensions minister in this country - John Denham - who just happened to have a background with Friends of the Earth. It was also a moment when there was strong cross-party support for ethical issues. In fact, we have been lucky as the subsequent pensions minister also has a strong interest in pensions disclosure.

"They had enough money to pay my salary for three years and the job was to get the organisation to a point where it could continue on its own. There are now five of us, and although my contract ended in June, I am still here, part of a task force reporting to the government on how to increase private investment in grass roots community projects."

But in this case the modesty may have been well placed as the two are so closely entwined - Ms Shepherd was the first full-time employee of the UK Social Investment Forum, shaping it into one of the primary bodies promoting socially responsible investment. She is the perfect example of the Forum's central idea that social responsibility and business can mix. Her professional background is with IBM, where she worked for 19 years. "Although I worked for just one company for so many years, later on in my career when I came to write my CV I realised just how many businesses I had worked with, because I had such a variety of clients. The whole point of my job was that I looked at what companies were doing, asking: 'What's the essence of this?' It was all about implementing systems." She studied maths at Liverpool University and thought of becoming an accountant. But after graduation she went to work in a home for single mothers in London. "I wanted to do something worthwhile, but I very quickly discovered that it wasn't for me. So I started looking at graduate job advertisements and took a post with IBM." By the end of 1994 her interest in green politics became a priority. "The Green Party addressed the spectrum of social and environmental issues, so I tried to get elected. The understanding I acquired of political strategy has held me in good stead in the business world," Ms Shepherd said. Her next venture was with Business in the Community, a sister organisation to the Prince's Trust. "When IBM fell on hard times in the early 90s I succeeded in being made redundant. Two days later I found my perfect job advertised in the Guardian: Gifts and Kinds manager at Business in the Community, which meant facilitating companies giving anything other than money to charity, such as surplus stock or old computers. "It's actually harder for companies to pass on goods than to make donations; it's all to do with logistics and legal issues. They have to ensure that the goods are safe and in the case of computers, that all information has been wiped from the memory." Ms Shepherd eventually set up her own charity, Gifts in Kind UK, which acted as a broker between companies and charities. "I stayed for two and a half years, and then started looking round again. I had not at that stage had any direct involvement with the UK Social Investment Forum, but I knew a lot about it. It brought together everything I was interested in - green issues, business and the community. It is a place where people involved in socially responsible investment network share their skills, and we also promote the concept of socially responsible investment in the press and in parliament. There is, in fact, a diverse range of members - banks, investment houses, NGOs, consultants and IFAs." The biggest move in SRI recently has been the changes to the pension regulation, increasing accountability in the industry. Pension scheme members will be able to know where their money is being invested. "I think that in the area of pensions there is still a belief that it is a choice between ethics and return and they still see ethical investment as a niche. But there is definitely a difference in attitudes between when I started this job and now - back then companies were seen as part of the problem whereas now they are perceived as part of the solution. The change is a gradual phenomenon, although high profile events such as Brent Spar have raised everyone's awareness. "I became the Forum's executive director, but in fact I was their first full time employee. For me, this was my big break as the timing was perfect: I started in July 1997, just two months after the new government had appointed the first ever pensions minister in this country - John Denham - who just happened to have a background with Friends of the Earth. It was also a moment when there was strong cross-party support for ethical issues. In fact, we have been lucky as the subsequent pensions minister also has a strong interest in pensions disclosure. fields.headline: Payouts for breast implant women
fields.trailText: Thousands of women who were told by the government to have their breast implants removed amid fears that they could cause cancer or reproductive problems are to receive compensation from a multi-million pound scheme set up by the manufacturers and suppliers.
fields.body:
Thousands of women who were told by the government to have their breast implants removed amid fears that they could cause cancer or reproductive problems are to receive compensation from a multi-million pound scheme set up by the manufacturers and suppliers.

Women who have suffered no ill effects, but were forced to have their soya oil-filled Trilucent implants taken out, will receive from £5,250 to £8,750 plus any expenses over £500, depending on whether they have new implants inserted. The companies will pay the cost of the operations.

Women who have experienced complications such as infection or scarring will be entitled to more. Unusually, the scheme will be open-ended so women who develop serious illnesses can come back for more compensation later.

Around 5,000 women in the UK have the implants. They were withdrawn from sale in March amid fears that they could produce a toxic reaction if they leaked.

In June, the government advised women to have the implants removed as a precautionary measure after the Department of Health received dozens of reports of "adverse incidents".

Some women suffered pain and discomfort and experts warned that if they leaked, the implants could cause cancer.

Women threatened to sue LipoMatrix Inc, manufacturers of the implants, and AEI Inc, their distributors. But lawyers representing more than 2,000 women and the two companies have thrashed out a compensation package which will avoid the need for the cases to go to court.

All women who had their implants removed after the government's medical devices agency (MDA) made its recommendation in June will receive compensation, regardless of whether they have suffered health problems.

Soya oil implants were marketed as a safer alternative to silicone. Now many of the women having their Trilucents removed following the government's advice are replacing them with silicone implants.

Experts for the MDA said that substances produced by the breakdown of soya oil in the body could damage molecules such as DNA and even cause cancer.

Paul Balen, a solicitor representing 2,000 of the women, said: "The companies responsible for the supply of Trilucent implants have agreed to set up a scheme which will ensure that women receive fair compensation as quickly as possible without having to go to court and in some cases without having to produce any evidence at all." The first payouts could be made as early as January 2001.

Paul Llewellyn, the solicitor representing LipoMatrix Inc and AEI Inc, said in a statement that neither company admitted liability or any defect in the product.

To participate in the compensation scheme, a woman had to show only that she had Trilucent implants removed after June 6 2000 in reliance on the MDA's notice.

webTitle: Jobs and Money:Hopes raised on endowment compensation

fields.headline: Hopes raised on endowment compensation
fields.standfirst: Help is on the horizon for endowment mortgage shortfall victims, reports Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Help is on the horizon for endowment mortgage shortfall victims, reports Tony Levene.
fields.body:
The banking ombudsman is holding out new compensation hopes to endowment mortgage shortfall victims.

Home loan complaints topped the list of problems in the year to September 30 for ombudsman David Thomas - and almost one in four concerned mortgages. And a large amount centred on endowment policies sold to pay off loans.

Insurance companies have refused to consider compensation for mis-sold policies issued before April 1988 when the Financial Services Act came into force. But the banking ombudsman says he can look at older cases which were sold by a bank. "As the regulatory requirements did not then apply, such cases have to be dealt with according to basic legal principles," he says. The ombudsman has ruled that if a bank offered advice, "it will be material to consider whether the customer was told there was a risk the policy might not produce enough to pay off the mortgage".

He warns that some banks sent out misleading advice. One (unnamed) bank told a customer about to sign up for an endowment that "for a lower repayment you not only have the benefit of full life cover but also the prospect of receiving a substantial tax free lump sum upon maturity of the policy".

But while the accompanying quotation made it clear the tax free lump sum - often the biggest trump card in the seller's hand - was not guaranteed, everything indicated that the policy would at least pay off the original loan.

He also says banks should have taken into account the customer's likely ability to continue paying the policy premium for the full term - many who had uncertain future job prospects were tied into 25 year plans, many of which have little value unless held to maturity.

The ombudsman has also slammed banks over obsolete accounts - the practice of offering new customers higher rates than existing account holders which successions of voluntary banking codes were supposed to outlaw.

"The issue came into sharp focus with Tessas," says Mr Thomas. "At one time we were receiving 8,000 calls a week on the subject." Most cases are still being thrashed out between customer and bank - the ombudsman only becomes involved when the two sides have reached deadlock. Tessa holders should receive interest rate compensation only if the bank did not pay a fair rate, based on interest levels paid on accounts with less onerous rules, and that it failed to tell investors by May 5, 1999 that the money could be moved freely.

Overall, the ombudsman scheme received a record 14,583 written complaints, a 14.7% increase on the previous year and more than eight times the number when the scheme started in 1986. Most are settled by banks without the ombudsman's intervention. Half of those which necessitated an enquiry ended with customer compensation. Last year payments ranged from small sums to £100,000, the maximum allowed under the scheme. The average compensation was £3,453.

webTitle: Review:  The Hitchcock Murders by Peter Conrad

fields.headline: Portly poses
fields.standfirst: Chris Petit  weighs up the Hitchcock legacy in Peter Conrad's  The Hitchcock Murders
fields.trailText: Chris Petit weighs up the Hitchcock legacy in Peter Conrad's The Hitchcock Murders
fields.body:
The Hitchcock Murders
Peter Conrad
362pp, Faber
£16.99

There is now a Hitchcock industry in a way that there isn't a Buñuel industry or a Fritz Lang one, or even a John Ford or an Ozu one. For the moment the two great survivors of the first century of cinema are those outsized talents and self-promoters, Hitchcock and Welles. (Message to posterity: direct fat.) Welles was a born show-off and risky business, though vindicated by Citizen Kane drearily topping every critics' poll going; Hitchcock, the more calculating, made himself into a public figure to sell his films, and his besuited act of portly Englishman in Hollywood was perfomance art years ahead of Gilbert and George. Hitchcock also understood and worked the Hollywood system in a way that Welles never managed.

Both men retained a childish awe for the power of cinema - echoed in Welles's remark about film-making being the best train set a boy could have - which still holds sway through the influence of directors like Spielberg, as opposed to the notion of film being, say, an instrument for political change. Yet, for all its intricacy and power, there often remains something arrested about much of Hitchcock's work, and it's worth pointing out that he was over 60 when he made what was essentially a youth movie, Psycho.

Hitchcock's present reputation is partly attributable to the current super-domination of American mainstream cinema, which still feeds off the type of film he pioneered, and, particularly, to Psycho, which laid down the template for the modern horror film. He was also a critic's dream in terms of personal content in a commercial context, subtext, and longevity. The career stretched back to early cinema ("Silents are a dead duck, Mickey," to Michael Powell), and later involved his successful export from England to Hollywood. A Catholic background - always a useful critical feed - allowed the films, like Greene's novels, to be read as essays in transgression and guilt.

Hitchcock provided a signature to his films (with his famous cameos) long before critics began cataloguing cinema by director; at the same time he was canny enough not to make intellectual claims for his work, preferring to see it as practical. His preoccupations - the business of suspense and the art of murder - remained constant, allowing for easy critical cross-referencing. The requirements of suspense meant that he was more concerned with the manipulation of assembly and structure than other directors. The films were famous for being premeditated down to the final angle, making the routine of shooting a chore and, just as famously, turning actors into cattle. Any modern screenwriting manual or class is a neurotic extension of Hitchcock's method, endlessly fussing over structural formulae.

As a promoter, Hitchcock was a consummate marketer, and his career can be offered as a model for contemporary analysis in terms of product and brand-identity. He also conforms to today's ideal of the artist: private vision harnessed to and rewarded by commercial success. The final cherry for the critic is, as David Thomson has noted, that Hitchcock's films "are deeply expressive of the way we watch and respond to stories. Their greatness is often employed to explain the nature and workings of cinema. Thus Hitchcock became a way of defining film, a man exclusively intent on the moving image and the compulsive emotions of the spectator."

The battle for Hitchcock's reputation was won long ago. The French New Wave, particularly Truffaut, who published a long interview in book form, and English Leavisites rallied to the cause in the 1960s, and film writers like Raymond Durgnat and Charles Barr, as well as Thomson, have written authoritatively and well on Hitchcock. Studio paraphernalia, scripts, memos, letters, tabloid-style exposés of Hitchcock's sadism towards actresses and decline in old age have all contributed to what has become an oversubscribed area.

Now we have the Faberisation of Hitchcock, and it's difficult to know what to make of it. A respected critic is asked to be both fan - a Hitchcock obsessive even, who confesses "a covert intimacy" - and respectable academic who can work his way round the subject without confining himself to the ghetto of film studies. Little reference is made to other film writing, with the exception of Truffaut, which is quoting Hitchcock anyway. Conrad also sideswipes modern film theory, which is understandable as his initial connection to Hitchcock was subjective and entirely to do with the forbidden impulse.

Conrad's obsession began at 13 in Tasmania, when he cut school and illegally sneaked in to watch an afternoon screening of Psycho; there "he lost his virginity". He also became infected. Much of his argument is to do with the notion of cinema as a coded form of sexual repository. Hitchcock, a repressed man, was more than aware of this. His films are littered with double entendres and visual sexual puns; in private he was given to smut, and sent tapes to Prince Rainier, for his eyes only. The body of work can be seen as the apotheosis of a censored cinema - being about what can't be shown (and what you can get away with) - and part of the young Conrad's bewilderment on seeing Psycho was that he was allowed to see as much as he did. The cleverness of the film, he knows now, is that it is the eye of the beholder that makes what is seen explicit.

Nevertheless, his account of his initiation is not particularly compelling, with a fudged Oedipal gag for its punchline (Conrad surprised in the shower by father brandishing carrots). From the academic angle, he is keen to enlist Hitchcock into the ranks of the Surrealists because of Hitchcock's understanding of film as an anxious form of dream state, but this argument could be extended to many other film-makers. Cinema has always been a form of reproduction (projection) and dissection (cutting) and Hitchcock's cinema reflected that more than most, peopled as it was with fretful ghosts (actors forbidden to improvise) inhabiting a landscape of sexual ambiguity and innuendo. Given this, it is not hard to find material to support a theory of cinema as 1) wet dream, 2) a form of death, and 3) both, with murder as its extension.

The Hitchcock Murders amounts to assiduous use of the VCR and impressive thematic cross-cutting between films, and occasionally the work of directors like Fritz Lang whose career ran parallel to Hitchcock's, and who was in many ways the more interesting film-maker. Curiously, for all its intellectual weight (Conrad is an Oxford professor of English), what the book doesn't do is encourage a re-viewing of the films, remaining firmly grounded and text-bound, at its best when dealing with text, particularly literary sources. Hitchcock had an eye for writers who adapted well to the screen - many now nearly forgotten, including Patrick Hamilton, Thomas Boileau and Pierre Narcejac, and Jack Trevor Story, as well as some whose reputations have held, like Daphne Du Maurier and Patricia Highsmith. Comparisons between film and source make for interesting reading, mainly for what Hitchcock left out. Many of the works drawn from included expressions of wartime or post-nuclear anxieties (even The Birds), which he was careful to cut. The overt message, it seemed, got buried with the body.

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.standfirst: Lose the lazy lips
fields.trailText: Lose the lazy lips
fields.body: Don't underestimate the impact of good articulation at an interview, says author Brian Krueger. "The ability to articulate your background is a combination of good preparation - which you have full control over - and vocabulary and enunciation - which you have little control over. If you have 'lazy lips', practise enunciating and forming your words more clearly. But don't continually reach for elusive words to perfectly portray your thoughts and feelings. Interviewers prefer an individual who is comfortable within their vocabulary level than one who is always searching a level above."

webTitle: Cool companies:  S J Berwin & Co

fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.standfirst: S J Berwin & Co
fields.trailText: S J Berwin & Co
fields.body:
If you are inspired by the antics of celluloid lawyers then think again. A career as a barrister or solicitor is far removed from the world of TV programmes such as Alley McBeal, LA Law or North Square, and caseloads don't come in racey 60-minute parcels.

But among the hundreds of law firms vying for law graduates is innovative practitioner S J Berwin & Co which has just picked up a Law Firm of the Year award. The judges singled out its unusual style, recruitment procedures, and culture of success.

With offices in London, Brussels, Frankfurt and Madrid, the firm is active in the emerging markets and international trade arenas. Established in 1982, the firm's objective is to provide "outstanding legal advice in a dynamic environment". Unhampered by the bureaucratic attitudes that hold back many older firms, it operates an open and fast-moving atmosphere that promotes progressive thinking and a creative approach to meeting its clients' needs.

As a relatively young firm with around 650 employees, it has grown up with a healthy disregard for petty formalities and rigid rules. For example, unlike at its more stuffy rivals, there are no separate dining rooms for partners and all employees are on first name terms. It also promotes diversity, specifically looking for trainees who come from a wide variety of backgrounds, subject areas, careers and attitudes.

Its trainees do share some common attributes though - they are bright, commercially-aware and ambitious. New recruits receive both 'hands on' and 'hands off' training, working with either a senior assistant or a partner. There are appraisals every three months when they can discuss their ambitions and the particular area they wish to pursue through the firm.

The firm says its aim is to train all of its lawyers to be outstanding - not only in their chosen specialisation but in their knowledge of the wider areas of law and commerce.

Many of its trainees join the firm via a Summer Vacation Scheme whereby students are placed with various departments and earn around £225 per week. The firm keeps tabs on each trainee who has travelled through the scheme, inviting them all to regular lunches and evening get-togethers.

The current starting salary for trainees is around £25,000 plus a maintenance grant of up to £4,500. Salaries for newly-qualifieds start at around £42,000. For details of its 2001 Summer Vacation Scheme placements, and Training Contracts, send a handwritten covering letter and CV to: Charlotte Bishop, Head of Legal Recruitment, S J Berwin & Co, 222 Gray's Inn Road, London.

For example, unlike at its more stuffy rivals, there are no separate dining rooms for partners and all employees are on first name terms. Its trainees do share some common attributes though - they are bright, commercially-aware and ambitious. New recruits receive both 'hands on' and 'hands off' training, working with either a senior assistant or a partner. There are appraisals every three months when they can discuss their ambitions and the particular area they wish to pursue through the firm. The firm says its aim is to train all of its lawyers to be outstanding - not only in their chosen specialisation but in their knowledge of the wider areas of law and commerce. Many of its trainees join the firm via a Summer Vacation Scheme whereby students are placed with various departments and earn around £225 per week. The firm keeps tabs on each trainee who has travelled through the scheme, inviting them all to regular lunches and evening get-togethers. The current starting salary for trainees is around £25,000 plus a maintenance grant of up to £4,500. Salaries for newly-qualifieds start at around £42,000. For details of its 2001 Summer Vacation Scheme placements, and Training Contracts, send a handwritten covering letter and CV to: Charlotte Bishop, Head of Legal Recruitment, S J Berwin & Co, 222 Gray's Inn Road, London.

webTitle: How to... cope with Christmas chaos

fields.headline: How to... cope with Christmas chaos
fields.standfirst: Prioritise your tasks to save time and anxiety
fields.trailText: Prioritise your tasks to save time and anxiety
fields.body:
Somehow Christmas wouldn't be the same if the office didn't descend into seasonal chaos - trying to do the last deal, finish the last project or launch the last product before the corporate world dissipates into a mire of festive parties, liquid lunches and all-day jollies. Bosses become more demanding, clients more agitated and instead of enjoying the run up to the festive period, it can be easy to feel more stressed and pressurised than ever. Ho, ho, ho.

"It does get hellish," admits Katherine Clarkson, who works for a firm of conveyancing solicitors. "Everyone wants to push their sale or purchase through before the Christmas period, people are constantly on the phone, demanding to know why their affairs aren't taking precedence over everyone else. At times it feels like if I stayed until midnight every night I still wouldn't dent the pile of files on my desk."

Every office goes through quiet and busy periods and often there is nothing that can be done to spread the work more evenly, but there are techniques that can be used when your workload gets out of hand. "Even if everything seems urgent, you can still prioritise," says business consultant Charles Kay. "Otherwise, if you think that everything has to be done immediately you'll just become increasingly stressed. It is worth taking half an hour to go through everything you have to do and prioritise each task - it will save you time and anxiety in the long run."

"I do have a system," says Katherine. "Basically I separate stuff into piles - 'urgent', 'top priority', 'desperate' and 'should have been done yesterday'. It might sound funny, but it does actually work for me. It gives a structure to what I feel I have to do. I also tend to make phone calls in batches. Rather than keep on getting interrupted, I put my phone on to voicemail and every couple of hours I stop and make four or five calls."

When work gets this pressurised, there is a danger that it can take over your life and it is essential to ensure that you keep a few hours of spare time each day.

"Every few months we launch a new site or update an old one, and things get very hectic before we launch," says Stephen Symonds, a website designer.

"I have ended up sleeping at the office, working evenings and weekends and not seeing my friends or girlfriend. I have sworn not to do it again - it makes me resentful about my job, short- tempered with everyone else and in the end I don't think I produce my best work."

This is the irony; if you never get away from the office your standard and level of work invariably becomes worse rather than better. One way to try and combat the feeling that work is taking over your life is to keep up some kind of activity outside the workplace.

"Everybody needs a break from their work and if you come home and collapse in front of the TV it's probable that you're still thinking about your job," believes Professor Cary Cooper. "If you do something completely different - join a football team, go to a pottery class, make a cake, anything - then it allows you to shake off the working day."

It's easy to dismiss the idea of doing something after work because you're too exhausted - but any level of activity can clear your mind. "I couldn't do a night class or anything after work," says Stephen Symonds. "But I do ride a motorbike, and I've started to tinker around it with in the evenings.

"It means I get out of my workclothes and am doing something that has nothing to do with computers. If I've had a really long, busy day then I go out for a ride, tear up and down a few quiet country roads and come back feeling loads better."

The most important thing is to retain a feeling of control, both in the office and out of it and to avoid being affected by how others are behaving.

"Establish your own rhythm," says Charles Kay, "and don't be swayed by other people. Some people love the drama of busy times. It makes them feel important if they don't leave their desk all day and stay until 10pm. But they're probably no more productive than someone who comes in at 8am, leaves at 6pm and takes half an hour for lunch. If you've achieved your objectives for the day then don't feel guilty about leaving on time - it's about how you work, not how long."

If you don't remember anything else...

When things get hectic stay calm. You can't do everything in one day, so don't try to. Prioritise your workload, set realistic targets - and go home with a clear conscience once you've achieved them.

webTitle: Moving on up:   An ABC guide to being a good loser at work

fields.headline: Moving on up
fields.standfirst: An ABC guide to being a good loser at work
fields.trailText: An ABC guide to being a good loser at work
fields.body:
A. Exit right

As if losing the fight for something you desire wasn't bad enough, there's the added pressure of having to conform to expectations about how the defeated should behave. Good losers are expected not to show dejection or annoyance. Although it takes passion to compete, only winners are encouraged to show emotion once the results are in. Losers should exit stoically with minimum fuss and be quickly forgotten. Never mind the internal injuries this can cause, it saves embarrassment to onlookers.

B. Loss adjuster

If you don't feel angry and disappointed, were you ever that bothered about winning? If not that might explain why you didn't. Better to release disappointment than suppress feelings that mature into bitterness. Allowing yourself to believe the world is against you is self-fulfilling - a quick tantrum is much healthier. The brave thing to do is take a close, honest look at what went wrong. Was it poor preparation or insufficient awareness of the competition that tripped you up?

C. Rule out

Learn from the tactics as well as the performance of those who defeated you. Did they push a little harder or tackle set-backs more creatively? Prizes are not always awarded to the best. Chances of winning are improved by a thorough appreciation of rules and how far they can be bent. That's something to work on in the long term. First, reflate your ego by cutting down on situations where defeat is likely. You don't want to end up feeling that being a good loser is your only strong point.
