webTitle: Handle rejection with a little help from your friends

fields.headline: Handle rejection with a little help from your friends
fields.standfirst: But the path to your first position can be a long and winding road
fields.trailText: But the path to your first position can be a long and winding road
fields.body:
It took JK Rowling a whole year to find a publisher willing to print her first Harry Potter book. Some of the rejection letters barely bothered to even address her. It was, she admits, an extremely difficult time.

The Beatles were on the receiving end of a string of knockbacks too, before landing the deal that launched their meteoric careers.

Rejection is a hard, even for blockbuster authors and epoch-defining pop stars, let alone graduates eager for a first break. "It does ebb your confidence away", agrees Rory McMahon who graduated from business studies at Southampton Institute and has only just scored a position with London-based recruitment consultants Lorien. Up to that point "mates would be telling me, 'look, don't worry, you're knocking on the door', but I just felt like I was getting nowhere".

When you are feeling down the last thing you want to hear are a bunch of cliches. What's the use of 'keeping a positive mental' attitude when all you want to do is drown your sorrows.

"By all means go to the pub if you need to," says Paul Farrer, managing director of the Graduate Recruitment Company. "But the next day," he continues, "you'll have to deal with a hangover as well as dealing properly with your rejection."

Begin by taking stock of the situation. Something is obviously not working. Could it be something that is beyond your control. In Passing the Interview author Judith Johnstone offers the following checklist:

 Were you applying for a job that might have a gender stereotype, or racial prejudice?

 Was there an in-house candidate?

 Was there any incompetence on behalf of the interviewer?

 Did anything happened before, during or after your interview which might explain your rejection?

Now, consider if it might be you that's the problem, and not them. You'll need to get some feedback. "Find out why," says Paul Farrer. "Don't just listen to what they tell you though - apply it."

Go back to first principles and take a second look at your CV. "Ensure that it's a great brochure for your skills and accomplishments," says Maria Hemming, director of Omega Coaching.

"Make any necessary changes," she adds, "and then believe in them. It is not just a piece of paper; it is you."

Now replay the interview. Was there anything else you could have done to sell yourself ? "Were you", asks Maria, "really present?". That is, "were you listening, actively, to the questions, and answering them in the best possible way".

Review your presentation too. What employers want these days, according to image consultant Laura Herman, are graduates who look like they'll fit in. Did your dress sense and personal grooming on the day match the work culture you were seeking to join?

Once you've considered all this, assess the sorts of jobs you are going for. Are they the right position for you, in the right area at the right level?

Not necessarily - is the answer Tom Sommerlad came up with after he took stock of the positions he had been applying for. A social geography and English graduate from Notthingham Trent University, Tom now reckons he has been "overshooting the mark a bit - going for jobs that I wasn't really qualified for".

At this point it's worth visiting your careers service again and finding out where your talents are and where you should be directing them. "Talk to someone - it will be a worthwhile investment" says Paul Farrer .

None of this changes the cruel reality of rejection. "Disappointment, disillusionment and disgust really can undermine you," acknowledges Judith Johnstone.

But, she says, "whatever has gone wrong so far, it must not effect the way you continue your job search.

"Every new interview must be treated with the same attention to detail as the first. "

webTitle: Taking cover from the cowboy websites

fields.headline: Taking cover from the cowboy websites
fields.standfirst: Lay your scattergun down, boy
fields.trailText: Lay your scattergun down, boy
fields.body:
Another day, another new jobs website that will change your working life for ever. Or so online agencies would have you believe. And for job-hunters it can appear like Christmas come early - a seemingly endless supply of dot.coms with jobs permed into their titles offering not just "Thousands of Exciting Positions!", but generous goodies like holidays and Palm Pilots.

A recent survey by recruitment consultant Universum suggested that a staggering 83% of graduates use web sites to search for their first jobs.

The good news is that the internet is making job-hunting faster and more efficient. It is estimated that there are more than 200,000 UK-based jobs advertised on internet recruitment web sites at any one time.

Hiring via the internet in the UK has risen by almost 50% over the past six months, with more than £20m spent this year in promoting a staggering 500 recruitment websites, according to a survey published last month by Reed Executive, the employment search company. It says that 68% of employers now use the net for recruitment.

The bad news is that because hiring online is still relatively new, no-one really knows what the rules are supposed to be yet.

For example, your details could be passed around hundreds of companies that you're not even interested in working for and you may be subject to prejudices that would be unlikely in traditional procedures.

Worse still, the CV you post to some online job sites could come back to haunt you. A survey by recruitment firm FirstPersonGlobal suggests four out of five job-seekers are unaware they risk sending CVs to their own employers because of the growing trade in personal details.

Lesley Knaggs, president of the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services (AGCAS), is particularly concerned about the quality of advice offered by some online job sites.

"Graduates are prime targets for cowboy online recruitment sites hoping to lure them in with the promise of sound advice and easy access to the top jobs.

"But graduates must learn how to discriminate between the different, and often extravagant, claims being made to ensure that they give themselves the widest set of choices and opportunities.

"Some recruitment organisations and start-up dot.coms are using the internet to encourage students and graduates to bypass more traditional recruitment routes such as careers fairs and contact with higher education careers services," she says.

"Students tempted by this shortcut could miss out on good, top quality careers guidance, gleaned through years of working with graduate employers, and the strategic planning which is essential at such a crucial lifestage."

To help you use the internet wisely to plan your career strategy, AGCAS offers the following advice:

 Approach with caution sites that offer to put your CV on the net. Lazy job searching is easy to spot so make sure that you know how potential employers will access your CV and that it will be presented properly.

 Avoid the scattergun approach to job searching. Employers much prefer carefully targeted campaigns. If your CV is just one of hundreds waiting to be picked up by the first employer who comes by, how dedicated and serious can you be?

 Employers look for easy ways to screen out the weakest applicants. Inaccuracies, such as names spelt wrongly and incorrect job titles, can easily occur when a third party is presenting you to employers.

 Be wary of giving out your email address willy-nilly. You could end up on the receiving end of all sorts of junk mail.

 Don't part with any money. Top quality advice is available free from higher education careers services;

 Wacky design isn't everything - it's the expertise and advice behind the content that counts. OK, we all like sites that are quick, easy and fun, but don't forget that you are making introductions that could affect the rest of your life.

 Beware rambling or casual emailing. It's easy to rattle off an email letter or covering note but an email is judged in the same way as a written letter and should be properly crafted, including correct grammar, punctuation and layout.

 Check that the site has the backing of a recognised, authoritative body such as AGCAS or the Association of Graduate Recruiters.

fields.headline: Top rung... bottom rung
fields.standfirst: TAG Worldwide
fields.trailText: TAG Worldwide
fields.body:
Top rung
Proby Cautley
Aged 64
Chairman
TAG Worldwide
People skills are, in Proby Cautley's opinion, the key to graduate success in the media. "In our business, graduates must have technical ability, but the ability to work with colleagues and dealing with clients is vital," he says.

Other must-have qualities: "General enthusiasm for life and interest in getting on."

CV to date: After three years of army service he joined the family firm to learn the pre-press business. In 1977 Proby formed Inline Graphics, servicing ad agencies with graphic arts production. The company became part of the Wace Group in 1986 and earlier this year he joined TAG Worldwide, part of The Adplates Group (TAG).

TAG team: London-based, but with international offices, the company finds solutions to help clients bring products to market more quickly and cost effectively. For example, it uses software to track a client's advertising campaign costs.

Client base: Firms using its online brand asset and advertising management services include huge blue-chips like Coca Cola, Nike, Ericsson and HSBC.

The buzz? "I enjoy the overall set-up: the group's background, the people and the prospects."

Bottom rung
Simon Underhill
Aged 25
Project manager
TAG Worldwide
Simon Underhill has clear views about the value of living life to the full while at university. "It should be as much about learning how to get on with people - to socialise and to mix - as it is about getting a degree," he reckons.

After graduating from Bournemouth in advertising management, Simon joined a small agency in the town to learn the basics. A year on he moved to a larger firm in Reading to develop his skills. Six months ago he took his present post with TAG Worldwide in London.

Job focus: Simon handles the Seagram (the international spirits and wines group) account which involves all production, brand management and marketing, sales and distribution around the world. He works directly with the client and its advertising agency.

TAG's asset management systems allow the client's offices around the globe to access everything needed for a particular campaign.

Training and progress: "As a young company, it is very open to suggestions about training and new ways of doing things. Appraisals and reviews are also part of the picture."

Next move? "My aim is to keep on learning."

For more details visit www.tagworldwide.com

webTitle: Help: I've got a bad feeling about this job!

fields.headline: Help: I've got a bad feeling about this job!
fields.standfirst: I've just been offered a job I'm keen on, but at the interview it was obvious the company had problems getting and keeping staff. I'm worried about going somewhere no one else wants to be.  TL, marketing manager, South Wales
fields.trailText: I've just been offered a job I'm keen on, but at the interview it was obvious the company had problems getting and keeping staff. I'm worried about going somewhere no one else wants to be. TL, marketing manager, South Wales
fields.body:
If the company and the job are something that would suit you, what does it matter if they're not attractive to others. Organisations with retention problems can be excellent places to work - they often make more of an effort to keep their staff. Your chances of progression may be better than if you were to join a company where everyone's so content that they never move. There are lots of reasons for high staff turnover, and not all of them reflect badly on the organisation.

It could be, for example that their training programmes are so good people get poached. Or maybe the type they attract have a moving-on gene. Perhaps no one wants to live where they're located or it could just be a temporary blip with no discernible single cause. Instead of guessing, get hold of some facts. You may not have felt comfortable raising this point at the interview, but now they're interested in you there's no harm in being direct and asking why so many have left recently. Investigate the possibility of a short work trial.

If you can get beneath the surface you'll be better able to decide whether the factors that cause others to move on are significant for you. Whatever else this company may be failing at, they seem to be enabling their workforce to find jobs elsewhere with ease. It certainly doesn't sound like a place you'll end up feeling stuck in.

 Email: Irene Krechowiecka

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: All at sea
fields.body:
All at sea

As finalists turn their attention to careers fairs, another group of graduates are 5,840 miles into the world's toughest yacht race, the BT Global Challenge, where volunteers are trained in CV-boosting teamwork and leadership skills. See www.challengebusiness.com if you'd like to take part in the next race in 2004.

Nose job

Tired of leaving work reeking of smoke. Wear a polyester suit suggests Rudolf Noble of the Cathedral Hill Clinic in San Francisco who tested the absorbency of different fabrics by hanging samples in a container with a burning cigarette for 15 minutes. Wool, cotton and linen gained 20 to 30 milligrams. Polyester absorbed only 0.7 milligrams.

Window shopping:

Don't be shy about doing your shopping on the web at work. Online errands make for happier, harder workers say workplace consultants in the US. "Employers are giving us more autonomy in making decisions when we want to be working and when we want to be doing something that's in our personal lives," says consultant John Challenger.

Copy cats:

A US firm is tempting final-year students in the UK to earn instant cash by selling course work online. New York company Papers-4-less has been emailing Cambridge University students, offering easy money and access to ready-made essays. A spokesperson for the university warns that "students found plagiarising will be disciplined".

Calling all scientists:

The numbers of graduates starting to train as teachers in England has gone up for the first time for eight years. But the numbers training to be secondary school teachers has failed to reach government targets. There were particular shortfalls in graduates who had studied modern foreign languages, geography and science.

Total recall:

Struggling to remember all your appointments and deadlines? A "memory pill" which alters potassium ion channels in our brains could restore our ability to learn and recall things, say researchers at the Wolfson Institute of Biomedical Research at University College London

webTitle: Anniversary of Japanese writer Yukio Mishima's suicide

fields.headline: Dead writer's knife is in Japan's heart
fields.trailText: Japanese nationalists gather today to mark the 30th anniversary of the ritual suicide of the country's most famous postwar novelist, Yukio Mishima, whose extremist views are increasingly common currency in the political establishment.
fields.body:
Japanese nationalists gather today to mark the 30th anniversary of the ritual suicide of the country's most famous postwar novelist, Yukio Mishima, whose extremist views - dismissed as crackpot at the time - are increasingly common currency in the political establishment.

After a failed coup attempt at Japan's military headquarters on November 25, 1970 Mishima, the homosexual author of Forbidden Colours, sliced open his belly with a sword and then ordered his followers to decapitate him.

This act of seppuku - the ritual suicide of a samurai warrior - did not go to plan. Mishima failed to disembowel himself cleanly and his cohort's hands were shaking so much that he could not chop off his master's head in one blow. The author, who had been tipped for a Nobel prize, died an agonising death.

According to the media and politicians of the time, the suicide was also pointless: at best, an artistic performance by a showman and, at worst, a futile gesture by a deranged extremist.

Today, however, Mishima's supporters say this ultimate act of self-sacrifice is at last being proved to be an important political milestone because many of the ideas that drove him to such a violent end are starting to enter the mainstream of public debate in Japan.

"Rightwing politicians distanced themselves from Mishima after his suicide by saying it was the act of a madman, but in certain nationalist circles he is held up as a god," said Henry Scott-Stokes, the author of a biography of Mishima. "He showed sincerity in a way that cannot be denied. He stuck a knife into the heart of today's Japan."

Mishima was a hardcore nationalist, who wanted to restore the divinity of the emperor, strengthen Japan's army and discard the country's pacifist constitution. He felt western values were invading and weakening Japan like a cancer.

In his final years, he formed a personal militia that won support from senior politicians in the conservative Liberal Democratic party and he was allowed to train with the army.

On the day of his suicide, Mishima made an impassioned speech to army troops, calling on them to rise up and "restore the emperor". As his suicide notes later revealed, he expected to fail, but hoped that his seppuku would transform Japan.

The mixture of shock and derision that this act provoked in 1970 has long since faded. Today, most young Japanese have little or no interest in Mishima or his novels, but politicians are recycling many of his ideas.

Earlier this year, the prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, caused an outcry when he described Japan as "a nation of gods centring on the emperor". Moves are under way to upgrade the defence establishment and parliament has begun debate on revising the constitution - a subject that was taboo until last year.

"People used to treat Mishima like a monster who was totally out of touch with reality. But since the end of the cold war, there is a growing movement to recapture our national spirit - in education, in the military, in constitutional debate," said Jushu Miura, one of the organisers of today's memorial service. "It is just as he foresaw. All the points that Mishima raised with his suicide 30 years ago are starting to be discussed."

The event is expected to attract about 1,000 people. The fairly small size of the crowd is an indication that Mishima, the man, remains a fringe figure. "I guess he was ahead of his time in terms of his beliefs," said a young member of the defence agency, who declined to give his name. "But the act of ritual suicide is very hard to understand for someone of my generation."

Others who knew Mishima said the political significance of his action was only now starting to be appreciated.

webTitle: £18m deal puts Ridsdale on the defensive

fields.headline: £18m deal puts Ridsdale on the defensive
fields.standfirst: View from the Financial pages: Leeds' decision looks reckless
fields.trailText: View from the Financial pages: Leeds' decision looks reckless
fields.body:
Peter Ridsdale, chairman of Leeds Sporting, the parent of Leeds United, was in sporting form himself this week, providing us with a bit of a financial forecast for the current year as he sought to justify the £18m splashed out on West Ham defender Rio Ferdinand.

"Our annual income has gone up from £20m to £57m and this year it should be more than £70m. That's not because of transfer dealings, it's because of our success on the pitch and the finance that attracts," he said. "We generate our revenue from qualifying for Europe, the income of playing in the Champions League, the gate receipts, the sponsorship, everything that success brings. That type of money far outweighs anything we might lose in the transfer market."

Mr Ridsdale almost passes for a man running a successful business. But then he did not refer to the fact that Leeds' share price has halved since the spring. Whatever the success on the pitch, the City says this company is headed into a financial offside trap.

While it is true that Leeds' turnover reached £57m in the year to end-June (up from £37m), pre-tax profits were a measly £1.2m and would have disappeared completely but for the fact that net player transfer costs improved sharply during the period.

Mr Ridsdale should know that the Ferdinand deal has set off alarm bells at one or two of Leeds' biggest shareholders. They are concerned that the chairman minding their £50m firm has just bet a third of its market capitalisation on one trophy asset - whose future value remains clouded by the EU's move against the player transfer system. Throw in Ferdinand's salary and bonuses over the next five years and Mr Ridsdale's wager looks seriously reckless.

Where the cash is coming from remains unclear, though there's talk of a Sky payment landing in January. But Leeds' balance sheet is not going to be a pretty sight. The annual amortisation bill for players alone will jump 40% to £12m on current figures. Elland Road regulars aside, investors should kick this stock out of their portfolios - sharpish.

webTitle: Leeds run the risk and raise the exchange rate

fields.headline: Leeds run the risk and raise the exchange rate
fields.standfirst: Leeds' move is a dicey if somewhat understandable one to resurrect a season that's looking mis-shapen after Wednesday's defeat by Real Madrid
fields.trailText: "The size of Ferdinand's fee is a refreshing reminder of the importance of having a defender who can bring the ball out from the back."
fields.body:
Asked in Turin 10 days ago to nominate the member of Peter Taylor's England team of tenderfeet most likely to break the British transfer record it is doubtful whether Rio Ferdinand would have immediately sprung to mind.

Ferdinand is a footballer of considerable potential. He is also one of the few English defenders with genuine pretensions as a libero. But when he mis-cleared the ball straight to Gennaro Gattuso, who promptly whisked it into the net to win the match for Italy, few onlookers would have priced Ferdinand at £18m with a similar sum to follow in wages.

Leeds United disagree. Their manager David O'Leary and chairman Peter Ridsdale see the 22-year-old West Ham player as fundamental to the business of bringing Champions League football to Elland Road on a regular basis.

So, despite the uncertain future of the whole transfer system under the European Commission, Leeds have been prepared to pay £3m more for a sweeper than Newcastle United did for a striker when Alan Shearer arrived at St James' Park from Blackburn four years ago.

It is a heck of a gamble from two points of view. In the first place Leeds' chances of returning to the Champions League next season and continuing to enjoy its lavish pay-outs have already been diminished by their indifferent form in the Premiership as well as Wednesday night's 2-0 home defeat by Real Madrid.

Secondly, if the player does not settle in successfully at Elland Road and the EC abolishes transfers, there is no way Leeds will recoup anything like their £18m outlay under any agreement to compensate clubs for losing players of Ferdinand's age.

On the other hand Leeds have to strengthen their squad if they are to offer a serious challenge to Manchester United and Arsenal at home while continuing to compete in Europe. Buying Ferdinand makes more practical sense than pleading, as O'Leary did this week, for the size of the Premiership to be reduced to accommodate his relatively modest playing resources.

The size of Ferdinand's fee, moreover, is a refreshing reminder of the importance that should be placed on having a defender who can bring the ball out from the back without looking like a man who has just stepped in a cowpat.

More often than not transfer records are broken by strikers. Clubs will pay almost anything for a regular goalscorer. But how often do they get their money's worth?

Shearer may have scored regularly for Newcastle but they have yet to win anything since he joined them and he has never been the same since an ankle injury forced him to miss half the 1997-98 season. Dwight Yorke, for whom Manchester United paid Aston Villa £12.6m, is not the player he was last season, the jury is still out on Emile Heskey, Liverpool's £11m buy from Leicester, and the £15.5m that between them Liverpool and Villa forked out for Stan Collymore was always going to be fools' gold.

So in a way Ferdinand is carrying a banner for the game's packhorses, the players largely confined to joining in the celebrations when a goal is scored rather than being the focal point of everybody's joy. If his move encourages managers and coaches to discover and develop more English footballers who can create attacks from defence, as Ipswich are doing with Titus Bramble, then Leeds will not be the sole beneficiaries.

Yet the price Leeds have paid for Ferdinand is still staggering and will doubtless have increased Tottenham's frustration at not being able to persuade Sol Campbell to sign a new contract. Campbell, playing it perfectly straight, will complete the season at White Hart Lane after which, under the Bosman ruling, he will be free to play for whom he likes; and Spurs will not see a penny.

That is fair enough except that Tottenham have taught Sulzer Jeremiah Campbell all he knows and are entitled to feel a little miffed at the thought of being left empty-handed if he goes to Manchester United or Liverpool next summer. Not that Gérard Houllier's defence appears to improve whenever new talents are added to it; quite the reverse.

Should England ever breed a libero combining Campbell's strengths as a defender with Ferdinand's ability on the ball the country would have its own Franco Baresi or Laurent Blanc, not to mention another Bobby Moore. Roy McFarland was the last England central defender to satisfy the libero's criteria without really being cast in the role.

Gary Pallister, excellent when going forward, has never been an England regular and, like earlier centre-backs with attacking tendencies, Phil Thompson or Dave Watson for example, has shown few inclinations to be a sweeper.

Ferdinand has some way to go before he can be compared with, say, Chelsea's Frank Leboeuf who, despite the occasional error or lapse of temperament, is a role model to which potential English liberos should aspire; or Patrick Vieira, another emotional Frenchman, who is in effect a sweeper in front of Arsenal's back four.

When Leboeuf or Vieira moves forward with the ball, opponents look nervous. When Campbell is coming, they think "hurrah, hurrah". For Leeds and England it is important that Rio now starts rolling.

fields.headline: A master in the making
fields.standfirst: Rio Ferdinand has drawn admiration from across Europe, writes  Roy Collins
fields.trailText: Rio Ferdinand has drawn admiration from across Europe, writes Roy Collins.
fields.body:
How can a defender, particularly one like Rio Ferdinand, who is yet to secure a regular international place, be worth £18m?

One might as well ask how a Picasso or a Van Gogh can be sold for that sort of money. Originality is priceless in any form of art and, as a young master of football's defensive artistry, it should not be surprising that Ferdinand has expanded the limits of the marketplace.

His ability on the ball, almost unique for an Englishman, so dominates the eye that the West Ham manager Harry Redknapp, who nurtured him to the peak of his talent and selling power, feels it necessary to point out Ferdinand's ability to do the basics of his job.

Redknapp says: "People forget that he is a good defender as well. One on one, I've never seen anyone as good as him. He's almost impossible to beat. People dig him up when he makes a mistake but he makes mistakes because of over-confidence on the ball. If you want someone who runs from the back, it's a high-risk game."

Paying £18m may seem an even higher risk strategy by Leeds United when football's transfer system could reduce Ferdinand's value to nothing in a month's time and in an industry when one mistimed tackle can end the brightest career. But should the Leicester manager Peter Taylor ever get someone as rich as Richard Desmond, the media magnate who this week bought Express newspapers, as a chairman, he would have no hesitation going that far down the financial road for Rio.

Taylor swiftly elevated Ferdinand to the England Under-21 team after first seeing him in the Under-18s three years ago. And, when he took over as England's caretaker manager for the game in Italy last week and began scribbling formations on scraps of paper, the first name he inked in was that of Ferdinand.

Taylor says: "I always had it in my mind to play him in the centre of a back three. But because of his versatility, his ability to run the ball out of defence or pass it out, I would have had no hesitation playing him in a four either. He is also happy to play the ball in tight areas, which inevitably leads to mistakes, but you can't have it both ways. The odd error goes with the sort of player he is."

Taylor believes that Ferdinand might already have been a fixture in the England team if Glenn Hoddle was still the manager. And many of the most experienced observers believe he will be from now on.

Marcello Lippi, one of Italy's most respected coaches, described Ferdinand's performance last week as "buonissimo", adding: "I was surprised by the way England played. Ferdinand looks as though he could be the best of a fine young crop of English footballers."

Ferdinand always seemed destined to move to Italy, where Juventus and Roma have both been intrigued by his skills which mirror those of their own defenders, rather than the block-and-tackle brigade in England. The team from the capital in fact have a dossier on him that is so detailed it would not have failed to impress J Edgar Hoover. It includes question marks about his "professionalism", a euphemistic way of suggesting he should control the drunken antics which have seen him featured on the front page of the News Of The World, although this is more than balanced by his praiseworthy characteristics.

Franco Baldini, Roma's transfer market advisor, says: "We have been keeping tabs on Rio for three years. I see him as a player with tremendous physical gifts and, though he is not muscularly developed, he has the wiry strength that allows him to be powerful, while retaining quickness and flexibility.

"His timing is good but inconsistent, which is an area he can improve upon. But technically he is very good and, unusually for a British defender, he is comfortable on the ball and thinks positively, always trying to find an open team-mate."

Because he chose to join West Ham as a 15-year-old, it was inevitable that, as a ball-playing defender, Ferdinand would be compared with Bobby Moore, though he finds the compliment embarrassing, saying: "I never even met Bobby but he was a legend, a one-off."

Redknapp, who played alongside Moore, believes a more fitting comparison would be between Ferdinand and Franz Beckenbauer. "When you look at the Germans, they have always had a player who attacks from the back - Beckenbauer, Sammer and Matthäus," he says. "Rio is what English football has been crying out for and he ought to be an England regular.

"Of course he is going to take chances on the field and once in every 10 games he will drop a clanger. But give me that any time rather than whacking the ball 40 yards upfield like a lot of central defenders have been doing for years."

Even in his salad days as a defender for Blackheath Bluecoat school Ferdinand stood out as a player who was exceptionally composed on the ball. His former PE master Andy Whomsley says: "We were lucky to have a lot of players almost as good as him. But he was always the one who was going to make it because he was so committed and so competitive."

West Ham's Paolo di Canio would agree. Despite the abridged comments from his autobiography which appeared to suggest that Ferdinand was not yet ready for international football, he remains a committed fan. "He is one of the most intelligent footballers I have met," says Di Canio. "I would say that he is currently at a level just below Paolo Maldini but he has the ability to be better than Alessandro Nesta, whom I rate the best defender in the world."

Originality is priceless in any form of art and, as a young master of football's defensive artistry, it should not be surprising that Ferdinand has expanded the limits of the marketplace. His ability on the ball, almost unique for an Englishman, so dominates the eye that the West Ham manager Harry Redknapp, who nurtured him to the peak of his talent and selling power, feels it necessary to point out Ferdinand's ability to do the basics of his job. webTitle: Tables turned ahead of Ibrox clash

fields.headline: Tables turned ahead of Ibrox clash
fields.standfirst: Rangers look to Flo's gangling guile while O'Neill remains prosaic
fields.trailText: Rangers look to Flo's gangling guile while O'Neill remains prosaic.
fields.body:
Rarely in the past 15 years can Rangers have gone into an Old Firm match feeling so like potential victims. If Martin O'Neill's rampant Celtic side win at Ibrox tomorrow they will go 18 points clear of their rivals in the Premier League.

Despite their game in hand, Rangers may learn what it is like to be horse-whipped. Yet the arrival of the £12m Tore Andre Flo may have the desired effect at Ibrox.

For the second time in two days Flo spoke yesterday of his joy at joining Rangers, and the striker may at least bring with him a type of gangling guile which the club badly need.

"We have had our problems but there is light at the end of the tunnel," said Dick Advocaat, the manager. "I think this will be a game of skill and passion. Celtic are obviously a very good team." Rangers will miss Giovanni van Bronckhorst and Allan Johnston through injury, and Fernando Ricksen has been dropped.

Advocaat also admitted that he might be prepared to release Van Bronckhorst at the right price. The 25-year-old, who has only one more full season on his contract, has already been linked with Barcelona, speculation which the manager feels has been agent-led.

"I've said it before, if a player is not happy or feels he can move on to a better club, then fine," Advocaat said. "But we will decide the price, not his agent.

"Anyway, he's not unhappy, he didn't say that at all. In fact he's happy at the club, but he probably wants to go to another club to find a new challenge. And if he wants to go then I'll give him my hand. But, again, we will decide the price and not his agent."

O'Neill has spent half the season trying to resist his own canonisation in the east end of Glasgow, but that modesty will be futile if his team win at Ibrox. Celtic, unbeaten in 16 league matches, are set to improve on Jock Stein's unbeaten start to a campaign with the Lisbon Lions at the start of the 1966-67 season.

"It's too early to talk of any transformation at this club yet," said O'Neill. "Last year Rangers beat us by 21 points so let's wait until the end of the season. But I'll say this: we've made inroads."

Chris Sutton did not train with Celtic yesterday but is almost certain to play.

Second-placed Hibernian, who have picked up one point in the last six and slipped eight points behind O'Neill's side, visit injury-racked St Mirren today boosted by the return of their top scorer Mixu Paatelainen and the Australian Stuart Lovell.

Eric Black, the former Celtic coach, has ruled himself out of the running for the vacant manager's job at Hearts, for which the former AIK Stockholm manager Stuart Baxter has been interviewed. Steve Bruce, fired as manager at Huddersfield this season, is also a candidate but has yet to meet the board.

webTitle: The rise and rise of Rio Ferdinand

fields.headline: The rise and rise of Rio Ferdinand
fields.trailText: 1978 Born November 8, Peckham. Cousin of England international Les Ferdinand.
fields.body:
1978 Born November 8, Peckham. Cousin of England international Les Ferdinand.

1995 Turns professional with the Hammers after coming through the youth ranks where he is a member of the side which wins the South-East Counties Championship in 1996 and collects an FA Youth Cup runners-up medal.

1996 Makes his debut as a second-half substitute in the 1-1 draw with Sheffield Wednesday at Upton Park in May. Loaned to Bournemouth in November and makes 11 appearances for the Cherries.

1997 Scores his first goal for the Hammers in the 2-1 defeat at Blackburn in February and makes 14 appearances for his club that season before his senior England international debut against Cameroon at Wembley in November.

1998 Named in the England squad for the World Cup finals. Although he does not play in France, he starts against Luxembourg and the Czech Republic the following season.

1999 Makes his 100th Premiership appearance against Leicester in January and plays for England against France, Hungary and Sweden.

2000 February Comes on as a substitute against Argentina at Wembley but is later left out of the England squad for Euro 2000.

March Plays for the England Under-21s (pictured) in the European Championship play-off against Yugoslavia.

April Hints in a magazine that he may have to quit Upton Park unless West Ham are challenging for silverware.

August Speculation continues to mount that both Leeds and Barcelona have tabled multimillion bids.

September West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp reveals the club have turned down two offers from Leeds for Ferdinand.

November 15 Plays impressively at the heart of England's defence in the 1-0 defeat by Italy in Turin, his ninth senior cap.

November 20 Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale confirms a £15m bid is still on the table.

November 22 West Ham accept Leeds' increased bid of £18m.

November 24 Agrees to join Leeds United, subject to medical, for £18m.

webTitle: Blue and green tribes keep the divide

fields.headline: Blue and green tribes keep the divide
fields.standfirst: Glasgow buzzes for tomorrow's derby and the 'ultimate experience'
fields.trailText: Glasgow buzzes for tomorrow's derby and the 'ultimate experience' writes Paul Weaver.
fields.body:
If you stand on Kingston Bridge, above the murky march of the River Clyde, you can see both Ibrox and Celtic Park. And you will probably be the only person in Glasgow to hold such a balanced view.

Tomorrow, once again, is Old Firm day. Rangers are at home to Celtic and the city's blue and green colours are freshly and vividly painted on the consciousness.

But this weekend, as the Tims (Celtic supporters) and the Huns (Rangers) prepare for yet another tribal confrontation, there is a sharpness in the air that is not entirely explained by the breeze that whips off the water.

Suddenly, unfathomably, after more than a decade of Rangers dominance, Celtic top the Scottish Premier League with something of a swagger. If they win at Ibrox tomorrow, for the first time in six years, and then beat Hibernian in midweek they will be 21 points clear, which just happens to be the margin of Rangers' sauntering success last season.

In Bairds Bar in Gallowgate, a green-to-the-gills watering hole only a short walk from Celtic Park, the glasses are clinking. This is a shrine to the hoops, the place where Kenny Dalglish gave regular sermons to the media.

This is a place of shamrocks and harps. There are pictures, everywhere, of Jock Stein's famous Lisbon Lions, who won the European Cup in 1967. "John Kennedy for President," screams a poster, and JFK is almost as ubiquitous as Stein.

The shirt worn by John Doyle during the Scottish Cup final of 1976-77 is here. So is another shirt which bellows, "It's no fun being a Hun." There is a rare picture of George Best wearing the green hoops in a charity match, and another of the A Team's Mr T, whose Celtic shirt does not look made-to-measure.

"God has sent His only son to Glasgow," says a pint of Guinness in the corner. "His name is Martin O'Neill and he is manager of Cellic." Note the Irish pronunciation, leaving the t silent.

Less than two miles down the track, in Paisley Road West, is the District, the favourite bar of the Rangers supporters. By a paradox, this feels a more Irish bar than Bairds. With its long wooden service area, its nicotine walls, its customers in caps and dark coats, it could be straight out of Dublin. Bairds is more theme-Irish.

Robert McElroy, who edits the Rangers Historian, says: "In Liverpool and Manchester and London you often see members of the same family supporting rival clubs. We don't have that in Glasgow. You might have friends and colleagues who support different clubs, though they will not journey to an Old Firm game together and if they enjoy a drink it will not be on match day."

The notion of a city divided by bigotry and bile and sectarian hatred is well known. This has been the narcotic of veteran football hacks as well as the city's social historians throughout the ages.

There is an intelligent, liberal viewpoint that says the lava has cooled, that Glasgow, recently Europe's city of culture and a place which has undergone substantial gentrification despite its enduring and notorious pockets of poverty, now looks upon the issue of its two great football rivals with a serene detachment. Unfortunately this is an attitude not shared by the followers of Rangers or Celtic.

"No, it's still pretty much the same as it ever was," says Charles Stewart, a non-Catholic Celtic supporter. "Old Firm matches generally pass off without too much trouble these days. But the feelings that go with them run just as deep, which is pretty depressing.

"Even the fact that Celtic have often fielded more Protestants than Rangers, and vice versa with all the Italians who have gone to Ibrox, the spit and hatred is still there. And I reckon it will be there for another five generations or so before people start to step back from it."

Both Tim and Hun would probably struggle to define his personal notion of Christianity. But the idea of a terrible schism lends colour to the tribal banners.

David Hodgeson, a taxi driver, is another Celtic supporter who is enjoying the new ascendancy. He says: "The Old Firm is still a very serious business, as we will see on Sunday when all police leave will be cancelled and there will be hellicopters overhead and a strict crowd segregation. But it's not so bad now as it was in the 50s and 60s.

"My grandfather, apart from being a Celtic supporter, was a great fan of Frank Sinatra. So when Sinatra came to Glasgow he was delighted. But the great man chose to sing at Ibrox. My grandad felt that by going there he would somehow be giving pennies to Rangers. So he got a train to London and saw Sinatra at the Albert Hall.

"The feeling was the same when McEwans sponsored Rangers. Suddenly you heard Celtic supporters saying, 'I wouldn't drink that piss,' and eventually the lager was withdrawn from Celtic pubs."

They are still finding plenty of beer to drink, it might be added, though their present euphoria does not have that rather unattractive Protestant triumphalism often associated with Rangers' successes.

Defeat also brings different reactions. The Celtic supporter is desolate, utterly dejected. His Rangers counterpart is pretty glum too, but there is also bewilderment in the blue ranks, indignation and outrage even, as if the natural order of things has been upset.

McElroy is still unconvinced: "Celtic haven't won anything yet. They are solid and hard to beat but I'm not sure they're a good side."

In the end, though, the football will count for little tomorrow. "I know what it's like to be called an Orange bastard and a Fenian bastard even though I've never been religious," says the former Celtic defender Jackie McNamara. "There is real hatred in these people's eyes. Old Firm games turn my stomach."

John Collins described it as the "ultimate experience" and Tommy Burns said: "You're exhilarated and nauseated all in one." So are we all.

webTitle: Make or break for Robson despite denial

fields.headline: Make or break for Robson despite denial
fields.standfirst: Bryan Robson banks on Boro breaking home hex
fields.trailText: Bryan Robson banks on Boro breaking home hex.
fields.body:
The Riverside's corporate boxes will be doing a roaring trade as usual, but any prawn sandwich-munchers expecting to be entertained by a flowing game brimming with attacking invention and a sackful of goals this afternoon will surely leave horribly disappointed.

Middlesbrough - seven defeats in a row, five home goals and no wins - welcome Bradford to Teesside with foolhardy early-season hopes of European qualification in tatters. Their visitors also had continental aspirations, albeit via the InterToto Cup, but have scored only five times in the league all season, with Jamie Lawrence's late equaliser at West Ham their only away goal and providing their only away point. For both, dreams of Europe have evaporated; the nightmare of the Nationwide League remains a reality.

The Boro manager Bryan Robson ducked out of the media firing line yesterday, handing his duties to Viv Anderson. "I'm going to kill Mr Robson for that," chuckled the assistant manager before machine-gunning the press with a barrage of football cliches: "There are no easy games when you're third bottom of the league"; "we've got to cut out the schoolboy errors"; "this match is not make or break".

In reality it may well be. After the humiliating 3-0 drubbing by Leicester, a poll in the Middlesbrough Evening Gazette this week revealed that a change of management was wanted by 89% of the 1,200 supporters asked. Robson may not be a quitter but he will step out of the dug-out with trepidation this afternoon should his team start badly.

"Bryan's disappointed, but he's been through it all in his career and is a man of honour," said Anderson. "He will see it out. We don't want to experience relegation again like in 1998, but it's November and there are 24 games to go. Relegation doesn't come into it.

"The fans are frustrated like we are, but stick by us and see what happens. The lads want to do better for the manager. They want to put things right."

A sentiment shared at Valley Parade, where Jim Jefferies's first week in charge has been geared to restoring confidence. City are without a Premiership win in three months but the change in management may yet spur a revival. "I think the lads have enjoyed the change," said Jefferies. "We need a result and if we can go up there and start nice and solid and cause them a worry or two then they might become edgy."

Finding any attacking verve appears to be his biggest obstacle. Last week at Derby, City played four strikers - two in midfield - and still failed to score, so the signing of Blackburn's defensive midfielder Billy McKinlay for the rest of the season will hardly have the travelling fans rubbing their hands in anticipation.

"The fans are frustrated like we are, but stick by us and see what happens. The lads want to do better for the manager. They want to put things right." A sentiment shared at Valley Parade, where Jim Jefferies's first week in charge has been geared to restoring confidence. City are without a Premiership win in three months but the change in management may yet spur a revival. "I think the lads have enjoyed the change," said Jefferies. "We need a result and if we can go up there and start nice and solid and cause them a worry or two then they might become edgy." Finding any attacking verve appears to be his biggest obstacle. Last week at Derby, City played four strikers - two in midfield - and still failed to score, so the signing of Blackburn's defensive midfielder Billy McKinlay for the rest of the season will hardly have the travelling fans rubbing their hands in anticipation.

webTitle: Liverpool crocks can still find the net

fields.headline: Liverpool crocks can still find the net
fields.standfirst: Heggem's online lay-off
fields.trailText: Vegard Heggem makes the most of time out of action.
fields.body:
What do footballers do when they are injured? Most mope around the physiotherapy room bemoaning their lot. But this week, in a dot.com operation in north London resembling that one in the BBC2 drama Attachments (all laptops and under-25s dressed in clubbing gear), I happened upon Vegard Heggem.

The Liverpool defender has been injured for so long that many may have forgotten he is still on the books at Anfield. But there he was, lurking behind a monitor, tapping away at a keyboard. And he wasn't just there to check up on his website (no self-respecting Scandinavian footballer goes without a website these days).

It turns out he is a director of the company. One of the first players to recognise the power of the internet, he has been involved in websites for years and in 1998 was voted onto the board of a Norwegian operation called Sportsprofile.

This week the company merged with Icons, the British e-business that organises sites for everyone from Dennis Bergkamp to Robbie Fowler, and Heggem was in London meeting his new colleagues. The business, he said, had helped keep him sane during his lay-off. And, he added, he hoped to be playing again by Christmas. By which time his legs may not be up to it, but his fingers will certainly be in full working order.

webTitle: Spurs supporters given early cheer as Carr signs new contract

fields.headline: Spurs supporters given early cheer as Carr signs new contract
fields.standfirst: Tottenham's fullback commits himself to another year while Neil Lennon struggles to get a word in edgeways at Leicester
fields.trailText: Tottenham's fullback commits himself to another year while Neil Lennon struggles to get a word in edgeways at Leicester.
fields.body:
Tottenham fans were given reason to celebrate last night when Stephen Carr agreed a new contract which will keep him at White Hart Lane until 2005.

Carr's future had been in doubt after he expressed displeasure at his old deal, which left him well short of the club's biggest earners. But the full-back, 24, settled on new terms yesterday and extended his contract by one season.

"I've been at Tottenham for a long time and it's still the club I want to play for," Carr said on his icons.com website. "What I wanted was parity with other players and that's what I've got. I wouldn't have signed a new deal if I didn't think I could win things here."

A bizarre row involving the Celtic manager Martin O'Neill and Leicester's Peter Taylor broke out last night when O'Neill said he was approached "out of the blue" by Taylor and encouraged to make the offer for Neil Lennon which Leciester turned down yesterday.

Taylor, who rejected a bid by Celtic in the summer, sounded angry at having received another offer when he said yesterday: "Neil is not for sale. I expect this to be the end of the matter for once and for all."

But O'Neill insisted Taylor had called him this month and said Lennon's form had been poor. "I have not been anywhere near them since [the summer] so Peter out of the blue called me and asked if I would be interested in Neil," he said.

Aston Villa's chairman Doug Ellis has responded to criticism from supporters by announcing that he is willing to invest in a new striker.

"I don't need seducing to come around to the belief of the manager that spending to land a top striker now could help us secure a place in the Champions League," said Ellis, who will spend around £8m.

Steve McManaman, the Real Madrid midfielder, has risked the wrath of his fellow countrymen by telling the Spanish newspaper El Pais: "I don't want people in Spain to regard me as an English footballer in the traditional sense, an idiot with lots of money who kicks opponents, boots long balls upfield and fights a lot."

webTitle: Ferdinand belongs to Leeds bar the shouting

fields.headline: Ferdinand belongs to Leeds bar the shouting
fields.standfirst: As Leeds and West Ham do the business, what does Rio Ferdinand's transfer say for football's fiscal sense?
fields.trailText: As Leeds and West Ham do the business, what does Rio Ferdinand's transfer say for football's fiscal sense?
fields.body:
Leeds United confidently expect Rio Ferdinand to conclude his record £18m move from West Ham this weekend provided the London club reach agreement with him over money to leave Upton Park.

The England defender has still to reach agreement about a severance fee and outstanding bonus payments. West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp denied that the 22-year-old was owed £2m but promised the club would pay any money owing.

Ferdinand stayed in London yesterday while his representatives tried to hammer out a settlement, and he will not have his medical at Elland Road until this afternoon, meaning he will not be registered in time for tomorrow's televised match at home to Arsenal. He is likely to make his debut at Leicester next Saturday.

The player concluded negotiations with the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale yesterday morning and has agreed a 5-year contract worth about £31,000 a week, putting him alongside Nigel Martyn and Harry Kewell as the club's highest earners.

"The deal is done, with the only remaining aspect being the medical. As far as we are concerned it's full steam ahead," said Ridsdale. "Pleasingly from our perspective we have landed a player of Rio's calibre without going outside our existing wage structure."

Within hours of Leeds announcing that the deal had been completed pending the medical, Redknapp suggested Ferdinand was having second thoughts. But the manager said later: "I really think the deal will go through at the weekend.

"I think it certainly wasn't easy for the boy to move because he is very happy at West Ham. But he met the chairman of Leeds last night and was very impressed with what he had to say about the club. They are looking to bring another couple of players in and really go places, and I think he convinced Rio."

The player's agent Pinhas Zahavi is in no doubt. "Talks have been completed with Leeds and everything is OK," he said. "There were no problems on either side."

When the deal goes through, David O'Leary will have spent £64.3m since succeeding George Graham as Leeds manager in October 1998, with a net deficit on transfers of £42.4m.

With the European Commission considering abolishing or radically altering the transfer system, senior figures in the game continue to suggest that spending a British-record fee is a financial gamble which Leeds may live to regret.

"In the current climate I think it's crazy to spend anything more than £5m," the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger said yesterday. "I certainly won't be spending anything until we know what is happening with the transfer system. I just don't understand how clubs can make big signings at the current time."

A leading City analyst, Paul Wedge, was even more critical, saying the Ferdinand deal was yet another example of football failing to run itself on a proper business footing.

"This is complete madness," he said. "Obviously the people who run football clubs are in a difficult position because if they don't deliver a successful team they have 30,000 fans outside the ground wanting to scratch their cars.

"With wages on top, this whole transfer will cost Leeds about £26m. That is £5m a year when, even under the current transfer system, the player will be worth nothing at the end of his contract.

"If this is what football calls a business, it certainly doesn't have the interests of the shareholders in mind."

fields.headline: Hoddle strikes chord with Beattie
fields.standfirst: One man has stood out in Southampton's recent revival
fields.trailText: Adam Sills talks to the man behind Southampton's recent revival.
fields.body:
As the shots rained in on Paul Jones at the end of Southampton training on Thursday the goalkeeper could have been forgiven for confusing which of the attacking pair was his manager and which the Premiership's hottest striker.

It is little wonder that James Beattie has scored five goals in three games when he is taking extra tuition from Glenn Hoddle. The manager has not lost his finishing class and it seems to be rubbing off on his team.

Home wins against Chelsea and Aston Villa and a draw at Sunderland, which followed three straight defeats, have moved Southampton seven points clear of the bottom three and, perhaps relevantly, to within two wins of the top six.

The transformation, says Beattie, has been all in the mind. "We've been working a lot on improving communication and concentration in the side as well as giving us belief in ourselves. If we went a goal down the lads used to think, 'Here we go again', but now we think, 'Let's get back in it'. The mentality has totally changed.

"We've been working on it with the gaffer since the beginning of the season. We all sit down and talk. If someone's not doing something right we'll tell them; it all comes out, no one has any secrets. We meet two or three times a week and the gaffer's got a sports psychologist in who is always here and sees what people get up to.

"He talks to us about positive attitude, believing in yourself and visualising things that have gone right for you, and I think it's helped a lot."

Upbeat thoughts would have been difficult for Beattie in the summer. After his £1m move from Blackburn in July 1998 he was named player of the year at the Dell in his first season. Last season, though, his chances were ruined by tendon injuries in both ankles.

"I spent my time staring at the ceiling in the medical room and you've just got to think about the good times from the last year and hope you can get back to that. Most of it was resting and I am not the sort of person who can do that for long. I just said to myself, 'I will never go there again'. But you've got to have times like that to appreciate the times I'm having now."

His luck almost took a further turn for the worse when Crystal Palace made a £2.6m offer for him last month. "That was close," he says. "I didn't want to go but the chairman accepted the bid. I stuck to my guns and said I wanted to fight for my place."

Hoddle, and the chairman Rupert Lowe, must be delighted Beattie stood firm. He has taken his chance in style and is something of a lucky charm: Southampton have never lost when he has scored. West Ham would be well advised to keep a close eye on him today.

webTitle: Jackpot sounds as chairmen splash cash

fields.headline: Jackpot sounds as chairmen splash cash
fields.standfirst: "Thirty-two million, five hundred thousand pounds: what could that pay for? A new hospital, perhaps." Jim White on the week's bizarre buying binge
fields.trailText: "Thirty-two million, five hundred thousand pounds: what could that pay for? A new hospital, perhaps." Jim White on the week's bizarre buying binge.
fields.body:
Thirty-two million, five hundred thousand pounds: what could that pay for? A new hospital, perhaps. Maybe a seasonal tenner for several million pensioners. Or how about the prize fund for an entire series of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, in which the jackpot is won every single edition? What it actually buys is three footballers.

At the best of times, these transfers may not be regarded as representing the greatest value, particularly when two of the players concerned were not automatic first-team choices at their previous place of employment. But what was so astonishing about the deals involving Rio Ferdinand, Tore Andre Flo and Rigobert Song is that in a couple of months' time all three could be absolutely worthless. Because by then the European Union may well have ruled that the transfer system is illegal, at which point clubs can no longer account for their players as assets.

Yet with that news in the air, football clubs have conspired to spend a record weekly sum. It is as if, on being told that next week Mohammed Al Fayed won't be able to charge anything for his stock and thus the whole lot would be available for nothing, well-heeled shoppers spent the weekend thrashing their credit cards in a last, nostalgic buying binge at Harrods. You would have thought the sensible option before opening the club cheque book would be to wait and see what the European court decides. But then, in the cash-bloated world of the new football, sensible is not an adjective considered of significant value.

Not that you can blame the selling clubs. There were West Ham, potentially going to lose Ferdinand for nothing at the end of the season, suddenly approached by a silver-haired fellow flourishing his cheque book with the mad abandon of a lottery winner. No wonder they sold the player to Leeds's chairman Peter Ridsdale, and though they had to forego some of the windfall to buy in a replacement, the £2.5m for Song can be accounted as commission on the deal.

Equally, Chelsea must have been thrilled when Rangers offered serious money for their third-choice striker. The Stamford Bridge club are financially so highly geared it makes the Duchess of York's income requirements look modest. And as they are now no longer in the European competition on which all their budgeting was based, they need every £12m they can get their hands on.

Despite crude financial necessity, this being Chelsea, the sale of a crowd favourite had to be spun as the player's own fault. Colin Hutchinson, the club's managing director, suggested that Flo had agitated for first-team football and, after Chelsea could not guarantee it, a sinister figure from abroad became involved.

"It's my belief that he's come under a lot of pressure from the Norwegian national coach, whom we also had a run-in with two years ago about his lack of starting line-up appearances and that his place for Norway was in jeopardy," Hutchinson said this week.

Interestingly, this analysis was delivered in the same week that Hutchinson demanded the return of his Finnish teenage striker Mikael Forssell from Crystal Palace, where he is on a year's loan, because, guess what, Palace could not guarantee him first-team football. "This is very frustrating for the player, who went there with the sole purpose of being fast-tracked to hopefully joining the first-team squad next summer," he said. Thank you Mr Pot.

Whatever gloss Hutchinson may have put on the Flo move, even he was obliged to admit that during negotiations with Rangers, one eye was on the potential revolution in the way players are exchanged. "One has to be mindful that within a month or so the transfer system could be drastically changed," he admitted. "And his value could be down to a minute amount compared to the £12m we are receiving from Glasgow Rangers. So that obviously is a consideration going through not only our minds but all the clubs at the present time, which makes the mind boggle at the reported £18m for Rio Ferdinand."

Chelsea, naturally, won't be doing anything so foolish with their windfall. You know, like spending £7.8m on the Danish winger Jesper Gronkjaer from Ajax, whose fitness and attitude was questioned by his own former manager.

Alan Sugar does not have many wise aphorisms to his name, but the one about the new money coming into football acting like prune juice (in one end and out the other before you can reach for the toilet roll) has never been more apt.

webTitle: Robson gives lads crash course in local bigotry

fields.headline: Robson gives lads crash course in local bigotry
fields.standfirst: Ron's in the dugout
fields.trailText: Ron's in the dugout
fields.body:
And a reader's letter! ... Chelsea fan Mark Pitts writes: "... Football's rubbish now ... maybe they was boozing, gambling womanisers in the 70s ... but they was Chelsea through and through ... not like today's footballers ... I wish we was in Europe like everyone else."

Well Mark ... you ... er isn't ... but ... maybe the game has lost something with the influx of foreign players ... ignorant of historical rivalries ... look at last week's north-east derby! ...

Bobby Robson's concern at the dearth of Geordies at St James' Park led to him giving his lads a crash course in mindless local bigotry! ... the result? ... A full-blooded tussle! ... and another victory for the Mackems!

Is Kevin Phillips worth an England place? ... Even Old Cloughie's been adding his twopennyworth! ... "'e might be a bit off the boil ... all strikers blow hot and cold! ... but 'e doesn't play for a "fashionable" side ... Look at me! ... two international caps from Walter Winterbottom? ... a man who never caused a ripple in his life?!" ... Ho ho ... Ol' Big 'Ead doesn't mince his words!

But a striker blowing hot always causes a ripple ... in the team bath at least! ... ho ho! ... maybe a touch of sour grapes from ol' "Winter-bottom" there!

And down at Maine Road it's business as usual! ... ferocious tackles ... City fans raining missiles at the United team ... bottles at Keane ... coins at Beckham ... marvellous!

Bryan Robson! ... hmm? ... he's been throwing money at players for years ... and not pound coins! ... imagine £78m fluttering down through the leaden skies hanging ominously over the Riverside! ... Ho ho ... the fans are revolting! ... reserving their biggest cheer for Boro's transfer-listed midfielder ... "Festa! ... Festa!" ... reminded Jack Charlton of a fiercely partisan Springbok crowd roaring on tiny Zola Budd ... Who'd have thought Big Jack was first to suggest the shoeless South African to the British athletics selectors! ...

But the Boro fans see Bryan as a bit of a cold fish! ... hmm? ... They look at Strachan! ... John Gregory! ... doing their pieces! ... men with fire in their bellies! ... even ex-Boro man Paul Merson ... in the middle of his domestic difficulties feels more at home amidst the flying crockery of the Villa dressing-room!...

Villa's toothless attack? ... hmm? ... memories of Joe Jordan in his pomp? ... Ho ho! ... remember "Norman bites your legs"? ... better than Joe giving them a mighty suck! ...

As Leeds took a midweek pounding from mighty Real Madrid it reminded me of Don Revie's masterstroke ... copying Real's strip back in the 60s! ... and it wasn't all one-way traffic ... in Madrid's Latin quarter there are still bars where you can enjoy a game of bingo and a pie 'n' pea supper!

Enough of the dizzy heights of the Premiership! ... let's descend to the grass- roots ... the greatest knockout tournament in the world! Ron's touching bottom ... but ... he's "Up for the Cup!"

Giant-killing ... hmm? ... David and Goliath? ... plucky David ... armed with a sling ... probably clad only in a loin-cloth ... potential banana skin for Mighty Goliath ... powerful image! ... isn't it? ... hmm? ... young boys ... loin-cloths for goalposts...

Er where was I? ... Yes! ... the romance of the Cup! ... but for the top teams ... a hiding to nothing ... and one hideous debacle in my playing days ... er ... still makes the Manager blood run cold ... one to sweep under the carpet ... er let's move on ... "Round One!" ... let's set the ball rolling ... Yeovil! ... the famous sloping pitch ... no need to set the ball rolling there ... great names...hmm?

Hampton and Richmond! ... owned by that fellow who wrote Steptoe ... at least "the Beavers" go down smiling at Tony Cottee's Barnet! ... marvellous! ... "the Bees" are buzzing! ... er ... Brentford 1 Kingstonian 3 ... er ... bad result for "the Bees".

Lowly Canvey! ... coming back from 4-2 down! ... It's just like the 70s! ... a feast of goals! ... streakers! ... marvellous! ... a great result for "the Gulls".

Hatswell's howler as Morecambe beat Forest Green Rovers ... 3-0 to "the Shrimps"! ... Aldershot soundly beaten by Brighton ... er ... used to be "the Shrimps!" ... now they're "The Seagulls"! webTitle: Jobs and Money: Now grass looks greener on  the other side of the hedge

fields.headline: Now grass looks greener on  the other side of the hedge
fields.standfirst: After a spell in the cold, the wild bunch of world finance has bounced back with something for small investors. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: After a spell in the cold, the wild bunch of world finance has bounced back with something for small investors. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
In late 1998 the spectacular Wall Street collapse of a $5bn hedge fund threatened the stability of the global financial system. Now the finance industry want us to buy hedge funds for our pensions or even as an alternative to an Isa.

Recently, Credit Suisse First Boston, a giant investment bank, has been telling British financial advisers that early next year it is to launch the UK's first hedge fund for small investors which will be available as an Individual Savings Account. Goldman Sachs' investment management division is also promoting its expertise in hedge fund investments to major British company and local authority pension funds. At the other end of the scale are small investment boutiques, such as Matrix Securities, which is planning to launch a hedge fund early next year for private UK investors with £10,000. Financial Services Authority rules forbid investment managers from mailing small investors with hedge fund products; all the ones currently in existence are unregulated, unauthorised funds which have no compensation scheme to back them up. They can only be sold to investors with whom companies already have an existing relationship, effectively restricting them to the wealthy clients of private banks. The FSA fears that highly-geared hedge funds pose a systemic risk to the financial system.

Credit Suisse First Boston is planning to overcome these UK rules by basing its hedge fund in Dublin which, as it is within the EU, will enable CSFB to sell directly to small UK investors in a similar way to unit trusts and Isas.

"This is a first in many ways for the retail marketplace. It is likely to have a minimum investment of £7,000, which is really bringing it to the smaller investor for the first time. It will be authorised, regulated, Isa-able and Pep-transferable," says Adam Habib of CSFB.

Enthusiasm for hedge funds in the past has come from the fees that their managers earn; typically, they charge a 1-1.5% annual charge, like unit trusts, but then take a 'performance fee' of anything up to 25% of the return above a benchmark such as the bank base rate, currently 6%. It means that a £100m hedge fund usually earns higher fees than that picked up by a £1bn unit trust. But Mr Habib adds: "Fees will be kept to a minimum and will be very competitive with other traditional products."

So are hedge funds the equivalent of bungee-jumping with your savings, or can they make up a sensible part of an investment portfolio? Coutts & Co, bankers to the Queen, think they're safe - but only for the rich. Coutts imposes a minimum investment of £150,000 for anyone wanting to buy one of its hedge funds - and you have to already have a minimum balance of £500,000 at the bank. But far from promising breathtaking returns, Coutts says its fund-of-hedge-funds is a safe, low volatility path to steady returns of 10-12% a year.

Coutts bravely stepped into the hedge fund arena in June 1998, shortly before the LTCM collapse, and has pulled in over £1bn into the funds. It says clients in its low-risk fund have achieved returns of just over 10% per annum, while its medium-risk fund is making 15% a year and its high risk fund (minimum investment: £250,000) launched recently is already showing over 20% returns a year. Coutts head of investment products Bob Dawkins says: "We are not suggesting clients use them as an alternative to traditional stockmarket investing. I wouldn't suggest them as the first investment choice for someone with £5-10,000, even if that was available."

Matrix Securities is already setting tongues wagging with its plan to launch a retail hedge fund for people with £10,000 or more to invest. Marketing director Bridget Cleverly is candid about the risks: "There is absolutely no investor protection. People will have to trust us explicitly .

"But what they offer is the ability to minimise downside risk. Put £10,000 in our fund, and you can expect to see returns of 0.5% to 1% every month. It's steady, and keeps your capital secure," she says.

Matrix is hoping that the 4,500 independent financial advisers who can sell unauthorised investments will snap up the hedge fund story, and expects to pull in £15m from smaller investors.

One of the biggest IFAs in UK, Hargreaves Lansdown, will only market hedge funds if regulations change. Investment director Mark Dampier says: "Hedge funds can be designed to avoid risk and give a heck of a lot of value."

But Goldman Sachs says the big breakthrough on hedge funds in Britain will be in the pensions arena. "We are seeing increasing levels of interest from major pension funds," says David Burnside, executive director of Goldman Sachs Asset Management.

Funds that made and lost a fortune

Soros: George Soros is the legendary hedge fund manager who 'broke the pound' in 1992 with a $10bn bet that it would not survive in the European Exchange Rate Mechanism. But this year he lost his Midas touch.

Misguided speculation in technology stocks earlier this year is reported to have cost the Soros funds $5bn in one month alone. In April he effectively withdrew from hedge fund management, radically restructuring his funds into lower risk investments.

He blamed the fact that the Soros funds, such as Quantum, had become too big and too closely watched by the market to be able to operate successfully. But he also acknowledged that markets had changed, becoming 'extremely unstable' and that traditional valuation methods no longer applied.

Now 70 years old, Mr Soros has turned his attentions to philanthropic projects (he is believed to be handing out $100m a year to schemes in Eastern Europe) and prefers to invest his remaining wealth in property and start-up capital for small businesses. Day to day running of his business is believed to have been largely taken up by his son, Robert.

Long Term Capital Management: This hedge fund used complex mathematical trading strategies to leap in value to $5bn in the four years up to April 1998. The biggest names on Wall Street joined the party. In the space of five months this 'low-risk' fund ran up losses of $5bn, including $500m in just two trading days.

This loss threatened to destabilise Wall Street as well as the big banks that had put up the cash for LTCM, and prompted a bailout tacitly backed by the US Federal Reserve. LTCM was set up by one of Wall Street's most famous traders, John Meriwether, and had two Nobel economics laureates on its payroll.

It sought to make money through a 'pairing' strategy that tracked the difference in yield rates between short-term Treasury bonds, in the expectation that the yields would eventually converge. It made money by leveraging its position in the bonds to a breathtaking degree. In its second year, it made a return of 59% for investors, but only around 1% is believed to have come from pure performance, with the rest from borrowing up to 30 times its capital base. The mathematical wizardry failed when markets behaved unpredictably in1998.

fields.headline: Trading places at the Royal Ballet
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Royal Ballet
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
It is one of the peculiarities of large scale ballet that as many as half a dozen dancers can share a role within a single run. This may be a necessity given that certain works are physically too shattering to perform every night. And the rotating system also allows artists to encounter a maximum variety of roles within their short careers. For audiences, though, it turns ticket buying into a lottery because changes of cast can so profoundly alter a work from one performance to the next.

Anyone who saw Edward Watson, for instance, tackling the lead in Antony Tudor's Shadowplay last week would have seen a very different ballet from that danced by first cast Carlos Acosta.

Physically the two men are opposites, and this alone impacts crucially on how the movement looks and feels. Acosta is solid and dark while Watson is lean and milkily pale-skinned, and the latter's body actually inserts itself more naturally into the fluid, detailed lines of Tudor's choreography.

The Boy with Matted Hair was first created for Anthony Dowell and Watson possesses a similar capacity to stretch and soften his moves with liquid effect. The clean length of his legs and the refined flexibility of his feet gives his dancing an exquisite elasticity embellished by the luxuriant twist of his torso and the wide carriage of his arms.

Dramatically the two men also play the role differently. The Boy with Matted Hair comes over as a cross between Mowgli and Buddha as he embarks on a bewildering rite of passage to adult enlightenment. While Acosta's Boy is a feral, commanding, almost symbolic figure, Watson's is vulnerable and very human. As the gods of the jungle crowd in on him his huge dark eyes flare with alarm and curiosity and his body twitches with reflex intimations of danger.

It is ultimately a far more affecting interpretation than Acosta's though it is marked by Watson's inexperience in principal roles. His technique lacks the fabulously centred strength of Acosta's and his partnering skills need honing. For those of us who have been tracking Watson's rise through the ranks, though, it's a performance that confirms his star potential.

When Tamara Rojo joined the Royal from English National Ballet this season her starriness was already established - but it had not been tested in a wide range of roles. And dancing Ondine on Thursday - Ashton's flawed but magical fantasy - Rojo's tiny, intelligent body found a sympathetic, testing showcase. Rojo cast herself headlong into the speed of Ondine's capricious steps and gestures, and into the extravagant, playful curves of her body.

While Sarah Wildor's Ondine last week was a creature from another world, Rojo's was an emotional girl. From the giddy thrill of falling in love to the broken anguish of losing her beloved, Rojo played the role not like an alien water sprite but like Juliet reliving her tragic affair with Romeo.

 Ondine is in repertory until December 11. Box office: 0207-304 4000
