fields.headline: Scanner
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Scanner
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Halfway through reading a diary entry from his teenage years, Scanner starts laughing and turns away from the microphone to regain his composure. He obviously went through a phase of summing up the day in one word, which makes him sound like the jazz man from the Fast Show: "Fab!" Perhaps he is embarrassed to be revealing his private moments to strangers.

It makes sense that Scanner (Robin Rimbaud) continues to write a daily diary. Since his early work, which included real telephone conversations found by scanning the airwaves live, he has been something like a photographer of sound. It is this capturing, more than the nuts and bolts of the music, that distinguish his work.

His latest piece, Diary, alternates music with diary readings. As the tour progresses he intends to include up-to-date entries of being on the road along with video and sound footage - nothing glamorous, just the humdrum of sound checks for example.

Here we hear him criticising his own music ("when I listened back it was quite boring"), or describing the difficulty of getting his gear to fit in one suitcase. But hidden in this prosaic world are little touches of emotion and poetry. "Just to talk to her is special," he says of a friend. "Beyond the phrase, beyond the idea."

The music is both tiny and grand. It is like the delicate movement of a watch spinning through space. Microscopic clicks, wood blocks and everyday sounds (such as current news broadcasts) are painted over rumbling, dark canvases.

Further in, there's a more big-beat, optimistic sound. It begins and ends at home - with the sound of Scanner packing his bags and leaving the house. The percussive bang of the door bookends the performance.

There is a difficult split-focus on the stage. Scanner is in the centre, with laptop, mixer, mini-sampler and sequencer. High above hi Tonne (Paul Farrington) projects manipulated images of the diary texts and live computerised graphics. It's not that the visuals aren't imaginative and sensitive, more that the scene onstage is compelling. This is partly because Scanner seems to be doing a lot of programming and sampler triggering "on the fly" - crossing hands and punching buttons with dexterity. It reminds you that the gig is live, and adds a tension often lacking in digital performances, where the connection between performer and what is actually happening is difficult to feel or see. Ultimately, by putting himself on the line Scanner managed to inject a form of music that is often distant and impersonal with warmth, human frailty and humour.

 Scanner is at the Dome, Brighton (01273 700747), tonight, then tours

fields.headline: LSO/ Pappano/ Chang
fields.standfirst:
Barbican
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
LSO/ Pappano/ Chang
Barbican
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Of all the epithets foisted upon composers and their music, Sibelius's supposed Nordic coldness is one of the most disingenuous. No matter that Sibelius's aesthetic is as indebted to Tchaikovsky and the Russian romantics as it is to mountains and forest wastelands, the image of Sibelius as granite-hewn behemoth seems as immovable as a Scandinavian glacier.

Ever since its first performance in 1902, Sibelius's Second Symphony, the most popular of the seven, has been synonymous with Finnish national identity. Yet the work was written in the heat and light of an Italian autumn - a world away from the dusk and gloom of Sibelius's native Finland.

So it was appropriate that the conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra, in the Musicians' Benevolent Fund's Royal Concert, should be Antonio Pappano, the Italian incumbent of the music-directorship of the Royal Opera House. For this annual concert, now a 50-year-old institution, all the musicians waive their fees. And the defining feature of the LSO's playing and Pappano's direction was a big-hearted generosity - of emotional range, of orchestral colour, and sheer weight of sound.

The performance convincingly negotiated the work's surface drama and structural depth. If Pappano's slow movement was full of contrast - from the doleful chant of the opening woodwind theme to the strings' luxurious phrasing of the long central melody - he never lost sight of the music's essential momentum. And where the oboe song at the heart of the scherzo was vividly languid, Pappano's finale was all power and purpose. Without sacrificing the integrity of Sibelius's unique symphonic design, Pappano revealed that expressive warmth is no less a part of Sibelius's compositional world.

In fact, there was more coolness in Sarah Chang's performance of Bruch's First Violin Concerto. There is no doubting Chang's phenomenal technical gifts, nor the matchless projection of her playing. Across the whole range of the instrument Chang's supercharged tone and vibrato slice through any orchestral texture. And she is a vividly gestural performer, articulating the shape of phrases as much with her body as with her bow. Yet Chang's playing lacked the glow of insight or involvement. It was as if the concerto was a series of challenges to be conquered and - albeit brilliantly - displayed.

No matter that Sibelius's aesthetic is as indebted to Tchaikovsky and the Russian romantics as it is to mountains and forest wastelands, the image of Sibelius as granite-hewn behemoth seems as immovable as a Scandinavian glacier. Ever since its first performance in 1902, Sibelius's Second Symphony, the most popular of the seven, has been synonymous with Finnish national identity. Yet the work was written in the heat and light of an Italian autumn - a world away from the dusk and gloom of Sibelius's native Finland. So it was appropriate that the conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra, in the Musicians' Benevolent Fund's Royal Concert, should be Antonio Pappano, the Italian incumbent of the music-directorship of the Royal Opera House. fields.headline: Hallé/Schiff
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Hallé/Schiff
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The practice of directing from an instrument has a certain visual charm, and Heinrich Schiff's role as conductor and soloist in Haydn's C major Cello Concerto had just that friendly quality. The physical appearance of a close rapport with the orchestra was upheld by the warm intimacy of his playing.

The scaled-down orchestra and Schiff's own unforced tone drew the listener in gently. Although graceful it was never sedate. The vivacity of the first movement was balanced by tender rubato phrasing in the Adagio, and the closing Allegro was tightly coiled and controlled. There were times when Schiff's inner momentum propelled him slightly ahead of the orchestra but this happily generated an extra frisson of tension.

It was in his performance of Mahler's First Symphony, however, that Schiff really shone. He is not a showman - his Mahler was controlled with an intellectual precision that could suggest dryness in a less musical performer.

But Schiff's account was anything but dry. The first movement did not have the joie de vivre that awareness of its basis in song (from Lieder eines fahrenden Gesellen) often prompts, but to give too much away here would have spoiled Schiff's longer-term strategy.

The darker side of this movement was explored with more care than is often bestowed upon it. Lingering over the passage Mahler marked Zuruckhaltend (holding back) and his unsettling hairpin squeezes (now commonly associated with Shostakovich at his most sinister) evoked a spectral quality.

The care Schiff lavished on detail did not extend to the double-bass solo that opens the funeral march. Mahler's breath marks are intended to convey the theme's folk origins, so seamless phrasing misses the point. This is a minor quibble only. The solo is scarcely ever played exactly as written, perhaps because audiences, now accustomed to hearing it smoothed over, would assume the soloist to be incompetent.

Schiff and the Hallé had Mahler's demonic finale tightly in their grip. It was here that the pent-up energy from the earlier movements was allowed to erupt. When the "Blumine" theme from the discarded slow movement shyly emerged, time stood still. Here, as throughout the symphony, Schiff's control of Mahler's precise phrasing and rubato was masterful.

To hear Mahler played like this felt like a once-in-a-lifetime experience.

fields.headline: How Tommy threw Frankie to the lions
fields.standfirst:
Frankie and Tommy
Lyric Studio
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Frankie and Tommy
Lyric Studio
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Garry Lyons ingeniously knits together two plays in this deftly enjoyable two-hander: a study of an embryonic comic genius and a voyage around his own father. What he offers is an account of an abortive double act in 1946 Egypt involving Tommy Cooper and Frankie Lyons that started in good humour and ended in tears. It is also further proof that while post-war troop shows may not have done much for local morale, they are something of a dramatic gold mine.

At first I felt the play might be comic history seen from the vantage-point of the vanquished. While Tommy Cooper went on to become a national hero, Frankie Lyons was essentially an amateur vaudevillian who returned to civilian life as a sheet-metal worker. But Lyons's account of his father's fatal pairing with the ambitious, overweening Cooper has the ring of truth.

As we see Cooper tearing up his partner's sketches, grumbling over his failings and hogging the limelight, we sense we are in the presence of a restless perfectionist and comic original who resented being teamed up with a genial traditionalist. Cooper emerges as a ruthless egotist. But, while the show sympathises emotionally with the outshone Frankie, it also pays professional tribute to the victorious Tommy. And even if some of the gags are wildly anachronistic - there certainly wouldn't have been ploughman's lunch jokes in 1946 - it's good to be reminded of Cooper's lunar strangeness.

We get the fez, the bungled magic and the bad gags: "I said to the doctor I've broken my arm in several places. He said I shouldn't go to those places."

But it is the looming physical presence itself that tickles. As George Jean Nathan said, a true comedian is someone who makes you laugh before they've even opened their mouth. You can see why Cooper couldn't work with a partner. His whole comic persona was based on eccentric solitude.

Lyons's play brings out the human sadness of the mismatch and gives equal room to both players. Ben Fox as Frankie exudes good-natured insecurity and is very funny in a Chaplinesque boxing sketch where he becomes helplessly embroiled in the ropes. Christopher Brand, asked to play a singular genius, rises above mere impersonation. In particular, he makes good use of a long-distance stare as if other people are simply things in his dream. All the show, directed by Laurie Sansom, now needs is an audience to give the two skilled actors something to play off.

 Until December 9. Box office: 020-8741 2311

fields.headline: The weirdness of hospitals in Cure
fields.standfirst:
Cure
Dean Clough
Halifax
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Cure
Dean Clough
Halifax
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Until you have pursued a pulsating 20ft leech through the underbelly of a 19th-century industrial complex you really haven't lived - or at least you've never experienced the insane magic of an IOU show. The Dean Clough-based co-operative has been promulgating its crackpot vision all over Europe for almost 25 years now. Yet Cure is the first time the company has explored its own back yard. Or should that be its own musty cellar?

The dank, vaulted warren running beneath the vast ex-carpet mill is already established as the subterranean home of Barrie Rutter's Northern Broadsides productions. The wonder is that it should have taken so long for IOU to scuttle underground in pursuit of its own nightmare.

IOU opt to develop the theme of a descent into illness. Cure is a distinctly queasy experience - a delirious promenade through a labyrinth of quack remedies and patent diseases, inhabited by a hollow-eyed population of mendicant patients and impatient medics where a cure is nowhere to be found. All this is articulated in IOU's inimitable style, matching Heath Robinson ergonomics to Samuel Beckett's sense of purpose. For anyone who thought the age of the dotty inventor was dead, it is a joy to witness the range of curative contraptions on offer, from the patient-frying, bicycle-driven scanning device to a ward full of swinging, singing colostomy bags.

IOU's more serious point is that there's no place weirder than a modern hospital, and nothing more destabilizing than the threat of disease. The bowels of the mill become both a surreal sanatorium and a fetid metaphor for the passages of the diseased body itself, through which the members of the audience find themselves swimming around like germs.

IOU routinely cook up visuals of such potency that the aural aspect of their work often goes underappreciated. Cure is a collaborative venture with the Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival and the scoring of composer and founder-member Lou Glandfield - whose own recent heart surgery lurks deep within the inspiration for this project - is a thing of forlorn, fractured beauty. A band of downtrodden, dressing-gowned sufferers wield ethnic instruments to concoct their own brand of world-weary music. Only a company in rude health could produce something so sickly. Take a warm coat and comprehensive health insurance.

 Further performances tonight, then from November 30 until December 2. Box office: 01484 430528
